**Juan One of *Records of Mount Mao***
Composed by Liu Dabin, Successor Master of the Highest Clarity Tradition
*Imperial Edicts and Supplementary Writings*
*Han Dynasty Imperial Pronouncements*

**Decree of the Celestial August Thearch Conferring the Nine Bestowments and Jade Register upon Lord Mao**
*In the second year of Yuanshou of Emperor Ai of Han, the year Gengshen, the eighteenth day of the eighth month, day Jiyou.*

Of fullness and emptiness, naturally emergent—far-reaching, luminous in the hidden depths.
Mystic subtlety arose of itself; in youth, unbound by convention.
On Northern Mountain, the heart stilled; in forests and marshes, thoughts accumulated.
Seeking the divine, he ascended perilous heights; treading valleys, he pursued the arduous path.
At the master’s gate, he cast off form; severing worldly ties, he offered his body.
With unwavering sincerity, he followed the natural course, unrestrained.
Thus he approached the radiant craftsman and received the sacred scripture.
With disheveled hair, he knelt in prayer; he severed his head and mutilated his body.
Girded with rope, he rejoiced alone, unashamed of hunger and cold.
His path was the Dao; his refuge, the True.
His devotion moved the Supreme Thearch, stirring the Great Mystery.

Now, with reverence, We confer upon him the exalted rank of *Taiyuan Zhenren*, Lord of the Eastern Marchmount, Supreme Minister, and Director of Destinies.
His heart is upright, his conduct firm as metal and stone.
His cinnabar resolve outshines the multitude; his spirit dwells in lofty clarity.

Thus, first, We bestow upon him the Jade-Iron Banner of the Eight Mighties, that he may subdue the roots of evil and vanquish the myriad spirits.

He endured frost in forests and valleys, savoring the mysterious and gazing upon the True.
His thoughts stirred the secluded peaks; his heart’s sincerity was revealed.
Thus, second, We bestow upon him the Purple-Tasseled Staff, the Lotus-Bloom Crown, that he may summon the thousand numina, seal the mountains, and command the clouds.

He forsook his home and journeyed alone, parting from kin to delight in immortality.
Through trials and hardships, he bared his breast to the mountains and rivers in winter.
Thus, third, We bestow upon him the Embroidered Plumage Robe and the Vermilion Skirt of Flying Clouds, that he may ascend the celestial steps with ease and bear the commands of the Jade Perfected.

He traversed forests and marshes, treading perilous heights.
His heart was devoted, his will steadfast, undaunted by hardship.
Thus, fourth, We bestow upon him the Chariot of Spotted Dragons and the Plow of White Tigers, that he may float through the great void and wheel his carriage in the imperial court.

He pushed through brambles, merging with the light, enduring frost and snow.
His heart sought the radiant Perfected, unwavering and unafraid.
Thus, fifth, We bestow upon him the Curved Dawn Canopy and the Jade Chamber of Green Radiance, that he may roam the Nine Palaces and still his spirit in warmth and secrecy.

He withdrew to secluded peaks, his heart untiring.
Concealing his form in hidden mountains, his thoughts pervaded the myriad groves.
Thus, sixth, We bestow upon him the Divine Firebrand and the Moon-Bright Spirit Pearl, that he may ascend to the Great Ultimate and convey his voice to the Supreme Clarity.

His steadfast heart was lofty and serene; no excess or defilement touched him.
Pure and luminous as white jade, his inner and outer walls stood firm.
Thus, seventh, We bestow upon him the Brocade Banner and Embroidered Banner-Staff, that he may summon the Six Yin Forces and the Jade Maidens to attend his chariot.

His compassion extended to all beings; his hidden virtue nurtured the myriad lives.
Even the tiniest creatures were the objects of his care.
Thus, eighth, We bestow upon him the Phoenix and Luan-Bird Cries, the Golden Bell and Jade Chime, that he may harmonize the spirits in the empty halls and delight in the joy of the Perfected and the numina.

He endured hunger and thirst to nourish his spirit, seeking the True through hardship.
The myriad things could not sway him; the thousand evils could not corrupt his purity.
Thus, ninth, We bestow upon him the Purple Nectar of the Forest and the Jade Elixir in a Golden Vessel, that he may attain a lifespan equal to the Three Luminaries and inscribe his name on the Cinnabar Tablet.

His bearing leads the pure and mysterious; his purple weft adorns the Eight Radiant Ones.
His heart shines with the double sun; his spirit leaps in the great rosy clouds—truly the foremost of the Perfected.
Thus We grant him the title *Taiyuan*, for his nine virtues are complete. The accumulation of his merits has moved the Grand Tenuity; heaven and humanity, without prior accord, have converged in harmony.
Now We recompense these nine deeds to requite his past devotion.

His heart and spirit are bright and upright, the abode of the Four Numinous Beasts.
His cinnabar truth shines forth; his integrity is unwavering.
His charge is whole and steadfast; his mirror reflects even the subtlest things.
Now We appoint him Supreme Minister, to govern the Eastern Marchmount.
We further entrust him with the Directorship of Destinies, to oversee the celestial registers.
We assign him forty Jade Boys and forty Jade Maidens, to attend him in the Grand Tenuity and serve in the Great Ultimate.

His administrative palace is the Red City, the Jade Cavern Repository.
Let him govern it with diligence, reporting all activities without fail.

The Supreme Thearch dispatches this decree, written in purple and white script, to the Central Lord.
*In the third year of Yongshi, the year Dingwei, the Supreme Thearch issued this command, as recorded by the Celestial Perfected.*

Maogu of Xianyang, whose family resided at the Southern Pass, styled Jivei, was destined for transcendence from birth. His rank was that of Registrar of Destinies, and he concurrently oversaw the terrestrial perfected. He was charged with recommending those of the Dao, whose lifespans were intertwined with their virtue. Wherever his diligence and reverence took root, the laws of the Four Poles were fully realized. His administrative palace was the Terrace of Winding Clouds, and his domain the Juqu Mountains of Danyang. Let him govern it with vigilance, reporting all activities without fail.

The decree in purple and white script to Junior Lord states:
Maogu’s younger brother, Zhong, embodies purity and clarity from birth. Though his return to rectitude came late, his thoughts were subtle and his sincerity profound. He severed ties with the Six Heavens of Delusion, his talent and intelligence shining brightly. Now We appoint him Director of the Three Offices, to safeguard life and establish names. He shall oversee Mount Tai, presiding over the records of death and birth. His rank is that of Earthbound Transcendent, the finest among the Nine Palaces. He shall instruct the young and uninitiated, guiding them to completion. He shall educate the female officials, imparting the wondrous arts of the numinous. He shall govern the hundred spirits, overseeing the exorcism of malevolent forces. He shall inspect the sources of rivers, ensuring the flow of the Yangtze and Yellow River. He shall seal and guard the Golden Valley, storing the jade elixir within. He shall supervise the cultivation of dragon mushrooms and luminous herbs that glow at night. His domain is the Mountain of Eternal Constancy, girded by the mouth of the Northern Grotto, where he shall guard the gate of the Yin Palace. Let him strive with diligence, reporting all activities without fail.

This inscription was carved in stone in the third year of Putong under the Liang dynasty. It appears in the *Hua Yang Nan Dong Jiu Xi Bei* and is recorded in the *Jian Wen Jin Shi Pian*.

**Appendix: Memorials and Edicts of the Qi and Liang Dynasties**

**Edict of Emperor Wu of Qi in Response to Tao Yinju’s Retreat to the Mountains**
You have relinquished worldly burdens and grain, longing for the clarity and emptiness of the mountains. In tranquility, you find your nature, and your joy is well-placed—We commend your resolve. Should you require anything, you need only report it. We hereby grant you ten bolts of silk and twenty torches. Additionally, We decree a monthly provision of five *jin* of superior *fuling* and two *dou* of white honey for your alchemical practices.

**Memorial of Yinju Requesting Resignation from Office**
Your servant has heard that the wind of Yao soared to the heavens, and the discourse of Yingyang stirred the Yellow River. The virtue of Han encompassed the earth, and the aura of Shangyin nurtured the mushrooms of immortality. Your servant has lingered in the world for many years, bound by cap and sash. Service was never for glory, nor study for salary. I have long yearned to cast off my official cords and plow the fields alone, to dwell in the moonlit ravines and play the zither amidst the clouds. By the grace of Your Majesty’s favor, I have been permitted to retire to the hills and vales. Now, I shall vanish like a shadow in the cassia courtyard, my spirit communing with the pines. Once I pass through the Eastern Pass, my homeland will be in sight. The mere thought stirs my heart, and I weep by the waterside. My boat is already lost to the currents, and I cannot present myself in person. Unable to bear the weight of my longing, I humbly submit this memorial.

**Emperor Wu of Liang’s Response to Yinju’s Treatise on Calligraphy**
The two scrolls you wished to retain briefly are not unusual in their paper. Since they are part of your traveling library, I had them sent to you earlier. There is nothing particularly noteworthy here, but if you require more finely written texts, I shall provide them. For instance, in the style of *lun* and *zhen*, Wang Xizhi’s calligraphy is not excessively fine. His *Yue Yi Lun* is somewhat robust, but I suspect it is not an authentic work. The *Tai Shi Zhen* is slightly more refined and charming, yet the brushwork is too delicate, and the style deviates—both have already been examined by the keenest eyes. Beyond these, there is nothing else to send.

**Memorial of Yinju to Emperor Wu on Calligraphy**

**Memorial of Yinju to Emperor Wu on Calligraphy (Continued)**

By Your Majesty’s decree, I have reviewed the works held by the Central Secretariat, and among those with some ability, only Zhou Xizan stands out. For the yellow of the heart’s core truly awaits the exhalation of *jiazhong*’s qi. Now that Your Majesty’s own calligraphy embodies the sublime, it perfects both principle and application below. Whenever I reflect on Your Majesty’s discussions of Zhong [You] and Wang [Xizhi] as models for the realm, the advancement of this art is only just beginning. What grieves me is my own dullness—I cannot fathom such heights, and my admiration verges on self-deception.

Previously, I received three sheets of Your Majesty’s divine brushwork, and with these, the total now reaches five. Not only does each character command my gaze, but every stroke pierces my heart. Day by day, their vigor and charm grow beyond description. Compared to those of past years, they are no longer of the same order. If these alone serve as models, why seek further among Zhong and Wang?

My reverence has always been profound, but now my admiration deepens still. Joy and delight fill me, and I cannot but report this. I prostrate myself in gratitude for the two scrolls, having examined their inscribed slips. All accords with Your Majesty’s decree. Though I dared not presume to retain them long, I could not bear to part with them at once. The tracing I had begun remains unfinished. Since the courier must depart now, and the paper lanes are already prepared, and as there are many other miscellaneous texts without further use, I shall await their completion and return them all together.

These writings are of the *pianzhang* style. Though I have not yet distinguished their forms, I may yet study and practice them. I only wish for finely written texts, such as the *Yue Yi Lun* or *Tai Shi Zhen*, to copy and preserve for posterity—recording only their essentials.

**Further Response to Your Majesty’s Edict**
I have also reviewed Your Majesty’s separate note, which states that such matters should be subtly recorded, for this appreciation is a noble pursuit, and oral instruction is not to be dismissed. Though this is not my usual practice, I venture a brief attempt.

When the brush is held askew, the strokes lack sharpness. When the grip is too loose, the writing becomes weak. Short dots and strokes produce a bloated form; long ones, a torn and scattered effect. If horizontal strokes are too compressed, the character tilts; if too sparse, the shape slackens. Constraint yields stiffness, while excess freedom lacks structure—pure bone without charm, pure flesh without strength. Too little ink makes the brush float and hesitate; too much, the strokes grow dull and sluggish. All these arise naturally from the hand’s movement.

Yet when modulation is apt and intent unerring, when the brush connects and severs with purpose, when it surges like waves and bends like joints, conforming to compass and square—when strokes descend in measured weight, their thickness and thinness balanced, their plumpness and leanness harmonized, their strength proportioned—then the writing appears gentle yet radiant, endlessly pleasing to the eye. Its edges sharp and its presence imposing, it seems alive. When it delights both eye and heart, it ranks among the finest. Even if one recognizes the styles of many masters, one must still grasp their underlying principles.

The Six Scripts may be mastered, but this too comes only through practice. Some can retain what they hear once; others, what they see once. Such people exist in every age. In the end, all discussion returns to practice. Cheng Miao reformed the script through long use; Zhang Zhi perfected his calligraphy through accumulated study. Only after long use and deep study can one discourse freely.

In my youth, I never even traced the *tian gan di zhi* on my palm, let alone on paper. To speak of it now is meaningless—it only invites ridicule from my contemporaries and mockery from future generations. Yet I have made bold claims, and reading them now makes my back burn with shame. In this, I have truly piled falsehood upon falsehood. This is but mastery of a single art, not what I would call a noble pursuit. It is but dust upon the heart’s Dao, not what I would call desirelessness.

Regarding the *Yue Yi Lun*, I have long suspected it to be a copy, though I dared not speak lightly. Now that Your Majesty deems it inauthentic, I trust my own judgment has gained some insight. The *Zhen Zan* is overly delicate and weak. That Xu Jingsu’s works were granted permanent provision fills me with awe at Your Majesty’s gracious praise, beyond words.

Though these writings do not follow standard models, their practical application and principle are sound. The fine regular script on the reverse invites repeated admiration. Earlier, in the capital, I obtained a scroll of *feibai* calligraphy, said to be Wang Xizhi’s prized work. Having never seen other examples, I could not verify it, but its power and force struck me as extraordinary. I humbly present it to Your Majesty. Though it serves no use to me, if it might grace Your Majesty’s collection, I would gladly offer it.

Once, at Ma Cheng’s residence, I saw a volume of Wang Xizhi’s *Zhengshu Catalogue*. Ma said that Wang had transcribed over ten works, including the *Luoshen Fu*, all in the modern style, except for two *Jijiu Zhang* pieces, which retained the tight, fine, and nearly archaic ancient method. Recalling this, I fear they have long since scattered and no longer survive. Ma also said that the inscribed slips from his traveling library were all imitations for the imperial princes and court officials. Recently, I saw three volumes. The first slip was said to be quite old, but I dared not presume to identify it. Such rarities are scarce. If even one or two slips from these three volumes could be included among the traveling library’s examples, it would be most fortunate.

Your Majesty’s decree has now granted the earlier volumes, filling me with awe and trepidation. When I first saw the volumes, they were numbered twenty-three or twenty-four. Delighted by their abundance, I now find the gifted texts have reached two hundred seventy. My astonishment knows no end. The imperial treasury is vast as the sea, not to be drawn by a single ladle. I can only still my heart in gratitude. Altogether, I have now received five volumes, large and small, far beyond what my crude talents deserve. Without Your Majesty’s extraordinary favor, how could I dare hope for such bounty?

By nature, I am broadly learned but lack precision. Once, I found my own calligraphy unworthy of viewing and aspired to become a scribe or historian. Later, I grew fond of clerical script and envied those who held official posts. I have often said that in the span of a human life, one’s understanding cannot encompass all things. The world is vast, yet we indulge only the five desires—this is truly shameful. I would rather become a talented ghost than a dull immortal, and this remains my conviction.

At first, I wished to abandon such pursuits, but since the *wuyi* year, state affairs have pressed heavily. My mountain heart grows weary and silent, and I dare not trouble Your Majesty with idle matters. Yet this topic has led me to importune Your Majesty excessively. I prostrate myself, praying that Your Majesty’s sagely compassion will forgive my presumption.

Having reviewed and distinguished the various manuscripts, I find your discernment truly refined. Whether they differ or align remains uncertain—all hinges on their merits. Two sheets are to be given to the *jishizhong* and *huangmen*: one for Ren Jing’s calligraphy.

Examining the characters sent under Jing’s name, they closely resemble the two sheets in question, yet Jing’s style is eclectic and fluid—this cannot be his work. One must further assess the nuances of brushstrokes, waves, and flourishes to grasp the essence of each master’s art. Such judgment cannot be rushed in the handling of brush and paper; for now, I shall guard my clumsiness and adhere to moderation. Both the copies of Xu Ren’s and Ren Jing’s works, along with the traced versions, are hereby returned. The first scroll (#7) contains miscellaneous pieces, which I have meticulously annotated in a separate note (#8). Fearing my assessment may not be just, I also submit the copies I privately made for Your Majesty’s review.

For over ten days, my thoughts have been fraught with anxiety, leaving no peace for other matters. Thus, this delay is unseemly, and I await the completion of the remaining tasks. The other entries are of no use, save for the two pieces, *Shuye* and *Weibi*, which adhere to the standard script style. I regret that they are presented as single volumes. Upon examining the scroll numbers, I find them far from few. Your earlier decree mentioned only four volumes, yet this collection appears to have been compiled during the *Yuanjia* era of the Liu-Song. Likely, many were later gathered and lost. Of Wang Xizhi’s renowned works, scarcely a handful survive—*Huangting*, *Exhortation to Advance*, *Portrait Eulogies*, and *The Goddess of the Luo River*—I cannot confirm whether these remain extant.

The twenty-third fascicle now contains twelve entries on a separate sheet. Of these, only eight are attributed to Wang Xizhi’s hand. The first, *Yue Yi Lun*, is executed with exceptional vigor yet lacks deliberate intent, resulting in several flawed characters. *The Grand Preceptor’s Admonition* and *The Great Odes* are painstakingly rendered but overly constrained, making them suitable only for fans or screens. The remaining five pieces offer little of note.

One sheet bears Minister Tao’s inscription, but this work is neither graceful nor by Wang Xizhi’s hand. Its provenance is unknown, and it appears to be a tracing. The two sheets for the *jishizhong* and *huangmen*, along with one sheet of *Zhikang Li*, are in Wang Xianzhi’s hand, though they too seem traced. Another sheet, *Ligu Fang*, is also by Wang Xianzhi and likewise a tracing. These four entries are not by Wang Xizhi.

The twenty-fourth fascicle now contains twenty-one entries, of which only eleven are attributed to Wang Xizhi. None are particularly fitting: many are careless, their strokes lacking refinement, and their elegance diminished, making detailed critique difficult. The first, from the second year of *Huangchu*, is a later imitation of Wang Xizhi’s style. One sheet, *Epitaph for a Tomb*, is by Master Xu; another, *Embracing Hidden Sorrow*, by Zhang Cheng; one dated the eleventh of the fifth month by a traced copy of Wang Min’s work; another, *Still Yearning for the Yellow and Qi*, also traced; one sheet of *Stagnation*; and a full piece, all imitations by others, clumsily executed. One sheet, undated, is by Wang Xianzhi but with altered months; another, dated the fifteenth of the fifth month, by Sun Bai; one sheet of *Zhiqin Fang* by Wang Min; and one by Xie An. These ten entries are not by Wang Xizhi.

Fearing Your Majesty may not yet deign to distinguish them, I now submit the calligraphy of Master Xu and Ren Jing for comparison, as outlined separately. From this, one may discern the hands of Wang Min, Zhang Cheng, Zhang Yi, and Xie An—works Your Majesty’s court should possess. Of the Zhong [Yao] and Wang [Xizhi] scrolls, one volume is traditionally deemed authentic, but I suspect all are traced copies, most unworthy of discussion. Only two or three lines faintly capture Zhong’s style. Wang Xizhi’s study of Zhong is evident in nearly twenty pieces. The rest, with their fine strokes and short lines, largely follow Zhong’s method.

I wish to have them mounted, but it is not yet convenient to deliver them. By next month, when the task is complete, I shall send them. Upon reviewing Your Majesty’s instructions, though the initial intent was limited to twelve pieces, the standards and judgments are comprehensive. Even if later works do not exceed two hundred, their praise and censure are fully encompassed—a single word suffices to capture the essence of calligraphy. This would instantly bestow new honor upon the aged bones of Zhong [Yao], while Wang Xianzhi’s delicate flesh would pale beside the night’s darkness. Only Wang Xizhi’s work allows for measured critique, revealing the jade-like purity of his art. Without Your Majesty’s sagely discernment in appraisal, the trend of favoring recent imitations may lead to eternal confusion.

Zhang Zhi is hailed as the sage of cursive script, and Zhong [Yao] himself is unmatched in clerical script. As the saying goes, their art shares a single mechanism—a divine treasure unmatched across ages. With this principle clarified, those who merely mimic the tiger should lay down their brushes at once. Returning to antiquity and restoring authenticity will truly herald a flourishing era.

My humble insights, though presumptuous, have been shared with joy and admiration beyond measure. The world now esteems Wang Xianzhi, while Zhong [Yao]’s legacy, though equal in the Qi and Liang dynasties, has faded in reputation. Not only is Zhong no longer recognized, but Wang Xizhi’s standing has also suffered. This is not a matter of rejection or dismissal but of being stained without purification—scarcely a few lineages remain. Now, upon receiving this discourse, I leap and dance with excitement, though it scarcely vents my fervor. I wish to privately show the traced copies to Hong Yuan and Si Kuang. These two are men of balanced judgment; they would surely leap with admiration, gaining more than half the benefit.

Though I do not know Hong Yuan personally, through my nephew Xu, we have corresponded and met. However, as he serves in the palace, he may have already heard of this. The size of the characters in the traced copies is unsuitable, but if Guo Jun were to adjust them, they might still suffice—though the brushwork’s intent may differ greatly. This work will be transmitted for a thousand generations, so the traces should follow accordingly.

Of the three sheets I present, upon examining the brushwork, I find them remarkably vigorous and precise. I fear that once words express intent, intent must align with words, and the heart must guide the hand and brush in harmony—only then can true accord be achieved. I humbly rejoice in this.

Admiration for the treasured gifts grows ever deeper. As the world universally declares, the traces of Zhong [You] no longer exist in Jiangdong. I have long regretted this, cherishing only the distant hope that when the Central Plains are pacified, the stele of Taiqiu might be traced and studied. Now, however, the imperial decree states that though authentic traces are few, they may yet be inferred. This suggests some still remain—though I know not how many characters survive. Since I cannot view them in person, I dare presume to request that skilled artisans trace and fill several lines. Should I be so fortunate as to receive them, it would be an undeserved blessing.

Moreover, when [Wang] Yishao studied under Zhong [You], his technique—subtle in movement, dense in form—surpassed his own spontaneous brushwork. I wonder how many sheets of such examples remain. The decree further mentions that works like the *Huangting Xiang Zan* may yet be provided. As for his spontaneous brushwork, I no longer dare hope. I only beg to study Zhong’s marvels, humbly awaiting this singular grace.

Additionally, before Yishao assumed office in Wuxing, his calligraphy had yet to earn acclaim. All his finest works—those he cherished and advanced—date to his time in Kuaiji, roughly the decade of Yonghe. After resigning his post and withdrawing from service upon the death of his elder, he scarcely wrote again himself, entrusting all to a single scribe. Yet the world could not distinguish their hands—how strange! In his later years, after Yishao’s death, his son Zijing, then seventeen or eighteen, imitated this scribe’s style so perfectly that their scripts became indistinguishable. Now, by the imperial decree’s illumination, all may suddenly recognize Yishao’s late work.

As for the criticism of Ruan Yan’s calligraphy in his later years, I recently heard of someone who studied Yan’s script so closely that their hands could no longer be told apart. Among the works I obtained through Guo’s tracing, though the character forms are roughly rendered, the brushwork’s intent and momentum are lost. I wonder if among the previous scrolls, one or two meticulously executed examples might be included in the set to be mounted.

Again, I am deeply moved by the imperial grace extended to the end of the year. This favor descends from heaven; I merely report what I have ascertained, without presumption or desire. *Emperor Wu’s Rescript in Reply to the Presentation of the* Xuantong Ji:

Having reviewed the memorial and examined the authentic words of Zhou’s relics, their evident verification of earlier prophecies is all the more wondrous. The four scrolls are now retained. The profound texts are fully recorded in part, with only added praise and admiration. Twentieth day of the twelfth month.

*Memorial Presenting Zhou’s* Xuantong Ji *by the Recluse:*

Your servant respectfully reports: In the final days of the tenth month, Zhou’s affair suddenly arose. As I was then observing purification rites, I could not immediately memorialize it. Now, I have meticulously compiled the events into four scrolls, which I present separately. Yet I, having lingered in doubt like a fish in a net, failed to believe and awaken sooner. In remorse and sorrow, I deserve severe censure. The profound texts are orally recounted in full. I humbly pray for leniency toward my negligence. I prostrate myself in submission.

*End of the First Scroll of the* Maoshan Annals.
