The eastern and southern portions of Yanling now belong to Jintan County in Qianjiang.

The *Inner Transmission of Great Primordiality* in the *Grotto-Heavens of Flourishing Yang* records: Within the great heavens lie thirty-six earthly grotto-heavens, of which the eighth is the cavern of Mount Juru. Spanning one hundred fifty *li* in circumference, it is called the "Grotto-Heaven of the Golden Altar of Flourishing Yang." Its four walls are hollow, their upper and lower reaches entirely of stone. The level ground lies beneath the earth, emerging only after thirteen or fourteen *li*. It measures forty-five *li* east to west and thirty-five *li* north to south, perfectly square and flat. Its hollow interior extends one hundred seventy *zhang*, its lower reaches still bearing hills and mounds, while its upper vault is perfectly level.

Within, the "Yin Radiance" and "Root of Solar Essence" illuminate the void, their brilliance rivaling sun and moon. The Yin Radiance governs night, the Solar Essence day; both are round like sun and moon, floating in the boundless dark. The grotto-palace of Juru has five gates, each approached by winding stone steps within the void, serving as thoroughfares for immortals and adepts. The light of sun and moon differs not from the world outside, nor do its grasses, trees, waters, or marshes. Birds soar through the air, winds and clouds gather thickly—yet none can fathom its mysteries.

Such is the divine grotto-palace, its numinous wonders beyond measure, beyond conjecture, beyond deception. The grotto-heaven of Juru connects eastward to the Forest Chamber, northward to Mount Tai, westward to Mount Emei, and southward to Mount Luofu. Its lesser paths and intersecting trails are too numerous to count.

During the Jianyuan era of the Han, Zuo Yuanfang, having attained the Dao, heard of this sacred mountain and came to dwell upon it, devoting himself to reverent practice. After five years, he found its gate and entered the hollow grotto, reaching the Yin Palace. The Three Lords bestowed upon him three kinds of divine mushrooms. Yuanfang wandered the grotto-palace for a year, marveling at its chambers and halls, their structures square and round, meticulously ordered, and fully furnished. He sighed: "I never imagined the world held such marvels—where spirits come and go, adjudicating life and death as if it were an earthly court!"

Jinling is the "Earthly Lung" among the blessed lands. According to the *Record of Grotto-Heavens and Blessed Lands*, there are seventy-two blessed lands, of which the Earthly Lung ranks first—this is the land of Jinling. As the *Inner Transmission* notes, its earth floats upon water, hence the comparison to a lung. The *Inner Chapters of Embracing Simplicity* mentions another "Earthly Lung Mountain," Jade Flow Isle, while Mount Shang is also called the Earthly Lung. Here, we follow the *Inner Transmission* as authoritative.

The Lord of Life-Preservation received the teaching that Jinling is the fertile marrow of the hollow grotto, the Earthly Lung of Juru. Countless tread its soil, yet none comprehend it. It is also said of Jinling: "Neither war nor flood may assail it; no calamity or plague shall befall it."

The forty-fourth scroll of the *River Chart’s Essential Primordiality* states: "Within the Altar of Jujin lies a mound. The sick do not go there; floodwaters do not rise there—truly a blessed land." The *Inner Transmission of Great Primordiality* adds: "Within Mount Juru lies the land of Jinling, spanning thirty-seven or thirty-eight *qing*. This is the Earthly Lung of Jinling. Its soil is rich, its well water sweet and fine; those who dwell here are destined for transcendence."

The *Essential Primordiality* also says: "There is an Earthly Lung, where soil is fertile and water clear. The mountains of Juru and the mounds of the Golden Altar enable transcendence and ascension." The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that Jinling’s earth resembles that of Beiyu and the Northern Valley Pass—firm and solid, ideal for growing grains. Digging a well there yields water akin to that outside Feng Gate in Chang’an, its pure source a distant subterranean spring. The water is white, and even those who do not cultivate the Dao will live long lives if they dwell upon this land and drink its waters.

The *Inner Transmission* further states: To the left of Jinling’s ridges lies the Valley of Decision, while to the left of its marshy springs rises a mountain, with fertile sources to its right, called Willow Valley. To the west of the ridges lies the Source of Relief, called Yang Valley.

The *Inner Classic of Sacred Mountains and Blessed Lands* further states: The land of Hidden Dragons lies west of Willow Valley and to the right of the Golden Altar, where one may dwell in lofty seclusion.

The *Record of Blessed Lands by Confucius* says: Between the ridges of Gang Mountain lies the homeland of Hidden Dragons, where one may evade floods, avert illness, and attain longevity. The very name "Gang" derives from the essence of Jinling itself. Yet over a hundred generations and countless changes, its original name has been lost—how lamentable!

The Perfected Right Assistant Wang received the teaching that beyond the Golden Court of Tongwu and the Golden Mound of Wujuru lies a blessed realm for nurturing the true and a numinous dwelling for attaining transcendence:

*"Five times the waters of Yao would pour eastward into the sea,
All men would sicken and die beneath the weapons of Wu’an.
What use are spears when I bear them not?
Near the secluded gates of the Terrace of Immortals, I wander at ease."*

The Great Mount Mao lies south of Yuanfu Abbey, its solitary peak the gathering place of the Lord of Destiny, the White Crane. The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that atop Great Mount Mao rests a bronze tripod from the era of the Dark Emperor, large enough to hold four or five *hu* of grain. Its casting is exquisitely refined, buried eight *chi* deep in the earth at the mountain’s highest point, sealed beneath a slab of stone. The Dark Emperor commanded the Spirit of the Eastern Sea to conceal it there.

It is further said that the Dark Emperor was Gaoyang, son of Changyi, who was in turn the son of the Yellow Emperor’s son, Xuanxiao. Born to a woman of Mount Shu, Gaoyang was titled Zhuanxu. His father dwelled in the land of Ruo Waters, while Zhuanxu himself molded the banks of the Seven Rivers—thus was he called the Dark Emperor.

At the mountain’s summit, divine radiance often appears, known as the Cinnabar Light or the Heavenly Lamp. In ancient times, there stood a stone altar and stone chamber; today, halls and pavilions have been erected, where the ancient stone statues of the Three Mao Lords are venerated. Each year on the eighteenth day of the third month and the second day of the twelfth month, the Lord of Destiny holds his wandering assembly, and people from all directions come to the mountain to pay homage. Grand *Lingbao* purification rites are conducted, a tradition unbroken from antiquity to the present.

Central Mount Mao lies north of Mount Jijin, its solitary ridge towering above all. The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that atop the Dark Ridge of Central Mao, the Lord of Destiny buried cinnabar from the Jade Gate of the Western Hu, buried two *zhang* deep and sealed on all four sides by slabs of stone. The streams flowing down the mountain’s flanks are tinged a faint red, and those who drink from them are strengthened. On either side of the mountain’s base lie small level areas, well-suited for quiet retreats.

The villages where the people of the Three Yangs are said to attain longevity are known as Zhuyang, Taiyang, and Beiyang.

Lesser Mount Mao lies north of Central Mount Mao. The *Inner Transmission of the Great Prime* states: In the third year of the Dihuang era of Wang Mang’s reign, on the *wushen* day of the seventh month, an emissary named Zhang Yong was dispatched to present five bronze bells, yellow gold, and white jade to the Three Immortal Lords of Juqu. In the seventh year of Emperor Guangwu’s Jianwu era, on the *dingsi* day of the third month, an emissary named Wu Lun offered yellow gold and jade silks to the Three Immortal Lords.

Mount Jijin stands to the north of Yuanfu Palace. The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that behind Greater Mount Mao and before Central Mount Mao stretches a long ridge, where a continuous outcrop of stone was known in ancient times as Mount Jijin. The location is well-suited for human habitation; one may seek out watered places to build quiet dwellings, which are most excellent. Here, one may compound the elixir to cultivate the Supreme Dao. The hermit said: "This is indeed a hermitage." The present dwelling site has to its east a transverse ridge of pure stone, its forms most strange and perforated with many cavities. To the southwest rises a great stone cliff, split open to reveal a cavern within. Entering several *zhang*, the passage narrows until it no longer admits a person, yet a rushing wind issues forth.

Mount Jinjun is a small, solitary hill in the eastern hollow of Mount Jijin. The Lord of Fixed Records called it a branch of the Juqu range, known as Junshan. This mountain is most excellent. The hermit said: "People today no longer know of Junshan. Its shape resembles a mushroom standing alone—or perhaps it is the character *kun* (困), shaped like a granary." According to the records, behind Greater Mount Mao’s long ridge and east of Mount Jijin, in a hollow, stands a solitary hill like a *boshan* censer, close to Mount Jijin—this is surely it.

Mount Hualao lies south of Chongxi Palace. In ancient times, the female immortal Sun Hanhua cultivated the Dao here, and a temple once stood but has long since fallen into ruin. This mountain often emits luminous phenomena at night, which some attribute to the *qi* of cinnabar mushrooms or numinous essences; local residents frequently observe it.

Mount Dinggong stands to the north of Chongxi Palace. Tradition holds that at the beginning of the Han, Ding Lingwei ascended to immortality here. How could one from distant Liaodong come to this mountain? Perhaps, having attained the Dao, he could manifest himself anywhere at will. Mount Ding lies east of Gongchen Valley.

Tiger Claw Mountain stands west of Mount Ding.

Mount Leiping rises above Leiping Pond, as the Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching. The residence now built by Director Xu faces east toward a small hill named Mount Leiping. In the Zhou era, the Lei clan came here to raise dragons.

Mount Yugang lies northeast of Lesser Mount Mao, also called Great Transverse Mountain. Its forests are dense and lush, appearing darkly luxuriant from afar, hence its name. The Lord of Fixed Records received the teaching that east of Mount Leiping, common folk call it Great Transverse Mountain, though its true name is Mount Yugang. This is the "Gangshan" mentioned in the *Record of Famous Mountains*. In ancient times, Li Ming compounded the divine elixir here and ascended to the mysterious. By the waterside, the site remains, known in antiquity as the Elixir-Refining Cloister.

Mount Fangyu, as the *True Instructions* states, lies northeast of Mount Leiping and southeast of Mount Liangchang, where three small hills stand in proximity like the beaks of swallows, named Mount Fangyu. Ancient adepts once compounded the Nine-Cauldron Elixir here. The Recluse delighted in dwelling here during his lifetime and often roams this place still. The *Hermit’s Record* says: "The aforementioned Li Ming compounded the elixir here." The Recluse was Xu Yuan after his passing; unwilling to reveal his name, he styled himself the Recluse.

Mount Sangong lies southeast of Yan’kou Cave.

Green Mountain stands east of Mount Yugang; the hill to its west is named West Green Mountain.

Mount Magu lies west of Mount Yugang.

Mount Xianzhu lies south of Mount Leiping. The *Jade Cabinet Record* states that it is commonly called Solitary Woman Mountain.

Mount Dugong lies north of Lesser Mount Mao.

Lesser Bamboo Mountain lies east of Lesser Mount Mao.

Mount Liangchang: The *Inner Transmission of the Great Prime* states that at the northern extremity of Mount Mao, at the mouth of a cave, stands a mountain named Mount Liangchang, also connected to Juqu—essentially the same name. In the thirty-seventh year of the First Emperor of Qin, on the *guichou* day of the tenth month, he set out on his tour. In the eleventh month, he arrived at Yunmeng, where he sacrificed to Yu Shun at Mount Jiuyi. Floating down the Yangtze, he passed through Jiexi, crossed Meizhu, traversed Danyang, and reached Qiantang, where he approached the Zhe River. The waves being perilous, he turned west for one hundred and twenty *li*, crossing the strait to ascend Mount Kuaiji. There, he sacrificed to Yu the Great, gazed toward the Southern Sea, and erected a stone stele to extol the virtue of Qin at Mount Kuaiji. Li Si requested to inscribe it, and the emperor then visited the mountains and rivers. He ascended the northern extremity of Mount Juqu and buried a pair of white jades. There, he assembled his ministers, feasted his attendants, and sighed: "The joy of imperial tours is unmatched by mountains and seas. From now on, let this be a constant practice." His ministers all raised toasts, hailing it as "good and constant." Then, with great drums and bells resounding, ten thousand voices joined in song, startling the mountains and marshes. The rites of praise and augury being complete, all acclaimed the occasion. Thus, the northern extremity of Mount Juqu was renamed Mount Liangchang, its meaning derived from this event. It is also said that on the southwestern slope of Mount Liangchang lies a place fit for habitation, where the Lord of Destiny once had a separate residence—also suitable for elixir compounding. Further, to the southeast of Mount Liangchang is another habitable place, where piled stones resemble a censer. Occasionally, *hujisheng* trees grow there, their forms like curved canopies. This site is most excellent, though regrettably shallow. Still, it is sufficient. To the northwest of the cave mouth lies a slightly precarious spot, requiring an outer dwelling for stability.

Mount Taiwang lies northeast of Dingjiao Road and Liangchang, a small, pointed hill where paths run both above and below.

The First Emperor also halted here, surveying the hills and mounds.

Dragon Tail Mountain is a ridge extending from Greater Mount Mao to the eastern border of Jintan, resembling an external dragon.

Three-Cornered Mountain lies north of Huagai Peak.

Haijiang Mountain lies above Qingyun Cave. Yundui Mountain stands south of Huangfu Valley. Xianfei Mountain—*The Declarations of the Perfected* records that Jiang Shumao planted the five pungent vegetables to trade for cinnabar. *The Recluse* states: "Now called Jiu Mountain, it lies west of Greater Mount Mao, thick with great leeks, and is commonly known as Stone Dragon Mountain." Aozu Mountain is west of Xianjiu Mountain. Greater Spirit Mountain and Lesser Spirit Mountain both lie west of Aozu Mountain. Bamboo Mountain is south of Dieyu Peak.

Wu Mountain—*The Recluse* states: "From the south of Greater Mount Mao, past Leek Mountain, Bamboo Mountain, Wu Mountain, and Square Mountain, the ridges continue in succession, extending to the mountains of Huxing and Tianmu." Square Mountain—*The Declarations of the Perfected* records: "Southwest of Greater Mount Mao is a level four-peaked mountain, commonly called Square Mountain." *The Recluse* adds: "This mountain lies some twenty *li* from Greater Mount Mao, and beneath it is a cave grotto."

Feng:
Soulun Peak is the eastern ridge of Greater Mount Mao, as documented in *Traces of Antiquity*. Five Clouds Peak faces the southeast of Jijin Mountain. Long ago, the Three Mao Lords each appeared atop the peak riding flying clouds, witnessed by the people and reported to the regional governor. An imperial edict proclaimed: "Thus do your resplendent clouds shine, your immortal forms distinct, able to blend the radiance of five hues and spread their canopy over the summits of the Three Maos." At the time, Prefect Xu was in the capital and often performed distant rites in that direction, saying: "Gazing afar at the three peaks, I move my heart in silent accord—thus do I attain resonance, for the lofty perfected ones heed my intent."

Daozu Peak lies on the northern side of Jijin Mountain.

Jade-Stacked Peak stands east of Greater Mount Mao. Canopy Peak lies east of Jade-Stacked Peak. White Cloud Peak is west of Central Mount Mao. Embracing Simplicity Peak is the northern ridge of Greater Mount Mao.

Long Seclusion Ridge, also called Crouching Dragon Ridge, is described in *The Recluse*: "The ridge lies on the southern bank of Master Guo’s Pool, a long and gently sloping mound that conceals serpents—hence its name." The ridge is entirely composed of fine gravel, unsuitable for dwelling. Only near its southeastern end, from Prefect Xu’s residence to the vicinity of Thunder Flat, are there habitable places. In Yixing, Jiang Fuchu and others established daily abodes at the ridge’s base, four or five *li* from Prefect Xu’s residence.

Wuzhi Mound lies in the Southern Grotto of Huayang. Peach Blossom Slope is north of Lesser Mount Mao, its forests and ravines secluded and profound. In spring, flowers and plants flourish in abundance, no different from the Wuling Source.

Arched-to-Heaven Valley, also called Arched-to-Heaven Stronghold, is northeast of Central Mount Mao. Master Liu’s encounter led to the construction of Yuanfu Palace, with an imperial decree assigning two hundred soldiers from Jiangning to patrol and sweep the area. A stronghold was thus established in the valley, as detailed in the *History of the Song*.

Huangfu Valley lies on Three-Cornered Mountain. Seedling-Planting Valley is north of Three-Cornered Mountain.

Black Tiger Gully is west of the long ridge between Central and Lesser Mount Mao.

The Perfected One says: "Heaven without name is called ‘void’; mountains without name are called ‘grottoes’; people without name are called ‘chambers.’ The hollow within a mountain is called a ‘grotto-court,’ and the hollow within a person’s head is called a ‘grotto-chamber.’ Thus do the Perfected dwell in heaven, in mountains, and in people—entering and exiting without obstruction. For just as the earth has mountains and grottoes, so too does the human body have facial cavities, through which the spirit and *qi* flow."

*The Inner Transmission of the Great Primordial* states: "The Grotto-Palace of Mount Gouqu has five gates: the southern two side gates, the eastern and western side gates, and the northern great side gate—together forming the five gates."

*The Recluse* records: "The great southern grotto of the mountain is the western side gate of the southern face. The eastern gate appears to lie within Wuzhi Mound. The Northern Eternal Grotto is the northern great side gate, while the eastern and western gates remain undiscovered."

Lord Dinglu received this teaching: "The eastern side gate lies at the mouth of the small ridge east of Central Mount Mao, so the western side gate should also exist—now called the Stone Tomb site."

The Southern Grotto of Huayang is within Xiangzhi Mound at the foot of Greater Mount Mao. Pei Su, courtesy name Zhongming, prefect of Yuezhou during the Tang, crafted a pine-seed stone table for his audience with the Perfected.

Mao Grotto lies beneath the stone steps of Yuanyang Abbey—this is the western side gate of the southern face. Lord Dinglu received this teaching: "Greater Mount Mao has a small cave in the south called the Southern Side Gate. By purifying oneself and fasting, directing one’s heart toward the Lord of Life, and regularly offering prayers on the second and fifteenth days to welcome and invoke the mountain, one may naturally behold me. If sincerity reaches such depth, how could the Dark Palace not be revealed? What manner of man was Zuo Ci?"

The Huayang Grotto is the eastern side gate. Lord Dinglu received this teaching: "East of Central Mount Mao is a small cave, barely large enough for a dog to pass—scarcely wide enough for a person to enter. Yet the deeper one goes, the more spacious it becomes. A flat stone seals the entrance, leaving only a small opening the size of a cup, guarded by the mountain spirits. This stone door occasionally opens—it is called the Hidden Gate of the Dark Palace. After purifying himself and fasting, Ziqin sought it out and entered here, finding it easier than the entrance to Eternal Grotto. Eternal Grotto has sandy paths, winding and treacherous where water flows, making passage difficult. Moreover, the road is long, not as convenient as the Small Ridge. Descending straight down from the entrance for three or four *li*, one reaches the Eastern Dark Gate of the Dark Palace. Unless one has already attained immortality, one cannot find the gate to enter."

The Western Grotto of Huayang lies at the eastern foot of Jijin Mountain—this is the "wind-whistling grotto of Jijin Mountain" mentioned in *The Recluse*. Successive dynasties deposited golden records and dragon tablets here—this is the western side gate.

Eternal Grotto is the northern great side gate of Huayang, governed by the Lord of Life-Preservation. Lord Dinglu received this teaching: "At the northern edge of Eternal Grotto’s entrance, walking two hundred paces south along the mountain ridge, one finds a pair of white jade tablets buried by the First Emperor of Qin. A small flat stone on the ridge covers the burial site. Li Si inscribed the tablets with these words: ‘The sagely virtue of the First Emperor brings order to mountains and rivers. In his imperial tour of the azure streams, he engraved his inscription on pure jade.’ Wherever the First Emperor trod upon mountains and rivers, he honored them with jade tablets—not only at Gouqu."

The stone altar north of the grotto is where Master Xu burned incense, bowed in worship, and attained transcendence—this is the "northern grotto’s end" referred to in *True Reports*.

Luo Gu Grotto lies west of Jinjun Mountain, named after Luo Yu, the female immortal of Mount Jiuyi. High Dwelling Grotto shares a stone boundary with Luo Gu Grotto.

Jade Pillar Grotto is south of the Western Grotto of Huayang, its interior filled with stalactites, leaving only narrow passages on all sides for human passage.

Hua Lao Grotto is on Hua Lao Mountain, named after Sun Hanhua.

Dengdu Grotto is at Purple Yang Abbey, as recorded in the section on Louguan.

Small Green Dragon Grotto lies above the Cinnabar Spring west of Lesser Mount Mao.

Heaven’s Window Grotto is on Jijin Mountain.

Azure Cliff Grotto is behind Chongshou Abbey. At its summit stands the Qinqi Pavilion, where ancient trees and perilous foundations remain.

The Female Immortal’s Grotto is thirty paces east of Azure Cliff Grotto. Its entrance, viewed from above, resembles a deep well. Tradition holds that the daughter of Master Ren attained the Dao and vanished here.

Wuzhi Grotto is south of the Golden Ox Cavern. Those who ventured inside once heard the sounds of wind, waves, and oars from Lake Tai.

Auspicious Cloud Grotto lies at the foot of Haijiang Mountain.

Black Tiger Grotto is to the left of the Nine Bestowments Stele in the Southern Grotto of Huayang.

Yellow Dragon Grotto is to the right of the Nine Bestowments Stele.

Southern Dipper Grotto is at the Female Palace’s Wondrous Dharma Convent on Three-Cornered Mountain.

Sea Spring Grotto is in Huangfu Valley, its source deep and unfathomable.

The Water Dragon Grotto lies at the foot of White Cloud Peak.

The Swallow’s Mouth Grotto is south of Square Corner Mountain, containing cavern chambers. The Female Immortal Qian Miaozhen vanished and transformed within it. In the fifth year of the Chunyou era, Inspector Xiahou Jiazhen and the Daoist priest of Jianlong Abbey visited the grotto to present dragon tablets. That very night, thunder shook the earth, the grotto’s entrance opened, and a court clerk ventured deep inside. There he encountered a Daoist priest and a bird of paradise; after consuming it, he ceased taking grain.

The Square Corner Grotto is atop Square Corner Mountain. The *True Records* states that the Square Corner Grotto has two entrances, one of which is the Swallow’s Mouth Grotto. The grotto is named the Square Origin Lodge, and its southern passage connects to Square Mountain south of Great Mao Peak, where two additional entrances are visible from the outside.

The Master’s Grotto lies on the mountain opposite Liangchang. Confucius never entered the realm of Wu; it is unknown how it came to bear this name.

The Square Terrace Grotto is at the base of Square Mountain, containing cavern chambers with two entrances visible from the outside. It is connected to Huayang and designated as a separate secluded lodge, where those who attain the Dao reside. The common people call it the White Stone Grotto.

The Azure Dragon Grotto is on Giving Seal Mountain, over ten *li* from Square Mountain. Giving Seal Mountain is now called Ya Tou Mountain and lies within the borders of Liyang Prefecture. The *Recluse’s Record* states: “A large entrance is visible from the outside. In ancient times, someone ventured deep inside and saw a great azure serpent, hence the name Azure Dragon Grotto.” The grotto is vast and profound, accessible to those who draw near.

The Flower Canopy Crag stands above the Inkstone Pool. At the end of the Song dynasty, the imperial court summoned the county magistrate Zhang Yun to select a residence before it.

The Waiting Immortal Crag is several paces east of Azure Cliff Grotto.

The Misty Leopard Crag lies below Azure Cliff Grotto.

The Jasper Crag stands above Cinnabar Valley Spring.

The Assembly of Perfected Crag is beside Mao Grotto.

The Grotto Where Perfected Qian Recited Scriptures is above Swallow’s Mouth Grotto.

The Golden Ox Cavern is east of Wuzhi Grotto. During the Qin dynasty, gold was mined here, and a golden ox was unearthed. When a woman touched it, the ox was cast aside and could not be retrieved. Pursuing it to Dingjiao, the place was henceforth named Upper and Lower Barrier. Another account speaks of the “Thundering Ox,” which plunged into the sea and was never seen again. The *Gazetteer of Geography* also mentions a stone here.

The Winding Water Cavern lies below Azure Cliff.

*Record of Mount Mao*, Scroll Six—concluded.
*Record of Mount Mao*, Scroll Seven.

Master Liu Dabin, Successor of the Supreme Clarity Lineage, composed *The Boundaries of the Divine Realm*:

**Waterways**

The Eastern and Western Streams of King Chu converge at the former site of Chongxi Abbey—these, along with the three waters of Huayang’s Western Grotto, merge and flow directly before Chongxi Abbey. In ancient times, King Wei of Chu once rested here, hence the name.

*The Recluse’s Record* states: To the east of the Recluse’s present dwelling lies a transverse ridge. To the southwest stands a great stone cliff, within which is a grotto. A few paces outside, a spring gushes forth, its waters clear in both winter and summer—this is the source for the lower abbey’s needs. Near the outer grotto’s mouth, another spring surges upward, its flow swift, warm in winter and cool in summer, directly facing the small path ahead. Below, yet another cavernous spring wells forth, most extraordinary. Neither great floods nor severe droughts alter its volume; its waters are slightly white, sweet, and soft, flowing endlessly. The only regret is that it lies entirely on the mountain’s western side, unable to flow eastward. Note: The transverse ridge is Grotto Ridge, the lower abbey is Chongxi Abbey, and this waterway is the Stream of King Chu.

**Crane Terrace Stream**—*The Recluse’s Record* states: Crossing Accumulated Gold Ridge to the southeast, a stone cavern appears, its waters flowing eastward most beautifully. The site is secluded and well-suited for compounding the elixir, directly before Mushroom Mountain and Peach Pond Stream.

**Spring of Renewed Joy** lies east of Central Mao Peak. Master Ren once used its eastward-flowing waters to compound the elixir, directly before the ancient Grotto-Heaven’s Pass.

**Nine-Bend Stream**—a tributary descending from the left flank of Great Mao Peak, emptying into Ten-Thousand Reeds Pool.

**Great Stream** lies east of Golden Mushroom Mountain.

**Flowing Goblet Bend** is west of Thunder Flat Mountain.

**Jade Standard Stream** lies two *li* west of Great Mao Peak. Master Guo Sichao once cultivated *Kerria* there.

**White Plum Creek** lies north of Lesser Mao Peak, where Lord Zhan planted white plums.

**Azure Dragon Creek** is west of Constant Virtue Mountain, commonly called Tinkling Water Stream.

**Guest-Welcoming Spring** lies north of Great Mao Peak, beside a square pond several *chi* deep. When guests arrive, the spring leaps and bubbles; if one approaches with noise or commotion, it stills and does not stir—another marvel. A hut here is tended by Sun Hanhua for incense offerings.

**Beneficial Spring** lies on the eastern ridge of Great Mao Peak. *The Hidden Decisions on Ascending to Perfection* states: To the left and right of the Celestial Market Altar are springs, all golden and jade-like essences. Drinking them benefits one, hence the name.

**Jade Butterfly Spring** lies on the western slope of Soughing Pinnacle. Two mouths hold the spring, one freezing and one warm in winter, also called the Yin-Yang Well.

**White Jade Spring**
**Numinous Spring** is atop Accumulated Gold Mountain.

**Grotto Spring** is the pool beneath Immortal-Bridging Bridge.

**Jade Sand Spring** lies west of Central Mao Peak. Lord Director of Destinies buried Western Hu jade-gate cinnabar on Central Mao’s Dark Ridge, and the spring’s waters, when drunk, benefit one.

**Cinnabar Spring** lies west of Lesser Mao Peak.

**Deer-Trod Spring** is to the left of Great Luo Source. Ancient adepts cultivated here, and a transcendent deer caused this spring to emerge.

**Hundred-Fathom Spring** lies in Arching Dawn Valley.

**Lock-and-Drink Spring** is on the southern slope of Great Mao Peak, its waters milky in hue.

**Sea-Eye Springs**—two in number. One, according to old records, lies at Yang the Academician’s mountain lodge. Its waters surge in response to the tides, located between Accumulated Gold and Central Mao to the west; the present spring in Western Garden is it. The other lies west of Inkstone Pool.

**Cinnabar Valley Spring** is east of Auspicious Cloud Grotto. Once, a Daoist drew its waters to compound the elixir, but a youth substituted other water. The Daoist detected this, and thus the name.

**Lord Tian’s Spring**
**Lord Tao’s Spring** is in Huangfu Valley.

**Jade Fluid Springs**—two in number. One lies north of the Immortal’s Stone-Cradling Peak. Its waters are sweet and fragrant, faintly milky, curing all abdominal ailments. Today, its waters appear pure white, also called White Spring. The other lies at Jade Fluid Hut on Three-Cornered Mountain.

**Hand-Clapping Spring**, also called Winter-Warm Spring, is below the Terrace Where Xiao Zhaoming Read. Upon hearing the sound of clapping, the spring surges like boiling water, its square pond always brimming.

**Single-Scoop Spring** is on the cliff behind the Terrace Where Xiao Zhaoming Read.

**Celestial Pool** lies atop Great Mao Peak, the abode of divine dragons, never drying even in great drought.

**Dragon-Rearing Pool** is at Celestial Sage Abbey. During the *Dazhong Xiangfu* era, an imperial edict urged the retrieval of a dragon’s offspring, and an imperial ode was composed to send it back to the mountain.

**Jade Pool** is before the Jade Emperor Hall at Celestial Sage Abbey.

**Life-Release Pool** is east of Changning Town.

**Inkstone Pool**, also called Sweetflag Pool. Fei Zhangfang of the Han studied the Dao here. When he inscribed talismans and rinsed his inkstone, the stream’s stones all turned black. Even today, using its waters to compound medicines yields extraordinary efficacy.

**Jade Nectar Pool** is before Longevity Abbey.

**Master Zhou’s Pool**—the pool of Zhou Ziliang, disciple of the Recluse, is at Numinous Treasure Cloister.

**Thunder Flat Pool**
**Guo’s Pond** lies several *li* east of Long-Hidden Mountain. The village is named Guo’s Pond after Master Guo Sichao’s external alchemy. Its waters remain perpetually full; when villagers drain it, thunder and lightning strike. Even now, prayers for rain here prove efficacious. On days when the Perfected are honored, rare fragrances assail one.

**Lord Recorder of Destinies received the mandate.**

The Four Perfected Ones once dispatched followers to cultivate this land. Year after year, whenever the Four Perfected traveled, they would pass through this mountain to compose their thoughts and survey the plains and hills.

**Crimson Stone Pond**
**Plum Family Pond** lies west of the Sea-Eye Spring.
**Tao’s Pond** is west of Thunder Flat Mountain.
**Protector-General Pool**, where Xu the Chief Clerk of the Outer Guard practiced external alchemy, stands beside Dingjiao Road. Each time he returned from abroad, he would first bathe here, purify himself, and only then enter the mountain—such was his reverence.

**White Tortoise Pool** lies before String-of-Pearls Mountain. During the Liang Tianjian era, Zhou Ziliang, disciple of the Recluse, built the Vermilion Yang Lodge as a quiet chamber. After thatching the roof with reeds, he gathered the leftover stalks and discovered a white tortoise, about six or seven *cun* long. Its body, scales, and shell were smooth and white as talc, save for black markings on its cheeks resembling talismanic script—though indecipherable. He caught it, played with it, then released it into the pool. After swimming several hundred paces away, it returned to the pile of reeds, a manifest auspicious sign. For details, see *Zhou’s Records of Mystic Communication*.

**Great Luo Source** lies west of Central Mao.
**Paulownia Blossom Source** is above Crane Terrace Gorge.
**Rosy Canopy Sea** lies above Paulownia Blossom Source.
**Cinnabar Pool** is east of Swallow Mouth Cave.
**Yang Valley Yi**—as *The Inner Transmission of the Great Primordial* and the *Golden Mound Grotto-Heaven* of Jinling record in detail.

The *Recluse’s Records* state: Yang Valley Yi rises before Central Mao, behind Great Mao, where several streams converge to form a single confluence. For accounts of other unrecorded waters, see the *Traces of Antiquity* chapter.

**Altar-Stone Bridge Pavilion**
**Nine-Tiered Altar**—there are two. One stands at Qianyuan Abbey, built by Zhu Guanmiao. The other is the Supreme Clarity Lineage Altar.
**Preceptor-Worship Altar** stands atop Thunder Flat Peak, erected by Wang Zhensu of the Southern Tang.
**Fire Court Altar** is at Mystic Continent Hermitage.
**Eight Trigrams Terrace** lies east of Mao Grotto.
**Fairy Maiden’s Terrace** is on Piled Jade Peak.
**Angler’s Terrace** is the sheer rock south of Central Mao Ridge.
**Crane Terrace** lies behind Golden Mushroom Mountain.
**Crane Temple Peak** is west of Central Mao.
**Phoenix Slope** is before Crane Terrace.
**Golden Star Ridge** lies south of Piled Jade Peak, where golden sand covers the ground.
**Green Jade Gorge** is east of Dinggong Mountain, a landscape of strange stones and wooded hills—the former site of Deep Secluded Pavilion.
**Climb-the-Clouds Steps** are below Azure Cliff, inscribed with Xu Kai’s great seal script on stone.
**Master Tao’s Drunken Stone** is on Central Mao Ridge.
**Immortals’ Offering Stone** appears as if borne by figures in the mountain hollow, at the western slope of Great Mao.
**Cloud-Root Stone** lies below White Cloud Peak.
**Go Board** is atop White Cloud Peak.
**Moving Stone** stands on Central Mao’s summit—one person can shift it, but many cannot budge it.

**Descending Perfection Bridge** is thirty *li* west of Lesser Mao on the Jurong Road.
**Communing Immortals Bridge** lies below the ridge of Yuanfu Palace, built when Master Liu founded the palace during the Chongning era.
**Perpetual Peace Bridge** is at Perpetual Peace Town.
**Swallow Cave Stone**—a bridge spans the chasm between two cliffs, its shape like a sword unsheathed.

**Embroidered Robe Pavilion**, traditionally said to be where the Great Lord of Destiny received the Nine Bestowals. Today, it is identified as the western ridge of Great Mao, where two or three towering stones stand facing west, with a small level area beneath the southern cliff marking the former foundation.

**Nine Bestowals Pavilion** is in the Southern Grotto, sheltering the stone pillar inscribed with the Nine Bestowals in seal script. The inscription reads: *"Xu Kai, Natural Disciple, respectfully visits Huayang Grotto-Heaven."* Tang and Song inscriptions remain, though most are broken.

**Azure Cliff Pavilion** stands below Azure Cliff Grotto, preserving the inscribed plaque of Song Chancellor Shi Hao [character missing].
**Qinchi Pavilion** is above Azure Cliff Grotto.
**Embroidered Feather Pavilion** is at Blessed Well, sheltering the well’s inscribed stele.
**Facing the Perfected Pavilion** is at the western gate of Huayang Grotto.
**Facing the Mountain Pavilion** is at the northern slope of Great Mao.
**Mid-Mountain Pavilion** is halfway up Great Mao.
**Spring Welcome Pavilion** is in Gongzhan Valley.
**Rosy Cloud Pavilion** is before Central Mao.
**White Cloud Pavilion** is north of Central Mao.
**Western Tortoise Pavilion** is above Willow Bend.
**Greeting Grace Pavilion** is north of Perpetual Peace Town.

**Perpetual Peace Town** lies fifty *li* southeast of Jurong County and sixty-five *li* west of Jintan County. During the Tiansheng era of the Song, Zhu Guanmiao petitioned the court to establish it as a resting place for travelers and merchants.

**Northern Town** is west of Jade Dawn Abbey.
**Western Garden** is on level ground west of Accumulated Gold Mountain.
**Deer Grave** lies beside the main road south of the mountain—see *The Transmission of Master Liu*.

*Record of Mount Mao, Scroll Seven* concludes.
*Record of Mount Mao, Scroll Eight* begins.

**The "Investigation of Antiquity" by Liu Dabin, Successive Master of Highest Clarity**

**Heavenly Market Altar**, as recorded by Lord Ya Yan of the Register of Destiny: Beneath the stone of Heavenly Market Altar lies the very center of the Grotto-Heaven, above the Mystic Window. This stone originates from the Heavenly Market Mountain of Anxi, whence its name. During the reign of the Dark Emperor, the gods of the Four Seas were summoned to transport this massive stone to the summit of the Grotto-Heaven. Ancient records place it atop Accumulated Gold Mountain.

*The Recluse* states: The location of the Heavenly Market Altar stone remains uncertain. Judging by the *Swift Wheel’s* proximity, it likely lies near Great Mao. Yet it seems improbable that the center of the Grotto-Heaven would be so close to the southern gate—perhaps it is near Central Mao. Even the village elders no longer know its whereabouts.

Another account: The **Immortal’s Market Altar**. In *True Reports*, Zhao Weibo, the Life-Preserving Minister, was skilled in whistling—his calls resembled a chorus of a hundred birds, or the wind rushing through forests, or the sound of drums. At times, he would ascend the Heavenly Market Altar, shake his beard toward the north, and whistle to summon the wind. Soon, clouds would gather above him, *qi* would stir the woods, and dark mists would descend, bringing gentle rain.

**Swift Wheel’s Edge**, as recorded in *True Reports*: Once, the Green Lad of the Eastern Sea rode a flying chariot drawn by a single swift wheel, traversing the mountains of You Terrace. *The Recluse* notes: Today, on the ridge of Great Mao, a road runs eastward—its sides leveled as if by human labor, wide enough for carts. Tradition holds this to be the Swift Wheel’s Edge. The Perfected often ride nine dragons, the left named *Swift*, the right named *Reverent*. Having ascended the mountain’s summit, they are said to mount the left dragon.

**Jiangba Road**, as recorded by Lord Ya Yan of the Register of Destiny: During the Qin, the Daoist Zhou Taibin and Jiang Shumao, the Marquis of Baling, came to dwell at the mountain’s foot. They planted the five fruits and the five pungent vegetables. Shumao was enfeoffed as marquis during the reign of King Xiao of Qin, hence the name of this place. *The Recluse* states: The main road from Little Mao leads to Yanling and is called Jiangba Road. However, during the reign of Duke Xiao of Qin, the state of Chu had not yet been annexed and divided into commanderies, and Baling County was first established in the early Jin. It is unclear how there could have been a marquisate of Baling—likely it refers to Ba of Shu.

**Thunder Level Pond** lies before Thunder Level Mountain. *True Reports* records that during the Zhou, the Lei clan raised dragons here. Lord Wei Yan of the Register of Destiny states: The pond before the abode was constructed by Guo Sichao. Its embankments were raised to deepen the water, but over the ages, the walls have crumbled.

Sichao often rowed a small boat upon the pond, striking the sides as he sang:

*I.*
A clear pond girds the numinous peak,
Long woods lush with verdant green.
Dark birds hide in secluded wilds,
Words of ease flow unconstrained.
Rowing oars upon the spirit waves,
I bow, yearning for the morning breeze.
Yet the hour of liberation eludes,
And I wander amid the forest of blades.

*II.*
Beyond the Nine Abysses, the Wave Spirit,
I refine the Dao to attain golden perfection.
I sheathe these spirit-phoenix wings,
Conceal my radiant dragon scales.
Lifting high this inch of heart,
Ten thousand gusts are but dust and grime.
Pity the mayfly born at dawn—
Who can exhaust your turning wheel?

*III.*
Roaming the void, the flying swift descends,
A spirit’s step leaves no trace.
The round sun gleams with bright rosy clouds,
Nine phoenixes sing at dawn.
Beating wings, they fan the River of Heaven,
Evening mists and auspicious clouds soar.
At last I reach the Palace of Grand Tenuity,
Embracing this golden pear nectar.
Wandering beyond the dark abyss,
Neither existing nor ceasing to be.

*IV.*
Riding the swift, I pity the divine clouds,
Donning rosy hues beneath nine suns.
The High Emperor’s dragon chariot aligns,
At last I reach the Northern Flower Chamber.
Spirit tigers dwell in the agate grove,
Wind and clouds merge as one.
Opening and closing the gates of dark mystery,
The numinous transformations vanish without trace.

The villagers below the mountain still call it a level marsh.

The "Guo Gan of the Earth" remains a surname from the Four Dynasties still spoken of among the people. Regarding Red Stone Pond, in a letter dated the first day of the third month from Lord Dinglu to Prefect Xu, it is written: "Now we must reclaim the fields at Red Stone to serve as a path for comings and goings, yet the task was never completed." Prefect Xu replied: "Long ago, we surveyed the Red Stone fields, finding them advantageous near the mountain’s base for travel, a matter of sincere devotion. But then came drought, the tenants reaped no harvest, and the pond’s collapse required immediate labor—this was a matter of strength unfulfilled, not of waning resolve. Now, dwelling at the mountain’s foot, we ought to restore the fields, though their distance from the cave’s entrance makes us reluctant to settle there."

*The Recluse* states: "These fields lie west of Great Mao and Central Mao, close to the great mountain, offering an excellent vantage for reverence and worship. Yet when it speaks of their distance from the cave’s entrance, it must refer to the northern cave’s entrance. Though the fields are fed by mountain streams, water dwindles in drought. The pond is also difficult to establish—who knows if they will ever reclaim them? The embankment still lacks repairs; with several hundred laborers, it could irrigate ten or so *qing* of land. The disciples at the Recluse’s lodge also sow crops here with the flowing water, ever wishing to restore this pond to benefit both near and far, and to bestow kindness upon the common folk."

Tian Gong Spring, also called Liu Fen Spring or Liu Valley Spring, lies one *li* southeast of Thunder Flat Pond. Lord Dinglu, mute of speech, said that on Huayang’s Thunder Flat Mountain there is a Tian Gong Spring whose waters expel the three worms from the abdomen, matching the flavor of the Recluse’s Spring. It is said to be a flow of jade sand, and when used to launder clothes, no ash is needed—this sets it apart. Long ago, a man named Tian Shu lived on Thunder Flat Mountain; after attaining the Dao, the spring was named in his honor.

The Cinnabar Well of Lord Mao lies within the Lower Resting Palace. The well of Perfected Li, where Perfected Li Ming of the Dark Continent refined cinnabar, is located east of the Yugang Square Grotto. The well of Prefect Xu is at Jade Dawn Abbey. *The Recluse* records: "In the seventh year of the Great Brightness era, an elder from Xu Village named Xu Ou said his ancestors had served Prefect Xu, passing down that this residence once stood where the present-day thicket lies. The former site of the scholar’s hall should be where the wutong trees now grow, and the old well still existed at the time, though overgrown with weeds. Clearing the brush, they found it—a brick well nearly filled with earth. They dug it out, reinforced its walls, and now it yields fine water, slightly white in hue, said to resemble the taste of the water outside Phoenix Gate in Chang’an. Two mouths share one source; in winter, one is cold, the other warm—hence its name, the Yin-Yang Well."

The well of Ge Hong lies at Embracing Simplicity Mountain Hut in Zhichuan. Xu Huangmin of Danyang in Jurong, a grandson of Prefect Xu, married the granddaughter of Zhichuan and lived on this mountain, as handed down through generations. The cinnabar well of Perfected Tao is located east of the stone bridge before the Upper Lodge of Huayang. Its water is sweet and clear, never failing even in drought. At the beginning of the Zhenghe era, the Daoist Zhuang Shenzi sought and restored it. After removing three *chi* of earth, they uncovered a stone well with a broken railing, which they reassembled, leaving it mostly intact. Carved around it in large characters were the words: "The Master, Tao Shiqí, Gentleman in Attendance of the Southern Qi court, came to this mountain in the *renshen* year. Dwelling in lofty seclusion, he styled himself *The Recluse*. His disciples who accompanied him included Lu Jingyou of Wu Commandery, and others named Yang, Wang, Wu, Dai, Chen, and Xu. Those who offered provisions—Pan Luo of Husu in the Palace Service, and disciples from near and far—are too numerous to record. Through the long ages, let none forget."

In the eighth month and fifteenth day of the third year of the Tianjian era of the Liang dynasty, Chen Maoxuan of Qiantang inscribed and unearthed a brick bearing Sanskrit characters. After excavating several *zhang* deeper, they recovered a round inkstone, approximately nine *cun* in diameter, with eleven toes arranged around its edge. When washed, its vermilion hue remained vivid. They also found a bronze incense burner with a magpie-tail design, and amidst the sand and stones, a single grain of cinnabar, as large as a lotus seed, its radiance dazzling the eye. Eager to retrieve it, they reached for it, only for it to slip and fall into the well.

The burner and inkstone were stored at Huayang, but were lost during the ravages of war. Another well lies beside the pond of Master Zhou at Lingbao Abbey—this too was the Recluse’s cinnabar well.

The *Zhen’gao* of Zhaozhen Terrace, annotated by Jian Shu in *Wings of the True Canon*, often speaks of "returning the seal to Zhaotai." This refers to the Recluse’s lineage, which practiced the supreme methods of the Three Perfected Ones—Yang and Xu.

This was the chamber for storing scriptures. After prolonged pillaging in the mountains, the sacred texts and authentic traces have scattered without a trace. Though scholars may be earnest in their pursuit, how could they ever again behold the handiwork of the Perfected? One can only sigh in lament.

Yuchen Abbey and Lingbao Abbey occupy this site. The Azure Altar and the Plain Pagoda—according to the old altar stele of the abbey—stood with the Azure Altar to the east and the Plain Pagoda to the west. Today, the pagoda has fallen into ruin, and the altar is no longer as it once was. Both were built by the Recluse to symbolize the dual cultivation of the Two Teachings, and should be located at Yuchen Abbey.

The Well of Prince Zhaoming’s Blessed Village lies east of the Reading Terrace in the Southern Grotto. The Reading Terrace of Prince Zhaoming stands above the Well of Blessed Village. The Altar of the Ming Emperor’s Register is beside the Jade Pillar Grotto.

The tomb of King Yue Yi lies at the foot of Great Horizontal Mountain. The Mute Lord of the Register, on the eastern face of Yugang Mountain, speaks of an ancient tomb of King Yue Yi. The *Records of the Recluse* state: King Yue Yi was the fourth-generation descendant of Goujian. Initially refusing to ascend the throne, he fled into a cave on Mount Xu, but the people of the state smoked him out. Later, during the reign of King Wu of Yue, he was relocated back to Kuaiji, only to be slain by Sun Zhujiu in the eleventh year of King Xuan of Zhou. How he came to be buried so far away remains unknown—perhaps there was something numinous about this place.

Upon present inspection, no definitive tomb mound is found, yet there appears to be a site marked for burial. Further examination reveals that the virtuous and retiring King Wu Taibo initially fled into the Zhong Mountains of Juqu. Thus, it is evident that this mountain has been a refuge for sages and worthies since antiquity.

The Recluse’s Secluded Lodge stands southwest of Mount Leiping. In the early Yuanyou era of the Song, the court eunuch Luo Chunyi studied the Dao in these mountains and once contemplated seclusion here. He possessed rare cinnabar and esoteric texts. One day, he opened a tomb to examine it and found only an empty coffin suspended by an iron chain, containing nothing but a sword and a bowl-mirror. The walls of the tomb were encircled by Sanskrit inscriptions in relief, forming a text that read: *"The Secluded Lodge of Huayang, where the Bodhisattva of Supreme Strength offered his body, disciple of Śākyamuni Buddha, servant of the Supreme Dao Lord, cultivating the Six Perfections of the Mahāyāna. The Three Perfected Ones of □□, resting in the sacred peaks to guard the frontier, roaming the great void to lodge the spirit."* The calligraphy was divinely wondrous, surely inscribed by the recluse himself. After the tomb was opened, the Daoist disciples copied these talismanic characters to show the world. Later, Chunyi also attained the Dao of corpse-liberation. This account was transmitted in the sixth year of Yuanyou by Lin Xizi of Changle.

The Recluse’s Alchemical Furnace lies beside the Upper Lodge of Huayang. When tested with water from the xun direction, the ground swiftly dries, forming a halo like the moon’s corona.

The tomb of Master Wang Fa lies east of the northern road in Changning Town. The Tang-era stone pillar of Taiping Abbey still stands there.

The tomb of Master Tongwu lies to the right of the Recluse’s Secluded Lodge. The tomb of Master Xuanjing lies southwest of Fuling Ridge, twenty paces from Leiping Pond. The tomb of Master Wei the Patriarch lies to the left of Master Xuanjing’s funerary palace.

*Record of Mount Mao, Scroll Eight* (concluded)

**Register of Daoist Mountains**
*The Five Thousand Character Scripture of the Dao and Its Virtue/Power*
According to the *True Register of Ascent* and *The Recluse*, the *Laozi’s Scripture of the Dao and Its Virtue/Power* exists in a hand-copied version by the Perfected Master Yang, transmitted from the ancient text of Zhang Zhennan. Zhennan was the third-generation master in the lineage of the Han Celestial Master, whom Emperor Wu of Wei enfeoffed as General Who Pacifies the South. The so-called *Five Thousand Character Scripture* indeed contains five thousand characters. The *Inner Scripture of the Lineal Masters* records 4,999 characters, with one character traditionally missing. For instance, "thirty spokes" was written as "卅 spokes" (卅 being a simplified form), which is not the orthodox character. The authentic traces of the lineage are no longer extant; the transmitted *Five Thousand Character Scripture* is now regarded as the standard version, divided into two sections without chapter divisions.

**Scroll Ten of the *Records of Mount Mao***

**Ranks of the Highest Clarity**
**Genealogy of the Seven Transmissions of the Sacred Masters of the Highest Clarity Scriptures**

**The Supreme Lord of the Great Cavern, the Most Honored Primordial Heavenly King of the Highest Clarity Dao Ancestor, the August Heavenly Emperor of the Purple Radiance and the Empty Sovereign of Heaven**
The Primordial Heavenly King is the honored one of the Jade Purity and the Primordial Heavenly Center. *The Scripture of the Yellow Court* states: "The honored one of the Highest Clarity, the Purple Radiance, and the Empty Sovereign." *The Scripture of the Jade Latitude* says: "The Empty Sovereign is the domain governed by the Great Dao, the progenitor of the myriad purities and the Dao." This is the revered deity of the *Divine Chapters of the Nine Heavens’ Generation*.

**The Sacred Master, the Most High and Sagely Jade Dawn Primordial August Lord of the Great Dao**
The Jade Dawn Lord of the Great Dao resides at the Terrace of Harmonious Dawn and the Flesh of Skin within the Palace of Numinous Radiance, governing the Pavilion of Medicinal Pearls and the Tower of Seven Jeweled Purple Chambers. To his left, he is girded by the Divine Tiger; to his right, he bears the Golden Perfected. His dragon crown and phoenix skirt are draped with a feathered cloak of brocade. His attendants—Heavenly Perfected, Jade Lads, and Jade Maidens—number thirty thousand each. The term "Most High" signifies one who scrutinizes the roots of the Dao and penetrates its origins, hence the Lord of the Highest Clarity is the teacher of Lord Lao and the sovereign of the myriad Dao. There is a transmission record titled *The Eight Simplicities of the Upper Scripture*, also known as *The Hidden Writ of the Most High: The Golden Perfection and Jade Radiance of the Seven Origins and Eight Effulgences Flying Scripture*. The *Scripture of the Yellow Court* refers to the Jade Dawn Lord of the Great Dao as the Most High, the true honor of the Most High.

**The Sacred Master, the Purple Palace Heavenly Emperor of the Great Dao of the Supreme Subtlety**
The Heavenly Emperor of the Supreme Subtlety is the sovereign of the thirty-six Heavenly Emperors, governing within the Purple Palace of the Supreme Subtlety. He is addressed by the Golden Pavilion Emperor Lord with the sixteen characters of the Five Emperors of the Sun’s Center: Solar Essence, Pearl Radiance, Illuminating Veil, Green Summons, Returning Radiance, Crimson Youth, Mystic Flame, and Terrace Image. These are the methods of ingesting flying roots, also called *The Scripture of Cinnabar, Golden Essence, Stone Radiance, Water Mother, and Jade Embryo*. The Emperor bestows these upon the Perfected.

**The Sacred Master, the Posterior Sagely Mysterious Primordial Lord of the Golden Pavilion Imperial Palace**
The Mysterious Primordial Lord of the Upper Dao is of the lineage of the Earthly August. He resides in the Palace of Jasper Terraces, attended by thirty thousand maidens and officials. Ascending to the Highest Clarity, roaming the Great Ultimate, and governing the Ten Heavens below, he rides the Flying Chariot of the Three Simplicities. In secret, he inspects the Dark and Absolute, the Terrace of Luminous Solitude, the various heavens, rivers, and seas, soaring to the Lesser Existence. He halts his carriage at Tortoise Mountain to examine and test the multitude of immortals, conferring ranks according to their talents. Every five years, he descends for a tour; every ten thousand years, he pays homage to the Highest Clarity. There is a transmission record titled *The Purple Writ of the Numinous Book*, also known as *The Precious Scripture of the Five Elders*—today’s *Arrayed Records of the Three Heavens*.

**The Sacred Master, the Jade Protector King of the Nine Subtleties of the Highest Clarity, the Grand Minister of Fate of the Golden Pavilion, the Highest Dawn Master, the Jade Radiance Azure Florescence Lad of the Eastern Sea, the Great Dao Lord**
The Azure Lad is also called the Azure Canopy Purple Lad and the Perfected within the Dipper. He governs within the Cinnabar Pavilion of the Yellow Chamber of the Eastern Sea’s Great Square Torch Palace on the Eastern Florescence Mountain. He rides the cloud chariot of streaming azure radiance, girded with a flying azure feathered cloak, attended by a thousand Perfected of the Mulberry Grove. He fed the *Scripture of the Three Origins and the True Unity* to Master Juanzi and the *Scripture of Demonic Dispersion* to the Red Perfected of the Great Void. During the Jin dynasty, he descended to the household of Lady Wei. On the eighteenth day of the third month and the second day of the twelfth month, he would arrive at Mount Gouqu together with the Minister of Fate of the Mao to examine and assess the learning of the Perfected. There is a transmission record titled *The Scripture of the Jade Protector’s Grotto Vision*, also called *The Upper Mystery of the Cloud Forest*.

**The Sacred Master, the Grand Minister of the Golden Pavilion, the Governor of the Western Limits, the Lord of the Western City, the Sovereign of the Myriad Perfected**
The Sovereign of the Myriad Perfected, surnamed Wang and named Yuan, styled Fangping, governed the Western City Mountain of Yizhou, the very seat of the Western Limits’ governance of the Myriad Perfected. He oversaw five thousand immortal officials at his abode and was the teacher of the Minister of Fate of the Mao. He once descended to the household of Cai Jing and met with Ma Gu. In the renwu year of the first Han’an era, he descended from Lord Lao to Mount Heming, where he fed the Celestial Master Zhang Daoling a thousand scrolls of scriptures and talismans. He then descended to Mount Yangluo and fed the *Upper Scripture of the Pure Void* in thirty-three scrolls to the Pure Void Perfected. During the Jin dynasty, he again descended to Mount Yangluo, where he fed the Dao to Lady Wei and bestowed the methods of the Three Perfected upon Yang and Xu. Each year on the second day, he would roam and inspect Huayang together with the Minister of Fate of the Mao, examining and assessing the male and female learners of the Perfected to determine who would become immortals. Chengdu, Guacang, and Kunlun all serve as the immortal seats of the Sovereign of the Myriad Perfected. Lord Wang governs the teachings of the Great Peace and the Twenty-Four Perfected, serving as the master of the Three Caverns.

**The Sacred Master, the Heavenly King of Lesser Existence, the Pure Void Lord of the Great Simplicity**
The Pure Void Perfected, surnamed Wang and named Bao, styled Zideng, was a native of Xiangping in Fanyang. He was the seventh-generation descendant of the Marquis of An’guo, born on the twenty-seventh day of the ninth month in the third year of the Jianzhao era of Emperor Yuan of Han. His father was the Literary Marquis Mi, and his mother was the granddaughter of Sima Qian. The Perfected studied the Dao on Mount Huayin, where he was moved by the descent of the Perfected of the Great Ultimate, who fed him the upper methods. The Sovereign of the Myriad Perfected bestowed upon him *The Upper Scripture* in thirty-one scrolls, and he became a master of covenant transmission. Together, they journeyed to the Dark Continent, where he petitioned for his true name to be recorded. He then returned to the Western City and proceeded to the Three Origins Lord of the Great Simplicity, where he received the *Flying Dawn Divine Staff and Jade Seal of the Flowing Gold, the Seven Origins, and the Eight Effulgences*. The Most High sent gifts: a feathered canopy of dawn plumes, a pair of pearls of moon-bright plain feathers, a jasper shaft, a cinnabar cord, and a brocade banner. He also dispatched a decree of investiture. His rank was established as the Pure Void Perfected of the Great Simplicity, the Left Protector and Upper Duke of the Three Origins and Four Offices of the Heavenly King of Lesser Existence. He governed Mount Wangwu, attended by three hundred Jade Lads and Jade Maidens, and oversaw the precious scriptures. He rode a chariot drawn by tigers and dragons, with a golden canopy and a jasper wheel, the Flying Chariot of the Eight Effulgences, wielding the staff of nine hues. He entered and exited the Highest Clarity, served the Great Simplicity, and reposed in the Great Ultimate.

The *Shangqing Scriptures* record that by this time, the sacred transmissions from the Seven Heavens had descended to the world seven times.

The first lineage-holder of the Shangqing tradition, the Grand Preceptor and Daoist Sovereign of the Shangqing, the Perfected of the Southern Culmen and Purple Authenticity, the Sagely Protector of the Supreme Microcosm and Jade Dawn, the Sagely Empress—who governed the Southern Marchmount’s Perfected of the Upper Realms and oversaw the life-destinies of the lofty and numinous, the Illuminator of the Purple Void and Primal Dao, the Perfected Sovereign of the Highest Origin—was surnamed Wei, named Huacun, styled Xian’an, a native of Rencheng. She was the daughter of Wei Shu, Minister of Works in the Jin dynasty, and was born in the third year of the Jiaping reign of King Jia of the Wei kingdom, the xinwei year. Gifted with extraordinary talent and a transcendent spirit, she stood apart from the common. From childhood, she studied the books of Laozi and Zhuangzi, ingested sesame and poria powders, and longed for seclusion. At twenty-four, her parents compelled her to marry Liu Youyan of Nanyang, bearing two sons, Pu and Xia. When Youyan served as magistrate of Xiwu County in Jijun, and their sons had grown to maturity, she withdrew to a separate chamber, resumed her original garb, and devoted herself to cultivation.

In the twelfth month of the ninth year of the Taikang reign, the wushen year, on the sixteenth day, at midnight, the Perfected of the Great Ultimate, the Lord of the Azure Lads, the Perfected Wang Jinglin of Fusang and the Yang Valley, and the Perfected of the Pure Void descended, addressing the Perfected Sovereign: “We have heard that you have secretly woven the true qi. The Supreme Thearch has commanded us to transmit to you the Way of the divine perfected.” Thereupon, they presented thirty-one scrolls of the Most High’s treasured texts, including the *Hidden Writ of the Eight Simplicities*, the *True Scripture of the Great Cavern*, and the *Mysterious Wings of the Lofty Transcendents*, personally bestowing them upon the Perfected Sovereign with the words: “These scriptures were once entrusted to the Master of All Perfected in the Western City. Now we pass them to you.” They also instructed her in the oral secrets of visualization, meditation, and practice before departing. The Perfected Sovereign was then thirty-seven.

Later, Youyan passed away. Her eldest son, Pu, rose to Minister of Works and Marshal of Qi; her younger son, Xia, served as Attendant to the Grand Commandant Tao and later as Administrator of Ancheng and Gentleman of the Palace. The Perfected Sovereign lived eighty-three years in the world. In the ninth year of the Xianhe reign, the jiawu year, the Lord of the Pure Void and Azure Lads descended again, bestowing two doses of divine elixir and commanding her to consume them at once, setting a date to meet at the Yangluo Palace. On the seventh day at midnight, the Great Unity dispatched a whirlwind chariot to welcome her. Employing the Way of Concealed Radiance, the Perfected Sovereign transformed her form and spirit, ascending to Mount Yangluo.

The following day, the Lord of the Azure Lads, the Four Perfected of the Great Ultimate, the Lord of the Pure Void, and forty-seven other perfected descended to instruct the Perfected Sovereign in the Cloud Terrace of the Hidden Grotto. Each perfected imparted their supreme teachings for three days before departing. The Perfected Sovereign studied and recited the jade scriptures for sixteen years, her countenance becoming like that of a maiden.

Thereafter, the Queen Mother of the West and the Perfected Sovereign of the Southern Culmen came to welcome her ascent. At dawn, she arrived at the Shangqing Palace. The Lord of the Great Dao of the Jade Dawn and Jade Clarity, the Heavenly Thearch of the Supreme Microcosm, and the Sagely Empress of the Golden Portal each sent envoys to confer investiture, bestowing upon her jade tablets and golden texts. Her rank was established as the Perfected Sovereign of the Purple Void, governing the Perfected of the Upper Realms and life-destinies of the Southern Marchmount, her position equivalent to that of a Transcendent Duke. She was charged with overseeing the teaching of aspiring transcendents at the Great Huo Mountain within the Terrace of Heavenly Platform. She also held banquets in the Palace of the Pure Void.

Subsequently, the life-destiny spirits and transcendents of the Southern Marchmount requested to be placed under her authority. As her welcoming procession arrived, the various perfected accompanied the Perfected Sovereign to the Terrace of Heavenly Platform on Mount Huo in Tiantai. En route, they passed through Jinqu’s Golden Altar, where they were hosted by Mao Shushen for two days and nights before proceeding together to Mount Huo.

Later, Pu rose to the position of Palace Attendant and was tasked with transmitting the teachings to Yang Jun, a Gentleman of the Palace in the household of the Prince of Langye, Minister of Works. In the third year of the Xingning reign, the yichou year, on the twenty-third day of the sixth month, the Perfected Sovereign descended with a host of perfected to the home of Yang Jun. From then on, she frequently descended to Jinqu, often accompanied by the Three Mao Lords of the Azure Lads and Pure Void. The transmission of the teachings beyond the single lineage of Huayang began here.

During the Yuanyou reign of the Song dynasty, she was enfeoffed as the Perfected Sovereign of the Lofty and Numinous, Illuminator of the Purple Void and Primal Dao. In the Taiding reign of the Great Yuan, Yu Ji, Director of the National University, composed eulogies for the forty-five ancestral masters. Her eulogy reads:

We gaze upon the Purple Void,
Majestic as the sacred peak of Zhurong.
Her soaring rosy clouds form verses,
Her flowing echoes shake the heavens.
Radiant as the sun and moon,
Her jade essence and golden visage.
She upholds the myriad heavens,
Inaugurating our lineage of transcendents.

The second lineage-holder of the Shangqing tradition, the Perfected Master of the Mysteries, the Perfected of the Shangqing, the Upper Protector of the Golden Portal, the Inspector of Transcendent Affairs and Life-Destinies, the Lord of the Eastern Florescence and Dao of the Cavernous Numinosity, the Perfected of Manifest Transformation and Supreme Virtue—surnamed Yang, named Xi, styled Xihe—was originally from Wu Commandery but later relocated to Jurong. He was born in the fifth year of the Xianhe reign, the gengyin year, in the ninth month. From childhood, he was spiritually attuned, possessed of a handsome appearance, eloquent and joyful, skilled in calligraphy and painting. His fame in these arts equaled that of Wang Xizhi throughout the land. Though his years differed greatly from those of Master Xu Mai (Changshi Mu), they early formed a bond of spiritual communion.

When Emperor Jianwen held the title of Prince of Langye and later ascended to the position of Chancellor, he appointed Lord Yang as Attendant Clerk of the Chancellery upon the recommendation of the Chief Administrator. Yet upon the Emperor’s enthronement, Lord Yang sought no promotion. His uncle, Gao, renounced worldly honors, and Lord Yang devoted himself to profound meditation, thereby attaining spiritual resonance.

In the fifth year of the Yonghe reign, he received the *Tiger and Leopard Method* from the Master of the Central Yellow. The following year, at the age of twenty-one, he studied the *Five Talismans of the Numinous Treasure* under Liu Pu, the eldest son of Lady Wei. In the third year of the Xingning reign, in the sixth month, the Primordial Lady of Purple Emptiness, the Lady of the Purple Tenuity, and the Perfected Consort of Ninefold Splendor descended to his home to expound the essential Dao. Thereafter, forty-seven Perfected Ones of the Clear Void and Numinous Purity descended in succession, some manifesting at Mount Changshi in response to his devotion. The scriptures and revelations he transmitted were often conveyed through spirit-writing to Master Xu and his sons. Thus, he became the master who transmitted the scriptures to Master Xu.

The Perfected Consort of Ninefold Peace, responding to the mandate of the age, became his celestial consort. She once declared to him: “Your luminous nature is serene and unadorned, your inner radiance as resplendent as jade, your virtue as profound as an orchid’s abyss, your pure resonance echoing through the golden palace—truly, you are a treasure concealed within, a hidden Perfected One whose brilliance shines inwardly. You shall become one of the Three Excellencies, attending the Emperor at dawn, a lofty assistant to the Four Counsellors, bearing the mandate of the Sagely Lord. You shall govern life and judge death, reward and punish spirits, command the myriad numina, seal mountains and summon clouds, discern the qi of yin and yang, and serve as the Lord of Life-Destinies over Wu and Yue. You shall ascend to heaven in broad daylight, riding dragons and driving clouds. If you cannot endure the smoke of wind and fire, and wish to preserve your true form in the secluded groves, might you not seek the Way of the Sword and Liberation, or the safeguards of a declared end?”

Later, the Lord of the Western City further instructed him in the method of absorbing the essence of the sun and moon. Emperor Jianwen became his disciple. In the eleventh year of the Taiyuan reign, the bingxu year, Lord Yang shed his mortal form at the age of fifty-seven.

**Eulogy:**
Serene and unadorned in nature,
His spirit companioned with the profound and mysterious.

The resonance of golden offices flows like melody,
Jade trees drift in mist and smoke.
The assembled perfected ones convene in counsel,
The Supreme Emperor bestows his summons.
By hand he transmitted the scriptures of the Dao,
His brush refined, his ink wondrous in skill.

Successor as the Third Perfected Master of the Highest Clarity,
Highest Clarity Immortal Marquis,
Left Minister of the Golden Watchtower,
Attendant of the Dawn,
Lord of Life-Destinies,
Greatly Virtuous and Perfectly Benevolent Perfected Lord of the Grand Prime—
his surname was Xu, his given name Mu, his courtesy name Siguan, and his other name Mi.
A native of Pingyu in Runan,
his sixth-generation ancestor Guang had relocated to Danyang.

Born in the second year of the Yongxing reign of Emperor Huai of Jin, the yichou year,
he began his career as an erudite of the Imperial Academy,
then served as magistrate of Yuyao,
later summoned as Gentleman of the Masters of Writing,
promoted to Regional Rectifier,
Protector-General’s Chief Clerk,
Gentleman Cavalier Attendant,
and Regular Cavalier Attendant.

Outwardly, he blended with worldly affairs;
inwardly, he cultivated the study of the true.
Once admiring his elder brother’s lofty path of distant wandering,
he encountered the passing of Emperor Jianwen,
devoting himself to stillness in his mountain retreat,
where he forged a pact of numinous clarity with Lord Yang.

During the Xingning era,
the host of perfected ones descended,
and Yang diligently transmitted the scriptures and decrees.
The Perfected Lord of Fixed Will imparted especially abundant teachings.
In the first year of the Taiyuan reign, he shed his mortal form at the age of seventy-two.
His sons and nephews observed the rites of interment,
entombing an empty coffin in the great tomb west of the county.

The *True Declarations* states:
His mandate was rooted in destiny,
his karmic conditions long established.
In a former life, he was the younger brother of Xue, the Duke of Changli,
ninth minister of King Wu of Zhou.
Inheriting the legacy of Xu Zhao’s meritorious deeds,
he was again destined to receive blessings as a later descendant.
Thus, borne by the turning of the times, he took rebirth,
and by virtue of his endowments, attained the Dao.

As a Perfected One of the Highest Clarity, conferred by jade tablets,
he was enfeoffed as a marquis,
his rank inscribed among the ministers and directors,
governing immortals and soothing the realm,
assisting the sagely in shepherding the people.

**Eulogy:**
His wind and verdure answered the turning of the times,
his noble lineage inherited the blessings of destiny.

The subtle unfolding of culture refines the mysteries of the divine,
while worldly honors brush the surface—what need for inner cultivation?
In the emptiness of the Jade Dawn, my heart wanders in true communion.

Fourth-generation lineage master of the Highest Clarity, Celestial Lord of the Golden Portals, Right Minister of Destiny, Attendant of the Eastern Radiance, Perfected of Primordial Unity and Vast Transformation—third son of the Immortal Marquis—his name was Liu, styled Daoxiang, with the childhood name Jade Axe. Pure and luminous, his brilliance surpassed all peers. Born in the seventh year of Chengkang of the Jin, the xin-chou year, in the first month.

Recommended for the imperial accounts and summoned as Registrar to the Minister of Education’s office, he declined both. He built his dwelling before Mount Leiping and secretly cultivated the supreme Dao. In the third year of Xingning, in the seventh month, the Lady of the Purple Tenuity descended with teachings. From then on, he exchanged written correspondence with the host of Perfected, diligently practicing the rites of Returning to the Origin, Flying Steps, and the Two Radiant Canopies. He longed to journey early to the Grotto Chambers and had no wish to linger in the mortal world. In the fifth year of Taihe, the geng-wu year, he journeyed to the Northern Grotto to announce his end, aged thirty.

Elders passed down this account: while burning incense and prostrating upon the stone altar of the Northern Grotto, he bowed and did not rise. At dawn the next day, his form appeared as if still living. The Lord of Preserving Life remained silent, permitting him to relinquish his form in hidden transformation, following the nocturnal release of Zhang Zhennan. Zhennan was the third-generation lineage master of the Celestial Master, Lu. Thereafter, he dwelled in the grotto-palaces of the four directions, often coming and going from the Square Terrace of the Four Directions.

*The Declarations of the Perfected* states: Sixteen years later, he shall ascend to the Eastern Florescence to receive the scriptures and be enfeoffed as the Celestial Lord of the Highest Clarity. His wife, daughter of Huang Yan, Prefect of Jiankang, was named Jingyi. She bore a son, Huang Min, whom he sent back to her family. Huang Min, styled Xuanwen, at seventeen entered official service, rising to the rank of Vice Minister of Agriculture. In the third year of Yuanxing, to escape the chaos in the capital region, he carried his father’s legacy of scriptures into the mountains of Ke.

**Eulogy:**
Receiving the scriptures from the Purple Tenuity,
he pursued the flight of the Two Modes.

Why linger as in a treasury, long abiding in vain?
Yielding form to the empty altar, merging with the Great Beginning.
The legacy of scriptures not forgotten, preserved by a worthy son.

**Fifth-Generation Lineage Master:**
The Perfected Lord of Preserving the True of the Highest Clarity, surnamed Ma, personal name Lang, also called Wengong, styled Ziming, was a native of Dongguan in Kexian, eastern Zhe. His family had long been wealthy, walking in trust and practicing righteousness, revered by his village. Hearing of Yang and Xu of Mount Mao who had attained the Dao, and the widespread transmission of the Southern Perfected’s Highest Clarity scriptures and methods, he grew ever more devoted in admiration, for his dwelling lay near the Golden Court and Heavenly Terrace, a mere handspan from the immortal realms.

In the third year of Yuanxing, when Vice Minister Huang Min of Agriculture carried the scriptures to escape the chaos, Lord Ma personally welcomed him at the roadside, inviting him to stay in his home, where he honored and supported him with reverence. In the sixth year of Yuangjia, when Vice Minister Huang returned to Qiantang, he sealed a chest of his ancestral Perfected scriptures and left it in Lord Ma’s quiet chamber, saying, “These scriptures are all traces of the divine immortals. Only I may retrieve them. Even if there are written instructions, do not give them to anyone.” He took only a dozen or so scrolls with him. Upon reaching Qiantang, he fell ill and, fearing he might not recover, sent someone to fetch the scriptures. Lord Ma, having received the books, firmly upheld the original injunction, thinking, “How could I dare lightly hand them over, having personally received this teaching?” Thus, he did not return the scriptures, and Xu soon passed away.

Lord Ma and his younger brother Han revered the scriptural treasures even more than their own father. They always kept two servant boys—one named Whitehead, the other Flathead—to tend the incense and fire, sweep, and dust. Often, divine radiance and numinous qi manifested in their chambers. Lord Ma’s wife could also perceive them, saying, “There are often azure-clad maidens and jade women coming and going in the air, swift as flying birds.” Thereafter, the Ma family grew ever more prosperous, their wealth vast, and they enjoyed long lives across generations.

**Eulogy:**
Heaven does not begrudge the Dao,
Earth does not begrudge its treasures.
Yet those who transcribe carelessly
cannot preserve them.
Handed down by the Perfected of Wei,
jade pendants and golden tablets—
few know them,
those who see them flourish.

**Sixth-Generation Lineage Master:**
The Perfected Lord of Assisting the True of the Highest Clarity, personal name Han, styled Ziyan, was the younger cousin of Lord Preserving the True. Together with his elder brother, he revered and upheld the scriptural treasures. A layman named Lou Huiming, who had earlier resided in Ke, was deeply enamored of the scriptures and methods, but his karmic obstacles were severe, and he had no means to study them. In the first year of Jinghe, he went to the capital and, at the urging of the Perfected of Pure Brilliance, sought an audience with the Song sovereign to request the scriptures from the Ma family. By the time the scriptures reached the capital and were presented to Jinghe in the Hua Forest, they were briefly opened, and he urged that they be entrusted to the Daoist of the Rear Hall—Master Lu.
