At that time, the **Kāiqìng** eunuch **Dǒng Sòngchén** secretly conspired with the **Pútú** Daoist **Zhū Zhīcháng**, seizing seals and swords at **Chìsōng Guàn**.
The Master went to the capital and reported his crimes to the throne.

The **Way** flows as before,
the **Kāiqìng** eunuch seizes the seals and swords and returns to the mountain—
the assembly acclaims and invites him to ascend the platform,
a gesture of dismissal with a wave of the hand.
Winter and summer are but a single breath.

Often, after sitting in meditation, he would rise,
his sleeves forever brushing the flames of **Daoist fire**.

On the second day of the ninth month, **Caixiān** era, **Jǐngyī Master** departed,
and the great assembly pursued him in reverence,
restoring him as the **orthodox Patriarch**,
to rectify the **jiǎ-yǐ** succession’s oversight.

They praised him:
*"Where the **Dao** is passed down,
even Heaven does not defy it.
Who dares to scoff,
asking what man can do?
If it can be asked of,
then it is not the true **Dao**.
I instruct the true **adepts**,
to guard their **spirit** and preserve their **virtue**."*

The **42nd Generation Patriarch, Guānyī Zhēnmiào Master**,
surname **Zhái**, given name **Zhìyǐng**, courtesy name **Tóngshū**,
of **Dānyáng**.
At age thirteen,
he entered the **West Gate of Huáyáng Cave**,
where he encountered a **Daoist** sitting atop a stone,
pointing to a stone wall and inscribing a name, saying to him:
*"Your name stands among the honored teachers."*
He looked back at the stone wall,
but the man had vanished.

When he grew older,
he indeed succeeded the **Daoist Master’s** lineage.
His bearing was gentle and his virtue frugal,
yet he followed the **Dao** alone.
From **Yǒngjiā**, he welcomed **Yùhǎi** to escort the **Master** back to the mountain.

In the year **Yǐhài** of the **Northern Expedition**,
the following year, **Bǐngzǐ**, he ascended to **transcendence**.
The time was the twenty-fourth day of the sixth month,
**Yuán** era, the thirteenth year.

They praised him:

**Hua yang’s cave** boasts walls of dark jade.
A thousand years it opens once,
revealing names of immortals in line.

The immortals’ **Dao** is such—
transformation, not advancement.
Humans bear fire’s legacy,
while I return to the **True Extremity**.

The **43rd-generation Master of the Dao**:
**Master Zhenghe Xuanjing Zhenying**,
surname Xu, given name Daoji,
style name Zuyu, of Jùróng.
He was a descendant of **Master Shangzhi Xianhou**,
born in the **Song Ending Peace** era,
third year, **Bingshen** month, twenty-seventh day.

As a child, he served **Master Jiang Du**.
His teacher’s conduct was upright and resolute,
never lightly giving his word.

At the dawn of the **reign**,
after the wars had ceased,
a year of drought, famine, and plague struck,
worse in the Huai region than anywhere else.
At that time, the **Metropolitan Inspector’s office** was in **Weiyang**,
and officials gathered in the **Hall of Avoidance**,
begging the **Master** to come to **Tao**—
and when he did, the rains came,
the sickness abated.
Thus, they were granted **post stations and provisions**,
and escorted to the **court**.

The **Emperor Shizu**,
suffering from an arm ailment,
summoned him to the **Fragrant Hall of Dadu**,
commanding him to apply his **method**—
and he was cured.
Again, he was ordered to pray for snow and still the winds,
both requests met with **wondrous efficacy**.
The emperor bestowed a **jewel-encrusted crown** and **Daoist robes**,
and issued a **decree** to **greatly protect his teaching**.
With **insignia in hand**, he returned south,
and all **Sanmao Mountains** came under his governance.

In the **year twenty-eight of the Yuan era**,
on the third day of the second month,
he **subtly showed signs of illness**,
clasping his **insignia tightly**,
urgently calling **Wang Jun Daomeng**,
and passing on the **scriptures and methods** before departing,
his age **fifty-six**.

They praised him:
---
The **lineage of Shangzhi**’s **Master**,
the world receives as **worthy**.

The **era of Jingyun** began anew,
and the **Daoist lineage** was restored.

With **breaths of harmony and precision**,
he safeguarded the **sacred body** of the **Emperor**.

Guided by **celestial omens and constellations**,
he was led by **thunderous winds**.

The **forty-fourth generation Master**:
**Master Yangsu Tongzhen of the Bright Teaching** (真人),
surname **Wang**, given name **Daomeng**,
courtesy name **Muzhai**,
a native of **Jurong**.

His **appearance was dignified and robust**,
his **demeanor solemn and awe-inspiring**.

At **fourteen years old**,
he studied under **Daoist Master Yuanfu**—**Shen Zongshao**—
his **conduct grew ever loftier without pretense**,
his **reputation spread without seeking praise**.

Before **forty**, men regarded him as a **predecessor** in **virtue**.

When he **succeeded the Teaching in the capital**,
he received **imperial favor**,
just as **Master Xu** had before.

In the **year of the Great Virtue Stewed-Hai** (大德戊戌岁),
when famine struck, he **twice went to Weiyang**,
**dispelling locusts and praying for rain**,
with **miraculous results**.

He was **specially granted the title True Person** (真人),
and his **practices and merits** were recorded in the **inscription of the Huayang Daoist Academy**,
composed by **Jinshi Yuan Mingshan**.

In the **year of the Great Beginning Xinhai** (至大辛亥),
he **requested retirement** and **transferred the lineage**,
so the **Emperor commanded his inner-chamber disciple Liu Dabing**
to **inherit his teaching**,
at the age of **seventy-three**.
He **ascended in Huayang**,
born in fact in the **year of the Song-era Baoliao Renyin** (宝佑壬寅).

They praised him:
**"Master Yangsu** was **simple in cultivation**,
**sincere in attaining the Dao."**

The inner teachings harmonized with the Mysterious Unity,
while externally aiding the Peaceful Age.
Locusts and pests lay dormant in hiding,
and the harvests flourished in abundance.

In his youth, his subtle virtues were already renowned in the world.
At forty-five, he succeeded as the **Dongguan Master of Micro-Mysteries and Responsive Truth** (洞观微妙玄应真人), surnamed Liu, given name Dabing, with the sobriquet **Wang Xuzi**, a native of **Hao Commandery’s Qiantang**.

In the **year of the Royal Grace Renaming, the Fourth Year of Yanyou** (皇庆改元赐号延佑四年), he received the **jade seal of the Nine Elders of the Immortal Metropolis**, and the officials reported this to the throne. The **Emperor Ren宗** issued a special decree, returning it to the **Sacred Altar**, to perpetuate the Daoist lineage.

They praised him:
*"Mountains and peaks rise in majesty,
Lakes and seas stretch in boundless depth.
The Mysterious Omen is complete,
Rooting the lineage in Huayang.
Inheriting the radiance of the Purple Palace,
Expanding the teachings of the Vermilion Chamber.
The Nine Elders of the Metropolis,
Bestow upon you this sacred seal."*

**Teachings of the Upper Clarity Successor Master Liu Dabing**—
*Volume Twelve of the Teachings of Mount Mao* (now completed)
*Volume Thirteen of the Upper Clarity Lineage*—
*Recorded by the Successor Master Liu Dabing.*

The **Record of the Celestial Registrar’s Bureau**—
The **Three Palaces and Five Offices of the Metropolis of Upper Clarity (Huayang Dongtian)** are: the **Palace of Easy Relocation (Yiqian Gong)**, the **Palace of Embracing Truth (HanZhen Gong)**, and the **Palace of Serene Leisure (Xiaoxian Gong**; the **Office of the Grand Primordial (Taiyuan Fu)**, the **Office of Recorded Decrees (Dinglu Fu)**, the **Office of Preserved Life (Baoming Fu)**, the **Office of Pure Beginnings (Tongchu Fu)**, and the **Office of Ethereal Emptiness (Lingxu Fu)**.

Among these, the **Offices of the Grand Primordial, Recorded Decrees, and Preserved Life** are governed by the **Three Elders of the Teachings (San Mao Jun)**. The **Palaces of Easy Relocation and Embracing Truth** are inhabited by **female disciples who have attained the Dao**. The remaining palaces and offices are staffed by **male Daoists**. The **Office of Preserved Life** sometimes employs a **female palace**.

The **Celestial Elder of the Azure Boy Who Binds the Seas (Shu Hai Qing Tong Jun)** visits the realm twice yearly, inspecting these palaces and observatories. Among the Daoist officials, the **Three Elders of the Teachings (San Mao Jun)** and **Elder of the Four Pure Ones (Gu Si Chao Jun)**, a native of **Yan State**, stand foremost. Four brothers, dwelling in **Fuyong** during the **Qin Dynasty**, all attained the Dao. **Si Chao** was the eldest. His **Daoist virtue** was such that he governed the **Three Elders of the Teachings** for **six hundred years**, never failing in his duties or being **transferred beyond rank**#1.

When his term concluded, he was **replaced in the Nine Palaces by the Left Celestial Lord of the Immortal Metropolis (Zi Xian Gong)**, who led the **Jade Platform Bureau**. It was said that the **Lingzhong (郎中)** had long been vacant, and later **Si Chao** was replaced by the **Junior Elder of the Teachings (Mao Xiao Jun)**.

The **Offices of Recorded Decrees** have **Left and Right Celestial Registrars (Zi You Li Zhong Jian)**, whose ranks correspond to those of **Worldly Longshis (Shichang Shi)** and **Celestial Masters (Sima)**. There is also the **Water Officer of the Northern River (Bei He Si Ming)**, who oversees aquatic affairs. These two offices **traditionally hold the rank of the Nine Palaces’ Celestial Guardians (Jin Bao Hou)**, and their duties are to **supervise those who should be nurtured as kindred souls**. Below the **Celestial Palaces**, these three ranks are the most exalted.

The **Left Celestial Registrar (Zi Li Zhong Jian)** corresponds to the **Longshi of the Grand Office (Da Fu Chang Shi)**. Formerly, **Han Chong** held this post, whose given name was **Buzhi Changwei**, a native of **Piling in Gaoyou**. In his youth, he took delight in the Dao. The **Forest Dwelling Immortal (Linwu Xianren)** **Wang Zhang** once **bestowed upon him the method of the Flowing Pearl Elixir (Liu Zhu Dan)**, which he reverently practiced, with great efficacy. **Zhang** spoke to him: *"If you follow this Dao, you may also attain secular office, without hindrance to your **Daoist election**#3."* Chong thus **accumulated merit and rose to the rank of Prefect of Ruanling**, later **transferred to the Governor of Runan**, with a salary of **two thousand bushels**. For **fourteen years**#4 in his office, his **administrative virtue** was profound and renowned, making him the **best under heaven**. At age **seventy-four**, **Zhang** then **bestowed upon him the method of the Hidden Resolution (Yin Jie Fa)**, enabling him to depart and enter **Mount Huo**. He further received **Zhang’s method of the Elusive Transformation (Dun Hua) Mud Pill (Ni Wan) and Purple House (Zi Hu) technique**, thus **crossing the mortal world and dwelling in the Metropolis**. (*His biography appears in the **Han Records***.)

The **Right Celestial Registrar (You Li Zhong Jian)** holds duties equivalent to those of a **Celestial Master (Sima)**.

「There was Liu Lan, whose courtesy name was **Zixiang** (later recorded in the *Han Records* as **Zixiang**#1). Lan was originally from **Yingchuan**, but in his youth he took delight in **Dao/Way and virtue**, often providing assistance without expecting gratitude, and saving the destitute—he was not a solitary figure in this. He was recommended for the **Upper Calculations** (Shang Ji) office and appointed as **Lan Zhong**, later transferred to **Governor of Chenliu**.

When he met **Master Ma Huang**, the latter told Lan: *"Your benevolence moves Heaven and Earth, and your hidden virtue is revered by gods and spirits. The **Most High** will surely commend your sincere devotion.* He has sent me to bestow upon you the **method of Longevity**. Lan knelt and struck his head in supplication, earnestly requesting to serve as an attendant. He then entered the **Tongwu Mountains** and was taught the **Eight Hidden Arts of the Earth** and the **Method of the Five Stars’ Splendor**, thus attaining the **degree of Eastern Hua**. He was then granted an office within the **Metropolis** (Dongzhong).#

The **North River Celestial Registrar (Bei He Sì Mìng)** had no incumbent, and in the past, **Yao Jun** was temporarily entrusted with the position. Jun was from **Qiantang**, having studied at the **Imperial Academy** (Taixue) and mastered the **Classics of Wei**. When calamities and omens occurred, he held the office of **Governor of Jiao**, but at the end of the **Han Dynasty**, he abandoned worldly affairs and entered **Zengcheng Mountain** to study the **Dao/Way**. He encountered **Shu Guo Youping**, a man from the **Qin era** who had long concealed himself in **Zengcheng Mountain**, a **Daoist adept** who taught Jun the **Nine Refining Qi Methods** and the **technique of aligning the stars within the heart**. After perfecting these methods, Jun came to the **Metropolis** and took charge of the **North River Celestial Registrar’s duties**, overseeing the **appraisal and punishment of water officials**. Though this position is officially registered in the **Fixed Records** (Ding Lu), in reality, it falls under the **command of the Bureau of the Purple Master (Zi Hua Guan)** in the **Celestial Metropolis** (Dongzhong). Yao Jun’s courtesy name was **Fang Zhong**.#

The *Records of the Hidden Residence* state: *"There is a tomb in Qiantang, near the **Linping** mound and altar, where the descendants of the **Miao** clan still linger in the vicinity. At times, the sound of drums and horns is heard, and outsiders dare not disturb it. It is commonly called the **Tomb of Registrar Yao**."*

Zhang Ji’s son, **Zhang Feng**, originally named **Ji Zi**, whose courtesy name was **Gongxian**, was from **Henan**. In his youth, he was called **Ji Zi**. He abandoned worldly affairs and entered **Ke Mountain**, where he met **Master Shantou**, who taught him the **Lian Yu Method**. After practicing it, he attained **Dao**. He then advanced to the **Purple Master’s Bureau**, where he was to serve as the **Celestial Marshal of the Supreme Pole (Tai Ji Xian Hou)**.»#

---
#1: *Note: The original text appears to have a typographical error ("作字子相" likely means "recorded as Zixiang" rather than "Zixiang" again).*
#2: *The term "Metropolis" (洞中) here refers to the Daoist Celestial Metropolis (Dongzhong), a realm of immortals.*
#3: *The term "Upper Calculations" (上计) refers to a Han-era office for assessing local officials' performance.*
#4: *The term "North River Celestial Registrar" (北河司命) is a Daoist office overseeing water-related affairs.*
#5: *The term "Nine Refining Qi Methods" (九炼精气) refers to a Daoist practice of refining vital essence (jing) and qi.*
#6: *The "Bureau of the Purple Master" (紫华官) is a Daoist administrative division, and "Celestial Marshal of the Supreme Pole" (太极仙侯) is a high-ranking immortal official.*

At times, he also held the office of **Nine Palaces Chancellor**, mirroring the **North River Marquis** in overseeing water governance. The *Record of the North River Celestial Registrar* states that he was also known as **Forbidden Preservation Marquis**, sharing the same duties by tradition. His governance was conducted within the **Celestial Metropolis**.

The **Record-Keeper’s Bureau** had its **Law Enforcer** **Chunyu Zhen**, styled **Shuxian**, who oversaw examinations of those who had attained the Dao. Zhen hailed from Shangyu in **Willow Grove**, having served as a county magistrate in **Xu Province** during Emperor Huan of Han. In his youth, he cultivated the Dao, mastered numerology and divination, and consumed **hempseed and rehmannia qi** elixirs. Later, he retreated into the **Hao Wu Target Mountain**, where he encountered the immortal **Huichezi**, who transmitted the *Rainbow Landscape Elixir Canon*. Through practice, he attained the Dao and took up his duties within the Metropolis.

The **Preservation of Life Bureau** had its **Bright Dawn Attendants**, with the **Office of Divine Mandate** overseeing the **Three Officials**—its staff numbered seven: four women and three men. The seven **Bright Dawn Attendants** held roles akin to modern **Censors-in-Chief**, all subordinate to the **Purple Master’s Domain**, with the **Preservation of Life Lord** overseeing them collectively.

**Zhou Yuanzhi** was the daughter of **Zhou Chang** (styled **Bochi**), the **River South Administrator** of Han. Chang, from **Ancheng in Ru South**, practiced hidden virtue, his deeds unnoticed yet profound. During the second year of **Yongchu**, a severe drought struck, and he collected and buried over ten thousand corpses of travelers who had died near Luoyang, erecting a righteous tomb and conducting funeral rites. The rains returned, and the harvests flourished—his deeds were many such. His hidden virtue reached the **Highest Sovereign**, who commanded Yuanzhi to receive transformation in the **Southern Palace** and ascend to the Metropolis. In her youth, Yuanzhi also cultivated the Dao, consuming **reed rhizome** for thirty years before encountering **Stone Longevity**, who taught her the **Method of Transformation and Evasion**—a form of **upper body ascension**. The *Hidden Residences* notes that Chang was Zhou Jia’s younger cousin, serving as **River South Administrator** during Emperor Chao’s reign and later as **Grand Officer of Light**. **Zhang Taozhi** was the mother of **Zhu Yu**, the **Secretary of the Capital Region** in Han. Zhu’s mother practiced hidden virtue, and though long rumored to have ascended, she was later appointed as an attendant. The *Hidden Residences* states that Zhu, from **Pei**, was among the **Eight Virtuous Ones** of the **Huan-Ling era**.

**Xia Fu**, styled **Zizhi**, of **Chenliu**, in his youth cultivated the Dao, consuming **wood-based elixirs** and mixing **mica**. Later, he entered **Hao Mountain**, where he studied the **Soul-Refining Method** under **Red-Bearded Master**, and later received the **Yellow Water Cloud Nectar Method** from **Tongxiang True Person**, attaining the Dao and ascending to the Metropolis. In his youth, Fu was summoned by a government office but departed by inscribing his resignation on a wall and hanging it from a mulberry tree—his lofty ambition thus displayed. The *Hidden Residences* and *Records of Later Han and High Virtue* state that Fu was a **Yù official** of **Chenliu**, recommended for his **upright speech** during Emperor Huan’s reign but declining the post. The *True Revelations* states that such attendants were selected based on **equanimity, rectitude, hidden virtue, and clarity of spirit**, without gender restriction. The remaining individuals cannot be enumerated here.

The **Preservation of Life Bureau** also had its **Forbidden Prohibitions Overseer**.

Zhang Xuanbin, a native of Dingyi in Shanyang. During the reign of Emperor Wu of Wei, he was recommended as a **Teacher of Virtue** (茂才). Returning to his hometown, he became a disciple of Ji Gong of Xīhé, learning to take **wooden decoctions** (服木饵) and practicing the **Dao of the Primordial Void** (洞房元白) within the **Cavern of the Mysterious** (元白之事).

Later, he encountered the **True Person** Fan Ziming at Shàoshì Mountain and was taught the **Dao of Evasion and Transformation** (遁变隐景之道). Once he resided at Tiānzhù Mountain, then moved to Huáyáng’s inner chambers, becoming the **Overseer of Forbidden Prohibitions** (理禁伯).

The **Overseer of Forbidden Prohibitions** was the official in charge of **meteorological rites** (主雨水官), also serving as the **Supervisor of the Preservation of Life Bureau** (保命之监国). Xuanbin excelled in discussing **emptiness and non-existence** (空无), being a **Daoist adept** (谈士), often expounding:

*"Non-existence* (无) *is the dwelling of the Great Existence* (大有), *and the lesser existence* (小有) *is where it arises. By accumulating lesser existence to nourish lesser non-existence* (积小有以养小无), *one perceives the Great Existence as the root of the Great Non-existence* (见大有以本大无). *Existence is also non-existence, and non-existence is also existence* (有有亦无焉，无无亦有焉). *Thus, my eyes see nothing, yet nothing hides from me. Non-existence depends on existence to achieve non-existence* (无寄有以成无), *and depends on non-existence to attain non-existence* (寄无以得无). *In this way, non-existence has no dwelling* (於是无则无宅也), *yet the Absolute Void also dwells in non-existence* (太空亦宅无矣).

*Before my birth, the world knew no non-existence* (我未生时，天下皆无无也). *I once visited* **Left Lord of Penglai**, **Song Chengsheng** (蓬莱左公宋晨生), *and discussed non-existence with him. His understanding surpassed others, and even the* **True Persons of Tongwu** (桐梧诸真) *could not refute him. Beyond this, I have yet to grasp the root of existence* (过此以去，尚未能本有)， *how could I grasp non-existence?* (安能本无耶) *Such was his lofty* **qi** (高气) *and profound Daoist principles* (秉理如此).

The **Deputy of the Preservation of Life Bureau** (保命府丞).

Zhào Wēibó, a native of Shù Commandery, in his youth studied under Master Zhāng of Nàzōu. He carried the luminosity of the sun and moon and wore the radiant petals of the Nine Spirits’ Mirror. Later, at Zhōngyuè, he received the *Yùpèi Jīndāng Jīng* from Fàn Qiūlín. Qiūlín was the wife of Wèi Xíngdào, the Han *Lóuchuán* General. The *Hétú* states: *"Hàochǔ has many who have glimpsed the Great Peace."* He often told others: *"These words are not false—this proof will soon manifest."* The luminous mirror he preserved was not of the ordinary world’s craft. After attaining the Dao, he dwelled within Huáyáng, serving as Deputy of the Preservation of Life.

The Preservation of Life Bureau has four deputies: Zhào oversees the *xiānjiè* (仙籍, celestial registers) and violent storms, commanding the Five Sacred Herbs of gold and jade. Those seeking torrential rains may present petitions to him.

One deputy is Lè Chángzhì of Xiányáng, a native of Dōngqīng, where the Lord of *Sìmìng* resides. He was recommended by the *Máoxiǎo* Lady and appointed as Imperial Secretary during Emperor Huán’s reign. Later, he studied the *Bùqī Yuānfǎ* from Master Lǐ of Zhōngyuè and ascended as an immortal. Chángzhì oversees calamities.

Another deputy is Zhèng Zhìzhèng, a disciple of the Inner Chamber of Master Méng. Méng recommended him, and he oversees examinations and registries.

The fourth deputy is Master Táng of Xīshān, a native of Fáng Shǔ. He served Lǐ Bābó. Táng oversees life and death.

The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: Huáng Yuánpíng, of Dōnghǎi, was about thirty years old, dressed in white linen robes. Yuánpíng carried a black tablet, which he presented to Deputy Zhào of the Preservation of Life, though he held no official rank. Lǐ Zhěng of Héjiǔ once received the *Shǒuyī Fǎ*, practiced in a cavernous chamber, and attained the Dao. Initially at Yángluò Shān, he later entered Huáyáng, where he also oversaw examinations and rituals for the people. Zhěng had once served as a tutor for the Lord of Chángdào, receiving the Dao and entering the mountains at age sixty. The *Yǐnjū* states: *"Zhěng resided at Sìpíng Shān and Dàmáo’s eastern peak, where he gathered victory stones, consuming them to attain the Dao. The gathering site remains."*

Zhōu Zǐliáng, styled Yuánsù, with the inner taboo *Tàixuān* and the style *Xūlíng*, was a native of Yǒngjiā. As a hidden recluse, he was a disciple of Gāojì. On the twenty-seventh day of the tenth month in the fourteenth year of Liáng Tiānjiàn (515 CE), he underwent *báirì shījiě* (白日尸解, daytime dissolution of the corpse) at age twenty. The recluse compiled his daily records of true transformations, categorizing them into four volumes, which he presented to Emperor Wǔ of the Liang—this became the *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì*. The text records two officials appointed as deputies of the Preservation Bureau, a position newly established to assist in managing celestial registers. Though their duties were minor, their virtue and purity were esteemed. Later, they would ascend to *Bǎochén Sī* (保晨司), overseeing the Daoist practices of immortals across the world and the methods of instruction.

The ghostly marshals of the Preservation of Life Bureau—Wáng Yán, Fù Huǎng, Fàn Qiáng, and Xú Wèi—were originally Daoist *sàijiào* (祭酒, ritual toasts). Having mastered the *xiàjiě fǎ* (下解法, method of descending dissolution), they were appointed as ghostly marshals.

**Huáyáng’s Celestial Child of Jade**—The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: In the heavens of Huáyáng, the Marshal of Dawn, Jade Child, surnames Jǐng, named Shàngqī.

**The Recluse of Xiāoxián Palace**—The *Zhōu Shì Xuántōng Jì* records: The Daoist official Zhāng Zǐ’ān of Xiāoxián, wearing a *fúróng guān* (芙蓉冠, hibiscus crown) and crimson embroidered robes, with three attendants. Zǐ’ān’s given name was Xiào, a native of Jiàjǐng in Róngyáng.

**Initial Marshal of the Bureau, Liú Wénráo**—Liú Kuān of Hóngnóng.

At seventy-three, one day he encountered Master Qīnggǔ in his chamber, who taught him the *zhàngjiě fǎ* (杖解法, staff dissolution method) and, as he prepared to depart for Huàshān, instructed him in the *jiǔxī fúqì* (九息服气, nine-breaths qi cultivation). He was also given the elixir furnace-fire formula. Having perfected his Dao, he later returned to the grotto, where he oversaw those who first sought the Way.

Kuān served the Han, rising to the rank of *Sītú Tàiyuè* (司徒太尉, Grand Tutor and Grand Marshal). He delighted in practicing *yīndé* (阴德, hidden virtue), rescuing the cold and destitute, and the common people rejoiced and clung to him as to parents. His biography appears in the *Hànshū*.

**Superintendent of the Bureau, Fàn Yòuchōng**—A native of Liáoxī.

He received the *Tàisù tāihuà yìxíng* (太素胎化易形, Supreme Primordial Embryonic Transformation and Metamorphosis) Dao. Daily, he would preserve the three *qì*—green, white, and red—each as a boat, drawing them from the *shùfāng* (束方, bound direction) as the sun descended, guiding them straight into his mouth. He would then embrace them ninety times before stopping once sated. Practicing this for ten years, he attained the Dao.

His method was concise, and its efficacy was proven—a secret transmission of the Supreme Primordial Dao. The "Superintendent Fàn" refers to this man, who once served as Superintendent of the Bureau and now resides in Huáyáng.

**Daoists of the Bureau:**
The Bureau of Jǔngchū includes Wáng Shàodào, Fàn Shūshèng, and Lǐ Bóshān—all its foremost figures.

**Wáng Shàodào**—A man of the Han era, surnamed Wáng, originally named Zhú’ér (逐儿). **Yùn**—a Han-era governor of Shānyáng.

**Fàn Shūshèng**—A native of Běidì, who served as *Huángmén Làng* (黄门郎, Imperial Attendant) under Wèi Wéndì.

**Lǐ Bóshān**—Father of Lǐ Chōng, who, in the Han, held the office of *Báimǎ Lìng* (白马令, White Horse Prefect). Chōng practiced *yīndé*, and it is said that either through accumulated merit over generations or innate virtue, his benevolence was profound. These Daoists all advanced step by step, gaining entry to this Bureau—not necessarily having come directly here.

**Grand Justiciar of the Three Officials:**
Fàn Shuài said: The Three Officials have a judicial officer, not called *Tíngwèi* (廷尉, Censorate), but *Dàlǐ* (大理, Grand Justiciar). Lǐ Fēng now serves as the *Shǒuhuò* (守缺, acting) Grand Justiciar of Dūyú, having been compared to Wáng Fùzǐ (王附子) but not to Xǔ Hǔ (许虎).

*The Hidden Residence* records: Lǐ Fēng, courtesy name Ānguó (安国), later changed to Xuānguó (宣国), was from Féngyàn. Lǐ Yì’s adopted son, originally of humble birth, possessed talent and ambition, and thus entered service under Wèi as *Shàngshū Fúshè* (尚书仆射, Minister of War).

The Grand Justiciar is the ancient judicial officer; during the Former Han and Wèi, the *Tíngwèi* was also called *Dàlǐ*. This is a Daoist office. Wáng Fùzǐ was the childhood name of Wáng Huò, and Xǔ Hǔ refers to *Hǔyá* (虎牙, Tiger Claw).

**Earthly Overseer:**
Bào Shuō, courtesy name Tàixuān (太玄), a native of Chénliú.

He served the Jìn, repeatedly summoned to the post of *Huángmén Shìlàng* (黄门侍郎, Imperial Attendant), later appointed Governor of Nánhǎi. Proficient in the mysteries of the grotto and well-versed in the *jīngwéi* (经纬, classics and divination), none could fathom his depth.

Bào Shuō’s master, **Zǔ Yuànfàng**, transmitted to him the *Zhōngbù Fǎ* (中部法, Central Sect Teachings) and the *Sān Huáng Nèi Wén* (三皇内文, Inner Scriptures of the Three Sovereigns), enabling him to command and subdue spirits and demons, and to seal mountains and pacify malevolent forces. Later, upon **Jiǎngshān**, he encountered the True Person **Yīn Chángshēng**, who instructed him in the *Dāojiě* (刀解, Blade-Severance) technique for protection.

According to the *Zhēnxù* (《真诰》), both Bào Shuō and his sister were descendants of a seventh-generation ancestor who had accumulated profound *yīndé* (阴德, hidden virtue), thus granting their lineage enduring blessings—hence their roles as **Earthly Overseers**. Within the grotto palaces, Bào Shuō’s studies were initially shallow and his nature unrefined, so he did not attain greater mastery.

The *Yǐnjū* (《隐居》) states: Bào Shuō employed the *Tàiqīng Shījiě* (泰清尸解, Embalmed Dissolution of the Mortal Frame) technique, suggesting that his rank among the Overseers was not the highest.

Bào Shuō’s daughter, **Bào Gū**, became the wife of **Gě Hóng**, the *Sànqí Chángshì* (散骑常侍, Standing Attendant of the Scattered Cavalry). Both Bào Gū and **Zhìchuān** (稚川) ascended to immortality in succession. There is also a separate account of **Bào Gū’s** use of *ài* (艾, mugwort) and *zhú* (灼, cauterization) to subdue a dragon maiden.

---
*Teammountain Records, Volume 13* concludes here.

*Teammountain Records, Volume 14* begins with the **Shàngqīng Sìzōng Shī** (上清嗣宗师, Successor Master of the High Clarity Dao) **Liù Dàbīn**.

**Records of the Celestial Bureaucracy**

**Yì Qiān’s Immortal of the Transferred Palace**
The *Yìqiān Guǎn* (易迁馆) and the *Hántián Tái* (含真台) are both official titles. Within the *Yìqiān Zhōngdū* (易迁中都), there were eighty-three immortals.

There was also **Xié Chén Fūrén** (协辰夫人), the true maiden of the Nine Palaces. The *Tàishàng* (太上) once dispatched her to instruct this group in Dao, granting them the *Bǎomìng* (保命, Longevity Prescriptions) and scriptures. **Xié Chén Fūrén** oversaw their teachings.

The lady was **Huáng Jǐnghuá** (黄景华), daughter of the Han *Sīkōng* (司空, Grand Tutor) **Huáng Jūn**. She studied under **Hán Zhōng**, who taught her the *Mínshān Dān* (岷山丹, Mineral Elixir of Mount Mín). Upon ingesting it, she attained immortality.

**Zhào Sùtái** (赵素台), the *Tái* (台, Pavilion), had resided in *Yìqiān Zhōngdū* for four hundred years and refused to depart, claiming no place on Earth surpassed its joy. She was the daughter of **Zhào Xī** (赵熙).

During the Han, **Zhào Xī** served as *Yōuzhōu Cìshǐ* (幽州刺史, Prefect of Yōuzhōu) and performed deeds of mercy for the destitute. He rescued **Wáng Huì** (王惠) and others from execution in the **Hézhōng** (河中) region, accumulating over ten acts of hidden virtue. Thus, his spirit was summoned to **Zhūlíng** (朱陵), while his sons dwelled in the *Dòngtiān* (洞天, Cavernous Heavens).

**Zhào Xī** frequently entered the *Dìnglù Fǔ* (定录府, Bureau of Recorded Destiny), while **Sùtái** often wandered the Daoist paths in plain attire, content with the mountains and marshes.

The *Xuántōng Jì* (《玄通记》) states: Among the *Yìqiān* were the Daoist consorts, including **Zhào Fūrén** (赵夫人), styled **Sùtái**, aged over thirty, clad in emerald brocade.

Within *Yìqiān Zhōngdū*, there were those of high attainment yet humble demeanor: **Bǎo Qióngyīng** (宝琼英), **Hán Tàihuá** (韩太华), **Liú Chūnlóng** (刘春龙), **Wáng Jìnxián** (王进贤), **Lǐ Xīzǐ** (李奚子), and **Guō Shūxiāng** (郭叔香). These six possessed innate brilliance, serene and distant in bearing, surpassing in talent and eloquence, their presence striking all who beheld them—truly the elite among the Celestial Overseers and prodigies of the Dao. Below them stood figures like **Zhāng Jiāngzǐ** (张姜子) and his ilk.

**Dòu Qióngyīng** (窦琼英) was the sister of **Dòu Wǔ** (窦武). Her seventh-generation ancestor, **Dòu Zhì** (窦峙), practiced the art of reviving the dead through the preservation of skeletal remains, and thus his lineage’s virtue extended to **Qióngyīng**.

**Hán Tàihuá** was the daughter of **Hán Ānguó** (韩安国) and the wife of **Lǐ Guǎnglì** (李广利), the Han *Èrshī Jiāngjūn* (二师将军, General of the Two Armies). **Lǐ Guǎnglì** had accumulated merit in past lives and now resides in the *Nángōng* (南宫, Southern Celestial Bureau) receiving transformation.

**Liú Chūnlóng** was the daughter of **Liú Fèngxiān** (刘奉先), the Han *Zōngzhèng* (宗正, Minister of Ceremonial Rites).

**Lǐ Xīzǐ** was the grandmother of **Lǐ Zhōng** (李忠). **Lǐ Zhōng**, the Eastern Píng *Tàishǒu* (东平太守) of the early Jin, was once a humble *Tiánshèrén* (田舍人, rural commoner). Yet he harbored profound hidden virtue—during a severe winter, he refused to cover his stored grain, even exposing it in his courtyard for fear that sparrows might starve. Such was his compassion.

**Wáng Jìnxián** was the daughter of **Wáng Yǎn** (王衍).

「Guō Shūxiāng was the mother of **Yì Qiān** (王修).

Furthermore, **Yì Qiān**’s maid, known as **Liùchū** (六出), bore the surname **Tián** (田), hailed from **Yúyáng** (渔阳), and was the granddaughter of **Tián Fěng** (田讽), the Prefect of **Jùnyí** (浚仪). At around twenty-two or three, she possessed a graceful appearance and a noble character, demonstrating great virtue—she was also destined to attain transformation alongside **Yì Qiān**.

**Yì Qiān**’s left consort, **Wáng Fūren** (王夫人), adopted the courtesy name **Tàiyīng** (太英), was about twenty years old, and clad in crimson attire.

**Yì Qiān**’s right consort, **Liú Fūren** (刘夫人), with the courtesy name **Xuánwēi** (玄微), was also around twenty, dressed in emerald-green robes.

**Yì Qiān**’s *Dūshǐ* (都司学) **Táo Fūren** (陶夫人), renamed herself **Zhì’ān** (智安), was approximately forty years old, wearing garments of green above and purple below.

**Xǔyuán**’s mother, originally named **Kēdòu** (科斗), underwent a change of name—perhaps this refers to her transformation.

**Yì Qiān** studied under **Lǐ Fēihuá** (李飞华), a native of **Huáiyín** (淮阴), who had resided in **Yì Qiān**’s abode for ninety-four years. At around twenty years of age, he was skilled in the **Qīngyī** (青衣) Dao/Way.

In **Yì Qiān**’s abode, there were also **Liǔ Miàojī**’s grandson **Fāng Huá** (芳华) and **Ruǎn Huìxiāng** (阮惠香). These three individuals had cultivated profound Daoist/Wayist attainments and were granted passage into the **Bāzhōu Jūtái** (八洲朱台) of the eighth rank, where they received scriptures and became *Xiānfēi* (仙妃, Celestial Consorts).

**Zhāng Jiāngzǐ** (张姜子) was from **Xīzhōu** (西州), the younger sister of **Zhāng Jì** (张济).

**Lǐ Huìgū** (李惠姑) was from **Qí** (齐), the wife of **Xiàhòu Xuán** (夏侯玄).

**Shī Shūnǚ** (施淑女) was from **Shānyáng** (山阳), the daughter of **Shī Jì** (施绩).

**Zhèng Tiānshēng** (郑天生) was the mother of **Dèng Zhī** (邓芝).

These several women, in their past lives, had practiced benevolent conduct of great renown. They were all granted residence in the *Dòng* (洞, Caverns).

**Hánzhēntái’s** *Xiānrén* (仙人, Immortal)

The **Hánzhēntái** (含真台), where these women who have attained the Dao/Way reside, is under the jurisdiction of the **Tàiyuán Shùgōng** (太元束宫, Celestial Bureau of Grand Unity), housing nearly two hundred individuals.

**Dìnglùjūn** (定录君) remarked: The **Hánzhēntái** (含真台) exists within all *Dòngtiān* (洞天, Caverns of Heaven), not exclusively here. This particular **Hánzhēntái** (含真台) is uniquely affiliated with the **Tàiyuán Fǔ** (太元府, Grand Unity Bureau), and falls under the administration of the *Sīmìng* (司命, Bureau of Fate).

Within it, two **Nǚzhēn** (女真, True Women) oversee the affairs: One is **Zhāng Wēizǐ** (张微子), the daughter of **Zhāng Qìng** (张庆), the Han *Zhāngdì* (昭帝, Emperor)’s *Jiāngzuò Dàjiàng* (将作大匠, Grand Master of Construction). **Zhāng Wēizǐ** (张微子) was devoted to the Dao/Way, attaining the *Shījiěfǎ* (尸解法, Method of Corporeal Dissolution), and habitually ingested *Wùqì* (雾气, Mist Qi), receiving her teachings from **Shùhǎi Shùhuá Yùfēi Chúnwénqī** (束海束华玉妃淳文期), the younger sister of **Qīngtóng** (青童, Azure Boy).

The *Wùqì* (雾气) refers to the refined essences of mountains, marshes, rivers, lakes, and the five elements—metal and stone *Yíngqì* (盈气, Qi of Abundance). By consuming it, one can disperse one’s corporeal form into the void and merge with clouds and mist.

The other is **Chuányǐ Hé** (传礼和), the daughter of **Fù Jiàn** (傅建), the *Shìzhōng* (侍中, Attendant-in-Ordinary) and distant cousin of the Han *Huándì* (桓帝, Emperor). Her family ardently practiced the **Fó** (佛, Buddha) and made diligent progress. She would often sweep and clean before the **Fó** (佛) at dawn and dusk, fervently vowing and praying, her heart’s desire being to transform into a celestial being. The divine spirits recognized her sincerity, and she was thus granted passage to this place. After spending a long time in **Yì Qiān**’s abode, she eventually became the overseer of **Hánzhēntái** (含真台). She habitually consumed the *qì* (气) of the Five Stars to attain the Dao/Way, and **Hé** (和) was skilled in song, such that birds and beasts would fly and gather to listen to her voice.

**Máoshān’s** *Xiānrén* (仙人, Immortals)

**Zhǎnshànggōng** (展上公), a figure from the time of **Gāoxīn** (高辛, Emperor Gao Xin).」

「The *Dìnglù* (定录) recorded the words of **Zhǎnshànggōng** (展上公): **Zhǎnshànggōng** (展先生) once studied the Dao/Way under **Fùlóng** (伏龙, Master Fu Long), where the mountain was planted with peach trees, filling every corner of his dwelling.

**Zhǎnshànggōng** (展先生) now serves as the **Yòubǎoshī** (右保司, Right Protector) of the Nine Palaces. He once said to the other Immortals: *"Long ago, in Huáyáng (华阳), I ate white peaches, whose flavor was extraordinary. I barely remembered the taste when suddenly—three thousand years had passed!"*

**Jiāngshūmǎo** (姜叔茂), the **Bālíng** (巴陵) Marquis of **Qín** (秦), attained the Dao/Way at **Jùqū Shān** (句曲山). He cultivated the Five Fruits and Five Pungent Herbs, selling them in exchange for cinnabar.

Shūmǎo (叔茂) once wrote to the officials of **Tàijí** (太极, the Supreme Ultimate): *"I once studied the Dao/Way in Guǐgǔ (鬼谷), attained it on Shàoshì (少室), nourished my wings in Huáyáng (华阳), and awaited my ascent in Yìyù (逸域). At that time, I rode in a gusting carriage and feasted at Jùqū (句曲)."* Reflecting on these words, he sighed deeply, lamenting the swift passage of time, the survival of things while people perish, and his own futile labor.

**Zhōu Tàibīn** (周太宾), endowed with talent and skill, excelled in playing the *qín* (琴, zither). Once, he taught **Mí Chángshēng** (麋长生) and **Sūn Guǎngdiàn** (孙广田, i.e., **Sūn Dēng** 孙登) the art of longevity. With a single string, he could play all eight tones—a truly remarkable feat.

**Dù Qì** (杜契), courtesy name **Guǎngpíng** (广平), was from **Dùlíng** (杜陵) in **Jīngzhào** (京兆). At the beginning of the **Jiàn’ān** (建安) era, he crossed the **Jiāng** (江, Yangtze River) and relied on **Sūn Cè** (孙策). Later, **Sūn Quán** (孙权) appointed him as the **Lìxìn Xiàowèi** (立信校尉). In the second year of **Huángwǔ** (黄武), he gradually began studying the Dao/Way. He encountered **Jièmiè** (介玫) Master, who taught him the **Xuánbái Wèi** (玄白卫, Mysterious White Protection) method, allowing him to eventually vanish his form.

He resided in **Zhōng Máo** (中茅), then departed and came to **Liángcháng Shān** (良常山). **Dù Qì** (杜契) and **Xú Zōngdù** (徐宗度), along with **Yàn Xiāngshēng** (晏贤生), were all in the **Máoshān** (茅山) region. At times, they could enter the **Dòng’ěr** (洞耳, Cave of Ears). Some would secretly gather and trade their clothing and food in the **Chóuqū** (墟曲) marketplace, yet no one would know of their presence.

**Xú Zōngdù** (徐宗度) was from **Jìnlíng** (晋陵), serving as **Sūn Huò** (孙皓)'s **Zuǒ Diǎnjūn** (左典军) and **Lǚ Dì** (吕悌)'s **Shìmǎ** (司马). He received the **Fēnggǔ** (风谷) Master's **Qì Jìn Wèi** (气禁卫, Qi-Protection) method.

**Yàn Xiāngshēng** (晏贤生) was the nephew of **Bùjīng** (步惊), the disciple of **Zōngdù** (宗度). The text *"Yǐnjū"* (隐居) states: *"Qì (契) sounds like 'Xuē' (薛), Qì (契) with four strokes is 'Guǎngpíng' (广平), and Qì (契) with three strokes is 'Zōngdù' (宗度). The distinction in strokes marks their difference in rank."* **Dù Qì** (杜契) had two disciples.

One was **Sūn Fèn** (孙贲)'s daughter, **Hánhuá** (寒华). **Sūn Fèn** (孙贲) was the younger brother of **Hàodà** (昊大) Emperor's **Quán** (权), serving as the **Yùzhāng Tàishǒu** (豫章太守). His father was posthumously named **Shānyīn Wáng** (山阴王), with the given name **Xí** (讳奚). **Hánhuá** (寒华) first entered **Jiàn’ān** (建安). Later, she came to **Máoshān** (茅山), practicing the **Xuánbái Fǎ** (玄白法, Mysterious White Method), and had a youthful appearance.

His other disciple was **Chén Shìjīng** (陈世京). **Shìjīng** (世京) was an official under **Sūn Xiū** (孙休) during his time as **Shìláng** (侍郎). Young, he took to the Dao/Way and frequently entered **Fó sì** (佛寺, Buddhist temples). Since he was from the same region as **Dù Qì** (杜契), he later received his teachings as well.

These disciples dwelled outside **Máoshān** (茅山), not as permanent residents within the caves. Yet, they too could sometimes enter the **Dòng’ěr** (洞耳).」

Zhèngyīng (左慈), courtesy name Yuànfàng (元放), during the **Jiàn’ān** (建安) era of the **Hàn** (汉), observed strict fasting and ascetic practices before ascending **Máoshān** (茅山). He entered the **Dòngxū** (洞虚) to craft an **yīnguān** (阴官, shadowy official), where the **Sānmáo Jūn** (三茅君) bestowed upon him divine **shénzhī** (神芝, sacred fungi). He then sought **Yùmén Dānshā** (玉门丹砂, cinnabar) from the **Sīmìng Jūn** (司命君), obtaining twelve *jīn* (斤).

The *Yǐnjū* (《隐居》) states: Yuànfàng was likely driven by **Wèiwǔ** (魏武) before returning, and the cinnabar he requested was used to forge the **Lúhuǒ Jiǔhuá Dān** (炉火九华丹, Nine-Petal Furnace Elixir).

The **Dìnglù Jūn** (定录君) spoke in silence: *"Zhèngyīng now resides at Xiǎokuò Shān (小括山), frequently appearing here. He often comes below, soon to be granted an official post."* His countenance remained youthful, a testament to the benefits of the **Lúhuǒ Jiǔhuá** (炉火九华).

It was also said that Zhèngyīng initially devoted five years to fervent worship of the **Língshān** (灵山, Sacred Mountain) before gaining deeper access to the **Dōngxī Gōng** (东西宫, Eastern and Western Palaces).

He was the master of **Lǐ Zhòngfǔ** (李仲甫) and the teacher of **Gě Xuán** (葛玄).

**Pú Xiānsheng** (蒲先生), whose name is lost, often rode a white deer to gather **zhīcǎo** (芝草, fungi) on **Máoshān**.

**Xǔ Xiānsheng** (许先生), named **Mài** (迈) and **Yīng** (瑛), with the courtesy name **Shū Xuán** (叔玄), hailed from **Dānyáng Jùróng** (丹阳句容). As a youth, he took to the Dao/Way, consulting **Guō Pú** (郭璞) on divination. The *Tài* (泰) hexagram’s sixth line revealed: *"You shall attain supreme fortune from Heaven; it is fitting to study the Dao."*

Initially, he followed **Bào Shuō** (鲍说) but hesitated to abandon his parents. He settled near **Xuánliù Shān** (悬溜山) in **Yánháng**, close to **Yánlíng’s** (延陵) **Máoshān**, which he regarded as the western gate of **Dòngtíng** (洞庭). Its channels connected to the **Wǔyuè** (五岳), a place once frequented by **Chén Ānshì** (陈安世) and **Máo Jìwěi** (茅季伟). He established a **jīngshè** (精舍, hall of refinement) at Xuánliù, traveling between the **Máolíng** (茅岭) caves, returning home only on the **suòwàng** (朔望, new and full moons) to pay respects.

After his parents’ passing, he sent his wife, **Sūn Shì** (孙氏), back to her family, renaming himself **Xuán** (玄) with the courtesy name **Yuǎnyóu** (远游).

In **Yǒnghé Èrnián** (永和二年), he settled at **Lín’ān Xīshān** (临安西山), associating with **Wáng Yòujūn** (王右军) and his son. Later, he moved to **Línhǎi Chìshān** (临海赤山), where he encountered **Wáng Shìlóng** (王世龙), **Zhào Dàoxuán** (赵道玄), and **Fù Tàichū** (傅太初). He then became **Shìlóng’s** disciple, receiving the **jiěshù fǎnxíng** (解束反行, Unbinding and Reversal Technique) and the method of ingesting **yùyè cháo nǎojīng** (玉液朝脑精, Elixir of Jade Dew and Morning Brain Essence), achieving transcendence through timely responses.

The **Sānguān Dūjìn** (三官都禁) dispatched **Zuǒ Láng** (左郎) **Zhōu Fǎng** (周纺), bearing the **Dānjiǎn** (丹简, Elixir Register) and **Zuìbù** (罪簿, Crime Ledger), alongside **Zhǔfēi Shǐzhě** (主非使者) **Yán Báihǔ** (严白虎). They demanded an accounting of **Yīng’s** (瑛) transgressions, threatening arrest if unanswered.

Terrified, **Xuānsheng** (先生) forcefully exhaled and retorted:
*"The Dao/Way knows no favoritism—only virtue is embraced.
Heaven and Earth hold no bias—they reward virtue alone.
Thus, even if **Jīquán** (圾泉) flows with blood, it cannot hinder the **Lóngrán** (龙髯, Dragon-Beard) ascension.
The **Sānmiao** (三苗) of **Dānyě** (丹野), **Zhúlù** (涿鹿), and **Jiàngcǎo** (绛草)—how could they obstruct the **Dàshèng** (大圣) from attaining supreme enlightenment and transcendent reach?

My seventh-generation ancestor, **Xǔ Zǐ’ē** (许子阿), amassed virtue and power, his deeds unseen yet profound.
In years of famine and plague, when people barely survived, **Zǐ’ē** distributed wealth to rescue them, personally concocting remedies—reviving **sìbǎi bāshí** (四百八十) near-death individuals.
His virtue descended upon us, granting three ascensions and five salvations of the world, with names recorded by the **Tàishàng** (太上). How could such glory be yours to anticipate?"

As he spoke, **Dìnglù Jūn** (定录君) sent **Zhōnghòu Lǐ Zūn** (中候李遵), who arrived clutching a **huǒlíng** (火铃, fire bell). **Zhōu Fǎng** and his companions laughed and fled. **Xuānsheng** was then enrolled in **Dōnghuá** (东华), becoming a **Dìxiān** (地仙) of the middle rank.

Later, he relocated to **Gàizhú Shān** (盖竹山), lamenting in a letter to his **Chángshì** (长史):
*"I regret encountering my master too late, delaying my nature’s refinement. The arduous path to transcendence is fraught with hardship."*

The **Dìnglù Zhēn Jūn** (定录真君) had already revealed this.

*"The debt of gratitude to the **Chónglài Chéngfù Jiùjì** (崇赖成覆救济) is beyond what Heaven and Earth can repay."*

**Rèn Zhēnrén** (任真人), named **Dūn** (敦) with the courtesy name **Shàngpǔ** (尚朴), hailed from **Lè’ān Bóchāng** (乐安博昌). As a youth, he studied the Dao/Way on **Luófú Shān** (罗浮山). During the early **Yǒngjiā** (永嘉) era of the **Jìn** (晋), he traveled to **Dàizōng** (岱宗, Mount Tai), later residing in **Huáyáng Nándòng** (华阳南洞). He mastered the **Bùdǒu Dào** (步斗道, Step-and-Fight Technique) and **Dòngxuān Wǔfú** (洞玄五符, Five Talismans of the Mysterious Void), capable of summoning ghosts and gods, hiding his form, and splitting his shape.

He consumed alcohol and **mùhuángjīng** (木黄精, yellow horny goat weed) elixirs. Digging seven *chǐ* (尺) into the earth, he extracted **chítán tǔ** (赤坛土, red furnace soil), resembling **chìshízhī** (赤石脂, red stone fat). He ingested nine pills daily, entering and exiting the earth.

Holding **jīngkē** (经科, scriptural formulas), he taught the unenlightened, drawing followers from afar.

In **Yǒngchāng Yīnián** (永昌元年), during the **Rénwǔ** (壬午) year, a snowfall of over *zhǎng* (丈) killed half the **wūshòu** (乌兽, dark beasts). He fed them in the mountains, and **hǔlù** (虎鹿, tigers and deer) numbering in the tens gathered to eat from his hands.

Each time he ventured out, a tiger with drooping ears and curled tail followed him.

One day, a man of towering stature—over *zhǎng* (丈) tall—clad in **wǔcǎi xuánhuáng yī** (五彩玄黄衣, five-colored dark-yellow robes) approached, bowing and asking:
*"Who are you, ghost or god? What brings you here?"*

The man identified himself as a messenger of **Hénà Lǎojūn** (和那老君), inquiring about his credentials. The **Zhēnrén** replied that his name had already been recorded in the **Dānjiǎn**.

The **Zhēnrén** had once served as the **Dòngtiān Jiǎnzhǔ** (洞天绾主, Master of the Cavernous Heaven), refining the **Dàdān** (大丹, Great Elixir). To his disciples, he declared:
*"I shall soon depart for **Kuòchāng** (括苍) and **Gàizhú** (盖竹) Mountains."*

His former residence became the **Chóngshòu Guàn** (崇寿观).

The *Yúnjì Qīqiān* (《云岌七签_) and *Chìchéng Zhì* (《赤城志_) both record his biography.

**Táoyuán Huáng Zūnshī** (桃源黄尊师), with lofty **fǎlù** (法录, spiritual records), constructed the **Tiānzūn Diàn** (天尊殿) on **Máoshān**, delivering sermons that drew thousands daily.

As the lecture platform was being assembled, a man burst in, his face dark, his speech vulgar, a **luóbiān** (骡鞭, donkey whip) at his waist—like a merchant’s attendant. He sneered:
*"Daoists! Gathering crowds while the world burns—what foolishness! You dare speak idly instead of secluding yourselves in the mountains to cultivate?"*

**Huáng Zūnshī** (黄尊师), unperturbed, descended from the platform without reply. The crowd, terrified, dared not protest.

After some time, the man’s demeanor softened:
*"Aren’t you building a hall? How much will it cost?"*
**Huáng** replied: *"Five thousand *guàn* (贯)."*
*"Bring every broken pot, pan, and scrap of iron—eight or nine *jīn* (斤) worth. Dig a furnace, melt them down, then stir in two pills from my gourd."*

He reached into his robes and poured out the elixirs.

After a short while, the fire had fully melted the silver. The man said:
*"This yields over ten thousand *guàn*—more than enough for the observatory’s construction. The lecture hall’s needs are modest; let it be abandoned."*

**Huáng** and his disciples bowed deeply in gratitude, asking what he desired. The man laughed and left through the gate, his destination unknown.

Ten years later, when **Huáng** was summoned to the capital, he suddenly encountered the man with the donkey whip on a street in Chang’an. The stranger carried a bundle over his shoulder, riding a donkey beside an elderly figure—no trace of his former Te Mountain aura remained. **Huáng** moved to kneel in reverence, but the man raised his hand and pointed at the donkey rider, who then bowed repeatedly. **Huáng** merely returned a distant obeisance from afar.

The old man’s hair was now entirely white, and his appearance resembled that of a fourteen- or fifteen-year-old girl. The account appears in the *Lost Histories*. The *Te Mountain Records* concludes here—originally incomplete, supplemented from the *Pí* edition.

**Admonitions on the Perfected Way**

**Hàochuò** was gathering the *Zhen* when, in the early years of the divine *Fèng* era, he came to Huáyáng Cave and saw a young boy playing with three large pearls beneath a pine. Chuò approached and asked whose son he was. The boy fled into the cave, and fearing he might be harmed by a tiger, Chuò followed, calling out for help. After no more than thirty paces, the boy transformed into a dragon, clutching the three pearls to fill its left ear. Bold by nature, Chuò struck the dragon’s ear with his alchemical axe, causing the pearls to fall and vanish, and the dragon itself to disappear. Before he had taken ten more steps, the cave entrance sealed shut. During the Song dynasty’s *Xuānhé* era, Chuò was ennobled as *Yǎngsù* Master. The account appears in *The Dragon City Records*.

**Xuè Biāozhī**, a native of Jìnlíng, from youth shunned worldly affairs and held no desire for rank or wealth. In the second year of the *Jiànwǔ* era of the Qi dynasty, he suspended his worldly duties to seek the hidden and mysterious. After three years, he returned and reported to the *Shùlǐng* Hall of the Great Te Mountain, where he practiced the Dao, subsisting on pine shoots and spring water, passing the years in seclusion. The hall was where the *Rèn Zhēnrén* of Jin had once attained perfection, and the tortoise-shell tablet remained, its spiritual efficacy undiminished. Thus, the master sought the ancient and true, dwelling right there.

**Féng Fǎxiān**, styled *Fǎyuǎn*, was from Qǔ’ē in Jìnlíng. In the first year of the *Tiānjiā* era of the Chen emperor, the court dispatched the middle official *Yú Lì* to summon Fǎxiān, who was then conducting a three-day grand ritual. At each bow in the ceremony, the bell chimed on its own, and when he recited the *Bùxū* scripture, the same phenomenon occurred—all marveled at it.

**Mǎ Shū**, styled *Yàolǐ*, hailed from *Nà* in Fúfēng. He was well-versed in the classics and histories, particularly skilled in Buddhist texts, the *Zhōuyì*, and the *Lǎozǐ Yì*. When the Prince of Shàolíng, *Lún*, served as Prefect of Nánxú, he appointed Shū as his scholar-official. When Lún raised troops to aid the capital, he entrusted Shū with twenty thousand volumes of books. Shū devoted himself to their study, then sighed deeply, saying: *"I have heard that those who prize noble rank and office regard Confucius and Yan Hui as the highest treasures. Those who cherish mountains and forests revere Yi Yin and Lü Shang as their greatest wealth. To bind oneself to name and gain is like the lofty grass beneath the pillars of a hall, while to despise purity and emptiness is to speak of the worthless husks on a mat. Examining profound teachings, each follows their own inclination. Yet why do those who seek the Way gaze longingly at the path, as if Heaven does not favor the lofty and virtuous? Why is there no fame in the mountains and forests?"* He then retired to Te Mountain, resolved to remain there. In the first year of the *Tiānjiā* era of the Chen dynasty, the emperor summoned him to the post of *Dùzhī Shàngshū*, but he declined. His vision was keen, able to discern objects at a distance. Swallows nested in his courtyard trees, tame and familiar, perching on his desk and coming and going for nearly thirty years. He passed away in the thirteenth year of the *Dàjiàn* era, leaving behind his *Dao Jué Lùn*, which circulated in the world.

**Dài Shèng**, styled *Shìróng*, was from Qǔ’ē in Jìnlíng. At a young age, he left home, his family’s wealth exhausted, and became a laborer for the village elder *Liú Biǎo*, who was a military officer and fond of hunting. Shèng abandoned him and came to Te Mountain instead.

**Chǔ Yǎ**, styled *Xuántōng*, was from Jiānyún in Hào Commandery. In the late Liang dynasty, he lived in seclusion among the mountains, generously giving away wealth and aiding the needy without measure. When his fields were ready for harvest, he would share the produce with the poor, allowing them to dwell with him. He would rise early each morning to sweep and water, and when fetching water, he would ensure that those gathering firewood and begging for alms were also provided for. In summer, he would plant melons, offering them to those who came to take them.

**Huán Fǎwén**, styled *Yànshū*, was from Dāntú in Shùhǎi, a disciple of the *Táo Yǐnjū* Ertóu. He served as the *Guǎnzhǔ* for the Prince of Nánpíng, *Qīngyuǎn*, but finding his duties too burdensome and hindering his cultivation, he built a *Xuánzhōu Jīngshè* on the right side of *Yùgāng* Mountain. The recluse *Zhōu Chǔshì* inscribed on the wall of the hall:
*"Li Jī’s ancient tripod remains,
Zhào Xiào’s winds and clouds depart.
Lofty and boundless, ascending and descending,
Now entrusted to you, O Master."*

The Prince of Wáng Sēngbiàn commissioned *Lù Huáng* to paint portraits of himself and the recluse on a screen, and also had *Fēibái* script the inscription by Sēngbiàn on the reverse. There exists a *Zhǐ Huán Jì* stating that Huán was the recluse’s attendant. The Daoist *Jiā Shànxiáng* of the Song dynasty compiled the *Transmissions of High Masters*, mistakenly adopting this claim. The *Yǐnjū* book contains his poems upon entering the mountains and his tomb inscription, which suffice to clarify the matter.

**Sūn Wéntáo**, also named *Wéi*, styled *Wénzàng*, was from Kè County in Kuàijì. He entered the mountains to study under the recluse, receiving true teachings, and later saw the *Shàngjīng* handwritten by the Three True Ones, *Yáng* and *Xǔ*. He practiced copying them, becoming highly skilled. He then studied the script of the Great King, achieving profound mastery, and was praised by contemporaries. The *Jiǔxì* inscription of the Nán Dòng and the old *Guǎn* stele of *Xǔ Zhàngshì* were both his work. The reverse of the Nán Dòng stele reads:
*"Wéntáo’s heart was gentle yet resolute,
His wisdom vast and his insight profound.
Having mastered the arts, he left no trace—
Thus, his name was carved in stone."*

**Qián Miàozhēn**, a woman of Jìnlíng, left her family to study the Dao under the recluse. During the *Tōngguāng* era, she lived alone in a secluded cave, reciting the *Huángtíng Jīng* at age nineteen. Her dwelling, *Yànkǒu Dòng*, remained for thirty years before she ascended. As she departed, she left a handwritten letter and seven poems to bid farewell to the recluse. One day, she donned white silk, vanished into the cave, and seized the land to establish the *Yàn Dòng Palace*. To this day, female officials tend her shrine.

**The Lineage of the Upper Clarity Daoist Gě Jǐngxuān of Dānyáng:**

**Shuò Shìxiǎn** of Lánlíng, having severed ties with the imperial house, devoted himself to the Dao in the mountains. His diligence in cultivation was unmatched, earning praise from ancient masters.

**Shào Yuàntài** of Lánlíng, whose Daoist influence was vast and far-reaching.

**Xú Bóqiān** of Shùhǎi, whose virtue and teachings were profound and harmonious.

**The Venerable *Bìqí* Huìzhī** of Kuàijì, a monk who practiced *Pútí* meditation, mastering the Five Vehicles and encompassing both teachings.

**Jiǎng Fùchú**, the *Guǎnzhǔ* of Yìxìng, who frequently visited Te Mountain with the resolve to entrust his fate to it.

In the second year of the *Yuán* era of the Qi dynasty, he was invited to the *Zōngyáng Guǎn* to practice and refine his cultivation.

**Daoist Masters of Distinctive Spirit and Virtue:**

Unmatched in cultivation, surpassing the age of *méishòu* (a traditional measure of longevity, often 120 years), and refining their *qi* through ascetic practice, they were:

The *Huàyáng* **Guànzhǔ** (Master of the *Huàyáng* Hall), **Lù Yìzhòng** of Hào Commandery.

The *Huàyáng* Hall **Guànzhǔ**, **Wáng Fǎmíng** of Tàiyuān.

These two masters, both of lofty resolve, dwelled in seclusion, never settling among the common halls.

The *Chóngyuán* Hall **Guànzhǔ**, **Zhāng Yuánzhī** of Jiāxīng, who was appointed in the *Jiànwǔ* era. He also built a pavilion atop *Jūn* Mountain, where white cranes would alight, and thus named it **Hètái** (Crane Pavilion).

The **Jūyáng Hall Guànzhǔ**, the Daoist **Pān Yuánwén** of Shàngqīng, who lived in seclusion and revered the *Sānmáo Èrxǔ Jīngbǎo* (Scriptures of the Three Teachings of Máo and the Two Teachings of Xǔ). The hall was established in the 12th year of the *Tiānjiàn* era by his invitation.

The **Sìzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Xǔ Língzhēn** of Jǔróng in Dānyáng, the sixth-generation descendant of the *Xǔ Zhēnrén* (True Person of Xǔ) lineage of the Jìn dynasty. The hall was founded in the 3rd year of the *Tiānjiàn* era by his invitation.

The **Chóngxū Hall Guànzhǔ**, Daoist **Zhāng Yì** of Hào Commandery, originally the Daoist hall established by Sòng Míngdì in the *Cháogōu* (Tidal Gorge) to honor the great *Dàfǎshī* (Grand Master) **Lù Xiūjìng**. In the *Qi Yǒngmíng* era, it was relocated to **Jiānglíng** by **Yì** (Effort), and **Táo** (the Master) revived it once more.

The **Zōngzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Wú Xiànzé** of **Qū’ē** (Curve and Ease), whose Daoist practice was profound and whose virtue was esteemed.

The **Zōngyuán Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Zhāng Xuánzōng** of Hào Commandery.

The **Chóngzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Táng Fǎyí** of Qū’ē.

The **Yánzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Wú Màizhī** of Yìxīng.

The **Zōngmíng Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Yú Wàndá** of Jiànkāng.

The **Jiànshàn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Luó Fǎxiān** of Jiànkāng.

The **Shàngshàn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Mèng Huìpǔ** of Hào Commandery.

The **Gǒngwū Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Wèi Língfú** of Lángyá.

The **Miàomén Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Jì Tiānlù** of Yúháng.

The **Fúlín Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Rén Yànzhēng** of Bócāng.

The **Qīzhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Yǐn Fǎjìng** of Jiànkāng.

The **Lóng’ā Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Chén Shàoxiān** of Qū’ē.

The **Fúxiāng Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Liú Zhànzhī** of Jìnlíng.

The **Jīnlíng Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Shòu Zūnzǔ** of Jiāxīng.

The **Zhāozhēn Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Xǔ Shūcún** of Gāoyáng.

The **Fāngyú Hall Guànzhǔ**, **Zhōng Wénzhòng** of Yánlíng.
