**Tóngwú Xiānshēng Wáng Guǐ**, courtesy name **Hóngfàn**, also called **Dàomó**, a native of Língyè Línshí.

His great-grandfather was **Jūn**, a **Sànqí Chángshì** of the Liang.
His grandfather was **Kòu**, a **Jiǎnwén Tàizǐ Xǐmǎ** of the Liang.
His father was **Yú**, an **Chén Zhùzuò Zuǒláng**.

At twenty, the Master served **Fǎzhǔ**, becoming a **jīnpíng dìzǐ** (disciple of the brocade bag), and remained so for sixteen years.
He followed **Fǎzhǔ** through the transitions of the **Suí** and **Táng** dynasties.

Initially, in the **Dàyè** era’s eleventh year (615 CE), he received imperial decree to survey the twenty-four commanderies of **Hénán** for extraordinary individuals.
During the **Zhēnguān** era, he was commissioned to rebuild the **Huáyáng Guàn**.
In the second year of **Qiánfēng** (667 CE), on the first day of the eleventh month, he told his disciples:
*"Yesterday, I dreamed three winged beings bore a tablet, declaring: ‘The Celestial Palace of Huáyáng requires you as its Daoist Master for ten thousand immortals, and you shall also oversee the celestial bureaucracy.’ I must now depart. Long ago, when I dwelled on Tóngwú Mountain, I already sensed this dream—now its time has come."*

On the eighth day, he bathed, changed into ceremonial robes, and on the ninth day, he ascended in solemn stillness.

In his eighty-eighth year, he was buried beside the tomb of the Daoist Master Táozhēn on Léipíng Mountain.

Wáng Yù possessed Daoist arts and resided on Qīngluó Mountain in Luòyáng. The villagers, seeing him, already took him for several hundred years old, yet he always maintained a youthful appearance. During the **Kāiyuán** era, he was summoned to the capital, where Emperor Xuánzōng observed his childlike face and flowing hair, greatly honoring him.

At that time, Xuánzōng had obtained from **Máoshān** the many Daoist masters Yáng and Xǔ, as well as the original scriptures of the *Shàngqīng* Daoist canon and true writings by Táozhēn. Among these scriptures, thirteen sheets were missing, so he dispatched Wáng Yù with imperial seals, letters, and coins to visit **Zǐyáng Guàn**, where Xuánjìng Master (Xuánjìng xiānsheng) completed the missing text.

The emperor said: *"I do not wish to command my subjects to presume upon the Master’s favor. I entrust you alone to go—certainly, I hope for the hand of a Daoist immortal, to ensure the scriptures continue from antiquity to the present."*

On the day Wáng Yù arrived at the mountain, a spirit crane soared and cried. When Xuánjìng was writing the scriptures, a celestial being descended into his chamber. These were all responses to his sincere devotion. The details are recorded in *The Gathered Remnants of Daoist Transmissions*.

Hào Jūn was a Confucian scholar from **Lǔzhōng**, who entered **Sōngshān** and followed his teacher Pān Shìzhèng as a Daoist. He transmitted the **Shàngqīng** Dao, studying it with great diligence until he mastered its techniques. During the **Kāiyuán** era, he traveled south to **Jīnlíng**, sought Dao in **Máoshān**, and later journeyed east to **Tiāntái**. He was particularly skilled in writing, and Emperor Xuánzōng, upon hearing his name, summoned him. The emperor found his conversation delightful and appointed him as a *dàizhào* (imperial attendant) in the **Hánlín** Academy.

Soon after, he requested to return to **Máoshān**, and permission was granted. Later, when chaos spread across the central plains and bandits plagued **Jiānghuái**, he withdrew to **Kuàijī Tiāntái**, where he exchanged poems with Lǐ Bái and Kǒng Cháo Fǔ. He wandered freely among springs and rocks, ultimately dying in **Yuèzhōng**.

The account is found in *The Biography of the Tang Book*.

Cuī Xīzhēn, a guest of **Zhōnglíng**, dwelled in the western suburbs of the prefecture. He excelled in playing the *qín* (zither) and was skilled in painting, while also cultivating Daoist practices with fervor.

On the first day of the tenth month in the second year of the **Dàlì** era, a heavy snow fell at night. At dawn, **Xīzhēn** opened his door and saw an elderly man in a **suō** (straw raincoat) and **lì** (bamboo hat) taking shelter from the snow beneath his gate. **Xīzhēn** was struck by his unusual appearance and invited him in, whereupon the old man removed his raincoat and hat. His **shénsè** (divine countenance) and **máogǔ** (frame of bones and flesh) were extraordinary, and **Xīzhēn** revered him even more, asking:

"At home, I have some **dàmài miǎn** (large barley grains). I can offer them to ease your hunger. Would you care to eat?"

The old man replied:

"Barley absorbs the **qi** of all four seasons, making it the finest of grains. If it is seasoned with **zhǐ** (fermented soybean paste) broth, it would be even better."

**Xīzhēn** then ordered his household to prepare the barley, and when they did, they also presented **sōnghuā jiǔ** (pine-flower wine). The old man said:

"The flowers are too astringent—no. But the common folk have something that can refine it and make it truly **chún měi** (pure and exquisite)."

He reached into his bosom and withdrew a yellow, hard pill, striking it with a stone. After placing a small portion in the wine, its sweet fragrance became instantly distinct. He then gave the remaining pill to **Xīzhēn** as a parting gift.

**Xīzhēn** returned to his home and, peering through a crack in the window, saw the old man before a **wéi** (screen) drawing on white silk. He sketched as if guided by unseen visions, then paused in an instant. When **Xīzhēn** stepped outside, the old man had vanished. He followed the snow tracks and soon reached the river, where he entered a **lúzhōu** (reed marsh). There, he saw a grand **fǎng** (boat), inside which several men of strange and striking appearances were gathered.

One of them turned and laughed:

"Bo **Gěsān**—now you are pressed by this man!"

He then addressed **Xīzhēn**:

"Follow the **Dao** with strict discipline, and such encounters need not occur."

**Xīzhēn** bowed in gratitude and departed. Upon returning home, he found the silk drawing. It depicted three figures, two trees, one white deer, and one **yàojí** (medicinal plant). The two figures seemed to be **fāngwài** (those beyond worldly affairs), each holding **xuánzhī** (a type of immortal herb), as if they were gathering medicine. The two trees resembled pines but bore the appearance of ancient, decayed trunks ravaged by wind and rain, their roots intertwined in an unnatural way—beyond ordinary comprehension.

Later, **Xīzhēn** brought the drawing and the pill to **Shān** (Mountain) **Máoshān**, presenting them to **Lǐ Shèguāng**, the **Tiāntái** (Celestial Master). The master said:

"This is the work of the **Zhēnrén** (True Person) **Gē Hóng**, the third son of **Gěsān**."

**Lǐ Shèguāng** further remarked:

"To depict a **Shénrén** (Divine Person) beneath withered wood suggests that those who attain the **Dao** may live longer than pines and willows. And this pill is made from the **gāo** (resin) of a thousand-year-old pine."

The account is recorded in *The Original Transformation Record*.

**Cuī Xīzhēn**, the **Chǔshì** (Master of Retirement), lived in seclusion at **Máoshān**. In the twelfth year of the **Zhēnyuán** era, the **Yòu Jiànyì Dàfū** (Right Advisor of the Imperial Censorate) **Wéi Qúmóu** recommended him. Emperor **Dézōng** summoned him to the capital, as recorded in the **Tángshǐ** (Tang History).

**Gē**, the **Daoist practitioner** (whose full name is unknown), resided at the **Pénglái Guān** (Pénglái Observatory) in the **East Sea**. He practiced **fúshí** (nourishment and abstinence) for over a decade. During the **Xiàntōng** era of the **Táng**, he attained entry into the **Huáyáng Dòng** (Cave of the Flowered Sun), where many extraordinary **língyì** (supernatural phenomena) occurred.

This is recorded in the fifteenth volume of *The Records of Máoshān*. #1: "於" was originally absent; added according to the **Dì** (variant) text.

「#2Twelve: The variant text reads *„Three“*. #3Originally, after *„person“* there was *„clouds“*; deleted according to the variant text.

**Records of Máoshān, Volume Sixteen: The *Shàngqīng Sìzōng* Master Liu Dàbīn’s *Cāizhēn Yóupiàn* (Essays on the Refined and True)*

**Xiàhóu**, the recluse (whose origins remain unknown), arrived at Máoshān during the late **Dàzhōng** era of the **Táng**. He habitually carried only a coarse linen sack and a bamboo staff, consuming food like any common man, yet dwelling alone in a single chamber—or sometimes sleeping exposed beneath the altar, in grassy thickets, or at the foot of trees. When others observed him, they saw only dense **qi** clouds, not his form.

Each time he wandered thirty or fifty *lǐ*, ascending mountains or crossing waters while keeping his eyes closed in blissful slumber, his companions heard his breathing and snoring, yet never stumbled in their steps. His feet #1 encountered no obstruction, and upon reaching his destination, he would awaken—earning the name *Sleeping Immortal* at the time.

Later, his fate remains unknown; as recorded in *The Collected Lost Accounts of Immortals*.

**Zhōu**, the recluse (whose surname was *Yóuyáo*), with the courtesy name *Xīyuán*, dwelled in the **Nándòng** (Southern Cave) of the **Chóngyuán Shèngzǔ Yuàn** (Sacred Ancestor Hall) in **Zhēnyuán** during the **Táng Bǎolì** era—this being the site where **Lǐ Gōng Déyù** of **Zànhuáng** sustained him. He also once resided on **Báoshān** (Enwrapped Mountain) in **Dòngtíng**, unmoved by day or night, unaffected by cold or heat, requiring no food yet possessing great strength, and though he drank, nothing leaked.

**Lìnghú Chǔ** wrote of him. *The Collected Lost Accounts of Immortals* also contains his biography.»

---

**Zhāng Shào Yīng**, a native of Dānyáng, became a Daoist recluse and never entered the city gates. Emperor Rénzōng, seeking the wisdom of those outside the court, summoned him along with his friend **Zhū Zì Yīng** to meet the wondrous **Miào Zōng Shī**. They were both called to serve **Yìng Shào**, but **Zhū** declined due to illness. The following year, **Chéngxiàng Dīng Wèi** and **Wáng Qīn Ruò** jointly petitioned the throne, and **Zhāng Shào Yīng** was summoned again. Two years later, when an imperial carriage was sent a second time, both declined, citing illness.

The court dispatched a eunuch, **Rèn Guì**, to deliver a formal reprimand at the mountain. **Zhāng Shào Yīng** was granted the title *Míng Zhēn Xiānshēng*, and his dwelling was renamed **Tiān Shèng Guàn**. At seventy-five, one morning after bathing and changing his clothes, he ascended the altar, bowed to the four directions, and sat with his shoulders facing above and below. His disciples, astonished, opened the door and found him already transformed. **Wáng Qǎn**, courtesy name *Zǐ Zhēn*, from **Qíxià Píngyáng**, was a descendant of the **Sìdiàn Zhèngxiàng** and his mother was of the **Sīmǎ** clan. His brothers all pursued official careers through the imperial examinations, but he alone studied the Dao.

While traveling in the countryside, he rested beneath a melon patch and encountered a Daoist woman begging for melons. Observing her milk-like *qi* concentrated in her abdomen, he was struck by her presence and gave her melons. She ate them and offered the remainder to him. **Wáng Qǎn** consumed it, and the woman rejoiced, saying: "You may be taught! I am **Xiāo Sān Niáng**, and the Immortal **Hǎichán Zǐ** resides here. When you open your door at dawn, you will see him together with me." She then instructed him in the elixir's secrets. From that day on, he revered the statues of the **Sān Qīng** and paid homage morning and evening, reciting the *Huángtíng Jīng* for months without stepping outside.

Later, he journeyed to distant sacred mountains, reaching **Chéngdū** in the west. **Fù Zhèng Gōng**, admiring his virtues, hosted him for eight years. **Chéngxiàng Lǚ Gōng** held him in even greater esteem, and officials wished to elevate him by recommending him for office as a **Guānyì Dàfū**. However, the ministers deemed him unsuited to human affairs and the proposal was abandoned. During the **Yuánfēng** era, he was again summoned to court and granted the title *Chōng Zhào Chǔshì*.

His nephew **Bìng**, who governed **Táizhōu**, wished to invite him there, but **Bìng** died before the journey could be made. Instead, **Wáng Qǎn** came to the mountain and received the **Shàng Qīng Jīng** from **Liú Xiānshēng**. On the night of his transmission, thunder rolled over **Zhōngmáo Shān**, and the door suddenly opened, revealing celestial music in the air. One day, while napping, he dreamed of two heavenly beings leading him through the door to a cave, where he met **Máo Jūn**, who declared: "You have been assigned to oversee the **Sīmìng Fǔ** in the Northern Quarter. I grant you a golden ruler." Upon waking, he predicted his own death and, seated in the home of a mountain Daoist named **Gě Chōng**, ascended in transformation at age sixty-one.

**Wáng Qǎn** practiced austere refinement, consuming only enough food to sustain an infant. He remained seated through the night, never removing his cap and sash, and even in old age moved with ease. **Zhāng Shùn Mín** composed an epitaph for him, which was engraved at **Fèng Xiāng**.

**Tāng Yòng Míng**, courtesy name *Huì Zhī*, was a Daoist from **Zhōng Líng**. His spiritual prowess was extraordinary, and he mastered the classics while exploring profound knowledge. He specialized in the inner alchemy of the *Zuòwàng* method. At the beginning of the **Yuán Yòu** era, though still in his prime, he heard of **Liú Xiānshēng**’s teachings and traveled thousands of miles to receive them in person, befriending **Lú Bì Qiáng**, **Tāng Dào Yuán**, **Féng Yuè Dào**, **Bào Liàn Shī**, and **Wáng Jǐng Shān**.

When **Liú Xiānshēng** was summoned to court, **Tāng Yòng Míng** and **Tāng Dào Yuán** wished to accompany him, but both declined, refusing to go. They built a hermitage on **Jīn Jūn Shān**, dwelling in seclusion beside a cave, with no contact with the outside world. Their rags and worn sandals betrayed no shame. In the early **Dàguān** era, **Tāng Yòng Míng** departed without illness.

**Féng Tàishēn**, courtesy name *Yuè Dào*, of **Chízhōu**, became a Daoist and gathered ten companions to reside on the mountain. When famine struck for consecutive years, nine of them left, but only **Féng Tàishēn** remained, his *qi* refined and unyielding. He stayed long in the temple halls, revered by both Daoists and laymen. There was a **Lú Xiānshēng** who built a Daoist observatory on **Càn Shān**, but it was unfinished when he heard of the summons and abandoned the project. His disciples, numbering thousands, dared not return, so they begged **Féng Tàishēn** to lead them. He used all his offerings to repay them and returned to the temple, soon ascending in transformation at his mountain dwelling. His disciples, **Shào Cì Shān** and **Gě Zhēn Yī**, were both serene and self-disciplined, held in respect by all.

**Chén Xī Wēi**, courtesy name *Yàn Zhēn*, originally named **Bó Xióng**, was from **Gūsū**. His father, **Zhī Cái**, served as a **Cháofèng Láng** overseeing the grain supplies of **Jiāngníng Fǔ**. During the **Yuán Yòu** era, **Bó Xióng** fell gravely ill, and his wife, the younger sister of **Ménxià Shìláng Xuē Áng**, begged **Liú Xiānshēng** for a talisman and sacred water to cure him. His illness was swiftly healed. After his father’s death, he took up mountain life as a Daoist, changed his name to **Xī Wēi**, and built a dwelling above **Liǔ Jì Quán**.

Emperor **Huìzōng** heard his name and repeatedly summoned him, but **Chén Xī Wēi** declined each time. The court then encouraged him to establish a Daoist observatory, naming it **Bàoyuán Guàn**, and granted him the title *Dòngwēi Fǎshī*. During the **Xuānhé** era, he was invited to write petitions for others, but he resigned after just one day. **Huáng Chéng**, a native of **Pílíng**, was affiliated with **Dānyáng Xiāntái Guàn**. In the early **Chóngníng** era, he was persuaded to change the name of **Yùchén Guàn** to **Chóngníng Wànshòu Gōng**, and **Chéng** was appointed as its abbot.

Soon after, **Huìzōng** issued an imperial seal summoning him to the capital. When **Chéng** arrived, he was instead assigned to oversee **Shénxiāo Wànshòu Gōng** on **Jīn Shān**. He was repeatedly granted the titles *Tàisù Dàfū*, *Chōngsù Jìngyī Xiānshēng*, and *Lǐng Yùtáng Gāoshì Zuǒyòu Jiē Dōulù Jìngyī Gōngshì*, with a stipend of 1,200 households and a purple-gold talisman. He requested retirement and returned to the mountain, departing in his hermitage built at **Yùchén**. Initially, the **Sānyuán Jīnglù**—including **Lónghǔ**, **Zhèngyī**, **Gézào**, **Língbǎo**, and **Máoshān Dàdòng**—each followed their own traditions. **Chéng** petitioned to unify them, and from this point, the lineages of **Lónghǔ Gézào** and **Shàngqīng Bìfǎ** began.

**Yáng Xī Zhēn**, courtesy name *Yuán Dào*, was a descendant of the **Yízhēn Mǐshāng** family, accumulating hidden virtue. **Yuán Dào** was born in the first year of **Jiànzhōng Jìngguó** (1101), and at six he could speak. As he grew older, he knew to honor the statues of the **Sìshèng Zhēnjūn**. One night, he dreamed of a divine being who said: "I am the Northern Quarter’s **Tiānfú Shàngshuài**. Pitying your sincere devotion, I will reverse your impure physical form and meet you at the **Huáyáng Xiānfǔ**. I will grant you a new body and bestow upon you sacred scriptures."

「Later, the Master often communicated with the unseen and divine, and if he suffered from any physical ailment, he would rush about in a frenzy, losing all sense of direction. In the second year of **Xuānhé** (1120), in the year of **Gēngzǐ**, he entered the **Huáyáng Dòng** and did not return.

The following year, he emerged from the cave, and upon his return, his neighbors were astonished. The Master said: "I was not truly mad before; I sought only the Dao. Now I have obtained **Tóngchū**’s initial great method, which can save the world."

The **Huīzōng** Emperor sought out this extraordinary man and requested the **Jiǔ Líng Yùyīng Shénbiàn** scriptures, along with the **Língxū Mìzhǐ** and other sacred texts. He was ordered to refine and compile them into the **Jiéhuáng Jiàodìng Lù**, to be included in the **Dàozàng** (Daoist Canon). The Emperor specially bestowed upon him the titles **Dāntái Láng**, **Chōnghé Miào-Yī Fǎshī**, and **Shìcháo Qǐng Dàfū**.

At the age of twenty-four, his physical form dissolved (**shísèjiě**), but after three days, he revived. He wrote a farewell note to his disciples, placed it on the door, and then sat down and passed away—on the seventeenth day of the third month, in the year of **Jiǎchén**.

Thus, **Tóngchū**’s method became renowned in the world, and his disciple, **Ménrén** the **Wèiláng** (Assistant Minister) **Shěn Yù**, composed the *Biography of Master Yáng Zhēn*.

**Shěn Yù**, courtesy name *Zǐzhōu*, hailed from a distant lineage that, during the time of **Hàoyuè**’s **Qián Shì**, served as a strategist. They became **Qián Táng** (Hangzhou) people, and their clan flourished in grandeur. As a young man of about ten years, he took no pleasure in mundane affairs but sought out the **Yuánzhēn Guàn** in his native district and became an ascetic. In the year **Yuán Yòu Gēngwǔ** (1090), he passed the **shìjīng** (scripture examination) and became a Daoist priest at the age of thirteen.

He studied the **Dàozàng** meticulously and supplemented his learning with external texts, comparing and harmonizing them with his fellow scholars. His understanding was comprehensive and profound, especially in the art of medicine. While traveling in the mountains, he visited the **Chóngxī Guàn** and lodged there. In the latter years of **Zhènghé**, he was invited to the **Yánkāng Dìng** as a **Xuéshì** (scholar-official). **Wáng Gōng Hànzhī** sought his counsel on inner and outer alchemy (**nèidān wàidān**), and they found mutual accord. When **Wáng Gōng** led the retreat to **Jiànkāng**, he settled in the **Dòngyáng Guǎn** within the mountains, and the Master was tasked with refining the great elixir (**dàyào**) while also widely dispensing medicine to cure the sick from all directions.

The **Huīzōng** Emperor summoned him again, compelling him to take up residence in the **Lóngdé Gōng**. After several months, the Emperor granted him the title **Dòngyuán Dàshī** and appointed him to a Daoist office. He declined due to illness, and the Emperor bestowed upon him a **jīnfāng fú** (golden prescription talisman) before sending him back to the mountains.

At the beginning of the **Shàoxīng** era (1131), he consumed the elixir and his physical form dissolved (**shísèjiě**) at the age of sixty-two.

**Tāng Yǒuchéng**, courtesy name *Dàoyuán*, was from **Tóngchuān** (Tongchuan). His elder brother **Tāng Jǐngrén** passed the **Jìnshì** examination. In the year **Xīníng Bǐngchén** (1066), he and his younger brother **Yǒuzhí** both took the **shìjīng** examination and became Daoist priests together.

**Yǒuchéng** served under **Xú Shénwēng** in **Tàizhōu**. The Master’s understanding of the **Tiān jī** (heavenly mechanism) was profound and subtle; he rarely interacted with others, only speaking with **Yǒuchéng** at times. After residing there for over a year, he once caught two mice, sealed them in a jar, and intended to release them. But upon opening the jar, the mice were already dead. The Master scolded him sharply (**duōduō yǒu suǒ yóu**), then ignored him entirely, and **Yǒuchéng** thus left his service.

The Master then instructed him to go to **Liú Zhēnshī** to receive the scriptures and methods (**jīngfǎ**), and together they cultivated in the **Hèmiào** (Hall of Cranes). **Wáng Gōng** invited him to oversee the **dànlú** (elixir furnace), and he also followed **Wáng Gōng** into exile at **Háoliáng**. When **Wáng Gōng** returned, they once again retreated to the **Hèmiào**.

During the **Xuānhé** Emperor’s summons for extraordinary men (**yìrén**), **Yǒuchéng** and his brother hid in secluded mountain huts, always fearing discovery. In the **Jiàn Yán** era (1127), when bandits rose in rebellion, **Yǒuzhí** fled into a deep ravine and never returned, while **Yǒuchéng** lived in the mountains for over fifty years. Upon returning from **Háoliáng** to **Jiànzhōu**, he never left his home again.

In the year **Shàoxīng Guǐhài** (1143), he foretold his passing. On the fifth day of the sixth month of that year, he drank cold water and bathed, asking when the day would end. At noon, he departed (**shì**), at the age of eighty-four.

**Lǐ Jué**, a native of **Guǎnglíng Jiāngyáng** (Yangzhou), engaged in the trade of **yào** (medicinal herbs). If anyone sought his help, he would give them a measure of herbs (**shēngdǒu**) to weigh themselves, and he did not change his profession even at over eighty years of age.

When **Li Gong**#2 **Jué** governed the **Huái Nán** region, **Jué**—sharing the same name as **Li Jué**—changed his name to **Kuān**.

Within months of **Li Jué**’s arrival, he established Daoist observances and fasts. One night, he dreamed of entering a **Dòngfǔ** (cave palace), where he saw a stone wall inscribed in gold with the name **Li Jué**, the characters spanning over a foot in length. **Jué**#3 gazed upon it with great delight, believing himself destined for the **Míng** dynasty, even to rise as a high minister. Now, he thought, his name was recorded in the **Dòngfǔ**, and he was surely a **xiānrén** (immortal).

As he rejoiced, two **qīngyī** (attendants in green robes) emerged from either side of the stone wall. **Jué**#4 asked: *"Where is this place?"*
They replied: *"Huáyáng Dòngtiān* (a celestial cave realm). This name does not belong to you, honored sir."

**Jué**#5 was startled and asked again: *"If not mine, then whose?"*
The attendants said: *"It belongs to a commoner named Li from your Jiangyáng district."*

**Jué**#6 awoke in shock, marveled, and ordered his officials to investigate for someone with the same surname and name. They found **Li Kuān**, whose former name was **Jué**, and brought him to a secluded chamber, bowing to him as a Daoist elder brother.

**Kuān** was naturally serene and possessed an extraordinary Daoist bearing, with a beard over a foot long, pure and radiant. At sixty years old, a Daoist instructed him in **tāixī** (embryonic breathing) and **xī** (suspended animation), and he abstained from food for long periods. **Jué** revered him even more, inquiring about his Daoist practices, but **Kuān** humbly declined, claiming he was merely a commoner who sold medicinal herbs. **Jué**#7 sighed: *"This is beyond the reach of ordinary mortals—his hidden virtue is unmatched."*

**Kuān** lived over a hundred years, remaining agile and vigorous until one night he suddenly passed away. After three days, his coffin split open, revealing his body as withered as a **chántuì** (cicada’s shed skin). The account appears in the *Xù Xiān Zhuàn* (Continuation of the Immortal Records).

**Fù Xiāo**, styled **Zǐ’áng**, hailed from **Jìnlíng**. Well-versed in antiquity and the classics, he excelled in calligraphy, particularly in **lì** and **gǔ** scripts. Entering Daoism from Confucianism, he resided at **Chángzhōu Tiānjìng Guàn**. Emperor **Gāozōng** summoned him to oversee the **Tàiyī** shrine, but he begged to return to **Máoshān**, receiving the title **Míngzhēn Tōngwēi Xiānsheng** and serving as **Shānmén Dùdàozhèng** at **Yùchén Guàn**, where he established the **Léipíng Yùan**. For forty years, he wandered the mountains, seeking hidden truths, rescuing the destitute, and benefiting many. He recompiled the *Yǐnjū Jí* and revised the *Máoshān Jiùjì*, though much of his work is now lost.

On the **Jìchǔ** day of the **Shàoxīng** era’s **29th year** (1159), on the first day of spring, he ascended.

**Yáng Rèn Dīng**, styled **Zhíjiǎ**, was from **Xiāngzhōu** in **Héběi**, with a commanding presence and imposing **qi**.

In the **30th year of Shàoxīng** (1160), he resigned his post and entered the mountains, building a hermitage beneath **Sōngshū Fēng**. **Wáng Yáng Gōng Cúnzhōng** dispatched five hundred soldiers to assist in constructing its foundation.

When the hermitage was complete, the master declared: *"I have never sought faith in mortals, only in Heaven."* Thus, he named it **Tiānxìn** (Heaven’s Faith). The master was adept in the **biàn dùn** (transformation and evasion) arts—truly a **zhēn yǐnzhě** (true recluse).

Born in the **Chúnhuà** era of **Tàizōng** (921), he passed away on the **15th day of the 2nd month of Chúnxī** (1178), at the age of **184**.

**Liú Dàohuái**, a native of **Ēnzhōu**, was known as the **Suōyī Xiānsheng** (Straw-Cape Master), residing at **Qíyún Yùan**. Emperor **Gāozōng**, in his own hand, summoned the master to serve as **Liúshǒu**, but **Cháo Gōng Qiānzhī** conveyed the imperial intent, urging him to accept. The master was forcibly escorted to the capital.

At the time, **Wán Yán Líng Yángwáng** **Wán Yán Líng** of **Jīn** (Emperor Yáng of Hǎiliáng), **Guānyán Ráng**, threatened **Guāzhōu**. The emperor, fearful, consulted him on state affairs. The master replied bluntly: *"No matter—no matter. The north and south will simply exchange rulers."*

Soon after, **Hǎiliáng** was assassinated, and **Gāozōng** abdicated in favor of **Xiàozōng**.

The master, aged **84**, died seated in **Qíyún**.

**Táo Yuánjìng**, from **Cáozhōu**, resided in the southern mountains. Like the **Suōyī Xiānsheng**, he was summoned, but he submitted a petition declining and returned to the mountains in the **18th year of Shàoxīng** (1148). At the time, they were known as the **Táo-Liú Érgōng** (Masters Táo and Liú).

**Chén Huái**, of **Jīngkǒu**, was styled **Jìngzhēn Xiānsheng**. During the **Shàoxīng** era, he served as **Dàizhì**, but declined office and retreated into the woods, constructing an **Bāguà Tái** in the east of **Máodòng**. A **shíshì** (stone chamber) with his likeness remains.

**Liú Zhìxiào**, whose given name is lost, was a native of **Xiántōng Lǐ**. At the age of majority, he lost both parents and vowed to wear coarse hempen garments for life, earning the name *Zhìxiào* ("Most Filial"). He dwelled at the **Báiè Miào** for several years, devoting himself tirelessly to its upkeep.

One day, while repairing a hall by the sea, beneath a pomegranate tree he found an object resembling a peach. Though it was winter and out of season, he and others peeled and tasted it—it had no pit, and all discarded it. Only Zhìxiào kept some, finding its flavor exquisite. That evening, he returned to the same spot and found another object, the size of a fist, green within and red without. The next day, he discovered one the size of a palm, its color and taste like that of a peach, yet even more refined and precious. From then on, Zhìxiào abstained from all cooked food, wandering the sacred mountains until his fate was unknown. Was this not the reward of pure filial virtue? Or did he encounter only rare elixirs of the Dao? This account appears in the *Dàozàng Língyàn Jì*.

**Liú Shāng**, a man of **Péngchéng** who resided in **Cháng’ān**, rose through the imperial examinations and served in the central bureaucracy as a *láng* (official). By nature, he was devoted to Daoist cultivation, often sighing at the fleeting glories of worldly office—what use were they to him? The ancient sages had all abandoned officialdom to seek the Way, and many attained transcendence to save the world.

Fortunate that his marriage was complete and he was free from worldly entanglements, how could he be inferior to Xu Yuan’s wandering? Thus, he resigned from office on the pretext of illness, donned Daoist robes, and set out to travel. Arriving in Guangling, he encountered a Daoist selling medicines. Among the crowd, the man noticed Liu Shang’s unusual bearing and, abandoning his wares, took his hand and led him up to a winehouse pavilion. There, he conversed on the affairs of Qin and Han as if witnessing them firsthand.

Liu Shang revered him as a master. As evening fell, the man descended the stairs and vanished without a trace.

The next day, Liu Shang searched the city streets, engaging in lively discourse and drinking deeply. He then produced a small medicine pouch and presented it to Liu Shang, jesting with the verse:

*"Without purpose to Yangzhou I came,
Together we climbed the winehouse’s frame.
This pouch of medicine is my parting gift—
What more could one seek across the ages?"*

After their separation, Liu Shang repeatedly sought him in vain, but found nine pills within the pouch. Following the instructions, he ingested them and instantly felt his spirit brightened, his hunger vanished, and his body lightened with clarity.

He then crossed the river and secluded himself in the mountains, occasionally visiting the Hu Fu Zhu docks. Woodcutters who encountered him would say, *"There goes Master Liu the Official,"* yet none knew his dwelling place.

Wen Decheng, styled Shaoshou, who called himself Shumengzi, was a native of Changle in the Three Mountains. He associated with scholars like Huì’ān Xiàngshān, and for thirty years oversaw the Yùchén Guan, compiling the Daoist Canon. Initially, he received his ordination at the Shēngyuán Guan on Jìzhōu Mountain in Hào Xīng.

He delighted in the *Tàiqíng* and the *Guīzhǔ* sutras.

The *jì* of the *jìchuán* continues:

In the fourth month of the *jiǎdìng* year *bǐngzǐ* (1216), Master Wen Decheng entered *shìhuà*, having lived to seventy-two. He was interred west of the *Jiāochí* in Wǔkāng County.

Fifteen years later, in the year *gēngyín*, as he rode in a shoulder-litter through the mountains near the *Bāguà Tái*, the guardian of the hermitage saw him and was astonished, saying, *"I was sent to inspect the Daoist ritual texts of Jiangdong at Shùyùe, and now I pass through my old mountain."* At that moment, a pair of cranes flew with a mournful cry, as if guiding and welcoming him. He took up a brush to leave a poem before departing.

The next day, the guardian brought the poem to *Bāo Shǒumíng*, the magistrate under *Chóngxǐ* jurisdiction. Bāo recognized it as the genuine hand of his old friend, Master Wen the Lecturer, and marveled greatly. The preface to the *Dōngméng Jí* records that the poem was later published in its final volume.

As for *Jīnyuán Fàn*, a Daoist of the *Níngshén’ān*, his nature was simple and rustic, yet he had never studied Daoist teachings. In the first year of *Bǎoyòu* (1253), when the tides of Zhèjiāng surged against Jiāntáng, the officials were powerless to stop them. Fàn dreamed that the Immortal of the Teahouse gave him a talisman and incantation, commanding him to subdue the tide. The next morning, he forgot it, but that evening, he dreamed of it again—three nights in total. Finally, he went to the imperial court to confess, and the authorities tested his method. When the tide raged, Fàn hurled the talisman and shouted, and the tide immediately retreated. From then on, the waters caused no more harm. The court appointed him to the Daoist bureaucracy, bestowed gold and silk, which he refused, asking only for exemption from taxes on his hermitage’s fields. At the time, Chancellor Xiè Fāngzú composed the lines *"With a shout, the river tides retreat—taxes forgiven, returned to the mountain."* His return was indeed recorded in the *Shìlù*, and he was widely praised as the *Jīn Zhēnrén*.

Yang Zhìyǐn, styled *Kōngjìng*, was a native of Èzhōu. As a child of mere years, he left his family without warning and drifted downriver on a raft to Jiangdong. As he grew older, he became a Daoist at the *Yuánsù Gōng*. He delighted in reading, though his appearance was most unusual. He encountered a strange man who taught him the art of summoning thunder and rain. In the early years of the *Dàyuán*, he used his methods to serve the *Shìzǔ* Emperor. Whenever the emperor inquired of him, his responses were direct and unadorned, never avoiding taboos, and the emperor treated him with favor.

Yang Zhìyǐn soon requested leave to return to the mountains, where he was entrusted with a imperial decree to oversee the Daoist teachings of the Sān Máoshān and took up residence at the Guānyuán Guàn. Throughout his life, he would not sleep until he had recited the *Huángtíng Jīng* once through at the stroke of midnight. His white hair, sometimes adorned with multicolored threads tied into small topknots, hung down to his crown. He wandered the mountains and marshes as if no one else were present.

One night, he ordered those who associated with him to hold a *Língbǎo* fast, then took out all his secret writings and burned them. The next day, he lay down and died.

Lín Dàfū, styled *Zǐ Xuān*, who called himself *Mùtōng*, was born in Yǒngjiā, a native of Píngyáng. The *Yùhǎi* Master Jiāng Zōngshī traveled through Jiangdong, and Lín followed him into the mountains. In the *Tizǐ* year of the *Dàyuán* era, Master Jiāng initiated him as a disciple. Lín was fond of wine and unrestrained in his ways, yet though he walked slowly, he moved swiftly. He traveled extensively across the Five Sacred Peaks and other famous mountains, and in his later years, he settled at the *Xuánzhōu* Precious Studio, building an altar and dwelling in a thatched hut.

On the eighteenth day of the second month in the *Wùxū* year of the *Dàdé* era, he bade farewell to all his acquaintances, saying he would depart for the mountains. The next day, seated in his thatched hut, he burned incense and recited the *Dòng Jīng* when suddenly he gave a loud shout and vanished.

The attendant, startled, looked on and saw him sitting upright in the flames, his voice still reciting the scripture. Soon, there was no trace of his remains—only auspicious clouds remained. This was what is called *huǒjiě* [fire resolution]. The onlookers marveled, and just then, a man named Xuē Dàomín returned from Yángzhōu, claiming to have encountered the master at Guāzhōu. He said the master had appeared and disappeared among people several times before sending a message to the mountains, departing at the age of sixty-one.

(*End of Volume 16 of the Máo Shān Zhì*)
(*Note: Original text had "之" for #1, corrected to "之" per the *Dí* edition. #2 was missing "公" in the original, added per the *Dí* edition. #3-7 all originally read "珏," corrected to "公" per the *Dí* edition.*)

(*Volume 17 of the Máo Shān Zhì*)
(*The Upper Clarity Lineage Master Liú Dàbīn composed this*)

**Volume 17 of the *Máo Shān Zhì***

**The Upper Clarity Lineage Master Liú Dàbīn composed this**

---

**The Lóuguān Sect’s Scriptures**

The **Yuánsì Wànníng Gōng** [Palace of Primordial Peace and Universal Tranquility], located at **Jījīn Shān** [Accumulated Gold Mountain], was originally the site of **Táo Yǐnjū** [Master Tao of Seclusion], whose Daoist name was **Dàozhēng**. Above this foundation, **Liú Míngshēng** [Master Liu], with the Daoist name **Hùnkāng**, established his residence.

When the master encountered **Zhézōng** [Emperor Philosopher], he was granted favor, and his dwelling was named **Yuánsì Guān** [Primordial Peace Hall]. Its construction was completed in the **Chóngníng** [Venerable Peace] 5th year [1106]. **Huízōng** [Emperor Gaozong] personally inscribed the plaque, which read: **"Yuánsì Wànníng Gōng"** [Palace of Primordial Peace and Universal Tranquility]. Additionally, a **Yuánsì Bié Guān** [Separate Hall of Primordial Peace] was built beside the **Shùqīng Chǔxiáng Guān** [Palace of Upper Clarity’s Auspicious Treasures], serving as the master’s residence when he entered the imperial court and took up duties.

Today, the palace retains its original layout: The first ascent to the mountain is marked by the **Tōngxiān Qiáo** [Bridge of Ascending Perfection], which leads directly to the gate of the **Yuánsì Wànníng Guān**. To the left is the **Guān Tīng** [Palace Hall], and to the right, the **Yùshì** [Bathing Chamber]. The second gate is called the **Yùhuá Mén** [Gate of Jade Flower].

The main hall enshrines the **Sānmáo Zhēnjūn** [Three Teachings of Perfection, i.e., the Three Pure Ones], named **Tiānníng Wànfú Diàn** [Hall of Heavenly Tranquility and Universal Blessings]. To its left is the **Yùcè Diàn** [Hall of Jade Registers], and to its right, the **Jiǔshì Diàn** [Hall of the Nine Auspicious Offerings]. Behind the **Jǐngfú Diàn** [Hall of Auspicious Scenery and Longevity] is the **Mǎjīngfú Wànnián Diàn** [Hall of Auspicious Scenery and Longevity, named "Sage’s Everlasting Auspiciousness"]. To the west is the **Yìngfēitiān Fǎshū Diàn** [Hall of the Responsive Celestial Law Transmission], flanked by a **Zhōnglóu** [Bell Tower] to the left and a **Jīnggé** [Scripture Pavilion] to the right.

Behind the **Tiānníng Diàn** [Hall of Heavenly Tranquility] lies the **Dàyǒu Táng** [Hall of Great Possession], followed by the **Bùkù Táng** [Hall of the Treasury] and the **Xīyún Táng** [Hall of Western Clouds]. Beyond the **Xīyún Táng** is the **Bǎolù Diàn** [Hall of Precious Records].

Behind the **Jǐngfú Diàn** [Hall of Auspicious Scenery] is the **Yún Chú** [Cloud Kitchen], and behind the **Dàyǒu Táng** is the **Zhòngmiào Táng** [Hall of Supreme Marvels]. To the left of the **Zhī Guān Wèi** [Office of the Palace Administrator] is the **Sān Sù Táng** [Hall of the Three Unadorned Ones], and to the right, the **Fùzhī Guān Wèi** [Office of the Deputy Palace Administrator] is the **Jiǔzhēn Táng** [Hall of the Nine Perfect Ones].

The **Běijí Gé** [Pavilion of the Northern Pole] stands behind the **Bǎolù Diàn** [Hall of Precious Records], while the **Zhònglíng Táng** [Hall of Trembling Spirits] is located behind the **Zhòngmiào Táng** [Hall of Supreme Marvels]. There is also the **Gǎngshén Ān** [Hermitage of the Harbor Spirit], situated behind the halls, which was burned by bandits in the **Jiàn’ān** [Rebuilding and Peace] 4th year [1130]. In the **Shàoxīng** [Glory to the Song] year **Wùyín** [1138], **Gāozōng** [Emperor Xiaozong] granted gold for its reconstruction and personally inscribed the palace plaque.

During **Lǐzōng**’s reign [1224–1264], the halls underwent repairs, and the emperor inscribed two plaques: **"Shùqīng Zōngtán"** [Altar of the Upper Clarity Sect] and **"Shèngdé Rényòu Diàn"** [Hall of Sacred Virtue and Benevolent Assistance].

The **Chóngxǐ Wànshòu Gōng** [Palace of Venerable Longevity and Universal Auspiciousness], located at the **Dīnggōng Shān** [Dinggong Mountain]’s forefront, was originally the site of **Yǐnjū Huáyáng Xiàwǎn** [Master Tao’s Secluded Dwelling in Mount Hua’s Lower Reaches]. In the **Táng Zhēnguān** [Tang Zhenguan] 9th year [635], **Emperor Taizong** [of Tang] built it for **Wáng Fǎzhǔ** [Master Wang, the Law Sovereign], naming it **Tàipíng Guān** [Hall of Great Peace]. In the **Tiānbǎo** [Heavenly Treasure] 7th year [748], **Emperor Xuánzong** [of Tang] forcibly took it from **Lǐ Xuánjìng** [Master Li of Mysterious Tranquility], relocating a hundred households of commoners nearby, exempting them from rent, taxes, and corvée labor, and perpetually assigning them to maintain the hall’s upkeep and cleanliness. During the **Zhōnghé** [Intermediate Harmony] period [881–885], bandits set it ablaze.

「During the **Tiānyòu** [Heavenly Assistance] period, **Dèng Qǐxiá** [Master Deng] rebuilt it. In the **Song** [Song Dynasty], it was renamed **Chóngxǐ Guān** [Hall of Venerable Auspiciousness], but was again destroyed by fire in the **Jiàn’án** [Rebuilt Peace] era.

**Qín Xī** [Master Qin] reconstructed it once more, and **Emperor Ningzong** [of Song] bestowed upon it the names **Gāoshì Yìrú Gāngzhǐ Táng** [Hall of the High Virtue of Just Repose, named after Master Yang] and **Fāngzhàng** [Square Measure], both inscribed by imperial decree. **Emperor Lizong** [of Song] later inscribed the characters **Yùqì Níngrùn** [Jade Qi Congealing] and **Hèqíng Chāoliáo** [Crane Emotion Ascending the Liao], and also bestowed the **Bǎozhū Lín** [Jewel Bamboo Grove] inscription upon **Sìtú Shī Tǎn** [Master Shi Tan of the Temple].

In the **Dà Yuán** [Great Yuan] [Mongol] period:
In the **Yányòu** [延佑] 6th year [1319], it was decreed to change its name to an official title.

**Yùchén Guān** [Jade Dawn Hall], located north of **Léipíng Shān** [Leiping Mountain], was where **Zhǎnshàng Gōng** [Lord of the Upper Court], **Zhōu Yǒu** [Master Zhou], **Guō Sì** [Master Guo of the Four Dynasties], **Jiāng Shūmào** [Lord Jiang, Master Maie of the Chángshāo River], **Yáng Zhēnrén** [Master Yang], **Xǔ Zhǎngshǐ** [Master Xu, the Chief Clerk] and his son attained the **Dao** [Way]. During the **Song Tàishǐ** [Song Taishi] period, the Daoist **Wáng Jǔ** [Master Wang] was highly regarded by **Jǐngwáng Yǎ** [Prince Jing of Chángshā, the Wise], and thus established the **Chángshāo** [Long Shao] retreat in the residence of the Chief Clerk.

In the **Liáng Tiānjiàn** [Liang Tianjian] 13th year [514], it was decreed to move it to **Júyáng** [Juyang] and name it **Júyáng** [Juyang] retreat, where **Táo Zhēnrén** [Master Tao] resided. A **Zhāozhēn Tái** [Platform of Illustrious Virtue] was erected to enshrine the true traces, scriptures, and edicts of **Yáng, Xǔ** [Masters Yang and Xu], and the three **Zhēnrén** [True Persons].

In the **Táng** [Tang Dynasty], **Emperor Taizong** [of Tang] built the **Huáyáng Guān** [Hua yang Hall] for **Tóngwú Xiansheng** [Master Mr. Tong of the Willow Grove]. In the **Tiānbǎo** [Heavenly Treasure] 7th year [748], **Emperor Xuánzong** [of Tang] decreed to change it into **Zǐyáng Guān** [Purple Yang Hall] for **Xuánjìng Xiansheng** [Master Mr. Xuán of Mysterious Tranquility]. It was then decreed to take two hundred households of nearby commoners, exempting them from rent and corvée labor, and permanently assigning them to maintain the hall’s upkeep and protection. **Wáng Zhēnshù** [Master Wang of the Pure and Substantial] of **Nán Táng** [Southern Tang] later resided there.

In the **Song Dàzhōng Xiángfú** [Song Dazhong Xiangfu] 1st year [1008], it was renamed **Yùchén Guān** [Jade Dawn Hall]. **Dìnglù Jūn** [Lord Dinglu] said: "This is the land marked for a tranquil retreat, the very site where the **Xuánjìng** [Mysterious Tranquility] retreat once stood. If it were not for the **Xuánjìng Xiansheng** [Master Xu of Mysterious Tranquility] and his son, how could this place have been preserved?" He added, "Future generations will have virtuous descendants who will reside here—this is indeed a blessed land." He further declared, "This is the very auspicious land of **Jīnlíng** [Jinling]."

**Chóngshòu Guān** [Hall of Venerable Longevity], located beneath **Dà Máocāng Shān** [Great Teased Mountain], south of **Huáyáng Dòng** [Hua yang Cave], and before the **Biànmén** [Convenient Gate], was the former residence of **Jìn Zhēnrén Rén Dūn** [Master Ren Dun of the Jin Dynasty]. In the **Song Yuánjiā** [Song Yuanjia] 11th year [434], **Lù Tàihòu** [Lady Lu] began constructing the hall. During the **Tàishǐ** [Taishi] period, **Kǒng Suìzhī** [Master Kong of the Lu country], the governor of **Lúlíng** [Luling], rebuilt it, and provided sustenance for the Daoist **Huà Wénxián** [Master Hua of the Wen clan, the Virtuous and Exalted] from **Qǔ’ē** [Master Qu of the E clan].

In the **Qí Jiànyuán** [Qi Jianyuan] 2nd year [478], it was decreed to establish the **Chóngyuán** [Venerable Source] retreat, with the **Tàizǐ** [Crown Prince] and **Emperor Wǔdì** [of Qi] visiting in person. **Wáng Wénqīng** [Master Wang of the Pure and Clear], the host, arranged the halls and chambers, which were most fitting and harmonious.

In the early years of the **Táng** [Tang Dynasty], **Zhēnguān** [Zhenguan], it was renamed **Chóngyuán Guān** [Hall of Venerable Source]. In the **Tiānbǎo** [Heavenly Treasure] 7th year [748], **Xuánjìng Xiansheng** [Master Xuán of Mysterious Tranquility] urged its reconstruction, and again took one hundred households of nearby commoners, exempting them from rent and corvée labor, and permanently assigning them to maintain and protect the hall. In the **Song Dàzhōng Xiángfú** [Song Dazhong Xiangfu] 7th year [1014], it was decreed to bestow its current name.

**Dìnglù Jūn** [Lord Dinglu] said: "Even beneath **Dà Máocāng Shān** [Great Teased Mountain], there is a spring, and beneath it, one may establish a tranquil retreat. Near the spring’s mouth is where one should reside." **Yǐnjū** [Master Tao] noted, "In the present age, there are those who reside near the southern entrance of **Dàdòng** [Great Cave], where the water flows well but is rocky. The terrain quickly becomes level, and this has been the case for generations."

In the early years of the **Qí** [Qi Dynasty], **Wáng Wénqīng** [Master Wang of the Pure and Clear], a man from **Jùróng** [Master Ju of the Rong clan], established a retreat here, naming it **Chóngyuán** [Venerable Source], which is this very hall. There is a stele from the **Táng Tàijí** [Tang Taiji] 1st year [617], inscribed by **Zhuōyú Sūn Chǔxuán** [Mr. Sun of the Zhuo clan, the Left Censor], with **Yáng Yōu** [Master Yang] writing the **Jīng** [Scripture] and the remaining characters indistinct and unrecognizable. In the **Yuán Táidìng** [Yuan Taiding] 1st year [1324], **Yùjí** [Master Yu], the director of the **Guózǐ** [National Students], rewrote the inscription, which was carved in regular script on the reverse side of the **Tàijí** [Taiji] stele.

**Xiàpō Guōng** [Retreat of the Lower Bank], located west of **Zhōng Máocāng** [Middle Teased Mountain], was where **Dà Sīmìng Jūn** [Lord of the Great Command] ascended from **Xiànyáng** [Xianyang] during the **Hàn Dì Jiē** [Han Di Jie] 3rd year [230] to meet his two younger brothers, **Chǔ** [Master Chu] and **Yǔ** [Master Yu]. **Yǐnjū** [Master Tao] noted, "The elders of the region passed down the tale that in the northwest level ground of **Dà Máocāng Shān** [Great Teased Mountain], among the **tánglǐ** [Tangli] trees, there was a place named **Xiàpō Chù** [Lower Bank Dwelling], which was said to be the former residence of the **Sīmìng Jūn** [Lord of the Command]."

In the **Táng Zhēnguān** [Tang Zhenguan] 11th year [637], a stele was rebuilt there, inscribed by **Huáng Xiansheng** [Master Huang] of **Táoyuán** [Peach Grove] and calligraphied by **Lú Shǐjūn** [Master Lu, the Official] of **Hézhōu** [Hezhou]. The current inscription is not the original; it was written by **Wáng Gōng Wěi** [Master Wang, the Duke], who once served as the **Táng Yùshì Dàfū** [Tang Grand Master of the Palace], and this is the record of his work.»

The **Huáyáng Gōng** [Huayang Palace] stands on the western slope of **Jījīn Shān** [Accumulated Gold Mountain]. The **Yǐnjū Shàngguǎn** [Secluded Upper Hall] was where, in the seventh month of the **Tiānbǎo** [Sky Treasure] 7th year [748], Emperor Xuánzōng received the *Shàngqīng Jīnglù* [Upper Clarity Scripture Record] from Master Xuánjìng and encouraged Daoist priests to burn incense in devotion. The hall was later destroyed by war. During the **Sòng Zhènghé** [Song Zhenghe] era, Daoist **Zhuāngshènzhì** [Solemn and Reverent] rebuilt it. The **Yǐnjū Dānjǐng** [Secluded Dan Well] and **lóujī** [pavilion foundations] remain there.

The **Quányuán Guàn** [Complete Record Hall] bears this inscription from **Dìnglù Jūn** [Lord of the Record], who said: Beneath **Dàhéng Shān** [Great Horizontal Mountain] lies a spring. Long ago, **Lǐ Míng** [Master Li] refined immortal elixir here and ascended to **Xuánzhōu** [Mysterious Isle]. In the **Tiānjiàn** [Heavenly Governance] 14th year [423], the recluse **Bìyù Gāng** [Obsidian Jade Ridge] built a retreat to follow the traces of Xuánzhou. During the **Tiānbǎo** era, Master Xuánjìng resided there, erecting the **Qízhen Táng** [Abiding-in-Truth Hall] and five pavilions: **Huìzhēn** [Gathering Truth], **Hòuxiān** [Awaiting Immortality], **Dàodé** [Dao Virtue], **Yíng’ēn** [Receiving Grace], and **Bàibiǎo** [Kneeling in Reverence]. In the **Dàzhōng Xiángfú** [Great Harmony Auspicious] 2nd year [1014], Master Guànmiào constructed a nine-tiered platform for Dao practice. In the **Tiānsèng** [Heavenly Veneration] 3rd year [1025], it was renamed **Jíxū’ān** [Gathering Void Hermitage], later restored to its current name.

The **Yàn Dòng Gōng** [Swallow Cave Palace] is at **Yànkǒu Dòng** [Swallow Mouth Cave]. A female immortal, **Qián Miàozhēn** [Money Miao True], vanished here, and a shrine was erected in her honor. A stele by **Liáng Shàolíng Wáng** [Liang Prince of Shaoling] no longer exists. In **Tiānbǎo** 7th year [748], the palace was granted its name, and three female Daoists were ordained to tend the incense. In **Yuányòu Jiǎchén** [Elemental Revival, Year of the Dragon] [1084], it was burned by wildfires and relocated to **Jùróng Xiàn** [Jurong County]. In **Shàoxīng** [Sovereign Peace] 20th year [1150], it was rebuilt on its original site in the west of **Zhōngmáo** [Central Teased], adjacent to the **Hèmiào** [Crane Temple].

In **Tiānbǎo** 7th year [748], a **jìngshè** [pure dwelling] was established beneath the temple, where Daoists were ordained and incense burned in honor of the **Sānmáo Jūn** [Three Teased Lords] and the Daoist patriarchs. A stele by **Túntián Yuànwàiláng Liù Shí** [Grain Field Outer Official Liu Shi] is now lost.

The **Huáyáng Guàn** [Huayang Hall] was the former residence of the **Liáng Zhāomíng Tàizǐ** [Liang Prince of Illuminating Clarity], once called **Hóngxǐ Yuàn** [Auspicious Felicity Hall] and **Fúxiāng Guǎn** [Felicity Village Lodge], located west of **Chóngshòu Guàn** [Longevity Nurturing Hall]. In the **Bǎolì** [Treasure History] 2nd year [826], it was granted imperial patronage and renamed **Bǎolì Chóngyuán Shèngzǔ Yuàn** [Treasure History Nurturing Origin Sacred Ancestor Hall]. At the time, **Zànhuáng Lǐ Déyù** [Li Deyu of Zhanhuang] enshrined statues of **Lǎozǐ** [Old Master], **Kǒngzǐ** [Confucius], and **Yín Zhēnrén** [Immortal Yin], and venerated **Tàixuān Zhōu Shī** [Master Zhou of Supreme Mystery] here. During the **Zhìpíng** [Political Peace] era, it was renamed **Hóngxǐ Guàn** [Auspicious Felicity Hall]. In **Xuānhé** [Extended Harmony], it received its current name.

The **Tiānsèng Guàn** [Heavenly Veneration Hall] is atop **Jījīn Shān** [Accumulated Gold Mountain]. In the early **Tiānjiàn** [Heavenly Governance] era, the recluse **Bì** [Obsidian] cultivated at **Xiǎozhǎo** [Small Marsh], nurturing a dragon child in the **Léipíng Chí** [Thunder Calm Pool]. During the **Zhēnguān** [Zhenguan] era, **Wáng Fǎzhǔ** [Master Wang, the Law Holder] resided here and encountered the immortal **Fǎběn Xiānrén** [Master Faben]. In the **Sùzōng Zhìdé** [Suzong Rectified Virtue] era, it was granted the name **Huǒyuàn Gōng** [Fire Hall Palace]. By the end of the Tang, it fell into ruin. In **Jìngdé** [Jingde] 3rd year [1006], Master **Míngzhēn Zhāng Shàoyīng** [Illuminating Truth Zhang Shaoying] rebuilt it. Mingzhen, along with **Zhū Guànmiào** [Master Zhu of Illuminating Mystery], were the two transmitters of the **Míngsù Tàihòu** [Illuminating Lineage Grand Empress]. In the 9th month of **Tiānsèng** 3rd year [1025], his residence was granted the name **Yánzhēn’ān** [Extending Truth Hermitage], and in the 5th year [1027], it was renamed **Qízhen Guàn** [Abiding-in-Truth Hall], located west of **Huáyáng Gōng** [Huayang Palace].

The **Yǐnjū Zhōngguǎn** [Secluded Middle Hall] was the residence of **Huáyuán Huáng Zūnshī** [Revered Master Huang of Peach Grove], with a stele inscribed by **Hézhōu Lú Shìmóu** [Lu Simou of Hezhou], now lost. During the **Xuānhé** era, it was granted its name.

The **Wǔyún Guàn** [Five Clouds Hall] is beneath **Wǔyún Fēng** [Five Cloud Peak]. Built during the **Tiānsèng** era, it was later granted its name after **Chéngxiàng Wáng Gōng Qǐnrú** [Chancellor Wang Qinru] passed away. **Xǔ Guó Fūrén** [Lady Xu of the State] petitioned the court to establish it as his resting place, and **Yàn Yuánxiàn Gōng** [Yan Yuanxian, Duke of Yuan] inscribed the stele.

The **Qīngzhēn Guàn** [Pure Truth Hall] is at **Dàluó Yuán** [Great Luo Spring]. During the **Zhènghé** era, the Daoist **Hàodé Qīng** [Virtuous Virtue Qing] built a hermitage to welcome wandering Daoists. Emperor **Huízōng** granted it the name **Guàn** [Hall]. Every year on the 18th day of the 3rd month, Daoists from afar gather to pay homage to the **Máo Jūn** [Teased Lord]. During the rituals, white cranes often soar overhead, giving rise to the legend of the **Hèhuì** [Crane Assembly].

The **Bái’yún Chóngfú Guàn** [White Cloud Nurturing Virtue Hall] is beneath **Bái’yún Fēng** [White Cloud Peak]. **Bìyáng Gōng Zhīgōng Wáng Jǐngwēn** [Palace Official Wang Jingwen of Biyang] retired here. Jingwen gained renown at the **Déshòu Gōng** [Longevity Nurturing Palace], and the hall was granted its name. He was later promoted through Daoist ranks, serving four successive courts. During the reign of **Níngzōng’s** [Ningzong] grandson, he received ordination and, upon ascending the throne, was granted the title **Xūjìng Zhēnrén** [Void Stillness Immortal]. **Dài Xī Xuéshì** [Scholar Dai of Dai Stream] composed the hall’s record.

The **Níngshén’ān** [Concentrated Spirit Hermitage] is in **Hēihǔ Gǔ** [Black Tiger Valley]. In **Shàoxīng Gēngwǔ** [Sovereign Peace, Year of the Monkey] [1140], the shrine and Daoist priests were rebuilt by **Zhāng Zhànglíng** [Zhang Zhangling], formerly named **Féngdào** [Encountering Dao]. Emperor **Gāozōng** annually sent envoys to offer incense in the mountains. In the **Yǐhài** year [1149], Zhang’s Daoist name reached the emperor, and he was repeatedly summoned to the **Déshòu Diàn** [Longevity Nurturing Hall], receiving gifts of a **móxiù bèi** [embroidered robe], **shuǐjīng huán** [jade ring], **zǐshí chá** [purple stone mortar], imperial calligraphy of the **Yīnfú** [Dark Secret] and **Qīngjìng** [Pure Stillness] scriptures, and an order to have his likeness painted in the **Shénxiān Gé** [Immortal Gallery].

The **Shēngyuán Guàn** [Ascending Source Hall], formerly the **Báiè Miào** [White Crane Temple], is a dedicated shrine to **Sīmìng Zhēnjūn** [True Lord of Command], located west of **Zhōngmáo** [Central Teased]. During the **Tiānbǎo** era, its halls were repaired, Daoists were ordained, and incense burned in accordance with the **Qǐdiǎn** [Sacrificial Rites]. In **Zhènghé** 8th year [1118], the governor of **Jiànkāng** [Jiankang], **Yú Zhuō** [Yu Zhuo], petitioned for its current name. In **Jiànyán** 3rd year [1129], it was burned by bandits. In **Shàoxīng** 14th year [1144], the Daoist **Máo Zōngbái** [Mao Zongbai] rebuilt it south of its original site.

「Liu Zhìxiào [Liu Zhi Xiao] three times encountered the spirit peach tree at its place, the events recorded in the *Cǎizhēn Yóu* [Adventures of the Transcendent Sage]. The **Bàoyuán Guàn** [Embracing the Source Hall], located above the **Liǔjì Quán** [Willow Rescue Spring], was in the **Zhènghé** 8th year [1118] when **Chén Xīwēi** [Chen Xiwei] of **Gūsū** [Gusu] followed **Liu Xiānsheng** [Master Liu] in Daoist practice and resided there. Later, the **Liǔgǔ Àn** [Willow Valley Hermitage] urged its transformation into a hall.

The **Yuányáng Guàn** [Primordial Sun Hall], an ancient hall, appears in **Gù Kuàng** [Gu Kuang]'s poetry:
*"For ten years I’ve wandered this hall,
For a thousand miles I’ve lodged in this room.
Returning to the old window below,
I take your verse again to read."*

The current hall stands above **Máo Dòng** [Mao Cave]. At the beginning of the **Lóngxīng** era [1163], the Daoist **Hàoxīng Dàorén** [Shen Shen of Bright Dawn], **Shěn Shànzhì** [Shen Shanzhi], dwelled in a cave, calling himself the **Dòngzhǔ** [Cave Master]. He met **Xīn Wáng** [Fire King] **Hán Fūrén** [Lady Han], who commissioned him to construct the hall’s buildings. Initially named **Chōngxū Àn** [Piercing the Void Hermitage], its name was later changed to **Guàn** [Hall] during the **Qìngyuán** era [1195–1200].

The **Cángzhēn Guàn** [Treasure of the True Hall], a serene shrine to **Jìngyī Liú Zōngshī** [Master Liu of Pure Unity], is located at **Diéyù Fēng** [Stacked Jade Peak]. In the **Dàguān** [Great Hall] era, its construction was completed.

The **Zǐyáng Guàn** [Purple Yang Hall], formerly known as **Dòngyún Àn** [Cave Cloud Hermitage], was during the **Jiànyán** era [1127–1130] when a Daoist from **Bó Zhōu** [Bo Prefecture] in **Héběi** [Northern Rivers], **Wáng Ruòníng** [Wang Ruoning], came to the mountains and lived alone beneath the **Dīnggōng Shān** [Ding Gong Mountain] **Shùyán** [Bundle Rock]. One night, he dreamed of a divine person pointing to a cave and saying: *"This is the place where the spirits of Dengzhou [a netherworldly region] interrogate the dead. You may dwell here, a hundred paces from the cave."* Upon **Qín Qiè** [Qin Qie]'s demise, **Fūrén Wáng Shì** [Lady Wang], a woman of pure virtue, visited **Jìngzhēn** [Settled Sage] **Liú Zōngshī** [Master Liu] and begged for a written petition, learning that **Qín Qiè** was imprisoned within **Dēngshān** [Deng Mountain]. **Wáng** [Wang] then ordered his son to build a **Tàiyǐ Diàn** [Great Unity Hall] at the cave’s entrance to seek a posthumous pardon. The **mò** [incense burner] and **shí** [stone tablet] he offered remain preserved there.

In the **Dà Yuán** [Great Yuan] **Tìyuán** era [1264–1294], specifically the **Gǔwǔ** year [1273], an imperial decree established it as a **Guàn** [Hall], retaining its ancient name.»

「The **Chóngyuán Guàn** [Hall of Exalted Benevolence], at the end of the **Shàoxīng** era [1131–1162], was founded by **Shí Xiānsheng** [Master Shi] of **Tóngchuān** [Tongchuan], named **Yuánpǔ** [Original Simplicity], who studied the **Dao** from **Yáng Yíjiǎ** [Yang Yijia]. He resided at the **Chángníng** [Constant Peace] **Yǎn** [Hermitage] on the southern slope of **Nánzhèn** [Southern Garrison], practicing medicine to benefit others. Daily, he would recognize one **cǎo lǚ** [straw sandal] and ten coins from passersby, hanging them on a tree outside his door so that travelers might take them freely, regardless of season. He lived to eighty-eight years old and departed without illness.

**Liú Zhài** [Master Liu] of **Màntáng** [Mantang] composed a eulogy for him.

In the **Dà Yuán** [Great Yuan] **Yuanfù** era [1294–1307], specifically the **Bīngzǐ** year [1306], an imperial decree granted the hall its ancient name, and his disciples thereafter maintained the **yàoshì** [pharmacy hall].

The **Shèngyòu Guàn** [Hall of Sacred Benevolence] stands atop **Dàmáo Shān** [Great Mao Mountain]. In the **Yányòu** era [1201–1208], particularly the **Sānnián** [Third Year, 1205], an imperial edict bestowed its name and elevated its seal to **Dàjūn Zhēnyìng Zhēnjūn** [Great Lord, Manifest Response, True Lord].

The **Déyòu Guàn** [Hall of Virtuous Benevolence] is atop **Zhōngmáo Shān** [Middle Mao Mountain]. As above, an imperial edict granted its name and elevated its seal to **Zhōngjūn Miàoyìng Zhēnjūn** [Middle Lord, Marvelous Response, True Lord].

The **Rényòu Guàn** [Hall of Benevolent Grace] is atop **Xiǎomáo Shān** [Lesser Mao Mountain]. As above, an imperial edict granted its name and elevated its seal to **Xiǎojūn Shényìng Zhēnjūn** [Lesser Lord, Divine Response, True Lord].

The *Tàiyuān Nèichuán* [Inner Transmission of the Great Yuan] records that in the **Yǒngmíng** era [58–75] of the **Hàn** [Han] **Míngdì** [Emperor Ming], the **Jìng** [Effort] **Jùn** [District] **Xiàn** [County] constructed a temple for the **Jūqū** [Jucur] **Zhēnrén** [True Person] of **Dānyáng** [Danyang]. *Yǐnjū* [Hidden Residence] states: "This temple still exists today." The villages of **Shūmóu** [Shumou] and **Liúxī** [Liuxi], along with others, each built their own temples. The **Hàoxū** [Hao Xu] Temple was located on the western side of **Dàmáo** [Great Mao], and the **Shùxū** [Shu Xu] Temple stood below the rear mountain of **Zhōngmáo** [Middle Mao]; both are now abandoned.

Only the **Shēngyuán Guàn** [Hall of Ascended Benevolence], originally named **Hèmiào** [Crane Temple], resides above the **cíyǔ** [ancestral hall], at **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] **Wèn** [Question], when it was rebuilt by imperial decree. A radiant **Dān** [Dan] light appeared at its foundation.

The **Dàoshì** [Daoist] **Lǚ Yún** [Lu Yun] inscribed its records, though they are now lost.

The **Guǎngjì** [Broad Benevolence] Temple, also known as **Tiānshèng Guàn** [Hall of Heavenly Saint] and **Lóngcí** [Dragon Shrine], was renamed in the **Shàoxīng** era [1131–1162] with the titles **Chúnxī** [Pure Heir] and **Chúnyòu** [Pure Benevolence], and three times elevated the **Shénlóng** [Divine Dragon] to **Fūzé Guǎngyìng Lìjì Zhēnjūn** [Benevolent Sower, Broad Response, Graceful Aid, True Lord].

The **Yuánfú** [Yuanfu] Temple and **Yuánfú Gōng** [Yuanfu Palace] were established in the **Yuánfú** era [1098–1100], with the **Shén** [Divine] **Yuánfú** [Yuanfu] enshrined as **Hùshèng Zhēnjūn** [True Lord, Protective Benevolence], and the **Yuánfú Gōng** [Yuanfu Palace] **Èrshǐzhě** [Two Envoys] enshrined as **Língyòu Línghù Zhēnjūn** [True Lord, Spiritual Aid, Soul Protector]. The records are detailed in the *Sòngshǐ* [History of Song].

The **Máo Shìtú Mìào** [Temple of Mao, the Grand Marshal] is located within the **Qiányuán Guàn** [Hall of Primordial Benevolence]. It faces the **Jiāngbā Lù** [Jiangba Road] to the south. In ancient times, a man suffering from illness lay at the roadside. In the dead of night, a guide arrived on horseback, demanding his name. The man confessed his ailment, and the horseman gave him a pill, saying: "I am **Máo Shìtú** [Mao, the Grand Marshal]." By dawn, his illness was cured, and he built a temple at the site. The account is found in *Qǐshén Lù* [Records of Divine Inquiry].

There is also a shrine one *lǐ* [li] outside the **Shūmén** [Shumen] gate of **Jiànkāng** [Jiankang, modern Nanjing].

The *Máoshān Zhì* [Gazetteer of Maoshan], **Juàn** [Volume] **Shíqī** [Seventeenth], concludes with the note: "The previous text has 『Féng』 [Encounter] instead of 『Dá』 [Reach]."

The *Máoshān Zhì*, **Juàn** [Volume] **Shíbā** [Eighteenth], records the **Shòuqīng** [Successive Sage] **Zhēnjūnshī** [Master of the True Lord] **Liú Dàbīn** [Liu Dabin] constructing the **Shàngqīng** [Upper Clarity] Temple.»

The **Lóuguān** [Louguan] section—**Mountain Lodges and Hermitages**

The **Xù Chángshǐ** [Xu Changshi’s] residence, now **Yùchén Guān** [Yuchen Observatory]. The *Yǐnjū* [Hidden Residence] states: *"After Xu Changshi’s residence fell into ruin, no one knew its location."* During the reign of **Jìngwáng** [King Jing] of **Chángshā** [Changsha], **Tántàifēi** [Tan Taifei, the dowager] sponsored the Daoist **Chén** [Chen], who established a response at **Léipíng** [Leiping]’s northwest—this was also where **Běichá** [North察] was located. Later, **Wénqīng** [Wenqing] **Wáng** [Wang] of **Jùróng** [Jurong] became the patron of those afflicted with **xiàn** [癣, ringworm], as recorded in his biography. It was known that Xu Changshi had settled here, and through inquiries among the elders, by the **Dàmíng** [Daming] era of the seventh year (1423), an old villager named **Xúǒu** [Xu Ou] recalled that his ancestors had served Xu Changshi and knew of this residence. I have also seen the **Chángshǐ jǐng** [Changshi’s well] within.

The **Língbǎo Yuàn** [Lingbao Abbey], located at the former site of **Yǐnjū Zhāozhēn Tái** [Hidden Residence’s Zhaozhen Terrace] beneath **Yùchén Guān** [Yuchen Observatory]. During the **Táng** [Tang], the masters **Sūn Zhìqīng** [Sun Zhiqing] and **Wáng Qíxiá** [Wang Qixia] rebuilt it, enshrining the image of the **Língbǎo Tiānzūn** [Lingbao Heavenly Venerable]. The plaque reads *"Língbǎo"* [Lingbao]. Within, there is also an ancient **Lǎojūn** [Laojun, Laozi] image of divine auspice. Originally erected by **Xuánjìng Xiānshēng** [Xuanjing Master], during the **Gāozǔ** [High Ancestor, Emperor Taizong of Song]’s reign, **Lǎojūn** [Laojun] repeatedly descended upon **Yángjiǎo Shān** [Yangjiao Mountain] in **Jìnzhōu** [Jinzhou]. A request was made to enshrine his image, and in the **Dàguān** [Daguan] era, fourth month of the third year (1109), **Liáng Wùzhēn** [Liang Wuzhen], a Daoist of **Yùchén** [Yuchen], drew water from the **Zhōuzhēn rén chí** [Zhouzhen Person’s Pond] before the hall—this was the **Zhōu Zhēnrén** [Zhou Zhenren’s] pond. Suddenly, a **zǐyīn** [紫姻, purple mist] enveloped him, and within it, he saw **Lǎojūn** [Laojun] riding a white horse, bestowing upon him the *Tiāndóng Jīng* [Tiantong Scripture]. Liang, though simple and unlearned, thereafter neither ate nor recited scriptures, and his words on others’ fortunes and misfortunes proved accurate. The *Tiāndóng Jīng* [Tiantong Scripture] was later inscribed on stone and transmitted.

The **Ruòshān Àn** [Ruoshan Hermitage], located east of **Guō Gāntáng** [Guo Gantang]. **Ruòshān** [Ruoshan] was, during the **Kāiyuán** [Kaiyuan] era of the **Táng** [Tang], the **Rùnzhōu** [Runzhou] prefect, who abandoned office and came to the mountain, later residing at **Tàihú Bāoshān** [Taihu Baoshan]. Today, a ruined stele remains in the forest.

The **Yóuzūn Shī Àn** [Youzun Master’s Hermitage], located south of **Bāguà Tái** [Bagua Terrace], a few dozen steps away. The master’s name is unknown, nor is it known when he resided here. Layered tiles formed its walls, and a stone mortar was carved from rock—its space barely exceeding a *zhàng* [丈, ~3 meters] in length and width. The remnants of his **áo** [鳌, turtle] still linger, long obscured by overgrowth. During the **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] era of **Chén Shàngshū** [Chen Shangshu], the hermitage was rebuilt, revealing it once more.

**Gù Zhùzuò Shānfáng** [Gu Zuzuo’s Mountain Lodge], situated atop **Jǔpú Tán** [Jupu Pond]’s **Shímò Chí** [Stone Ink Pool]. **Gù Qiào** [Gu Qiao], who styled himself **Huàyáng Zhēnyì** [Huayang True Hermit], was the author of the *Jiāoshān Zuòhè Míng* [Seat Crane Inscription of Jiaoshan]. Qiao served as **Kànqiú Guān** [Kanqiu Official] under **Hán Qiào** [Han Qiao], later holding posts as **Jiāngnán Jùnshèng** [Jiangnan Circuit Inspector], **Jiàoshū Láng** [Jiaoshu Clerk], and **Zhuózùo Láng** [Zhuozuo Clerk]. After years of neglect, he abandoned worldly affairs and built a dwelling in the mountains. His son, **Fēixióng** [Feixiong], passed the **Jìnshì** [Jinshi, advanced scholar] examination and successively served in various prefectural offices. During the **Dàzhōng** [Dazhong] era, he held the post of **Yùyí Bùmù** [Yuyi Bureau Clerk].

The **Qín Xì Shānfáng** [Qin Xi’s Mountain Lodge], located beside **Shímò Chí** [Stone Ink Pool]. According to the *Yúdì Xún* [Yudi Seeking], **Qín Xì** [Qin Xi], a **Táng** [Tang] scholar, carved a **yàn** [研, inkstone] from stone to annotate the *Dàodé Jīng* [Dao De Jing]. The *Yǐnyì Zhuàn* [Hidden Retirees’ Biography] also records him as a native of **Kuàijī** [Kuaiji, modern Shaoxing], skilled in poetry. **Quán Déyǔ** [Quan Deyu] remarked: *"Liú Zhǎngqīng* [Liu Zhangqing] called himself the ‘long wall of *wǔyán* [五言, quintain verse],’ and I, with my inferior forces, though aged, still press onward."* During the **Sòng** [Song], **Qíqiū Shānfáng** [Qiqiu Mountain Lodge] was built atop **Hǎiyǎn Quán** [Haiyan Spring]. The lodges of **Zhèng Shàngshū** [Zheng Shangshu], **Péi Tàishī** [Pei Taishi], and **Yáng Shàngshū** [Yang Shangshu] were also near **Hǎiyǎn Quán** [Haiyan Spring]. The lodges of **Zhào Shūjì** [Zhao Shuji], **Yáng Shìláng** [Yang Shilang], and **Zhōu Shìláng** [Zhou Shilang] were all in the southwest of **Zhōng Máo** [Zhong Mao]. The lodges of **Lǐ Shìláng** [Li Shilang] and **Gāo Jiàoshū** [Gao Jiaoshu] were at **Wúzhī Lǒng** [Wuzhi Ridge]. The lodges of **Liú Shìláng** [Liu Shilang] and **Péi Shìláng** [Pei Shilang] were before **Zhōng Máo** [Zhong Mao]. The lodges of **Léi Lángzhōng** [Lei Langzhong], **Zhāng Shíyú** [Zhang Shiyu], and **Hé Xiānshēng** [He Xiansheng] were on **Lóngwěi Shān** [Longwei Mountain]. The lodges of **Cuī Zhēngjūn** [Cui Zhengjun], **Yuàn Liànshī** [Yuan Lianshi], and **Wáng Liànshī** [Wang Lianshi] were on **Léipíng Shān** [Leiping Mountain]. **Cuī Dìngyán** [Cui Dingyan] composed emotional verse. The lodges of **Dòu Liànshī** [Dou Lianshi], **Hóu Xiāngū** [Hou Xiangu], **Yán Liànshī** [Yan Lianshi], **Táng Liànshī** [Tang Lianshi], and **Jīnshān Rén** [Jinshan Person] were in **Nán Dòng** [Nan Dong].

The **Sòng Zhāng Wénjiǎn Gōng Shānfáng** [Zhang Wenjian Gong’s Mountain Lodge], located in the **Shēnxiù Xuān** [Shenxiu Pavilion] of **Huàyáng Gōng** [Huayang Palace]. The master’s name was **Gāng** [Gang], who served as **Cánzhī Zhèngshì** [Chanzhi Chancellor] during the **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] era. He read in the mountains and compiled the *Huàyáng Lǎorén Jí* [Huayang Laoren Collection] in forty volumes.

The **Qíyún Àn** [Qiyun Hermitage], located in **Zhōng Máo** [Zhong Mao], west of **Xiǎo Máo** [Xiao Mao] and above **Yùshā Quán** [Yusha Spring], was the residence of **Liú Shāyī Xiānshēng** [Liu Shayi Master].

The **Tiānxìn Àn** [Tianxin Hermitage], located beneath **Sōulún Fēng** [Soulun Peak], was the residence of **Yáng Zhíjiǎ Xiānshēng** [Yang Zhiya Master].

The **Dòngyáng Guàn** [Dongyang Pavilion], located west of **Huàyáng Guān** [Huayang Observatory] in **Nán Dòng** [Nan Dong]. During the **Zhènghé** [Zhenghe] era, it was rebuilt by **Yánkāng Dàxiànshì Wáng Gōng Hàn** [Yankang Grand Academy Master Wang Gong Han], who sponsored the recluse **Shěn Zǐzhōu** [Shen Zizhou] and refined elixirs there.

The **Yuánxǐ Àn** [Yuanxi Hermitage], established during the **Shàoxīng** [Shaoxing] era by the **Pílíng** [Piling] Daoist **Yú Huìcōng** [Yu Huicong]. Huicong practiced **péngtóu kǔxíng** [蓬头苦行, ascetic austerity], first dwelling at **Dàluó Yuán** [Daluo Spring], weaving two **cǎoxié** [草屦, straw sandals] daily to exchange for grain. Each evening, he knelt in prayer to the **Dòu** [斗, Big Dipper].

A certain night, he was moved by a black tiger lying at his side. Emperor Gaozong, hearing of his fame, summoned him to the De Shou Palace, bestowing upon him abstinence rice and saying, *"This rustic has no use—let him remain for military provisions."* The emperor smiled and released him back to the mountains, whereupon he relocated to the front of Longwei Mountain.

**East Tianning Temple**, located in Danyang County, Zhenjiang.
**West Tianning Temple**, located in Jurong County, Jiankang—both part of the Yuanfu Estate, granted the name by imperial decree in the fifth year of Chongning.

**Qi Bai An**, built by the scholar-official Qin Qiao of Huawen Ge, overseen by Zhang Dongyuan during the Yuanfu era, situated on Dinggong Mountain, where the cliffs are exquisitely steep.

**Xuanzhou Jing She**, atop Hetai Ravine. In the Zhiyuan era of the Great Yuan, established by Master Jiang Zongshi of Yuhai. The hall still stands on Yugang Ridge, an ancient name.

In the **Rénshù** year of **Zhìzhèng** (1323), Master Liu Zongshi requested permission to establish a retreat and built **Wàijìng** at the site where the Purple Pavilion Immortal’s fire was extinguished.

**Huayang Dao Yuan**, on the bundle of Jijin Mountain. Built by Master Wang Zongshi of Mu Chai during the Dade era. To its west stood a strange rock, upon which Chancellor Yuan Mingshan inscribed a stele.

**Sanmao Dao Yuan**, established by the Yuanfu Daoist Jiang Dagui during the Dade era.
