**Records of Gold and Stone: Song Stele #1 *Imperial Composition of the Ode to the Dragon with Preface***

The *Mao Mountain Records* [茅山志] states:
*"The Thunderous Pool of the Fire Hall, the Imperial Pool of the Fire Hall—
within them dwells a small black dragon, now rarely seen.
There is also the Pool of Master Guo [郭真人池], where such dragons are always present.
These spirit-beings shift and transform, their abodes not fixed—
men sometimes capture them and bring them down from the mountain,
yet even when sealed in vessels, they vanish without trace."*

Recently, the court dispatched the imperial envoy **Ren Wencai** [任文庆] to perform **rites of exorcism and prayer** [醮祭] at the sacred peaks,
seeking blessings for the people.

**Ren Wencai** [文庆] procured one dragon and presented it,
then carried two dragons with him as he journeyed.
Midway, winds and rains arose—
indeed, one dragon was lost.

Holding the remaining dragon at the imperial gate,
he closely examined its form—
truly remarkable, so I composed this ode to record it.

**The Ode:**

*The foremost of the Four Spirits is this dragon,
whose transformations are fixed and hard to match.
The Three Teaches’ blessed land, the abode of the Dry Immortals [旱仙宅],
where spirit-forms gather in this sacred pool.

The immortals of the pool tamed it with their Dao,
yet to this day, its hidden and revealed nature remains unmeasured.

Riding the clouds, it moves alone with wondrous grace,
bringing rain and nurturing life, all through its virtue/power.
Common folk seize it, yet it flees their grasp—
once out of the mountain, where can it be found?

The imperial envoy sought it with earnest intent,
wishing to present it to the court and proclaim its auspicious signs.

At first, he carried one dragon to the **Wei Gate** [魏阙],
then, by chance, held two as he left their cavernous home.
Human hearts and dragon hearts, if in harmony, are like matching seals—
one departs, one remains—what spirit is more strange?

I beheld the true dragon and was not alarmed,
for sincere devotion pleases the dragon’s ears.
I only hope winds and rains will follow year after year,
so that granaries may overflow in every place.

In the third year of **Great Harmony and Auspicious Symbols** [大中祥符], sixth month.

The **Empress Dowager of the Song Dynasty, Heavenly Saintly and Pure**, received the *Upper Clarity Record of the Great Cavern Dao Master*, inscribed by the Purple-Granted Subject Zhu Ziying and calligraphed by the Palace Academy Attendant Meng Yingzhi under imperial decree.

In the fourth generation of the Song Dynasty’s auspicious mandate, during the third year of the Sage’s benevolent reign, the Holy Mother Empress Dowager Liu—refined essence of the Nine Spirits, nurtured by the Three Primordials—ushered in an era of radiant prosperity. With the talisman of sagely virtue in hand, she harmonized the inner realm, reverently ordering the nine clans, and extended her enlightened governance outward, refining the affairs of the people.

In moments of respite from statecraft, her mind dwelled in the void’s boundless expanse, her spirit soaring in the boundless realm. At the jade-paved hall, she brushed away the golden incense’s smoke; in the chamber of pure whiteness, she scattered fragrant blossoms. She further purified her mind and stilled her thoughts, reciting the *Huangting Erjing Sutra*, her resolve inwardly cultivated, tireless in morning and evening. Was it merely to subdue spirit and soul, aligning with the lofty words of the Sage? Or was it also to return to the roots, to nurture the virtue/power that would shelter all under heaven?

Thus, she contemplated the Three Pure Ones, mused upon the Nine Immortals, bowed to the adorned jade scepter, and admired the pendant of the Dao. The Southern Immortal appeared faintly yet with eager anticipation. The Western Mother seemed to manifest in leisurely observation. The responses of the *Pangmi* [膏沐] were revealed day by day, and the accumulated merit progressed year by year. Truly, the Dao can be learned, and the Way is not an empty pursuit.

Yet, still mindful of her own incomplete refinement, she had not yet reached the source of the Way. She heard that the **Wuzhu Yuanjun, Wei the Lady of Southern Peak**, in the year *Xingning Jiazi* of the Eastern Jin (349 CE), on the *Xiaoyou* [小有] day of the *Qingxu True Person*’s teaching by the *Xiaohao Tianwang*, received the *Upper Clarity Great Cavern Treasure Scripture* and passed it down to the *Donghua True Person* Yang Jun of Mount Mao, and later to the *Upper Clarity Dao Marshal* Xu Changshi.

Since then, the sacred lineage of the source continued, inheriting the traditions of Huayang, extending the branches of the Dao, and spreading its fragrance across the world. Now, by imperial decree, the *Zhaoying Official of the Jade Clarity* Suong Miao Dasheng Huangfu Xiji and the officials Wang, Wei, and Wen were commissioned to study the margins of Yang and Xu’s teachings. They obtained the *Upper Clarity Three-Grade Divine Scripture*, the *Jade Clarity Hidden Writings*, the *Nine Clarities’ Secrets*, the *Golden God’s Two Tigers and Eight Scenes Jade Record*, the *Imperial Ancestor’s Jade Taboo and Yuan Shi Genealogy*, the *Flowing Gold Fire Bell*, the *Returning Chariot’s Complete Dao*, the *Three Primordials’ Jade Inspection*, the *Nine Phoenix Sacred Scriptures*, the *Purple Text and White Belt*, the *Taixi Yellow Scripture*, the *Guile Palace’s Lingfei Record*—ten volumes in total—and fifteen *Golden Immortal Jade Horse Certificates*.

According to the prescribed rites, they prepared the *Golden Dragon*, *Jade Fish*, *Golden Ram*, *Silver Crow*, *Green Silk Golden Button*, *Cloud Brocade Phoenix Pattern*, *Bixia Waving Dust Silk*, *Red Seal Mortuary Silk*, the *Four Rectangular Clear Mirrors*, the *Jingzhen Sacred Sword*, the *Five-Colored Silk Upper Clarity Daoist Robes*, and all ceremonial offerings—none were omitted.

First, envoys were dispatched with secret petitions to Southern Peak, conveying the message to the Wuzhu Yuanjun. In silence, she assented to the divine intent.

Next, the **Inner Palace Attendants** Kang Congzheng and Jiang Deyong of the *Western Palace Supply Office*, along with the *Right Street Vice Dao Master* Li Zhishun—who oversaw the *Jade Clarity Zhaoying Temple* and managed the *Left and Right Street Teaching Gates*—the *Suongzhen Dasheng* Shi Zhizhang, the *Left Street Overseer* and *Shouning Guan Abbot* Mingzhen Dasheng, the *Jade Clarity Zhaoying Temple Vice Director* and *Xuanjiao Dasheng* Zhou Suiliang, the *Jade Clarity Zhaoying Temple Abbot* Suongmiao Dasheng Huangfu Xiji, and the *Co-Abbot* Suongmi Dasheng Xue Qinghe—were commissioned to present the *Blue-Worded Petition on Yellow Silk* and perform the rites in person.

At the **Chongxi Observatory of Mount Mao in Jiangning**, they constructed the *Upper Clarity Yellow Altar*, presided over the *Jade Record Dao Ritual* for seven days and nights, and conducted *360 sessions of the Great Fast* during the day. Following the rites, they held a *Three-Day Thanksgiving Dao Ritual* and a *Grand Fast for All Mountain Daoists and Female Immortals*. They also cast the *Golden Dragon Jade Tablet* and *Golden Ring Jade Fish* into the *Huayang Cave*, *Yan Cave*, and *Jinshan Water Palace*, thereby paying homage to the Seven Saints and expressing sincerity to the Nine Clarities. Thus, the rites of transmission and reception were fulfilled, and the rituals of master and disciple were complete.

On the day of the ritual’s commencement, the sacred crane descended to greet beneath the feathered canopy. As the altar was erected, the clouds gathered afar in the layered heavens. The morning dew inscribed the true scriptures, and the offerings were presented with reverent sincerity. The orchid incense burned brightly, and the jade moon gathered its light.

The hundred spirits, ordered and refined, manifested auspicious signs. The Five Peaks’ guardians stood vigilant, offering blessings. At midnight, a sacred wind swept through, and auspicious rain fell. In an instant, the Milky Way shimmered, and the stars blazed like scattered jewels. It was said that the Wind Lord swept the altar, and the Rain Master sprinkled the feast—how could it be otherwise?

When the day of transmission arrived, the radiance of the *Nine Xias* flowed like light, dazzling and concentrated. The *Three Pure Ones’* misty qi drifted ethereally in the sky. The wind gathered in awe, the rainbow banners gleamed, and the ritual movements seemed to float. All spirits stood in solemn reverence.

At the moment of dividing the golden contracts, a white crane circled above the altar, and crimson clouds swirled in the mountains. The osmanthus wind enveloped all, and the sacred fragrance permeated the wilds.

Though the myriad wonders of the Dao have many paths, learning follows an order; though the most sublime mysteries have no fixed method, responses require no delay. This demonstrates the Empress Dowager’s profound sincerity.

The talismans were reverently received, the spirits and humans aligned in harmony, and the Dao’s mysteries were fulfilled. Without the accumulated virtue of countless eons and the fruit of lifelong aspiration, who could attain this?

It is known that a good beginning ensures a beautiful end. If one plans with the Dao, what need is there for concern? Thus, the *Eight Scenes of Flying Xias* will gather in celestial feasts, the *Nine-Colored Phoenix’s Brain* and the *Ten Refined Waters* will be offered daily without end.

In reverence for the Holy Thought, the sacred texts were treated as if they were the most confidential of secrets. This was to glorify the Celestial Sovereign, to safeguard the True Master, to firmly establish the ancestral Dao for ten thousand generations, to bestow triple blessings upon the people, and to forever quell warfare, so that all might share in prosperity and longevity.

The blessings of later heaven, the boundless lineage, the distant golden lineage, and the grace bestowed upon the common folk—how fitting they are!

Observing the achievements of an age and examining the unrecorded deeds of a hundred kings, I dare to record them in plain words.

In the third year of the Tian Sheng era (2甲子 year), on the 23rd day of the fourth month (戊午朔), the 23rd day being 庚辰, this was respectfully recorded.

At the altar, the following were commended and promoted:
- Upper Clarity Great Cave Master, Minister Zhang Shaoying,
- Upper Clarity Great Cave Master, Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the Teachings of the

---

In the realm of the Daoist tradition, there are teachings of purity, tranquility, and boundless void, and doctrines of returning to the True and embracing simplicity. Later generations who took delight in its ways expanded upon these themes, thus arose the dissemination of esoteric scriptures and hidden precepts, the illumination of the Celestial Capital and Sacred Isles, the cultivation of the Three Clouds and Eight Sceneries, and the gatherings of the youthful immortals and the Broad Cold. From the august sovereigns to the humble subjects, all drew upon its transformative power, as recorded in the *Yi Zhuan*. Initially, Emperor **True宗** (Zhenzong), having laid down arms and embraced peace, devoted himself to literary and cultural pursuits, ascending Mount Tai, offering tribute to the Earthly Sovereign, visiting the Celestial Precincts, and erecting the Sacred Hall, striving to unify the imperial rites and emulate the grandeur of former dynasties.

At this time, the Master held the weighty office of **Grand Marshal and Chancellor**, enjoying the highest favor of the winds and clouds. Alongside a few senior statesmen and eminent scholars, he both adorned the imperial designs within and deliberated on scriptures and rites without. Employing the **elixir of refinement** and the **award of inner nourishment**, he relied on precedent to establish his course and aligned with the humility of the Dao to ensure his decrees were carried out.

When it came to inspecting the jade tokens of the sacred mounds, sitting upon the tapestry mats of the **Sui** (Zui) region, patrolling the nearby prefectures, and presiding over the grand altars for ritual offerings, all adhered to the secret records, and his diligence shone forth. He led the **Three Caverns** rites before the Eight Palanquins set out, and also took part in the ceremonial escort.

In the year of the **Tiger (丙寅)**, he received celestial blessings, revering and honoring ancestral achievements. The Five Sacred Mountains were elevated in title, the numinous springs bore their fruits, and the sacred precincts were expanded in splendor, the hallowed legacy made manifest. The Master was again entrusted with the role of **Imperial Envoy**.

He gathered the **Sacred Hair** (Hao) attendants and the **abundant scriptures**, selecting the **mirror of ages** from the past and the **rectangular measure** of the future, and was once more commissioned to oversee them.

With the **mysterious and primordial laws** of Dao, he contributed to the harmonious gatherings, encompassing the essence of lofty peaks and the flow of imperial prosperity. Encountering the flourishing era of the **Sacred Reign**, he obtained the sequence of discussions, and thus selected those scholars who were well-versed in its teachings, examining and rectifying them with meticulous care. The treasures hidden in the **Sacred Mountains and Caverns**, the **golden tablets and jade scriptures**, were all subject to his revisions, concluding without error or discrepancy.

Endowed with innate purity, he furthered the **Sacred Court’s** harmonious assemblies, wandering in the realm of **clustered mists and grand effulgence**, reciting the **melodic verses of Broad Cold**. In dreams, he roamed with **Red Pine**, and in waking moments, he indulged in the **elixir of golden ladle**. Occasionally, he met with the **True Worthies**, engaging in profound discourse on the **wondrous pivots** of the Dao. Thus, he secretly aspired to ascend on clouds, transcending the mundane and departing from the common folk.

Whenever he emerged during moments of rest or on auspicious days, he would screen out worldly affairs and diligently perform the **ritual of exorcism and purification** (挣醮). The altars were solemnly constructed, the **silken banners** fluttered in the breeze, the **dust of the world** did not dare intrude, and the **sacred visions** seemed to resonate in the air. Wrapped in fine wool, he rested for long hours, accumulating his **qi** and forgetting weariness.

In the year of **Renxi (壬戌)**, he was assigned the **imperial seal** of **Miling** (秣陵), and his heart yearned for this sacred mountain, which lay close to the capital. Soon after, he received an imperial decree, extending his commendation, and was directed to visit the **numinous soil** of the mountain, lingering in its **auspicious domain**. His spirit was at ease, and he drifted in forgetfulness of return.

A recluse named **Juzhi** (朱自英) dwelled in the fertile caves of the mountain, his abode changing with the years. The Master took pleasure in his simple and unadorned ways, as if they were a **kindred spirit of stone**. In the second year of his return to court, the recluse’s reputation had spread.

He was summoned to the capital, where the Master hosted a grand banquet and engaged him in intimate conversation, far beyond the ordinary. When the recluse returned to the mountain, the Master again made arrangements for a future visit to his **cave-dwelling abode**, their correspondence marked by deep reverence and mystery. **Juzhi** (朱自英) was astonished by this.

A few months later, the Master passed away, leaving behind words that echoed his intent: to build this **sacred structure** here. The total expenditure from his private funds amounted to **150,000**, with no additional contributions from the state.

Subsequent imperial decrees allowed **Juzhi** (朱自英) to come and go as he pleased, all in accordance with the Master’s original intentions.

According to the *Zhenzhuang* (《真诰》), the **Sententious** (句曲) land is the **Lung of the Earth**, with fertile soil and pure waters, known as the **Hua Yang Sacred Cavern** (华阳洞天), capable of **transcending the world and nurturing the people**, untouched by the **Three Calamities**. It further states that those of **utter loyalty and filial piety** would first receive **sacred commissions**, then ascend to the ranks of the **Celestial Worthies**, with their **ascensions and descents** recorded in the **registers of the dark and luminous**, akin to the **appraisal of human merit**.

Thus, the Master’s devotion to this **lofty peak** and his reverence for its **wondrous symbols** were not in vain.

Indeed, he emerged during the **Age of the Virtuous Sage** (应贤运), ascended to the **highest echelons of power**, and rendered great service to his time. His **virtue and power** were profound, and his **achievements and influence** vast. Without **embracing the numinous qi**, how could he have **aligned with the august worthies** and fulfilled his **grand mission**? Without **harmonizing with the sacred records**, ascending to the **true stages of immortality**, how could he have **manifested the vigor of the Great Peace**?

His character matched these earlier accounts, and their **mysterious resonance** was confirmed.

Ah! To **ride the winds of time**, **striving in both martial and literary pursuits**, **holding the reins of governance**, **revering the sovereign and sheltering the people**, **exhausting his wisdom and virtue**, **upholding the balance of the Dao**, **unshaken by the controversies of the age**, **radiant and awe-inspiring**, and to **end his days in glory**—then, to **shed the mundane and ascend**, joining the **Xianmen** (仙门) and **Yueye** (雇佺) **adepts**, meeting them at the **boundaries of mist and vapor**, was this not a grand and splendid fate?

Indeed, his wife **faithfully upheld the imperial mandate**, never forgetting to **pursue and honor** him. His son, **Yanliang** (寅亮), **Chancellor of the Palace**, **wholeheartedly assisted** in completing the **victorious construction**, ensuring his **exemplary legacy** would endure and forever shine in history.

It is said that **Chen Fu** (陈辅), a **disciple of the early years** who frequented the Master’s **abode of literary pursuits**, was entrusted with **commissions for writing**, and his works were inscribed upon **gold and stone**. Thus, he accepted the **honor of the imperial appointment**, though he was unworthy of such grandeur.

The Master bore the surname **Wang**, given name **Qinruo**, and courtesy name **Dingguo**. His wife bore the surname **Li**.

The lineage and official records of the Master’s **native village and clan**, along with the **sequence of his ancestral offices**, are inscribed in the **historic annals** above and **engraved in stone** below—these details are known and thus omitted here.

This inscription was made in the **second year of Regency** (庆历二年), the year of the **Tiger and Horse** (壬午), on the **twentieth day of the tenth month** (乙卯).

**Mengzi Xuan** (孟子宣), **Judge of the Daoist Temple** at **Buzheng** (句曲) and **Superintendent of the Observatories**, granted the **purple robe**, and **Leiping Hu** (雷平胡恢), **Superintendent of the Daoist Temple**, inscribed the **stele** with their brushes. **Lugong** (陆绛), a **Junior Official** and **Guardian of the Juren County** (句容县尉), was responsible for **overseeing the construction and erection** of the stone.

**Stele of the 23rd Generation Grand Master of Upper Clarity, Master of the Great Cavern, Miao Xiansheng** (幽光显扬) **of Jianyuan Temple** (乾元观妙先生) **at Mount Mao** (茅山).

**Chen Fu** (陈辅) of **Cloudyang’s Southern Suburbs** (云阳南郭) **crafted** the stele, while **Cai Reng** (蔡仍), **Scholar of the Western Mountains of the Seven Prefectures** (七闽西山), **wrote and inscribed** the epitaph.

The Master bore the surname **Juzhi** (朱氏), given name **Ziying** (自英), and courtesy name **Yinzhi** (隐芝), hailing from **Juyang** (朱阳里) in **Juqiu** (句曲).

The Master was eight or nine years old when he tended cattle in the **Goudian Village** (郭干村). The other boys rolled up reeds to make whistles and played with them, cracking their whips and driving the cattle. The Master declined to join, and the herdsmen laughed at him. The Master smiled and said, *"How is it that you ride oxen, yet cannot ride a crane?"* Slowly, he drew a flute from his sleeve, split a bamboo stalk, and a crane descended from the sky, dancing in the air. The Master mounted it, but the crane soared and he fell. The herdsmen gasped in alarm.

From that time onward, he followed the herdsmen, and often summoned cranes. Some warned that this was an omen of misfortune, so his parents abandoned him to the Dao. He became a disciple of **Master Zhu Wengji** (朱文吉) at **Yuchen Temple** (玉晨观). His studies were diligent, and though he was enrolled in the **literary register**, he would read a text, close the book, and declare, *"I am familiar with it."* His teacher, though unable to match his mastery, marveled at him.

At eleven, he was ordained as a Daoist. His celestial bearing and refined bones already set him apart from the world. Though born in the countryside, he had never seen Confucian classics or Daoist scriptures, yet when asked about burning incense and reciting the **Six Classics**, the **Hundred Schools**, and the **Three Vehicles and Thirty-Six Divisions**, he spoke fluently without pause. Elders from afar, well-versed in learning, sought his presence, eager to behold his countenance.

The Master sat alone in a chamber, eyes closed, reciting texts from memory. Those who listened found not a single word omitted. As he grew older, he composed essays with effortless grace, excelling particularly in **elegant verse** (风雅). His words were sharp and profound, like the resonant tones of an empty void.

**Ma Gong** (牧马公), **Bright** (亮), of **Jinling** (金陵), sent an official with a letter, which the Master set aside without reply. His teacher, fearing offense, confessed his inadequacy, but the Master said, *"No, you have honored me."* Thereafter, he traveled with **Master Zhang Shaoying** (张炼师绍英), scaling **Jijin Peak** (积金峰) by clinging to vines, and residing in the **Tian Shi Altar** (天市坛) and **Ronghuo Hall** (宠火院).

The two withdrew from society, their bodies growing gaunt from fasting on **stardust** (沆尘), and they pursued the **Three Manifestations** (三景). They practiced the **Yili Dangpei Method** (仪璘当佩之法) to hasten their lightness of being. Soon, their outer chambers were filled with visitors, and the Master turned to Zhang, saying, *"What is this? You have brought so many to my doorstep—do you not fear it is too much?"*

Zhang replied, *"Do not worry. People will soon tire of you. If you were to seek fame in the world, there would surely be those who would not tolerate it. Why bother traveling?"*

The Master said, *"To stay or to go—each follows its own path. Why must they be the same?"*

Thus, he would ascend the altar by day and cross the river by night, intending to pay homage to the **Primordial Origin** (混元) at **Hao She** (毫社) and to greet the **Celestial Master** (天师) at **Qingcheng**.

As he passed through the **Sword Gate Pass** (剑门) and journeyed westward, he encountered an old man with a long beard, white hair, and piercing eyes like a calf’s. The old man sat cross-legged and demanded, *"Young man, whence do you come?"*
*"From Huayang,"* he replied.
The old man asked again, *"And where are you bound?"*

The Master said, *"From Shu."*

*"In Shu, what do you seek?"*
*"The Great Elixir."*

The old man cast his head back and laughed aloud, *"Young man, have you not heard of Tao the Hermit of Yinxu? He was a man of worth! After five refinements, his elixir still did not manifest, and only then did he utter his three-day lament over fleeting fame. Thus, he never achieved the White Day’s soaring ascension, but instead followed Gubao and left.

As for you, your foundational Dao is not yet complete, your Way only partially attained. If you do not **withdraw and conceal your luminous virtue** (潜晦光曜), they will **brandish you with benevolence and righteousness** (桁扬汝以仁义) and **mutilate you with rites and music** (劓刖汝以礼乐), making you a spectacle for both Heaven and the people—truly lamentable!"*

The Master said, *"Cast me into the depths of a cavern, and I shall reveal my fate."*

The old man then pointed and gazed into the distance, *"The Hermit told me: seven hundred years hence, a child of virtue shall emerge from Maoshan. Surely this is your destiny."* He then recited the *Precepts of the Hidden and True Hermit* (登真隐诀) and commanded the Master to close his eyes. *"Hold my staff firmly."* Suddenly, the Master felt a brush against his feet, opened his eyes, and found himself seated beneath Qingcheng Mountain. He then **silently performed** the Nine-Turned Golden Cauldron (金鼎九转) and the Flying Essence Sword Method (飞精剑法).

When the matter was concluded, the Master said, *"My flesh-born body and eyes of mortal sight cannot recognize your venerable self. Another day, I shall come again—like the shadow of a mountain at the foot of the valley—is that acceptable?"*

The old man replied, *"The world knows me as Chen Tiejiao; that is I."*

*"In years past, the late Emperor Taizong sent me to seek the elixir beyond the seas, but there was only Danji Anqi’s lingering delay—thus, I missed the chance."* He finished speaking and vanished.

The Master left the pass, intending to continue his journey eastward. Yet, he reflected that the *Daoist Canon of the Three Maos* (三茅道藏) was incomplete, so he **loaded his supplies and traveled to Lixiang** (濑乡), where he **collated and corrected** the ancient texts of the *Way of Great Clarity* (太清).

After a year, a mendicant of the Wu clan often came by day, carrying a patched basket to the **alms hall** (斋堂), where he would **upside-down** the remaining food on the stone plate before departing. The crowd scolded him for not taking it, but when the Master had finished washing the utensils, the mendicant inquired about his affairs.

The Master was then in his **yellow robes of the first grade** (黄衣初腊). The mendicant raised his hands and exclaimed, *"Jute Maoshan and others are like this beggar seeking the Five Daoists!* (伍仙#4) Thus, I abandoned my search. I shall meet you tomorrow at the **flag pavilion inn** (旗亭酒家) to discuss the Way with you."*

Turning to the Master, he said, *"You are truly a Daoist vessel! Only, your old habits have not yet been purged—you have not yet been **washed and refined** (洒濯). If you do not, you will only burden yourself further. Can you go?"*

The Master replied, *"How dare I disobey your command? I shall **conceal my eyes** (藏睛)."*

A short while later, a **rustling sound** (哄然) struck his ears. Suddenly, he beheld a **bounded landscape** (阅阖), and the mendicant turned to him, *"This is the River Middle Prefecture."* Before long, they reached the river, where the **flow was halted** (截流) to allow crossing. The Master **stepped forward** (踵之), as if **treading upon flat land** (平陆).

Upon reaching the shore, the mendicant Wu, **joyful and delighted** (欣欣), exclaimed, *"A worthy disciple can be instructed! I am your Water Star Disciple."* (水星童子)

*"Your single journey has already brought you to the **Great Transformation of Form at Taiyin** (度形太阴). Yet, you must **retreat into seclusion** (幽屏), and not weary of **deep concealment** (深眇). The great artisan does not reveal the unpolished gem to the world—otherwise, it would not be easily understood."*

At another time, they met again to **delve into the subtle mysteries** (审究夷微). The mendicant then **abruptly departed** (遽背而去), and the Master was **deeply grieved** (怆恨).

When he returned to his native mountain, he **examined his heart and refined his resolve**, treasuring the teachings of the two Masters, **preserving the Three Protections and the One** (存三守一), and **emulating the fervor of Yang and Xu** (追杨许之烈).

Not long after, the **Palace of the Celestial Clarity** (玉清昭应宫) was completed. A decree was issued selecting men of **renowned conduct** (名行). The **Minister of Works** (工部侍郎), Xue Ying, submitted the Master’s name, and the court sent an envoy to summon him. The Master declined with a **respectful memorial** (表辞), but the official carriages soon followed in procession. The **Emperor of Virtue** (章圣) ascended to Heaven, and the **Temple of Benevolence** (仁庙) succeeded his **spiritual service** (嗣服).

Under the **reign of the Illustrious and Austere Empress Dowager** (明肃太后), who ruled from behind the screen, Ding Jinong (晋公) and Wang Jiping (冀公) both recommended the Master to the court. The Master was summoned twice, but again declined. His **decline was expressed with warmth and elegance** (谢表温雅), bearing the **refined character of a Confucian scholar** (儒臣高世之风). The court admired him, and thus the two ministers composed poems:

Ding Jinong’s poem:
*"Great Concealment—why fear the bustling capital?
The Three Heavens’ **pure disputes** (澄诤) to pay homage to the Primordial Sovereign."* (元君)

Wang Jiping’s poem:
*"Why did you, a man of worth, break your ancient vow?
**Carrying your lute and burdening your crane** (负琴担鹤), waiting to follow me."*

The Master responded in kind, his words **exquisitely refined** (词极清妙). The two ministers then **urged the Empress Dowager** to compel the Master to accept office, and the local officials **pressured him with threats of punishment** (敦迫). The Master, **having no choice** (不得已), thus **reluctantly took up the appointment** (受命劫).

Before he had **formally presented himself to the court** (经朝见), all officials were **prohibited from visiting him** (禁不得通谒), even **梁器、陶景、唐礼、昊筠**—yet these were **not worthy to compare with even a fraction of his merit** (未足方万分).

Soon, by imperial decree, he **ascended the Treasure Symbol Pavilion** (宝符阁) to **inspect the Celestial Scriptures** (观天书). He repeatedly **submitted memorials requesting retirement** (累表乞退), but the **two Sovereigns** (二圣) favored him more than ever, fearing that his **bold defiance of courtly norms** (重违雅尚) would bring shame. Thus, the Master was **granted permission to return to his homeland** (得请束归故乡), where he **resolved to focus his mind and refine his thoughts** (决志精思), his **heart drifting into the boundless expanse** (心驰太空之境).

The court **bestowed rewards upon his journey** (赐劳), and **processions of carriages** (车盖) stretched endlessly.

Before this, a **nobleman** (贵人) had **reported to the Empress Dowager** (传上) about the Master’s **request for a mountain retreat** (近山立常宁一镇), saying that he wished to **provide a resting place for travelers and merchants** (为游客行商息肩之所).

The Master replied, *"A Daoist must **dwell in rocky retreats and cavernous abodes** (岩居穴处), diligently **cultivate the Supreme Methods** (勤修上法), and **follow the rigorous ascetic practices** of the Great Mao’s **Celestial Command** (保大茅司命之苦行). Only then can I **recompense the imperial favor** (报国恩).*

*"If I were to **imitate the Western lands’ ornate temples and grand decorations** (效西方土木装严), it would not align with the **Teachings of the Venerable Laozi’s frugality and benevolence** (老氏慈俭之教)."*

The court **acceded to his request** (从之).

The **Daoist Canon of the Three Caverns and Four Stages** (三洞四阶灵文宝岌), containing **sacred texts bound in gold and sealed with jade** (金绳玉检), is the **great secret transmission** (秘传大法) of the Way. From **Wei’s Nan Yue** (魏南岳) onward, down to the Master, it has been **passed through twenty-three generations** (二十有三代).

The Illustrious and Austere Empress Dowager wished to **follow the precedent of the Purple Void** (紫虚故事), **praying for the transmission of all the Dao’s methods** (祈授毕法). She **distant-revered** (遥尊) Zhu and Zhang as **Guiding Masters** (度保师), bestowing upon the Master the title **Observing Marvels, Illuminating True Perfection** (观妙明真), and constructing the **Heavenly Holy and Primordial Sovereign Observatories** (乾元、天圣两观) to **honor his teacher-student lineage** (旌师资). The Master did not decline this.

At that time, **the elixir vapors ascended, the divine essence flew** (琅讦飞精), and the **three furnaces’ divine aura** (神景三炉) had reached the **fourth turn of fire** (四转火).

One day, the **Jiangning Prefecture** (江宁府) received a letter from the **Shu State Governor** (蜀州守), Xiao Guan, regarding a **Daoist named Wu Bao** (道士武抱) who had **a book in hand** (一书者). The Master took the book, and **tears flowed in streams** (泣数行下). His disciples could not **fathom its meaning** (莫测所以).

The letter **reproached him for his prominent name and exposed virtue** (责姓名显耀), warning him of the **fault of revealing celestial secrets** (天机暴露). It **urged him to avoid worldly affairs and conceal himself** (避俗藏身), and even **suggested he depart in the middle of the night** (中宵引去), saying that **this might yet be salvable** (犹为可救).

The literary style was elegant and refined, with much to admire. The *jìnshēn* (文致) and *zǎoliàn* (藻练) scholars and officials, wearing their official caps and robes, frequently criticized and opposed the Master, warning against his influence. Their portraits and inscriptions were passed down through the ages—such as the so-called **Wu Xian Tong** (武仙童).

In the seventh year of **Tian Sheng** (天圣), when the **Great Elixir** (大丹) was completed, the cauldron overturned, and the elixir favored the disciple **Mao Fengrou** (毛奉柔), who secretly informed the Master of its state. The Master sighed and said: *"The setting sun is near, and the dog’s mouth has passed once—truly so."*

By that year’s eleventh month, he had **laid down his office** (解驾), at the age of fifty-three. That very evening, he **closed the mountain gate** (掩关), forbidding his disciples from entering, which was **unusual** (颇异常时).

As the night reached its midpoint, the disciples gathered around his furnace altar, awaiting the **Dawn of the Jade Morning** (玉晨), when a **red-robed messenger** (朱衣使者) holding a scroll stood below the courtyard. Though his bearing was **composed and dignified** (甚都), his radiance dazzling like a mirror, the boy questioned him: *"Who are you?"* The messenger replied slowly: *"I am **Zhen Guan Xia Lu Wenxiu** (真官下卢文秀), sent by the **Celestial Emperor** (帝) to welcome the **Jade Master** (朱真人)."*

The disciples **stood in stunned silence** (牢肩惕息), not daring to move. Shortly after, the Master inquired about the hour, and was told: *"The third watch has passed."* Then he asked again: *"Has the **Jade Morning Bell** (玉晨钟) sounded yet?"* The reply came: *"Not yet."* He asked repeatedly, four times in all. When the bell finally chimed, the Master called his attendants: *"I depart now."* Upon entering, they saw him **seated in solemn stillness** (危坐), holding the **Auspicious Symbol** (祥符) bestowed upon him—a **jade *ruyi*** (玉如意)—**erect and dignified** (俨然).

That evening, the heavens were bitterly cold, yet the Master’s neck emitted a **circular radiance** (圆光), filling the chamber with warmth. His **jade body** (玉体) glistened with sweat like pearls. As the **final rites** (大敛) were being conducted, a faint sound emerged from his coffin. The **Daoist law** (法固) called this **corpse dissolution** (尸解). When the coffin was lifted, they suspected only an empty robe remained.

The day before, **Tao Zhenren** (陶真人) had sat in silence, **shaken by tremors** (无故震者) three times. The assembly was **astonished** (咸异), but the Master remarked: *"Why should this concern you?"* That very night, his **spirit was transferred** (迁神), and **cranes cried** (鹤唳) as the altar revolved. The **valley winds hummed like flutes** (谷鸣若箫), and this continued for three days.

The **temporary magistrate of Jùróng** (句容权令), a **harsh official** (酷吏), was later replaced by **Chancellor Lǐ Gōng Dí** (丞相李公迪) during his tenure. When the Chancellor sent his subordinates with **words of invitation** (致词), urging the Master to visit and **bestow Daoist blessings upon the county** (俾县加道修肃), the Master **passed through the town without stopping** (不顾而去), and the magistrate, **harboring resentment** (阴衔之), **did not detain him further** (还又不少留).

His attendants urged: *"The magistrate has donned his official robes and awaits you on the left. You should descend from your carriage and pay him a visit."* The Master replied: *"It is not that I refuse, but the **blood-stained air** (血腥) is too hard to bear."* Later, when the magistrate’s **misfortunes grew worse** (闻益患), he **accused the Master’s disciples of poisoning him** (中丹毒死) and **drove them away** (尽逐先生徒弟). Many fled without time to spare, and the **strange auspices of Jiāxiáng** (嘉祥异瑞) were **suppressed and slandered** (为其所抑，诬) by him.

Even the **Nine Palaces** (九重) of the imperial court were **vast and distant** (寥廓), offering no recourse. The following year, when the magistrate was removed from office, the disciples were finally able to **return and bury the Master** (葬反真之宅) in **Yùgāng’s western slope** (郁冈西麓), near the **corner of the *Fāngyuán* Cave** (方隅洞之束), a few steps from **Lǐ Zhenren’s Elixir Well** (李真人丹井), at a height of three *chǐ* (尺).

Alas! **Though the Master’s foundation of purity and cultivation was profound** (夙净基修), it was **unfulfilled in some way** (宜无不圆), yet even he met misfortune. **How much more so for the ordinary disciples** (况悠悠之徒)!

The Master’s successor, Xu Master, with his disciple Stone Zhirou serving as attendant, after fifty-nine years, in the year *Dīngmǎo* (丁卯), when Stone Zhirou had passed eighty, **ascended to the Dao** (得西剑州道客任), and was entrusted with the task of recording the Master’s deeds. Yet his account was **scanty and incomplete**, with more than half **obscured and lost** (漫灭过半矣). Kneeling and weeping, he said:

**"The Master’s Dao can be grasped in a moment, but how can it be rejected for a thousand years?** (先生之道，可扼於一时，庸拒郁於千载。) Thinking to awaken the **hidden virtue** (潜德) of his **faintly luminous essence** (幽光), who but the Master himself could accomplish this? His intention was that, at **ninety years of age** (仆九十岁), he, as a **partial favorite** (偏亲) of the Master’s Three Scenes disciples, would obtain a **detailed account** (详).

Upon his return, he told his kin: **"The Stone family’s words are indeed my long-held aspiration** (石氏子之谓，乃吾素志), why not **commission the Great Teacher** (大宗师) to **craft elegant prose** (奉命藻雪) and **inscribe it with meticulous strokes** (涓辰而书)? Thus, he bowed with clasped hands and prostrated himself, offering a **praise in verse**:

*"Descendant of the House of High Yang* (繁高阳氏之遗裔兮), born in the **numinous precinct** (灵墟) of his name.
In youth, he wore the **purple robes of Zǐyáng** (紫阳之羽褐兮), yet **answered the call of the Red Infant’s symbol** (应赤子之识符).

He crossed the **treacherous peaks of Jiànlǐng** (剑岭之危峨兮), clutching the **long skirts of the Iron-Soled Sage** (执铁脚之长裙).
He forded the Yellow River **barefoot** (凭黄河以徒涉兮), following the **dual footprints of Xīngtóng** (蹑星童之双亮).

At the time of the **threefold imperial blessing** (帝三叶之庆祥兮), his **courtly rank was empty** (属春宫之位虚).
He was **honored with the jade bracelets of the High-Sleeved** (祀高襟以诏弓镯兮), yet the **Celestial Cavern ceased its charge of fate** (洞天辍司命之友于).

He received the **transmission from the Jade Maiden** (膺玉女之受度兮), continuing the **Purple Void of the Primordial Lord** (续元君之紫虚).
He sheltered in the **hidden desk of Zāoyìng** (昭应之隐几兮), gazing upon the **Celestial Script** (观天书) while **embracing the Treasure Seal** (阁宝符).

He first **followed the Dao of the Upper Realm**, ascending *Kōngtóng* (崆峒) and descending with the **favorable wind** (顺下风兮), then **suddenly vanished**, arriving at the **path of return** (俄泠然而及归途).
Clinging to the **imperial favor** (攀帝恩), yet **reluctant** (恋恋兮), how could he **dare to delay the Sage’s appointed term** (奈仙期之敢瑜)?

Morning he left the **vermilion gate** (绛阙), evening he returned to the **embroidered peaks** (绣岭), yet the **True Official had already descended to the courtyard** (真官已降于庭除).
With **three vehicles perfected** (三乘圆) and **seven fruits attained** (七果), he **soared his form** (将耸身) to **pierce the void** (凌空).

No **farewell bows** (揖) were needed as he **rode the flying wheel**, mastering the **Six Qi** (御六气兮), and **ultimately returned to the Dao** (竟归神) in the **Pure Capital** (清都).
He **preserved the sun’s essence** (系日保深息兮), and his **dwelling was woven of mist and clouds** (烟霞结庐).
His **mysterious wanderings** (玄游) were vast—**Dragon and Tiger** (龙虎) **joined their chariots** (胶舆), yet **he soared beyond** (怅超遥), leaving no trace in the **elixir furnace of Tóngwú** (桐梧之丹炉).

The **Green Cow Valley** (青牛谷) resounded—**stone altars overgrown with moss** (石坛藓合).
The **white willow rustled with solemn wind** (白榆风肃兮), while the **jade coffin and lone sword** (玉棺剑孤) stood.
All were **emptied in the Imperial Grace’s embrace** (俱虚皇之在宥), and the **Treasure Record was entrusted to the ancestral diagram** (绵宝录於宗图).

The **Martial Sage** (武仙) **inscribed the records of the Immortal Attendant** (童书碑), with **the Sage’s small likeness carved** (上刻仙童小像) and **the Daoist’s portrait of Daochéng** (道士戴道成画) beside it.
He held a **single scroll** (抱一启), declaring:

*"He roamed in lofty ease, scornful of wealth and high rank* (啸傲升平，轻欺富贵). He **leaned against the sparse laurels** (扶疏丹桂), yet **could not conceal the bright moon’s light** (难藏明月之光).
**Steeple and sheer as the green peaks** (峭绝青山), he **did not halt the white clouds’ passage** (莫滞白云之迹).
**Words are insufficient** (言之不足), yet the **Dao is within** (道在其中).
**His name and lineage are now revealed** (名姓已彰), yet **his form and spirit remain hidden** (形神别隐) in the **Three Mountains** (三山), across the **four seas** (四海)."

「The years pass—how fixed is their span? Why seek the **lead and mercury** (铅汞) of fate?
If one merely follows convention, one may only sink into **lifeless decay** (僚倒).
The **true pearl** (真珠) is round and its beauty lies in its form;
The **red snow** (绛雪) congeals and **naturally becomes so** (自然而然).
In the marketplace, who is not extraordinary?
In the mountains, who is truly virtuous?
Water gathers to form the sea,
**Qi** (气) accumulates to form the **spirit** (神).
Not by my own recognition,
But by **few words and no idle speech** (少言休语).
What profit is there in **selling medicines for fame** (抱一货药而利名)?
Does **harmonizing with the light** (和光) mean the **Dao/Way** (道) and the **common folk** (俗) are truly distinct?

**Lightly ascended**, he **practiced the Dao/Way** (行修);
**Long life** (长生) is within the **Dao/Way** (道).
Many are **free and easy among clouds and waters** (逍遥於云水),
Yet few have ever **recklessly exposed themselves to the heavens** (暴露於天机).
Who needs words when the **knowing one** (知者) understands?
The **practitioner** (行者) reveals himself through action.
Let me **unbind my heartfelt thoughts** (聊舒恳捆),
As a substitute for **laughter and idle chatter** (笑谭).

---
**The sun’s decline** (日三秋) and **a finger’s breadth as ten thousand li** (咫尺万里),
**Yang-qi** (阳气) dissipates like mist,
**Wasteland’s effect** (荒效) flows like water.
**Preserve harmony** (更保冲和),
**Cease idle questioning** (别休清问).
Now, **through the auspices of the fish and crow** (因鱼鸦),
I **temporarily attach my humble thoughts** (聊附寸心).
When the **scroll reaches the mountain’s foot** (书到山前),
The **crane’s longing gaze** (鹤望) is already expressed.
**This account is respectfully inscribed** (谨状不宣).

**Former acquaintance, the Daoist Master Wujīang** (故交道士武江上),
**The rightful successor** (道者之右).
On the **second day of the second month** (二月二日),
**The sacred sovereign searched for those beyond the world** (圣主搜罗物外人),
And **all gathered at the golden gates to behold the numinous and true** (总来金阙见灵真).
I **do not wish to flaunt my name and lineage** (余余不愿彰名姓),
Yet **I have gained the favor of Tianyuán’s Dao/Way** (别得田元道可亲).
I know my **good name** (好名) will already be **transmitted through the ages** (传世),
So **I must swiftly depart to hide in these deep mountains** (早须速别隐深山).
On another day, when we meet again,
**I shall be gone** (去也).
**The night’s farewell** (夕婷吵).

**Observing Master Miào’s former encounter** (观妙先生),
He **once met the Martial Sage** (曩尝邂逅武仙童).
Later, **Master Miào** (后先生) **responded to the imperial summons at Rén Regio’s Temple** (於仁庙时应诏还山),
When suddenly **he received the Martial Sage’s scroll** (忽接仙童书),
**Urgent and earnest** (殷勤) **in teaching and admonishing** (诲谕),
His **intent was to warn Master Miào** (意警先生),
To **conceal his light and obscure his teachings** (韬光晦边),
So that **the world would not flaunt his name** (世不耀名).

**His true handwriting** (其真墨迹),
During the **fourth year of Zhenghé** (政和四年八月间),
**The emperor, the Daoist Sovereign** (圣上道君皇帝),
**Searched for strange and wondrous writings** (搜罗天下奇异之文),
And thus **ordered the local magistrate, the scholar-official Huang Xueshi** (本邑句容令黄学士唐傅),
To **obtain and present them** (索取以进).
**Truly**, this **is but a copy of an old companion’s work** (斯本旧偶摹写),
Now **I command artisans to carve it upon stone** (今命工刊于石),
So that **its transmission may endure forever** (庶永其传焉).
At that time, **the eighth year of Zhenghé** (政和八年),
**The year of the wu-xu** (岁在戊戌),
On the **mid-autumn full moon** (仲秋望日),
**The abbot of Qianyuán Guan at Maoshan, Master Guàn** (茅山乾元观住持知观道士杨守程),
**Inscribed this preface** (题志).

---
**Inscription on the Sacred Hall of Chongxi at Maoshan, Jiangning Prefecture** (江宁府茅山崇禧观碑铭):
**Scholar-official Zhang Shāngyīng** (朝谙郎新权知洪州军州事、兼管内劝农事、充江南西路兵马钤辖、赐紫金鱼袋张商英),
**Authored this text** (撰),
**Scholar-official Wáng Gǔshū** (朝散郎、会书荣州军州事、判官厅公事、轻车都尉、赐诽鱼袋王古书),
**Engraved the seal** (篆额).
**The eminent sight of the southeast** (东南之望) **is Jùqū Shān**,
**Truly the** **Huáyáng Cavern** (华阳洞天) **and** **Earth’s Lung** (地肺),
**The dwelling of** **Yì Yán’s true essence** (福地易迁含真之所宅),
**The domain of** **Sìmìng’s child** (司命童初之所治).
From the **Jìn and Sòng dynasties onward** (晋宋以来),
**Those who attained the Dao/Way** (得道之士) **numbered** **Xǔ, Yáng, and Táo**,
And **their ancestral halls and dwellings remain** (遗坛故宅犹有#7存者).
**Twelve temples** (宫观十二),
**Master Zhōng Bùxǐ** (忠不禧) **oversaw them all**.
The **state, in accordance with Heaven’s will** (国家灵承天心),
**Spread blessings upon the people** (敷锡民福),
With **golden bells** (锺金之儿),
**Jade tablets** (镂玉之简),
**Divine incense** (妙真之香),
And **refined Daoist scriptures** (丹素之词),
**Regularly offering sacrifices** (岁修常典).
**At times, envoys were dispatched** (间遣王人),
**Officials appointed to oversee their administration** (设官以提其纲),
**Fields granted to support their congregations** (赐田以赡其众).
Thus, **it was fitting that their temples were grand and splendid** (宜其宫阙壮丽),
**Where the sages resided below** (列圣下居),
**With deep and solemn halls** (廊麻深严),
**Ten thousand spirits standing guard** (万灵侍卫).
**Those who arrived were awestruck** (至者悚然),
**Their senses moved by the spectacle** (有以移其视听).
**Those who dwelled were solemn** (居者肃然),
**Their hearts purified by its presence** (有以洗其心志).

From here **emerged the secret Daoist precepts** (仙科秘范之所出),
And **the sacred scriptures and divine seals** (宝章灵篆之所宗).
Yet **the door of Xīyí’s refined detachment** (希夷淡泊之门),
And **the teaching of secluded non-action** (寂寞无为之教),
**Scholar-officials and literati have yet to discuss** (学士大夫，未之或讲),
Nor **are they a priority in local governance** (州县政事，又非所先).
**Tax revenues from the fields** (田租所入),
**All were appropriated by the state** (悉笼於官).
**Daoist leaders assessed households for levies** (道倡计口而赋粮),
**Government clerks exchanged vouchers for collection and distribution** (有司互券而出纳).
**Only the occasional debate over ritual purity** (方斗质之钩考),
**Or idle discussion on construction** (孰土木之暇议),
**Occurred between superiors and inferiors** (上下顾望).
**Years dragged on in inertia** (岁月因循),
**Roofs collapsed without repair** (屋颠而不持),
**Looms stood idle without use** (梭故而不革),
**Dams fell into ruin without restoration** (圯废而不兴),
**Walls crumbled without reconstruction** (垣颓而不作).

**The scholar-official and former** **Bǎowén Attendant** (宝文待制何公君表),
During the **Yuányòu era** (元佑中),
**When his inclinations were misaligned with the times** (以趣向背时),
**Oversaw the** **Chóngfú Temple in the Western Capital** (提举西京崇福官),
**And resided in** **Jīnlíng** (居金陵).
He **often visited the mountains** (尝至山中),
**Fully aware of their neglect** (熟知其弊).
During the **Shàoshèng era** (绍圣亲政),
**He was summoned to the palace audience hall** (召对便殿),
And the **following year was transferred to govern here** (明年移镇於此).
**He implemented his former intentions** (伸发曩志),
**Proposing the construction of a virtuous hall** (议营善之).
**When Zhang Shāngyīng was exiled to oversee the granaries** (会商英谪莅管库),
**Master Hè presented him with the diagram** (公伴图以授商英),
Saying: **"As for your knowledge of Daoist learning** (子於道家之学),
**It is vast and long-standing** (博且久矣).
All **deviations and omissions not in accordance with the classics** (凡向背与开阖之不如经者),
**Should be corrected based on ancient precedents** (其悉据古考正之).

**Zhang Shāngyīng observed the diagram** (商英视图),
And saw that **the southern gate of the three halls marked the passage of the Daoist and the common folk** (南面三门则道俗出入之所由也).
**The three halls of** **Sānlǐng, Běijí, and Běn Mìng** (三清、北极、本命三殿) **stood aligned**,
Yet **the Hall of Yùhuáng** (玉皇殿) **was positioned at the rear corner** (乃在束隅).
**Zhang Shāngyīng carefully followed** **Lǎozi’s teachings** (商英谨按老子之书),
Saying: **"Heaven follows the Dao/Way** (天法道),
**The Dao/Way follows Nature** (道法自然).
**Nature** (自然) **is the origin of pure** **Yīn-qi** (清气).
**Heaven’s realm is** **Qīngwēi** (清微),
**Its domain is** **Yùqīng** (玉清),
**Its sovereign is** **Yuánshǐ** (元始),
**Its emperor is** **Yùhuáng** (玉皇).
**The Dao/Way** (所谓道者) **is the pure** **Yīn-qi** (气之纯清),
**Its heaven is** **Yǔyú** (禹余),
**Its domain is** **Shàngqīng** (上清),
**Its supreme sovereign is** **Dàdào Yùchén** (大道玉晨君),
**Its emperor is** **Tiānhuáng** (天皇).
**Heaven** (所谓天者) **is the accumulation of pure** **Yīn-qi** (气之积清),
**Its heaven is** **Tàichì** (太赤),
**Its domain is** **Tàiqīng** (太清),
**Its supreme sovereign is** **Lǎojūn** (老君),
**Its emperor is** **Běijí** (北极).
**Běn Mìng** (本命) **is the deity of the branches and stems** (支干之神),
**Subordinate to** **Běijí** (以统於北极者).
**Běijí** (北极) **is the pivot of Heaven’s center** (天中之枢),
**To receive** **Yùhuáng** (以承玉皇者).
**Now, with** **Běijí** **placed after the** **Sānlǐng** (今以北极次三清),
**And** **Běn Mìng** **after** **Běijí** (以本命次北极),
**While** **Yùhuáng** **resides to the left** (玉皇居左),
This **is not the proper order of the Dao/Way** (非道之序也).
**The spirits, when they arrive, cannot find their rightful place** (神而来格，亦莫安於其位矣).
I **request that** **Yùhuáng** **be placed first** (请先玉皇而后北极),
**Then** **Běijí** (而后北极),
And **that** **Běn Mìng** **be positioned to the left** (而左本命)."」

The Three Gates are the pathways of the divine spirits; without ritual offerings and exorcisms, they remain closed. To the east, a Daoist academy was established; to the west, a guest hall was set up. Thus, distinctions of rank are preserved, Daoists and laymen do not intermingle, and mortals and spirits remain separate.

The official said: "Your reasoning is excellent. The temples of this mountain have been built and abandoned at different times throughout history. Many Daoist attendants have dwelled here. Yet none has ever used the theories of the Three *Qi*, the Three Heavens, the Three Venerables, and the Three Emperors to correct the order of ascension and descent. Was it perhaps the elevation of the formless and the return to stillness? Or was it a neglect of the proper use of ritual implements, leading to the creation of movement? Or an ignorance of the essence of the Absolute Void?

Following your proposal, the county of *Yóuchéng* was reassigned to oversee the rectification. The work was completed accordingly.

The following spring, in the fifth month, the Hall of Yùhuáng was finished. On the day of its consecration, a pair of white cranes circled and soared above for the entire day, their cries echoing from afar. Then, the Master of the Upper Clarity Great Cavern, **Liú Hùnkāng**, along with his disciple entrusted with recording, remarked: "At other times, white cranes would gather here on the eighteenth day of the third month, sometimes appearing and sometimes not, never consistently. Now that the hall is complete and the cranes descend, this is not merely the result of the official’s sincere reverence—it is the silent harmony with the True. How else could such an auspicious sign be summoned? We request that a portrait of the official be painted in a separate chamber, so that the people of our land may forever honor his memory."

After the rites were completed, a request was made of **Shāng Yīng** to compose a record, and he wrote the following ode:

Before the *Qi* coalesced, it was called *Zìrán* by force of name.
To embody the Void was the Dao; to move the Dao gave rise to Heaven.
Three manifestations, one concealed; one foundation, three perfections complete.
Divided into Nine *Qi*, arranged into Eight *Xián*.
Lofty and towering, the Teased Peak—southern sentinel of the land.
The Emperor resides in the Daoist temple, exalted above the mountain’s base.
At first, the rites were mismanaged, their order confused and disordered.
The official corrected them, and the spirits responded as if in echo.
The cranes, adorned in ceremony, descended from the cloudy heights.
Who guides them? There, they drift in boundless ease.
Their *Qi* converges at the Supreme Void; their spirits wander in profound stillness.
Observed from below, their virtue shines resplendent.
The palaces gleam, the cliffs and valleys radiate brilliance.
The winds bear the banners, the officials pause and rest, then depart.
This mountain bears auspicious signs; this land has its worthy.
May the Son of Heaven reign ten thousand years, his blessings extending to all quarters.
The official governs his domain—all affairs are in order.
The spirits heed him, for it is his virtue alone.
Grant him abundant harvests, that his people may prosper.
Bestow upon him many blessings, that he may live long and in peace.
The people, moved with reverence, paint his likeness.
May his image endure with the mountain, to match the eternal scene.

「In the third year of the *Shàoshèng* era, on the eighth day of the eleventh month, the Daoist master *Sān Jǐng* of the *Shàoshèng* Three Scenes Sect, the abbot of *Jiāngníng*’s *Chóngxǐ* Observatory, and the officials *Dīng Wéi* (the *Jiāngníng* Prefectural Inspectorate’s *Tújiǔ* for temple renovations) and *Hé Zhèngchén* (the *Jiāngníng* Military Prefect, *Jiāngnán* Circuit’s *Bīngmǎ Jiànxiá*, and *Zhùgōng* with a purple sash and golden fish pouch) erected this stele.

Emperor Xuānhe’s Inscription on the *Huàdào* Stele:

The Dao/Way is boundless, its subtleties unfathomable.
It encompasses the transformations of existence, nurturing the heavens and earth.
Thus, the state devoutly reveres the Most High,
and with awe honors the Dao/Way—
expanding the sacred origin of transformation,
all returning to the true teaching of rectitude.

Since the birth of the people, none have truly known the path to the Dao/Way,
and this has endured for ages.

Whenever I reflect upon this, my heart aches with sorrow,
for the Dao/Way is the embodiment of the Sage’s essence,
used daily by the common folk without their knowing.
Hence, its principles are kept hidden in reverence,
and I seek earnest and profound minds
to establish norms and guide customs,
so I issue earnest admonitions,
that all who come after may find clarity and return to the Dao/Way.

Now, those who are agitated and restless,
unaware of the Dao/Way’s wondrous nurturing,
yet instead follow the heterodox customs of ritualistic practices—
accustomed to their ways, they also teach their methods.
They equate stillness with emptiness,
and extinguishment with true joy,
leading the ignorant masses to perish in their delusions.
This is their natural course—
how can one not pity their profound confusion?

Moreover, humans dwell between heaven and earth,
at the most vital point of existence.
When conceived in the womb,
they are nourished by the Three Primordials,
their form shaped by the Nine *Qi* breaths.
Bearing heaven above and earth beneath,
none escape the Dao/Way’s foundation.

Those of superior wisdom,
who early discern the numinous and refined,
need no instruction and naturally incline toward the Dao/Way—
perhaps three in a thousand.

As for those of middling or lesser wisdom,
they are ensnared by the concerns of names and rituals, wealth and rank.
Though the Dao/Way’s benevolent nurturing exists,
they yield to the burdens of familial affection,
still lingering in the pleasures of sound and color,
thus appearing as if lost or barely present.

The lowest of the wise,
content with fine food and clothing,
comforted by ease and familiar customs,
remain utterly oblivious to the Dao/Way’s path,
forsaking truth for falsehood,
unaware that their very form and *Qi* are born of the Dao/Way itself.

Indeed, humans are to the Dao/Way as fish are to water—
fish lose the water, they die.
Humans lose the Dao/Way—what fate awaits them?

All who govern the people must surely uphold the Dao/Way.

The Dao/Way is the summation of the void,
the source of all transformations.
Its vastness knows no beginning,
its depth no end.
All phenomena arise from it,
the Five Tones take shape through it—
thus, though the six directions may seem immense,
they are contained within it,
and though a single hair may seem minuscule,
it owes its form to its influence.
Its remoteness cannot be ascended step-by-step,
its responses are swift yet unseen—
this is called *húnlún* (indiscriminate unity).

*Húnlún* is the essence of the *Tàijī* (Supreme Ultimate).

Thus, the *Tàijī* generates the Two Polarities—
heaven and earth.
The clear *Qi* ascends to form heaven,
the turbid *Qi* descends to form earth,
and their harmonious mingling creates humanity.
Hence, the Five Celestial Stems radiate their essence,
the Three Celestial Lights descend to aid,
and the Three Talents are perfected.

In its transformative workings,
the Dao/Way manifests the seasons of heat and cold, dryness and moisture,
the names of square and round, form and instrument,
the degrees of waxing and waning, ebb and flow.
Thus, the sun and moon adorn the sky,
the stars follow their appointed courses,
thunder and lightning strike like drums,
winds and rains moisten like waves.
It sows the hundred grains in due time,
to nourish the people,
and multiplies life and growth,
to enrich the eternal harvests.
Then, each person fulfills their potential,
and all things follow their nature—
thus, they reap to eat, weave to clothe,
and rejoice in the world of great peace,
all because of the Dao/Way’s wondrous creation and nurturing.

Observe the ages from *Fúxī* down to the Three Dynasties—
though their titles differed,
their reverence for the Dao/Way and service to heaven remained one.

Now, those who are shrouded in ignorance and inverted in their ways,
should investigate its principles and worship them with awe—
is this not virtuous?

And what of those who are clearly enlightened above?
They are indeed to be feared and revered.

Now, I clarify and instruct,
spreading salvation to those steeped in old habits,
expanding the blessings of all under heaven,
so that those who change for the better may cherish life,
awaken with sudden realization,
and renew their resolve,
returning to the true Dao/Way.
Above, this aligns with the Most High’s enjoyment of heaven,
below, it fulfills the mandate of the *Yīn* (dark) and *Shào* (light) to continue the *Bù* (ancient) and *Xù* (future) traditions—
thus, the beauty of the *Huángjí* (august sovereignty) radiates,
enduring in the realm of virtue and morality,
permeating the domain of benevolence and longevity—
is this not magnificent?

On the *Xiāntiān* Festival of the *Gēngyín* year of the *Dàguān* era,
inscribed at the *Xuānhe* Hall.

In the second year of the *Zhènghé* era, on the twenty-sixth day of the first month,
the Daoist master *Shǒujìng Chénghé* of the *Guàndìng* Sect erected this stele,
followed by the Thirty-Third Heavenly Master of the Han lineage, *Zhāng Jìxiān*,
who inscribed the text.
This concludes Volume Twenty-Five of the *Máoshān Zhì*.
