**Teachings of the Twenty-Seventh Volume of the *Mao Shan Zhi***

The **Upper Clarity Successor Master** Liú Dàbīn constructed [the temple].

**Recorded in the *Mao Shan Zhi* (Teachings of the Twenty-Seventh Volume of the *Mao Shan Zhi*)**

**Upper Clarity Successor Master** Liu Dabin constructed [the temple].

---

**Record of the Golden and Stone Inscription**
*Yuan Dynasty Stele*
*Inscription of the Hua Yang Dao Yuan (Daoist Temple)*

The **Hanlin Direct Scholar, Court Official, and Keeper of the Imperial Edicts** Yuan Mingxian composed it, while the **Hanlin Attendant Scholar, Middle Order Official, and Keeper of the Imperial Edicts** Zhao Mengfu inscribed it.

The **Daoist adepts** follow the tradition of **符錄 (symbolic records)**, claiming they can summon the winds and thunders, command spirits and ghosts, and some may doubt this. **Dao/Way and humanity are one**; when cold, the body shivers; when hot, the body perspires. This is because **形 (form)** is what **天 (Heaven)** manifests, and what surrounds **形 (form)** is none other than **天 (Heaven)**. Thus, it is said that at the juncture of **Dao/Way and humanity**, there is only **感 (response)** and **應 (correspondence)**.

Only when a person’s **氣 (qi)** is perverse does it begin to diverge from **天 (Heaven)**. Even a foolish man or woman, with a single resolute thought, can stir movement. How much more so for **高人德士 (noble virtuous ones)**, dwelling in solitary halls, refining their practices with utmost purity, where their will is set—**天 (Heaven)** will never defy them.

In the time of the **World Ancestor Emperor (世祖皇帝)**, Master Xu of **Jouqu (句曲)** came to court. When he **梼 (invoked)** disaster, it **應 (responded)**. The Emperor was astonished and specially ordered him to oversee the temple rituals and continue the **符錄 (symbolic records)** tradition. As Master Xu was about to ascend, he pressed his seal upon the **待 (awaiting)** hands of the present Lord Wang until he arrived to receive it.

In the **second year of the Great Virtue (大德二年)**, locusts plagued **Huainan (淮南)**. The **宣慰使 (Commissioner of Pacification)** of this **道 (Daoist region)** respectfully invited Lord Wang to Jiangdu, where he performed **醮 (ritual exorcism)** to avert the calamity. Soon, the locusts that had not yet sprouted wings were choked by the rain, and those that had wings were struck by a sudden wind that darkened the sky. They pecked at the locusts, ate them, then spat them out—pecking and spitting in cycles over several days. The locusts did not become a disaster.

Before this, when the drought **梼 (invoked)** rain, the people of **Huainan (淮南)** were greatly alarmed and delighted. They competed to offer gold and silk, worshipping and kneading it in reverence, but he refused none, and those who escorted him filled the road. On his return, he said: *“Do I truly need the rain to cease?* My sincerity alone suffices to fulfill my **法 (Daoist method)**.”

When he **二 (twice)** achieved swift responses and saved countless lives across several prefectures, it was truly because **三茅君 (San Mao Jun, the Three Venerable Masters of Mao Shan)** had guided him. Moreover, the **宝运 (auspicious era)** was flourishing—how could there be starving people? The gold and silk he received, if stored in his coffers, would be a fortunate gain. I, in my separate dwelling, pray to the Three Venerable Masters on behalf of the nation, and also worship my two parents to repay their private blessings. This, perhaps, is fitting.

That year, he thus **遂 (completed)** the construction at the **束 (eastern side)** of the **Yuanfu (元符) Hall of Ten Thousand Tranquilities (万宁宫)**, gazing upward at the **枫轮 (crimson wheel, i.e., the sun)**, downward at the **金菌 (golden fungi, i.e., the moon)**. The mountain found its proper place, and the temple was forever established. The **限 (boundaries)** of the sacred site were refined into elegance, perfectly suited to the terrain. Neither frugality led to vulgarity nor excess to disorder. A total of over fifty halls were built, with **San Mao Jun** enshrined in the main hall and their **考妣 (ancestors)** in the side chambers.

From the laying of the foundation to the completion of the work, it took six years. The temple was named **Hua Yang Dao Yuan (華陽道院)**.

In the **third summer of the Great Virtue (至大三年)**, the Emperor commanded the **Upper Clarity Successor Master (上清嗣宗师)**, the **Hao Zhenren (昊真人)**, to perform **醮 (ritual exorcism)** in **Jiangnan (江南)**, beginning at **Jouqu (句曲)**. Lord Wang traveled near **Jingkou (京口)**, and the **Hao Zhenren (昊真人)** said: *“The incense and offerings you have prayed to in court, I will now receive with my hands. I dare not disrespect them.”* As the **暑雨 (summer rains)** were relentless, he requested that the next day’s rites would reach **Yuanfu (元符)**. If the rain persisted, even a drop would be a shame to the **神 (divine)**.

Lord Wang replied: *“I dare not fail to respect your words.”* The following day, the rain barely ceased. After the offerings were made, it poured heavily during the rites, then stopped again. The **Hao Zhenren (昊真人)** returned to court and, in detail, recounted Lord Wang’s deeds as above, and thus sought an inscription for **Hua Yang (華陽)**.

I heard that Lord Wang was **简 (modest)** yet **章 (illustrious)**, **庄 (serene)** yet **和 (harmonious)**, **静 (still)** yet **动 (active)** with perfect balance. He was truly a **道君子 (Daoist noble)**. Thus, when he **出言 (uttered words)**, calamities were averted; when he **有梼 (invoked disaster)**, the divine became manifest; when his **功 (deeds)** were complete, he did not claim credit; when his **德 (virtue/power)** was fulfilled, his humility only increased. Therefore, the Emperor granted him the title of **养素通真明教真人 (Nourishing Virtue, Penetrating Truth, Illuminating Daoist Master)**.

**Jouqu (句曲)** has long been a **名山 (famed mountain)**. The **高人德士 (noble virtuous ones)** who dwell there, because of its secluded depths and worldly isolation, its tumultuous distance from the near, halt their **灵光 (spiritual brilliance)** to cultivate enlightenment and appreciation. Having recorded his deeds, I further inscribed these words, echoing the **步虚 (Ascending the Void)** hymns and capturing his **闲远 (tranquil and distant)** thoughts.

Lord Wang’s name was **Dao Meng (道孟)**, with the sobriquet **Mu Zhai (牧斋)**. He was from **Juchong (句容)** in **Jiankang (建康)**, the **四十四代宗师 (forty-fourth generation successor master)**.

**Inscription:**
*The towering and dim Jouqu (句曲) mountain,*
*Where the gods and immortals dwell beneath clouds,*
*Its purple banners and feathered canopies unfurled,*
*The carp vanish suddenly—where do they flee?*

*The **通真真人 (Tong Zhen Zhenren)** refines the **元精 (original essence)**,*
*Feasting on mist and inhaling **氣 (qi)**—his complexion now clear.*
*He lingers in **Yanggu (陽谷)**, blowing the jade flute,*
*His **瑶装 (jade adornments)** and cranes in the **Kunlun (昆仑)** courtyard.*

*When disaster looms, he spreads his wings to transform the world,*
*When peace is restored, he stores blessings for the **天明 (Heavenly Clarity)**.*

*His distant heart seeks **Penglai (蓬瀛)**,*
*Handholding **青芝 (bluegrass, i.e., sacred herbs)** before the **丹经 (Cinnabar Scripture)**.*

*At the **琼都 (Jade Capital)**, I gather these words,*
*Greatly summoning the **真倡 (True Procession)** to touch the **幽灵 (profound spirits)**.*

*Here, clarity and tranquility require no exertion,*
*No disturbance—your **精 (essence)** can thus attain **長生 (longevity)**.*

*Below, the dusty world is plagued by a hundred woes,*
*Drunkenness and death in dreams—alas for short-lived suffering.*

*In the **重阴 (dense shadows)**, no altar gazes upon the sun and stars,*
*Yet those with desire may seek this inscription.*

**Inscription of the Jouqu Mountain Cave and Spring:**
*In the **泰定甲子 (Tai Ding Jia Zi, 1324)** year, the **玉虚子 (Yu Xu Zi, Jade Void Master)** constructed [this].

**Mao Shan’s Three Mountains and the Luo Luo Peaks.**
**The Great Dipper and Little Dipper**, mirroring the **七宫 (Seven Mansions)**.
**Upper Clarity has its altar**, high and central.
The mountain bends to contain, the waters flow to pay homage.

I cultivated the **華池 (Hua Pool)**, its inner landscape harmonizing.
At the **艮 (Kan, northwest)** it stands still,
Blocking the **兌 (Dui, southeast)** void.
The **丹井 (Cinnabar Well)** flows westward,
The **石梁 (Stone Beam)** stretches eastward.

The **玄師 (Mysterious Master)** had his works,
Omen of this **灵综 (profound convergence)**.
Storing the **玉浆 (jade nectar)**, once used by **奚穷 (Qi Qiong, a legendary immortal)**.
Benefiting all things, **Dao/Way** does not speak of merit.

**Inscription of the Blessing Village Well:**
*Only the **萧 (Xiao, a surname)** has a **台 (platform)**,*
*By **曲水 (bending waters)**,*
*The well’s **梵 (sacred)** essence unchanging,*
*My thoughts turn to **若人 (such a one)**.*

*Who is **若人 (such a one)**?*
*His peers are **桐梧 (Tong Wu, legendary immortals)**.*

*He received the **教 (Daoist teachings)** of **Hua Yang (華陽)**,*
*And spread blessings to the **近 (nearby)** **丹丘 (Dan Qiu, Cinnabar Mound)**.*

*His blessings endure for a hundred generations,*
*Like **金玉 (gold and jade)**.*

*This is called **正明 (True Clarity)**,*
*And all receive its blessings.*

**Inscription of the Great Dao Altar:**
The **Upper Clarity True Master (上清真人)**, **Pan Zunshen (潘尊师)**, embodied the **玄 (Mysterious)**, and built the **弘道坛 (Great Dao Altar)** at the **嵩 (Song) mountain’s** southern slope.

The **外史 (Outer Historian, i.e., Lord Wang)** of **Jouqu (句曲)**, with **基石 (foundation stones)** aligned to **Dao/Way**, restored the ancient ways and enshrined the **圣神 (Sacred Spirits)**. Forever, he set the **宪矩 (normative standards)**.

**Inscription of the Great Daoist Master (刘大彬) and Record of the Revered Longevity Palace (崇禧万寿宫)**

The **Upper Clarity Daoist Master (上清宗师)**, **Liu Dabin (刘大彬)**, inscribed the **Zhen (True) Seal Altar (篆镇坛)**,
while the **Great Cavern Daoist Master (大洞法师)**, **Ni Tiankui (倪天奎)**, pledged sincerity and purchased the stones in cooperation.

**Record of the Revered Longevity Palace (崇禧万寿宫):**
The **Jouqu (句曲) Outer Historian (外史)**, **Wang Quji (王去疾)**, who had once served in officialdom and later retired, composed the text,
while **Zhao Mengfu (赵孟俯)**, the former **Hanlin Academician (前翰林学士)**, **Chengyi Grandee (承旨荣禄大夫)**, and **Master of Drafting Edicts (知制诰)** who also oversaw the compilation of **national history (国史)**, inscribed and titled it in **seal script (篆题)**.

**Hua Yang (華陽) Cavern of the Dao:**
Since **San Mao Jun (三茅君)** established the **Sacred Dao (神道)** and taught here,
those who received its blessings—**divine men (瑞人)** and **spiritual adepts (神士)**—could not be counted in succession.
Each generation had its own worthy inheritors.

Examining their lineage through history,
only **Tao Zhenren (陶真人)**, the recluse, established a **hall for high disciples (立馆以处高弟)**,
and his nurturing and protection of successors were most abundant.

The **Revered Longevity Pavilion (崇禧观)** today is the **Tao Zhenren’s hidden retreat (隐居曲林馆)**.

In the **Tang Dynasty’s Zhenguan (貞觀) era (年)**,
Emperor **Taizong (太宗)** recalled that **Shengzhen Wang Zhenren (升真王真人)** had once dwelled here,
and since he had formerly been a disciple of **Tao Zhenren (隐居)**,
he built the **Taiping Pavilion (太平观)** to house him,
granting him **fields and mountains (赐田与山)**,
and providing **scholars with stipends (赡其学者)**,
**allowing them to distribute grain and money (飧钱铺粟用给)**.
Under his jurisdiction were twelve **palaces and pavilions (宫观)**.

In the **Song Dynasty’s Zhenghe (政和) year 3 (三年)**,
the **fields were divided (分田)** to support the disciples,
so they could sustain themselves—details recorded in the **mountain annals (山志)**.

The **Song (宋)** renamed **Taiping Pavilion (太平观)** as **Chongxi Pavilion (崇禧观)**,
erecting **pious and solemn altars (揭虔妥灵)**.
Though lacking in teaching, its **splendor endured (有盛无教)**,
reaching today’s grandeur—**expansive halls and refined corridors (广殿修廊)**,
**magnificent Daoist paths (弘弘辙辙)**—
adorned with **ornaments of phoenix and cassia (检题牖槐之饰)**,
**fragrant incense and offerings (婶华香火之供)**.
For a thousand years, no such **reverence and devotion (崇奉)** had been seen.

The **Three Sovereigns (於皇三君)** of the **Dao (道)**,
their **mighty and sacred spirits (威神)** dwelling in heaven,
**subtly aiding and unseen (阴隐默相)**,
made the **Dao of Hua Yang flourish (华阳道振)**,
as did **Lu (鲁)**, **Mao (沬)**, and **Si (泗)**.

Though the world has **ascents and descents (世有升降)**,
the **Dao knows none (道无升降)**;
though time has **manifestations and obscurities (时有显晦)**,
the **Dao remains constant (道无显晦)**.
**Tao Zhenren’s (陶真人)** relation to the **Three Sovereigns (三君)** was one of **divine communion beyond measure (神交沈寥之上)**.
**Wang Zhenren’s (王真人)** connection to **Tao Zhenren (隐居)** was through **heart-to-heart transmission (心授问答之间)**.

Their **lineage stretched unbroken (绵绵延延)**,
**passing from ancient to modern (往过来续)**,
as if a single day endured for a thousand years.

When the **Ming Dynasty (皇元)** first arose,
the **heavenly armies (天兵)** crossed southward,
and the **divine and luminous (神明)** supported them,
**leaving the altars untouched (坛宇如故)**.

**Zou Jun Dao Yuan (邹君道元)**, whose **mind was distant as the Dao’s essence (心远)**,
was like the **Creator (造物者)**—
a man chosen by the **Dao/Way (拟其人)** for his time,
whose **voice resounded through the nine heavens (叫闻阖於九天之上)**.
The **Upper Realm (上方)** ceased its martial ways and turned to **cultivation of the Dao (修文)**,
establishing a **seal of purity and tranquility (以清静为坛)**,
and a **dwelling of benevolence and frugality (以慈俭为宇)**.
With **intentions toward the Mysterious Teachings (垂意玄教)**,
the **Dao/Way (道)** commanded **Zou Jun Dao Yuan (邹君道元)** to oversee its affairs,
**protecting all the mountains (尽护诸山)**.
His successors—**Hong Jun Zongyuan (洪君宗源)** of **Shu Jian (束涧)**,
**Yang Jun Yuanche (杨君元澈)** of **Fuyang (复阳)**,
and **Cai Jun Depu (蔡君德溥)** of **Bi Quan (碧泉)**—
**continued the lineage (继继承承)**,
and thus **preserved the favor of successive dynasties (用保有累朝之宠命)**.

At the **beginning of Spring (元春)** in the **Reign of Hongwu (皇庆)**,
**Chen Jun Zhixin (陈君志新)** of **Nan Wu (南呜)** paid homage in court.
The **Emperor (上)** observed the **celestial light (天光)** at **Qingdu (清都)**,
**Zi Wei (紫微)**, and **received special grace (承九重之殊渥)**,
**honored with the title of True Master (荷真人之美名)**,
and **granted a golden Daoist robe (赐金栏道衣)** as a mark of distinction.

In the **Yanyou (延佑) year 4 (四年)**,
**Chen Zhixin (陈志新)**, the **Southern Pavilion Master (南院君)**,
reflected privately:
*"The Chongxi Daoist Hall (崇禧道场) has long governed all these mountains,
truly a place where the **Supreme Deity (上帝)** rests and **bestows blessings (储祉)**.
If we do not **properly honor it (有以表章之)**,
how can its **name be held in esteem (名有尊)**?
I petition to **elevate Chongxi to the rank of a palace (宫)***,
and **presented this to the scholars of the Jixian Hall (集贤诸公)**,
**submitting the matter to the court (以其事闻于朝)**.

The **following year (嗣岁)**, upon his **return to the mountains (陛辞还山)**,
the **Emperor again bestowed incense (上复降香)** to honor his journey home.

On the **22nd day of the 8th month in the Yanyou year 6 (延佑六年八月二十二日)**,
a **jewel-toned decree (玉音)** descended from heaven,
**granting the name Chongxi Wanshou Palace (崇禧万寿宫)**.

**Zhang Gong (张公)**, the **Great Daoist Master (大宗师)**, **Grand Master (上卿)**, **Great True One (大真)**,
and **Hao Gongxing (昊公兴)**, the **Successor Master (嗣师)** who oversaw the **Daoist teachings (掌教真人)**,
were instrumental in this.

On that day,
**radiant and unusual qi (荣光异气)** ascended,
**illuminating the layered heavens (上烛层霄)**.
The **lofty mountains and steep peaks (崇山峻岭)** all bore a **reverential hue (矜色)**.
**Chen Zhixin (陈志新)**, the **True Master (真人)**, led his **Daoist disciples (羽士)** in **prostrations and double obeisances (稽首再拜)** at the **left of the Dao (道之左)**,
and **responded to the Emperor’s blessings (对扬休命)** with:
*"The **illustrious Heavenly Son (明明天子)**,
may his **longevity and rule endure forever (万寿万年)**.
This **truly aligns with the primordial decree of Taizong (太元司命君)**,
from the **opening of the cosmic gate (自混沌瞑津开关)** at the **beginning of time (之始)**.
Even before the **vast and boundless cycle (赤明龙汉浩劫)**,
they **joined in aspirations (俱以愿力)**,
**crafting their roles as helpers and protectors (裁成辅相)**,
to **govern the people (左右民)**.
Though **times and circumstances differ (虽今昔殊时)**,
and **their presence may be hidden or revealed (幽显异迩)**,
their **receiving the mandate from the august Sovereigns (受命於皇皇后帝)***
is **the same across ages (则异世而同符也)**.
**Thus, let all be at peace (於摩休哉)**."

Then, the **crowds in ceremonial dress (冠巾之众)**,
as one voice, **praised him (祝之)**:
*"Since **Chen Zhixin (陈志新)** succeeded **Tao Zhenren (隐居陶真人)** in establishing the hall,
he has **first been honored as the Taiping Pavilion (太平观)**,
then **as Chongxi Pavilion (崇禧观)**,
and now **the Emperor grants this new name (上赐今额)**—
a **most splendid achievement (甚盛举也)**.
Future **historians compiling national records (秉国史之笔者)**,
when they **chronicle the years and months (系年击月)** and **days (击日)**,
will **inscribe in bold (大书之)**:
*'The transformation of a pavilion into a palace began with **True Master Chen Zhixin (真人陈志新)**.*
**How can one repay such imperial grace (其皇恩如天)**?
Only by **serving the Emperor with utmost reverence (在帝左右)***,
**ever respectful and dutiful (必敬必恭)***,
**constantly pondering (蚤夜以思)***,
and **assisting in the Dao’s grand work (弼成玄功)***,
can one **hope to answer the favor of the Sovereign’s nurturing and protection (君师宠绥之造)***,
and **thus the True Master’s name will be immortal (真人亦有无穷之闻)**.*

The **True Master (真人)** replied:
*'The **sacred spirits of the Three Sovereigns (三君之灵)** are **manifest (也)**,
and the **Emperor’s grace (吾皇之赐)** is **bestowed (也)**.
What **power do I possess (臣何力)** to repay this?*
**I dare not fail in reverence (敢不敬恭)** and will **follow the ritual norms (以从祝规)**."*

In the **summer of the 4th month in the Yanyou year 7 (延佑七年夏四月)**,
**Wang Quji (去疾)**, the **Southern Buttress Master (南坞君)**,
recorded these events for **future Daoists (以传方来)**.
**Wang Quji** believed that **only a mountain Daoist of profound insight (必有山玄卿其人)***
could **craft an inscription worthy of the new palace (而后为新宫铭)**,
and that **my humble writings (草野之文)** were insufficient to **commemorate such grandeur (何足以纪盛事)***.
Yet **he could not decline the command (辞不获命)**,
so he **composed the record (乃举前说为之记)***
and **further adorned it with poetry (而又黑沐系之以诗)***.

*"Since the **mountains first emerged with the cosmos (自有宇宙有此山)***,
who **cleared them and established this place (开山者)**?
It was **Gaoxin (高辛氏)**.
**Taizong (太元君)**, the **noble and virtuous (耿耿祉哉)**,
was the **heavenly helper and protector (天之辅相)**,
**relying on whom the people prospered (民估恃)**.
**Tao Zhenren (曲林旧馆陶真人)**, in his **hidden virtue and luminous Dao (潜德幽光)***,
**shone for a thousand years (发千祀)**.
The **mountain’s map ascended to the heavenly court (山图飞上天皇家)***,
and **divine decrees were divided across ten thousand leagues (云汉分章来万里)**.

**Magnificent Chongxi Wanshou Palace (崇禧万寿官)***,
**its grand inscriptions penned by the ancient sage (巨扁鸾飞羲献字)***,
**where phoenix songs and crane dances resound with harmonious grace (凤歌鹤舞锵钧韶)***,
**and the mountains, rivers, spirits, and ghosts all rejoice (山川鬼神共欢喜)**.

**No pestilence afflicts the people (物不疵疠)**,
and **the harvests are abundant (年谷丰)**.
**The heavens and earth are purified (乾坤清夷)***,
and **the winds and days are beautiful (风日美)**."*

The Emperor, in joyful reverence for the **Grand Ancestor** (太皇),
commenced this era of **ten thousand years and countless ages** from this day onward.

In the first year of **Yuan Zhi Zhi** (元至治), on the fifteenth day of the first month,
the **Chongshou Observatory Stele** (崇寿观碑) was erected.
**Chengde Lang** and **Guozi Siyu** from **Shu Commandery**, **Yu Ji** (虞集),
composed and inscribed the text, as well as carved the inscription on the tablet.

Beneath **Damao Peak** (大茅峰), at the **southern entrance of Huayang’s South Cave** (华阳南洞之便门),
stood **Chongshou Observatory** (崇寿观), originally the residence of **Dongtian Guan’s** (洞天馆) former overseer, **Ren Dun** (任敦).
In the **eleventh year of Song Yuanjia** (宋元嘉), **Lu Taihou** (路太后) first constructed the hall and altar.

During the **Taishi era** (太始中), **Luling Taishou Kong Sizi** (庐陵太守孔嗣之) rebuilt it
to honor **Qu’e’s lofty recluse, Hua Wenxian** (曲阿高士华文贤).
In the **second year of Qi Jianyuan** (齐建元), **Juan Jucong Wang Wencheng** (劝句容王文清)
reestablished and took charge, naming it **Chongyuan Guan** (崇元馆).
The **Emperor Wu** (武帝), as **Crown Prince**, often visited it.
At the beginning of **Tang Zhenguan** (唐贞观初), it was renamed **Chongyuan Observatory** (崇元观).

There exists a stele from the **Taiji era** (太极元年), though its stone remains intact while its inscription has faded—
only the names of **Zuoxieyi Sun Chuxuan** (左拾遗孙处玄) and **Yang Youjing** (杨幽经) can be discerned.

In the **seventh year of Tianbao** (天宝七年), **Master Li Xuanjing** (李玄静先生) undertook a grand restoration,
with contributions from **a hundred families of commoners** (民百家).
In the **third year of Baoli** (宝历三年), the overseer was **He Sibaobao** (贺思宝),
whose records were later confirmed through inscriptions on artifacts.

In the **seventh year of Song Dazhong Xiangfu** (宋大中祥符), the name was bestowed as it is today.
In the **second year of Yuan Zhi Zhi** (大元至治二年), **Zhang Jun Sizhen** (句曲外史张君嗣真) first arrived to oversee it.

Gazing upon the **square platform facing south** (方台近对南面),
to the left, **peaks stacked like jade** (左峰迭玉),
to the right, the **branches of Damao Mountain** (右引大茅之支) curve and converge here.

**Dinglu Jun** (定录君) remarked:
*"Beneath Damao Mountain lies a spring, where a quiet retreat may be established near the water’s mouth."*

**Tao Yinjü** (陶隐居) noted:
*"Near the entrance of the **Southern Great Cave** (南大洞口) flows clear water amid rocks,
and after a short ascent, the land levels out—here, **Wang Wencheng** once resided."*

Thus, this observatory is indeed the place.
He sighed and said:
*"The halls within these mountains, from the **Qi, Liang, Tang, and Song dynasties** down to today,
have been successively enlarged and augmented by each generation."*

「In tracing the legacy of the Jin people, only this place and the residence of the Master of Xu, Master Yuchen, remain.

Yet what I have undertaken here is to restore and expand the neglected and humble structures—is this not my responsibility? Thus, I assessed the materials and gathered the workers, transforming the rear hall into the **Great Primordial Hall** (太元殿) to revive its former grandeur and enshrine the **Three Masters of Mao** (三茅君) within. To the east, I built the **Shrines of the Five Masters: Ren, Hua, Wang, Li, and He** (任、华、王、李、贺五君祠), and to the west, the **Shrine of Tao Yinjü** (陶隐居祠).

I filled the foundation of the front hall to create the **Grand Dao Platform** (弘道坛), and inscribed a eulogy upon it myself.

To the north of the platform, I established the **Shrine of the Dark Warrior** (玄武祠), to the west, the **Shrine of Broad Benevolence** (广惠祠), and behind it, the **Literary Virtue Lecture Hall** (文贤讲堂), while at the front stands the **Main Gate** (都门).

Beyond the gate, I dredged the ancient **Jade Spring Pool** (古玉津池), collecting all the waters from the southern slopes of Damao Mountain.

Following the pool’s southwestern edge, I discovered the **Reading Platform of Master Zhaoming** (昭明太子读书台).

Beside the platform lies a well called the **Well of Fukang** (福乡井)—Fukang, as it derives its name from the **Dao Retreat of Master Zhaoming** (昭明道馆).

Clearing the thickets and wild growth, I marked the site with inscriptions and stones, sheltering them under pavilions. All the scenic rock formations, caves, and springs within a hundred paces, I surveyed and recorded them as worthy of observation.

In the first year of **Taiding** (泰定), the **Master of Shangqing**, the forty-fifth generation **Master Liu Dabian** (刘君大彬), came to the capital, and I reported to him the details of my work, so that he might approve the sequence.

**Zhang Jun** (张君), a native of the **Hao Commandery** (昊郡), was named **Tianyu** (天雨), with his inner name **Zhizhen** (嗣真), courtesy name **Boyu** (伯雨), and alternate sobriquet **Zhengju** (贞居). At twenty, he abandoned his family to embrace the **Dao/Way** (道), wandering through the renowned mountains of **Tiantai** (天台) and **Kechang** (括苍).

A man from Hao, **Zhou Dajing** (周大静), was first a disciple of Master Xu and inherited the teachings of **Yang** (杨) and **Xu** (许). Zhang Jun followed him as a teacher, receiving all his doctrines. Once, he accompanied **Master Wang Shouyan of Kaiyuan** (开元王君寿衍) to the capital, where he was honored with imperial decrees and granted courier privileges. Though elevated by his teacher’s influence and appointed to office, this was not his true aspiration. He then swore never to seek advancement, and in response to the **Three Masters of Mao’s** (三茅) summons, he descended to serve the Five Masters—**Ren, Hua, Wang, Li, and He** (任、华、王、李、贺)—composing a declaration to that effect. He vowed to dedicate his full strength to this sanctuary, and his works include *The Outer Historian’s Mountain World Collection* (《外史山世集》) in three volumes, *The Record of Mystic Gatherings at Biyuan* (《碧岩玄会录》) in two volumes, and *The Chronicle of Mountain Seeking* (《寻山志》) in fifteen volumes, all marked by meticulous research and vast erudition.

Ah! Since Master Ren first resided here, spanning nearly five hundred years, only five individuals have succeeded in transmitting the legacy—what profound dedication to the distant future is this! How unlike later generations, who merely entice their disciples and bind them through personal ties, as if they were household servants or father-son relations!

Thus, I prefer to wait for those who share my vision of grandeur.

Now, Zhang Jun has no prior imperial assistance to rely upon; clad in coarse robes and subsisting on simple fare, he labors here alone. Yet his heart is vast, and he contemplates aligning with scholars across the land to establish a foundation for the ages—is this not the spirit of a noble and magnanimous man? Therefore, I consider him a **secular friend** (方外友), admiring his foresight in reaching beyond my own.

Hence, I composed this poem in his honor:

---
**Damao’s Southern Slope**, where **Primordial Qi** (元气) gathers,
**Yin Pass** (阴关) seals its gates, the **Yang Caverns** (阳洞) open wide.
**Twisting Caverns** (曲穴) hold flowing springs, safeguarding this **Spiritual Retreat** (灵宅).
Master **Ren** (任君) comes to taste the **Yellow and Red Stones** (黄赤石).

**Heaven’s Unity** (天一) bestows the **Great Primordial Seal** (太元册),
**Qu’e** (曲阿) nurtures with discriminating care.
The **Hall’s Foundations** (构宫) stand firm, as decreed by Master **Wang** (王伯),
**Pure Processions** (清跸) pause here, their **Spiritual Echoes** (灵响) resonant and refined.

**Empty Forests** (虚林) flourish with crisp clarity, their splendor transformed,
**Fukang’s** (福乡) imperial child bestows sweet nectar.
How many years without sustenance, yet his **Sacrificial Arms** (遗臂) remain steadfast,
**White Clouds** (白云) mirror the void, where **Master Yuchen** (玉清客) dwells.

In **Kaiyuan’s** full vigor, the world was burdened with endless tasks,
Holding the **Imperial Seal** (持节), he stood at noon’s height, offering incense to the **Dark Warrior** (熏璧).
Since then, the age has declined, generations have passed in isolation,
**Stone Mirrors** (石镜) bear inscriptions, while **Earthly Demons** (土漫画) deface them.

Who now revives the ancient customs? Only **Zhang Jun, the Outer Historian of Qu’e** (句曲外史), whose **crown of excellence** (美冠乌) shines brightest.
He pored over a thousand volumes, his **innocence** (天真) and **spiritual lineage** (玄系) traced in careful succession.

Within the **Jade Chamber and Golden Hall** (玉室金堂), there is no lack of instruction.
---
**The Chronicle of Mao Mountain, Volume Twenty-Seven** concludes.
**The Chronicle of Mao Mountain, Volume Twenty-Eight** begins.»

The **Mao Mountain Chronicle** concludes its **Upper Dao/Way Sect** lineage:
The Master Liu Dabian of **Succeeding Upper Clarity** crafted *Golden Carpets* and *Jade Weavings*,
The **Poems of the Northern and Southern Dynasties** and the **Fifteen Hundred Lines of Hua Yang Stone Eulogy**,
As well as **Tao Qian’s** *River Chapters* and the **Records of Past Renown**—all bearing **Confucius’** mark.

For three nights, the **Luminous Hosts** adorned the heavens,
Two **Golden Ones** stood as earthly emblems.
The **Right Pivot**—its dwelling shifts from non-existence to existence,
In existence, it returns to emptiness.
The **Spiritual Structure** needs no craftsman,
The **Void Form** achieves success on its own.

The **Right Essence and Manifestation**—the divine essence encompasses the **Three Palaces**,
The **Five Circuits** intermingle with the **Five Colors**.
The **Yin Luster** greets the night’s wisdom,
The **Morning Essence** gazes toward the dawn’s suspension.

The **Right Form and Position**—the **Southern Peak** displays the **Mystic Cauldron**,
The **Northern Ridge** spans the **Qin Seal**.
Its **outer boundaries** embrace the **Jade Sands’** crossing,
Its **inner wheel** veils the **Hidden Circuits**.

The **Left Belt** follows the **Grove of Willow and Samphire Waters**,
The **Right** clears the **Yang Valley’s** streams.
The **soil** cradles the **Northern Darkness’** hue,
The **wells** reflect the **Phoenix Gate’s** chill.

The **Right Traces and Marks**—the **Guo Dry Banks** stand in silent vigil,
The **Jiang and Ba Distant Paths** stretch endlessly.
The **Crane Temple** sometimes offers feasts,
The **Separate Dwelling** remains in constant reverence.

The **Right Category and Affiliation**—the **Celestial Residence** knows not the earth,
The **Yue Tomb** curses the **Hidden Migration**.
The **Tree Canopy** bends in vain beneath the shade,
The **Stone Tortoise** never tasted incense smoke.

The **Right Material Paths**—the **Fruit Grove** lingers in **Nai’s** shadow,
The **Vegetable Patch** sprawls with **Xin’s** vines.
The **Glowing Reishi** can light the night,
The **Field Springs** once stirred the dust.

The **Right Gatherings**—the **Descending Guest** of **Gui Mountain**,
The **Unbridled Chariot** of **Qing Hua’s** youth.
They dined in the **True Essence Hall**,
And convened in the **Lofty and Serene Palace**.

The **Right Talents**—their **Pure Songs** soared in the **Feathered Assembly**,
Their **Long Whistles** returned with the **Cloud’s** turn.
A **Single String** held its **Graceful Tune**,
Yet **Empty Talk** found no equal.

The **Right Learning and Aspiration**—the **Pathway to the Dao** already ascends,
The **Flying Flowers** now guide the heart.

The **Right Divine Aid and Fate**—the **Spirit’s Salvation** exists as it should,
Departure or stay follows its natural course.
Why seek **Manifestation** when the heart is near?
The **Dark Path** knows its own way.

The **Right Rectitude and Fulfillment**—in the **Four Corners**, the **Jade Blade** wanders,
In **Hua Yang**, the **Hidden Dweller** takes root.
The **Seven Elements** may yet support the **Buxu**,
If **Repeated Separation** should ever resemble.

The **Right Omen and Promise**—the **Hao Cycle** will soon be complete,
The **Hai Count** not yet ended in **Ding**.
When **Tang’s** era arrives, the **Guest** comes to the **Holy Court**.

The **Right Sincerity and Hope**—engraved on the **Mystic Window**,
Inscribed at the **Bent Stage’s** gate.
In **action and repose**, they wish to be recorded,
Not failing the **recommendation of virtue/power**.

The **Right Response to Command**—

---

**Mountain Retreat**
What does the mountain hold?
White clouds abound on the ridges.
Only for oneself may it bring delight,
Unfit to send to you, my lord.

**On Departure**
The nature of mind was born of old,
Green virtue long sustained.
Though transformed, it does not vanish in obscurity—
In the Dao, joy and sorrow are borne.
Crown and sword cast empty shadows,
Reins and bridle mark the immortal form.
From this bright hall of revelry, I depart,
To join the guests of Penglai’s isle.
If you can follow in my footsteps,
I will guide you to the Dao’s hidden ford.

**Seeking Master Huan in the Mountains**
*By Xiao Yao of Shaoling*
Unyielding peaks and valleys stretch in Ucing,
Where wind and cloud enter the clay-walled cell.
Unless one harbors the spirit of retreat,
Who could endure frost and dew’s relentless chill?

**Entering the Mountains**
*By Dafa He*
Morning dawns in the cold valley’s embrace,
Seeking truth after setting down my gifts.
The sacred altar droops with dense leaves,
Clear waters teem with crimson scales.
Though the peach grove hides wild beasts,
The immortals’ fields await the worthy.
When the elixir’s craft is perfected,
The furnace’s silver begins to fade.
Know this place surpasses all others—
Here, the clamor of the world dissolves.

**In Reply to Master Tao of Huayang**
*By Shen Yue*
The Three Pure Ones are not yet veiled,
Yet one breath remains—still preserved.
I wish to reclaim the fading light,
To rescue souls from peril’s grasp.
If granted the Nine Elixirs’ gift,
What fear have I of the Six Dragons’ flight?

**Returning to My Garden in Reply to Master Tao of Huayang**
Long I wished to seek the sacred peaks,
Waiting till my marriage rites were done.
Though these two tasks are now complete,
Other matters still remain undone.
News of the Dragon Chart’s arrival came,
And honor’s glow now fills my hall.
As Vice-Premier of the Eight Directions,
I open lands and grant a thousand homes.
Though my cap and sash were never shown,
Wind and rain never touched my comb.
Jade chimes resound at the cavern’s gate,
Golden cicadas gleam in morning’s sun.
Ashamed I lack the humble’s gratitude,
Yet still I bear the Lord’s high rank.
How could I forget my lifelong vow—
To spare no salt in my care for all?

**Master Huayang Riding the Tower and Not Descending**
A sage once spoke of humble wood
Ascending to the clouds’ domain.
The lotus bud, though bought with coins,
Unfolds not on the earthly plain.
The immortal’s home is rich with towers bright,
Where I await the Three Rare Herbs’ bloom,
And watch the hundred deities in court.
The black tortoise bears the sacred scroll,
The noble guest arrives with dragon reins.
Not just the spirit peach bears fruit—
Now the great *zhuang* tree withers too.

**In Farewell to Lady Yi, Master Huayang’s Outer Soldier**
Feasting on jade prolongs the years,
Swallowing mist restores the form.
Faintly I recall the Green Mound’s trees,
And see again the sun at the Mulberry’s gate.
The mirage’s slow waves stretch wide,
Mountains rise from the boiling cauldron’s tide.

**In Reply to Master Qu from Jianqu**
All day, auspicious mists exhale,
By evening, strange vapors brew.
Lofty gorges nurture rare herbs,
Layered cliffs yield the wine of life.
Within dwell men of true refinement,
In coarse robes guarding the Dao’s depth.
Stone doors hide ten arcane secrets,
The golden altar summons the Nine Immortals.
Riding the *an* bird, they tread the Han,
With crane reins, they soar to heaven’s span.

**In Reply to Master Quan Qi of Maoshan**
*By Huangfu Yan*

**In Farewell to Lady Yi, Master Huayang’s Outer Soldier**
*(as previously translated)*

**To Lu Qianfu on His Journey to Teahill Grotto**
Southward I gaze—Jiangnan’s peaks are snowbound,
This sorrow lingers, who shall bear its weight?
In vain I follow the grass-clad clerk, never idle,
While with the scholars I’ve been long parted.
Hearing you sit in quiet, lost in books,
Planting trees and thatching reeds at your old home.
All day the white clouds drift by—enough to content,
Next year’s fragrant grasses, what will they bring?
Life’s cares press heavy, unfulfilled,
Even public doors cannot fully spare.
When will the spring wind bear my boat home?
First tell me of Huayang’s cave—deep or shallow?

---

**Sending Zhang Daoist Back to Teahill Mountain**
Alone toward the mountain, one man walks,
Near the grotto, a crane greets him alone.
Only white letters pass to his disciples,
And white stones earn him the title *Master*.
Endless peach trees clothe the green hills,
Moonlit fields await the plow’s return.
Long he served the Lesser Lord,
Now he follows Mao’s node to Qingcheng’s peak.

---

**Sending Zheng the Outer Official to Teahill Mountain**
I see your whole family depart—
Who knows when you’ll return?
White clouds greet the valley’s mouth,
Flowing waters ask of those within.
Crowns and robes cast aside,
Divine affairs fill the mountain.
There must be treasures unseen,
Why value just a body’s ease?

---

**Sending Zheng the Second to Teahill Mountain**
The stream cuts through the ravine,
All day the grass grows long.
Deep in the mountain at spring’s end,
Dogs bark, cranes cry.
Where are the mulberry rows,
Planted by whom in vain?

---

**Mountain Residence—Miscellaneous Notes**
*(by Gu Kuang)*
The Teahill Immortal descends from his thatched hall,
Serene and secluded in the hidden realm.
Yang Jun’s leisurely law ascends,
The Lord of Fate halts the flowing years.
Peach blossoms gather at the water’s edge,
Window frames the willow valley’s mist.
Holding my grandson, I watch the trees grow,
Leaning on my staff, I ask of the plowed fields.
Let worldly affairs disturb no more,
Floating fame may fade to one side.
From old, like Xie Anshi,
He never sought the elixir’s spring.

---

**Peach Blossom Ravine**
At Peach Blossom Ravine, I meet a maiden’s veil,
Between the trees, apricot leaves fall on the altar.
An elder hands down the *Upper Purity Register*,
Night’s step on the Void Mountain—chill as moon.
*(Note: "Upper Purity" refers to Daoist scriptures of high attainment.)*

---

**New Dwelling on Great Teahill Mountain, Remembering My Lost Son Who Followed the Dao**
The valley raven still calls for my child,
The mountain man weeps at dusk.
Across life and death, my heart aches,
In vain I climb these heights.
The gate is barred with sorrow,
West River’s grief runs deep.
From ancient times, the Middle Way was lost,
Only in scriptures do we seek it now.
The Great Symbol never ceases,
Swiftly it shapes past and future.
His early death was no misfortune,
His body refined by the Dark Yin.
Who would dare climb the Cloud Stairs,
Like gold forged in fire?
The empty hall keeps his old notes,
The grotto’s room hides his idle lute.
Spring’s sources rise at Fangzhu’s peak,
Above, the empty green pines.
As if dreams and waking merge,
The faint, lonely sounds drift.
Soft grass covers the riverbank,
Fresh clouds hover, light as mist.
The sun’s farewell paints the scene anew,
Waves clasp the shore in rippling cries.
The stone cave cradles a cloud’s nest,
Far off, the southern peak stands lone.
Grief and regret now sever,
No dust can stain this stillness.
True quiet shifts in an instant,
Sitting or rising, all is one.

---

**Two Poems on Returning to Peach Blossom Ravine**
A wasted life, now broken,
Later years may fade as swiftly.
Poets lament the wind and rain,
When will the long night end?
No ties to the court’s affairs,
Few dreams of home’s return.
No aid in midlife’s struggles,
I choose stillness, forget the world’s noise.
Fair scenes turn to heavy shade,
The grotto’s mountain stands alone.
If the spirit tide bears word,
Send thanks to the west-flying crow.

---
**The First Poem:**
Morning, I meet my beloved beneath the green trees,
Seated where blossoms blush.
Evening, I wait for my beloved,
Rain flies, drenching the green pavilion.
Where is my beloved’s home?
Midnight’s heart is lonely.
I recall the flowers just opening,
Now shocked to see the leaves fall.
Riding through the deer’s spring stream,
Outside, the twin seas’ cranes call.
My wishes have their source,
How can I dwell in such thinness?

**The Second Poem:**
*(as above)*

**Inscribed on Lu Daoist’s Chamber**
Autumn’s pestle echoes on the fallen wood,
Sitting with the Teahill Master.
Only two boys stand outside,
Drawing water where the flowers bloom.
The empty altar basks in white daylight,
The divine tripod sends phoenix sand aloft.
Dust trails sweep the frost-kissed grass,
Golden bells chime in the clear, high sky.
The chapter above separates from the mundane,
I watch the chessboard’s shade slant.
Bowing, I ask of the Dao’s essence,
Yellowroot’s flower may be my feast.

---

**Recalling the Mountain**
Spring returns, yet I cannot return,
My home lies deepest in the hills.
The orchid garden’s spring is damp,
Moonlight maps the idle window’s pane.
My small fields border the valley’s mouth,
My humble duties I ask of others.
Where I go, there is no strife,
Heavy gates lock the secluded path.

---

**Sending Li Daoist Back to Peach Blossom Ravine**
Wasted years in the human realm,
The Dao’s source still waits.
Envy your bamboo staff,
As you leave, hidden in Peach Blossom’s shade.
The crow departs—does it know the way?
Clouds fly, as if they remember home.
Do not fret over changing hair,
The Purple River’s elixir remains.

---

**Midnight Gazing at the Immortal’s Observatory**
At dusk, the crow returns with flowers in its beak,
Under moonlight, the green mountains rise.
I know the jade maiden’s window trees,
Only immortals may climb.

---

**In Reply to Wei Xiaqing on His Return to Teahill Mountain, Also Commemorating Lady Jing’s Name**
The Jade Emperor dwells in the Golden Gate,
To which sacred peaks does he pay homage?
His edicts still strike fear,
Yet divine logic transcends even that.
The Crane Temple’s new home is near,
The Dragon Gate’s old land lies far.
My departing spirit lingers,
The grotto’s flute plays on.

---
**Sending Gu Kun Back to Teahill Mountain**
*(by Wei Xiaqing)*
In this sacred age, you are exiled,
The Void Sovereign makes you his minister.
The Law is revered,

**Sending Gu Kun Back to Teahill Mountain**

In this sacred age, you are exiled,
The Void Sovereign makes you his minister.
The Law is revered,

**In Reply to Wei Xiaqing on His Return to Teahill Mountain, Also Commemorating Lady Jing’s Name**
*(continued)*
The **Great Void** is praised,
Though your studies of the **Upper Purity** have just begun,
Your virtue/power is already slight—
A humble first step toward the True Dao/Way.

Wei Xiaqing first received the **Lingfeng Scriptures of the Zhengyi Dao**,

Your brush strokes now bear the mark of clouds and mists,
A fresh style in sacred ink and brush.

I envy you seeking the **Jucur River**,

**Sending Gu Kun Back to Teahill Mountain**

The **Golden Gate** still holds your lingering affection,
And the **Dragon’s Bamboo** steed awaits your ride.
First you enter the **Teahill Immortal’s Grotto**,

The **Lord of the Flute** lingers,

**In Reply to Wei Xiaqing, Gifting a Name for a Tree Chicken**
*(by Han Yu)*
Its tender green and crimson form is easy to guess,
Yet when you call it back to the pot,
You must first summon the **Wood Plate**—
Then the **Left-Eared Dragon’s** ear is taken.
