**Encountering a Teahill Mountain Daoist at Ge Stream**
*(by Zhang Jie)*
Nearly parting at Ge Stream,
I meet a Daoist clad in twelve layers of green.
He claims to ascend heaven yearly,
That **Luo River** is the closest peak to the sea.

---

**Gifting to Teahill Mountain’s Yang Judge**
*(by Zhang Jie)*
You must possess a heart that rises above the clouds and mist,
To seek the Daoists of Teahill Mountain.
You spare the crane’s appearance,
Yet secretly debate the **Chu Sound**—
Its resonance is your own.

Your long sighs always come from beneath the pines,
Your new verses fit for moonlit recitation.
In the **Southern Expedition’s** tent, many guests gather,
Yet you alone know me most deeply.

---

**Sent to Na Sun, the Refined Master of Huayang, Three Poems**
*(by Li Deyu)*
Where is the most **sui-ran** place?
Huayang’s eighth peak.
The wind through the pines carries dew,
The moon over the **luo** trees is still.
Sudden alarm—cranes at the **Yao Altar**,
Timely cries—cicadas at the **Jade Trees**.
To ride a thousand miles, I must pause in thought,
Only the **Fengmen Spring** holds my affection.

Purple **xun** blooms on the rocky stream,
The **bi** mountains’ mist dissolves in flowing water.
The **ju** flowers must surely have no human witness,
In spring, only **feathered immortals** may meet them.

Alone I seek the **lan** isles to enjoy the fading light,
Leaning idly at the pine window, gazing at the verdant heights.
I imagine the spring mountains’ bright moon at dawn,
The **Yutian Altar’s** pure sounds guiding me back.

---

**Lamenting the Refined Master of Teahill Mountain, Three Poems**
*(by Li Deyu)*
The cicada’s shed skin remains empty,
Its spirit soars into the **Upper Purity**.
Comrades mourn the **sword’s severance**,
Old friends feel the **cloak’s** lightness.

The yellow crane will soon take flight,
The spotted **lin** stands solemn yet to depart.
Only in the **Bao Shuo Hall** should you linger,
The night’s echoes reveal the **Chu Sound**.

The void leaves behind a **red tortoise**,
Layered clouds enfold **feathered robes**.
At the old mountain, the crane’s transformation is heard,
The lingering crane still shines in flight.

How many days does the strange fragrance remain?
In what year will the white crane return?
I think of you wandering in the **Xia Bo Pond**,
Yet sigh that my own journey is not yet done.
The **golden seal** marks your first arrival,
The **flying wheel** never stops your departure.

The mountains crumble, the **wu dan** stones fall,
The sky collapses, the **Shaowei stars** descend.
My disciples weep for Xu Jia,
My attendants mourn Cai Jing.
Only the **jade crane’s** call remains,
Still lingering at the **Fupiang Pavilion**.

---
**The Refined Master is Yellow Mr. of the Peach Blossom Source, a Disciple of the Dao**
*(by Li Deyu)*
I, the humble student, have just reached the market,
Now the Daoists of Teahill Mountain’s halls and shrines
Are all your disciples.

My teacher has long ascended as a guest.
The **cave-heavens** must never sleep,
The **source-trees** know only spring.
These are the traces of the **Peach Blossom Source**’s affairs.

Evening guests leave behind the **child of the Dao**,
The **Daoist child of Qiu**—your disciple.
The **Peach Blossom Source**’s immortal child,
Recorded in the **transcripts of the past**.

The **mountain spirits** avoid the **straight and divine**.
When the Master first arrived at Teahill Mountain,
The **child of the Dao** mistakenly struck the **law-gong**,
Its sound echoed.
The Master suspected it was the mountain spirit’s work,
And summoned it with a talisman—
The divine marvels were as described.

There was no cause to grasp the **stone marrow**,
Yet he divided it to nourish those seeking life.

---
**Four Poems Engraved on Stone in the Spring of the 10th Month, 8th Year of Huichang (848 AD)**
*(by Kuaizhi, Secretarial Scholar, and Upajivaka Kuaizhi)*
The **reed of the stream**—
A Chu guest again encounters the **lan xun**,
Its lingering fragrance has yet to fade.

**Leaf unfurls in clear, shallow streams,**
**Blossoms gleam in radiant, festive hues.**
**Purple splendor mirrors the fresh canal,**
**Light fragrance clings to dew-kissed purity.**

**If parting gifts were meant to send,**
**Briefly, I’d pluck them for the recluse.**

---
**From Purple Yang Observatory to Hua Yang Cave**
*(to Li Yanling, by Liu Changqing)*

**Stone forests charm with misty vistas,**
**Sententious curves wind through verdant fields.**
**Southward, auspicious qi thickens—**
**Peak upon peak fades into the distance.**

**Gradually reaching Hua Yang’s pass,**
**A narrow path leads into boundless blue.**
**Seven luminaries hang o’er the cavern’s hall,**
**Five clouds enfold the deep palace’s eaves.**

**Who now unlocks the silvered casket?**
**Golden elixir waits—yet offered in vain.**
**A thousand years pass, the peach blossoms fade,**
**Qin’s folk know not their hidden glade.**

**East Brook—joy in meeting once more,**
**Pure white as faces in reunion’s light.**
**Azure-black birds come and go at leisure,**
**Crimson mists shift with dawn and dusk.**

**Since burying the chaste bones here,**
**Ten thousand miles ride the lightning’s speed.**
**Luo-month steps into the void,**
**Pine winds intoxicate the idle feast.**

**The recluse departs—long journey ahead,**
**Te Mao’s lord must fight his battles now.**
**At dawn, I return to the Qin Hall,**
**Knowing you’d rather loaf than govern.**

---
**Staying at Hua Yang Cave, to Yuan Chen**
*(by Li Du)*

**Hua Yang’s flower cave grows dim at dusk,**
**The altar lost ‘neath the shadowed pines.**
**Spring’s brook gurgles through the hollow glen,**
**Nightshade blooms deep by the window’s light.**

**Stone jars hold mountain wine untouched,**
**Pine whispers answer to the jade zither.**
**Dai’s home lies north of the creek—**
**Snowy night calls me to seek you there.**

---
**To a Daoist of Mao Shan**
*(Anonymous)*

**Name and lineage omitted from the high sage’s scrolls,**
**Yet form and spirit bear the free man’s grace.**
**Already passed the Flower Cave to meet the Qin,**
**Now points to Mao Shan’s path to Shu’s embrace.**

**Lazy to speak of years like Glan the aged,**
**Content to be called “Duo-wong of the hills.”**
**All day selling fortunes—none recognize,**
**In rags, he wanders through the market’s throng.**

---
**Inscribed on Master Li’s Mountain Retreat**
*(by Qin Xi)*

**The Celestial Master, though a century old, looks like a child.**
**Only in deep mountains does one truly meet him.**
**Each time he washes elixirs, he stands by cascading waters,**
**When ascending the void, he climbs the highest peaks.**

**By the fence, May’s snow lingers—**
**At the altar’s right, ancient pines cast strange shadows.**
**Now, how far from mortal realms?**
**Gazing back, misty valleys layer upon layer.**

---
**Gulu Valley’s Old Residence**
*(by Quan Deyu)*

**Dismounting in the wilds as the sun burns low,**
**The murmuring stone stream heard in stillness.**
**Crows cry, flowers fall where no one treads—**
**Silent mountain windows frame the drifting clouds.**

---
**Spring Excursion to Mao Shan**
*(in reply to Du Pingzhi’s poem)*

**Joy in finding this heart’s delight—**
**Spring mountains care not for the traveler’s pace.**
**Fragrant grasses weave along the streams,**
**Half the ridge clears of clouds in the bright air.**

**At the cliff’s edge, I drink the jade-like ice,**
**The altar’s embrace holds the picked herbs’ freshness.**
**Though you dwell in mortal lands, my thoughts remain,**
**Not sharing this moment’s pure emotion.**

---
**Inscribed on Master Cui’s Grass Cottage**

**Bamboo paths lead to the Daoist’s thatched hall,**
**Leisurely, he sweeps away the dust with spring’s stream.**
**The world’s chariots and horses pass unaware,**
**Yet often, returning clouds visit his pillow.**

---
**After Failing the Imperial Exams, to the High Recluse of Mao Shan**
*(by Gu Feixiong)*

**Before your hall, I pause and gaze—**
**The Great Mao’s peak looms high above.**
**The pond’s crows cry in strange dispute,**
**Cold earth sharpens the pines’ green hue.**

**Men sleep beneath earthen jars, moonlit,**
**Deer drink at the phoenix gate’s spring.**
**Too ashamed to pity your high retreat,**
**Another year—still no achievement.**

---
**To High Shihui of Mao Shan**

**All men chase wealth and office,**
**Gray-haired, still scurrying endlessly.**
**If one grasps the Way’s effortless art,**
**He forgets even the name of immortality.**

**Wild birds peck at scraps beneath the eaves,**
**Fine herbs grow tangled in the fence.**
**Awakening from dreams, the rock’s spring drips—**
**Still, I think it’s the palace’s night watch.**

---
**After Gaining Fame, Returning to Mao Shan**
*(in reply to Cao Gong’s farewell)*

**Who does not seek this name’s renown?**
**Men congratulate—yet you alone resist.**
**Your ancestral trade now fully yours,**
**Leaving the banquet hall, your homeland welcomes.**

**Dusk’s crows cut the sky’s last light,**
**Morning’s ferry ferries the cold’s retreat.**
**Beneath the old Mao’s peak,**
**Pine roots coil ‘round stone as I rest.**

---
**In Reply to Judge Zheng’s Farewell as I Return to Mao Shan**

**Your parting words were thick with meaning,**
**Heavy cups marked our final toast.**
**Unmooring by the city’s willows,**
**The boat turns toward the sea’s distant peaks.**

**At the Monkey’s Rapids, I saw the drinking spree,**
**At the Crow’s Ford, I met the washing crowd.**
**Though scholar and recluse may never meet,**
**The rain’s blessing falls like a dragon’s bed.**

---
**To Master Liang of Mao Shan**
*(by Xu Hun)*

**How long have you dwelled in the cloud-house?**
**Green mountains and white days stretch endlessly.**
**Spring’s flowers bloom where the snow was swept,**
**Night’s incense burns in the moon’s pale light.**

**Above, the immortal’s form expands like a jar,**
**Below, mortal life is but a fleeting dream.**
**Fortunate to inherit the Dao’s lineage,**
**I beg for the great return’s elixir.**

---
**To Master He, the Recluse**

**Gazing north toward Mao Shan, past Qin’s reach,**
**The Plum Immortal’s scrolls speak of knowing men.**
**Beneath the green peaks, you boil the stone—**
**Though I met Tang’s sage, I dared not approach.**

---
**To High Shihui of Mao Shan (Two Poems)**
*(by Li Shangyin)*

**From hunting’s return, the brocade songs rise,**
**Mao Shan’s peak casts a thin shadow on autumn’s waves.**
**The mountain hermit sweeps red leaves from his hall,**
**The wild path sends the monk off through green grass.**

**Long buried, the old maps fade with dusk’s last light,**
**New elixir names multiply in the garden’s plot.**
**In the clouds, the golden crane flies ten thousand miles,**
**Roosting alone, free from net or snare.**

---
**One flute greets the wind—ten thousand leaves take flight,**
**Forcing down the brush and quill to trade for soldier’s garb.**
**The tide’s chill in the coastal land brings early pestles,**
**Moon’s dim light delays the mountain city’s dawn.**
**The rock’s echo urges the traveler onward,**
**Deep pools send fishing boats home at dusk.**

**Midlife, I’ve not known the soldier’s joy,**
**Yet near the Three Mao’s peaks, I gaze at the Lesser Dipper.**

---
**Sending Master Gu to Dan Yang**
*(by Wang Jian)*

**Jiang City’s willows blur with sea-gate mist,**
**To reach Mao Shan, the boat must first disembark.**
**I know your home lies where the waterfall plunges,**
**Guzhu Pond before your thatched retreat.**

---
**On the Road to Mao Shan**
*(by Zhao Gen)*

**Stream-side trees thicken, waters rush amiss,**
**The horse’s cry cuts through the rain’s last drizzle at dusk.**
**Before the gate begins the path to the immortals,**
**Cold clouds block the view—no journey today.**

---
**Autumn Day to Hua Yang’s Hermit**
*(by Gao Qian)*

**Clouds and trees hasten autumn’s fleeting grasp,**
**Wind and waves freeze the stars into stillness.**
**The silver-saddled prince’s spirit may break,**
**The jade-crossbow general weeps alone.**

**Mao Shan’s cave swims in white clouds with the rain,**
**At Xing Creek, the yellow crane calls through frost.**
**If men ask of the cold’s unyielding ways,**
**Still, I beg the creek hermit for painted screens.**

---
**In Memory of the Three Mao Daoist Friends**
*(by Xiong Jiao)*

**When will the dust’s affairs cease to mock the recluse?**
**Ten years—easily spent to reach the Three Mao’s halls.**

**Hua Yang’s Retreat in the Green Grotto**
*(by unknown)*

**Longing beneath the cloud-window of the Jade Grotto,**
**Once I borrowed the Yellow Court’s scrolls by moonlight.**
**The cinnabar osmanthus bears a heart to lean on lofty discourse,**
**The Five Peaks hold no worth to seek profound fellowship.**

**The apricot platform’s immortal revels should mock me,**
**Yet only for fleeting fame I refuse to cast aside.**

---

**Inscribed on the Hua Yang Daoist Platform’s Pharmacy**
*(by Liu Yan-shi)*

**Disturbance beyond the world of dust,**
**One grotto of Hua Yang in spring.**

**Daoist texts in golden script, small,**
**Immortal gardens with jade sprouts, fresh.**
**Mushroom grasses greet the flying swallow,**
**Peach blossoms laugh at the vulgar man.**

**Towers vie to tower above the Han,**
**Even the humble dog scorns the Qin.**

**I wish for green shoots to scatter,**
**To dwell here year after year.**

---

**Six-Character Verse on the Retreat Grounds**
*(by Xiao Biao)*

**The bustle of the market ages unending,**
**Forest glens shrouded—four worthies in seclusion.**
*(The four worthies refer to Yang Guo and the two Xu.)*

**The Yellow Crane does not return to the cinnabar turtle,**
**White clouds nurture themselves in the elixir fields.**

**Creeks and banks flow moonlight through eternal nights,**
**Feathers and wings abide in the clear autumn sky.**

**Lofty traces left unmarked, none follow further,**
**Emerald peaks lonely—solitude’s lone smoke.**

---

**Three Poems on the Road to Jinling in Reply to Hua Yang’s Master from Nan Yang and the Three Daoist Worthies**

**First Poem**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

**Cold mist clings by promise to Hua Yang’s halls,**
**Gazing afar at the recluse’s thatched retreat.**
**Half a day’s fast to seek the green message’s meal,**
**Time spent in idle prayer—incense of white sandalwood.**

**Crane chicks at dusk return to cloud-houses,**
**Milk vessels in spring fall to stone beds.**
**Who says the Master lacks companions in revelry?**
**Not far from the window—he meets the sage of ancient times.**

**Dwelling in Hua Yang’s eighth heaven,**
**I await your word to bind the fine green jade.**

---

**Second Poem**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

**The Master’s shoulders wrapped in grotto’s eternal embrace,**
**His kitchen roofed by springs from rocky roots.**
**Ancient pines on the altar seem to transcend the world,**
**Forest whispers to the hidden crow—fear it may become immortal.**

**Unknown what matter greets the new year,**
**In his fur-lined sleeves, he sleeps one dream.**

*(From the *Wu Na Qiu* collection, seen in Wang Jun’s anthology.)*

**Five-colored incense smoke stirs the inner chamber,**
**Xu Yuan’s distant journey—burning fragrant smoke with honeyed wine, slightly tipsy.**
**About to open the cinnabar turtle’s gate, yet fear the crane’s return,**
**Plotting chess diagrams, only to gaze at drifting clouds.**

**Half my life spent in the sea’s mist, now I see the grotto,**
**Frosty cascades at dawn—mountain sounds heard through the ice.**
**How could one in the world’s retreat lack fellowship?**
**Even one outside the Golden Furnace’s lineage has you, Master.**

---

**Third Poem**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

**The Master’s robes, woven with mist and clouds,**
**His brush rests in ease—sealed away from the world.**
**Alone he opens the imperial archives, testing the sands of the forest.**
**Do not say the grotto’s halls can summon the recluse—**
**Together we’ll roll the celestial wheel to meet the Jade Emperor.**

**Within the pot, one may walk and sit with heaven in tow,**
**How much more so when questioning the forest’s myriad greens!**

**Sashes and ribbons may dangle from three grades of stone,**
**Jade pendants and rings fall from the Four Worthies’ springs.**
**The cinnabar platform has already stirred the yin-yang fire,**
**The emerald scroll must carve the order of the immortals.**
**I imagine the spring of Lei Ping’s stirring colors,**
**Five elixir vapors—again the Keel Minister is bound.**

*(Keel Minister refers to the legendary figure who sought immortality.)*

**The Master should not move—his words are fixed,**
**Golden libations, though sour, intoxicate him still.**
**The ancient song of Master Gui’s crimson snow,**
**The new verse of Master Tong leans on the dark clouds.**

**Spring arrives at the willow valley—the oriole awakens first,**
**Warmth stirs the wild osmanthus—the crane hears it too.**
**Treasure the double jade staff, now cast aside,**
**Entirely rely on the Three Isles to send you, Master.**

---

**Three Poems in Memory of Hua Yang’s Master, Master Ren**

**First Poem**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

**The Master ever serves the Sovereign of Void,**
**West of the Celestial Market—he forgets the world.**
**At the forest’s edge, he questions the tortoise for qi secrets,**
**With the knife and ginseng, he tests the elixir’s way.**

**In stillness, he probes the stone brain’s damp robes,**
**At leisure, he refines the pine resin’s hallowed fragrance.**
**I hear the Master’s worth requires imperial decree,**
**Yet know not when I’ll reach your hallowed grounds.**

**My heart in darkness serves only the White Crane Master,**
**Not asking of men—only rank and merit matter.**
**Beneath the forest, I sleep drunk where immortal deer appear,**
**Within the grotto, I converse idle where hidden mushrooms whisper.**

**The stone forest where I lie—no moss grows,**
**The bamboo basket’s hope—fear it may summon clouds.**
**I recall the Jade Emperor’s new decree’s form,**
**Green phoenix tablets with emerald script.**
**Phoenix bones light as they arrive—praised for slender grace,**
**Hua Yang’s Master, not yet an old man.**

**A few lines of jade letters remain in my heart,**
**A sip of cloud water rinses my teeth in vain.**
**White stone boiled long turns the hearth black,**
**Cinnabar buried deep dyes the spring red.**

**In years to come, when I serve the Master,**
**Tenfold responsibility must be added to my reckoning.**

---

**In Reply to the Same Theme**
*(by Lu Gui-meng)*

**Often descending to the silent grotto’s true offices,**
**Lu Gong once visited in dreams—nowhere to be found.**
**Asking the brows for stillness’s triple-star vision,**
**Behind the elbows, the Five Peaks’ spirit diagrams.**

**The Northern grotto’s trees shaped like curved eaves,**
**The mountain’s folds colored like a lacquered stove.**
**Could the Golden Furnace’s blessed land contain me?**
**I’d rather be Jiang Fu’s humble ox-herder on the hills.**

**The fire’s glow should not reach the grotto’s halls,**
**The wind’s chill lingers—let the Master’s beads sway freely.**
**Discarding dust in the tail of the Dao, cast off with clouds,**
**Swallowing dragon’s essence, dissolved in wine.**

**There’s a path yet to join Red City’s peaks,**
**No spring without sharing the Purple River’s flow.**
**Strange texts must be passed on soon,**
**Do not ask of immortals—turn to Ge Hong instead.**

**All day long, I burn incense to worship the grotto’s clouds,**
**More so, I ponder the qin tree’s laborious turning.**
**Once I sought the Lower Retreat, tasted its month-long trial,**
**Yet never reached the Central Peak—another spring’s burden.**

**Daoist paths highest in the Green Phoenix’s jade records,**
**In summer’s heat, the white gauze cap is most fitting.**
**If I meet the Master of the Hua Yang’s Mao,**
**I beg for twelve pounds of the crimson child.**

*(The crimson child refers to the legendary elixir of immortality.)*

---

**To Zhang Master of Hua Yang, Who Wishes to Reside at Ke Xiang**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

---

**To Zhang Master of Hua Yang, Who Wishes to Reside at Ke Xiang**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

**Earth’s lungs are ever a land of fortune,**
**Broad Literature’s refined essence is unmatched.**
**Green essence rice steams as clouds invade the tortoise’s shell,**
**White hemp cloak shines—snow splashes against the window.**
**Bamboo-lattice windows reflect sunlight, inked with countless words,**
**Winter’s *wèijiān* tea simmers in two or three jars.**
**The mandarin fish is indeed your family’s flavor,**
**Do not forget the Song Jiang taste when recalling the Han River.**

---

**In Reply to Broad Literature**
*(by Lu Guimeng)*

I do not know where the hidden Heaven lies,
Yet wish to linger in the twin traces of mist and clouds.
The crane’s pavilion cannot yet match the moon’s chariot,
The deer’s gate merely hopes to share the cloud-window’s fame.
Moss clings to the crumbling steps, my mulberry sandals shift,
Spring wine soaks into the flowers, filling stone jars to the brim.
Do not pity my carefree hair for fishing companions,
Even the East Seal’s waters should have more than enough.
**Sending Rùnqīng’s Regards to Hua Yang**

*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

Snow beats the boat, leaving the wine banner behind,
The Hua Yang recluse returns half-drunk from his journey.
Leisurely wanderings fear only meeting the Cloud Official,
Serene tranquility should surely invite the Moon’s Consort.
The immortal market’s deer-flesh tender as velvet,
The shadow realm’s swallow-meat rich as butter.
The public carriage’s grass mats rot from overuse,
Yet none can stop him from flying in broad daylight.

*(Same theme as above)*

*(by Lu Guimeng)*

Why does the light boat linger near the return of the cold?
The brothers of the bamboo grove await your coming.
The jade grotto’s seals are hollow—no music resounds,
The frost altar’s wine cups are muddy with lingering dregs.
The Cloud Lodge’s Master shares the *qì* of harmony,
The Mountain Diagram’s Scholar loves words and talent.
I urge you to recommend me to the Eastern Official,
The snow-swept hall’s true treasures are hidden in plain sight.
**To Rùnqīng of Hua Yang After His Return**

*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

Spring’s hues melt into the thawing pond,
Sunlight bright—idle swallows perch on the rock’s chamber.
The jade box opens in quiet, no one witnesses,
The golden nectar first shared with the crane.
Eightfold scriptures’ old texts often copied by the bedside,
Sevenfold precepts’ lost edicts pondered in leisure.
I do not know where dreams may lead me to,
Red medicine fills the mountain—moon and clouds perfume the air.

---

**To Rùnqīng, Expressing My Regards**

*(by Lu Guimeng)*

The crane’s pavilion—when will the immortal descend?
His pupils bright as water, his brow serene.
He does not pass on Yang’s chariot in dreams,
Nor does he allow mortals to question the Oracle’s whispers.

*(In reply)*

*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

Yang’s chariot has already vanished into the mist,
The *Bóshān* incense still lingers in the haze.
I do not know if he will come tonight,
So I first carve the red wax—five divisions.

*(In answer)*

*(by Zhāng Bēn)*

The immortal’s song has no need to visit Cai’s scriptures,
Twice the *Shàohuò* wine flows from the crimson court.
If mortals gaze upward from the tower’s height,
Should they not marvel at the *Wénxīng* near the *Kèxīng*?

**Thanks to Rùnqīng for His Kind Letter and Tea**

*(by Pi Ah-xiu)*

The Three Officials’ tea is passed on by name,
The Great Yuezhi hears it said—there are immortals among you.

---

**Again to Rùnqīng**

*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

High sleep may serve as the essential *Xuānxiōng* incense,
The magpie-tailed golden censer burns through one’s lifetime.
Those outside the dust know only the chance of fate,
The mountain’s true landlord is the Lord of the Bamboo.
To gather mushrooms, one must guard against the snow,
To dry books, one cannot bear the clouds.
If Hua Yang were to stay forever beyond the world,
Who would compose the *fēngxiān* texts for the Han dynasty?

**Responding to Xí Měi’s Use of My Earlier Rhyme**

*(by Zhāng Guì)*

I suspect Heaven has not yet lost this refined culture,
So I choose the Hua Yang peak to send my regards to the White Cloud.
After drinking, only the Stork Sea’s guest remains,
Before the incense, only the Purple Yang’s Lord appears.
In recent years, I have abandoned my love of poetry,
Today, I even burn my brush and inkstone.
For this mortal body, suffering still persists,
I do not know which is the true *Xuānxiōng*.

*(In reply)*

*(by Lu Guimeng)*

Suddenly, you leave the bright Master’s sacred service,
Taking the Jiang Ba path straight into the clouds.
When bowing to the dragon’s seal, your light command is given,
After donning the rainbow robes, your small *Xuānxiōng* is revealed.
Before the peak, the Northern Emperor holds the Three Officials’ gathering,
On the stone, the *Shùqīng* is bound with the Nine Sacrificial texts.
You laugh at the world’s cravings for fame and gain,
Yet your spirit palace still lingers in plain sight.

**Wénqiáo Invites Rùnqīng, Who Declines with the Excuse That a Daoist Friend Is Coming**

*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

When will the immortal descend from his crane’s feathers?
His pupils round like water, his brow pure as jade.
He does not pass on Yang’s chariot in dreams,
Nor does he allow mortals to question the Oracle’s whispers.

*(In reply)*

*(by Zhāng Bēn)*

The immortal’s song has no need to visit Cai’s scriptures,
Twice the *Shàohuò* wine flows from the crimson court.
If mortals gaze upward from the tower’s height,
Should they not marvel at the *Wénxīng* near the *Kèxīng*?

---

**Wénqiáo Invites Rùnqīng, Who Declines with the Excuse That a Daoist Friend Is Coming**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

**Reply to the News of the *Qīngjīng*’s Offering of *Xùnfàn***
*(by Zhāng Bēn)*

The *Qīngjīng* of the West Liang has passed down the name of the *Xùnfàn*—
Great Yuezhi hears that the Daoist exists in the realm of the *Qīngjīng*.

---

**To Zhāng Bēn’s Offering of *Xùnfàn***
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

The *Xùnfàn* is made from *Qīnglóng* rice, pure as mist-driven clouds,
And folded with *Zǐzhēng* stalks—
The *Nánzhú* wine glows faintly purple, steaming where no double cranes dare tread,
For fear that the Five Clouds might rise from its depths.

The empty hall sits void of hunger’s hue,
As I rinse my throat with golden elixir’s flow—
A single voice.

---

**In Reply to Zhāng Bēn’s Offering of *Xùnfàn***
*(by Lù Guìmēng)*

I’ve heard of the *Jīnxī*’s fragrant Daoist feast,
Now see the *Qīngjīng*’s jade-hammered meal.
I laugh at my reflection, no bones to record,
Yet might ascend the *Zǐxiā* heights on wings.

---

**Sending Minister Zhāng to Game Teag Mountain**
*(by Pi Ri-xiu)*

Your noble bearing is worthy of a fine ladle’s tilt,
To seek the *Ér Xǔ*’s home after the *Yáng’ān*’s meal.
The mountain’s shadow late reaches the golden well’s water,
Its spirit guards the jade gate’s sands.

After the empty wine vessel’s rites, the incense mother dissolves,
When the green cave’s glow touches the milky dew.
Wait till you become the *Tíngwèi* of the court,
Then need not return to the *Fēngxiā* feast.

---

**In Reply to Minister Zhāng’s Journey to Teag Mountain**
*(by Lù Guìmēng)*

Your lineage’s fame soars high above the world,
Yet still your Daoist descendants serve as ministers.
You’ll ride beneath the feathered canopy, bowing at the jade gate,
Once wore the fish talisman at the *Chìchéng*’s red peak.

The frost still clings to the lone stone’s hue,
The snow lingers, echoing the ancient pine’s voice.
Know that the *Sìshàn*’s scriptures hold their secrets,
Awaiting your return to bloom the jade grasses.

---

**Sent to My Daoist Friend Hé**

All my life I’ve upheld the jade precepts,
Yet the red talismans still wait to be passed on.
How much more so since we once shared the same lodging,
And now part ways, years drift between.

Asking of your face, I find it even more refined,
Listening to your discourse, my thoughts soar beyond the mist.
Your ancient texts drip with morning dew,
Your new verses rise, untainted by smoke’s breath.

Bees provide sweet honey in measured servings,
Humans send coins to buy the mountain’s shade.
The purple swallow nests long in the cavern’s depths,
The green turtle suddenly ascends the lotus.

The basket holds the edicts for recluse-seekers,
The pouch carries the *Shuòshēng*’s sacred scrolls.
The garden warms, the *Zhītái*’s sprouts gleam,
The cliffs bloom, the *Rúguǎn*’s dew rounds like pearls.

In the forest, I dwell like Sunzi’s crane,
In the hall, I host brothers of the Dao.
Fortunate if I may peruse the *Língshū*’s pages,
I yearn for but a single volume’s grace.

---

**Autumn Evening in the Daoist Palace**

The moon stands at noon, the mountain’s air empty—
The *Guìhuá* of the *Guìyáng* falls.
The stone altar’s incense drifts as I linger in vain,
The *Shānlíng*’s dew drips cold from the pine’s branch—
A crane’s handle.

---

**Sent to My Daoist Friend, the *Huáyáng* Master**

Outside the *Huáyáng* gate, the Five Herbs grow,
After the meal, I fret your retreat into the distant void.
Alone in the night, I still dream of you,
Yet when we met before, I forgot your form.

*(Fragment)*

For the *Kēdòu*’s division, the leaden trench invades,
You speak of the *Bènggēng*’s seat at the bamboo’s peak.
When will you return to the *Zǐgé*’s lofty halls?
Since parting, I’ve spent the day reciting the *Huángtíng*.

I leisurely teach the young apothecary to distinguish herbs,
In stillness, I recognize the crane’s return—
Its surname is *Dīng*.

The deep ravine’s spring water is thick with the sheen of lamb’s fat,
Beside the forest, I burn stones to summon wild smoke’s scent.
The valley’s echoes hum with the *Shūqìng*’s chime,
A fleeting glimpse of mist’s light falls on the painted screen.

No need to seek the ancient texts in *Yǔxué*’s depths,
Nor carve new calendars—
The *Yáo*’s realm knows no such folly.
The *Zhūgōng*’s palace welcomes *Xiāoshǐ* with phoenix song,
Yet who among men will visit the *Cáijīng*’s scrolls?

The long black-green robes hang steady on the frame,
The small *Dānzhuàn* talismans lie potent on the desk.
At the *Níxuān*’s dawn, I enter the cave with the first moon,
With the *Yùjié*’s nodes, I ascend the altar to pay homage to the Seven Stars.

On the path alone, I stride past the *Hǔbào*’s charge,
Facing the wind, my lone cry stirs the thunder’s might.
My spirit condenses in the sealed chamber—
White as the frost, pure as the *Shūshì*’s lore.
I weave your deeds into linked volumes—
Green as the *Jīng*’s ink, yet no trace remains.

The earth’s contours all darkly mirror your form,
The sky’s silence holds your resonant voice.
I divide the fire’s strength to roast the golden tortoise,
And brush away the moss’s stains to wash the wine cakes.

On the emerald walls, I chant from morn till night,
Beside the warm clouds, I drink and wake in delight.
I lean on my staff, its length measured by my mood,
And borrow a guest’s height to build the thatched pavilion.

I set you as the stern *Cháoběi Dì* of the north,
And ask of the *Shùmiǎn*’s clear depths—
Who will guard the evening’s retreat?

Often I think of the garden’s near orchards,
And plan to borrow the neighbor’s peak to gather *Lí*.
I stake half the tree to the half-open door—
Cool and bright in the morning’s haze.
Behind me, the zither’s strings hum faint,
Beside the dimming candle, the dawn’s glow glitters.

Once, I knew *Wángměng* by his flea-picking,
Now, I sigh like *Guǎnníng*’s dragon’s departure.
The *Chánpò*’s glow may yet visit my *Huì*’s curtain,
But my fishing rod alone rests on the *Fēngtíng*’s bank.

The fine grass drinks in the smoke’s breath—
No end to its emerald hue.
The idle flowers rise with the rain’s intent—
Fragrant as the morning’s dew.
The waves strike the shore, startling the *Fěicuì*’s flight,
The sunlight slants through the curtains, hindering the *Qīngtíng*’s path.

At first, I was summoned to the *Hàn*’s mountain passes,
Now, I await the day to break the *Yànshān*’s seals.
The six reins still loose on the thousand-mile steed,
A single pouch holds but the autumn’s fireflies.

I grieve the *Wángměng*’s true wisdom, left in the sleeves of the world,
Yet others hire the *Zhāngjiànfàn*’s talents—
Heroic as the court’s grand feast.
Together we seek the deep ravine’s scattered woods,
I ask but a single floating lotus from the *Cānghǎi*’s depths.

Often I cast aside the world’s trivialities,
My heart clears, my gaze fades into the mist.
Already I’ve bought the flat-bottomed boat,
To bind the *Zhēnzhì*’s true precepts.
With Daoist texts in hand, I let the winds lift my vessel.

---

**Sent to Hé Wēiyí and Wèiyí of Teag Mountain (Two Poems)**

The great and small *Sānfēng* stand beside the *Jiǔhuá*,
The *Língzōng*’s threads now all belong to the Hé clan.
In *Hàn* times, the Daoist ascended with the crane’s clouds,
In *Shǔ* lands, the spring bloomed with the cave’s flowers.

Leisurely I stand by the piled mists to seek the waterfall’s eye,
The frozen waves and scattered snow yield the *Zhī*’s sprouts.
These years, I’ve followed the *Huángtíng*’s teachings,
Each evening, I refine my spirit, each morn, I drink in the clouds’ glow.

Once I asked men how to pay homage to the *Jiēní*,
Suddenly I doubted—
Was it through dreams that I reached the Daoist ranks?
My robes are light, drawn by the crane’s feathers,
The clouds’ mist swells my hair—
High as the *Lùshí*’s deer’s antlers.

The mountain’s warmth spares no meat,
Only the peak’s *Jiǔ* is left.
The water’s chill lingers,
Still the cave’s *Táo* falls.

I’ve heard tales of your future quests for wonders,
Now I feel my spirit fly each night in labor.

---

**Farewell to a Friend Retiring from Office into Teag Mountain**

I call my boy to brush the dawn’s dust from my saddle,
To ascend the great *Máoshān*’s heights.
Though my meager stipend ceases to sustain me,
The morning’s *Míngxiá*’s glow is ample feast.

The dark frost turns the pine’s leaves crimson,
The sparse rain chills the hall’s thatched eaves.
Again, I carve the *Zhōngfēng*’s stone,
To rebuild the altar where the moon is worshipped.

---

**Preface to the *Zhūqū*’s True Words**

In the twelfth month, on the second day,
The *Zhūqū*’s Daoist Master *Zhāozhēn* on the *Dàmáofēng*’s peak,
Where disciples from ten thousand miles gather to learn of the immortals.
I, though distant from the *Huáyáng*’s heavens,
Have only a single night’s journey by horse—
A day’s dust—
And cannot fulfill my wish to go.
Thus, I send my spirit each morning,
As if I already ascend with you.
I composed the *Zhāozhēn*’s verses,
One for welcoming, one for farewell,
To ease my longing heart.

**迎真**
The Nine-Hua bell tolls sharp against the chilled spring,
Ten thousand flags sway, damp with emerald mist.
The *Sīmìng*’s banner still hangs unlowered—
Incense burns, I clutch my tablet, standing still in reverence.

A dying star casts light upon my brocade hem,
A crescent moon divides itself, yielding to the crane’s shadow.
From the hollow cave, a sacred chant rings out—
And spring awakens, awakening the valleys’ smoke and blossoms.

**送真**
The coiled clouds loosen the phoenix’s hair,
Jade staff and iron rod held high, advancing first.
The *Cháozhēn*’s disciples stand silent, bowing twice—
A jade cup brims with *hángméi* wine, its vapor rising.

The fire-bell clatters, the dragon-hair canopy leaps,
Green locks tumble, the *bìliàn* sash unfurls.
In an instant, all things dissolve—
Only the moon’s edge hums with the echo of a jingling belt.

---

**江南秋怀寄华阳山人**

Frost grips my hair at dawn’s first light,
Yet my old land’s spirit still swells within me.
My heart longs to return in a single night,
But autumn’s sickness weighs me lighter than nine seasons.

I rise to sing beneath the eaves,
Then weep at the loom’s sad, measured hum.
Mountains invite me to retreat—
Yet what path leads to honor’s hollow gain?

I trace my staff in vain, claiming fate,
Hold my rod but scorn its name.
If forgetfulness awaits me,
Then laziness may yet find its ease.

A narrow path parts the grass,
A crooked door barely marks the years.
The lotus cups the morning dew,
The chrysanthemum sleeps in smoke’s embrace.

I tune my strings to listen to the wind,
Sketch the waves to watch the sea’s calm.
The heron’s feathers drift white on the isle,
The fish’s tail parts the water’s pardon.

The courtyard orange bows for my scent,
The garden melon is plucked for the pot.
The crow pecks at my ink-stained table,
The field mouse gnaws the bookshelf’s edge.

I plant beans and mourn the *Yáng*’s decline,
Cast melons and recall *Wèi*’s elegance.
Who binds the neighbors as a recluse?
The *Nánguō* master stands alone.

The stars’ domains grow sparse and cold,
The mountains’ *guà* signs bring little luck.
My robes are coarse, my learning vast yet scattered—
The *Sāo*’s leaves cling to my sleeve,
The *Nèishǐ*’s broth warms my bowl.

Though the *Ōuguān*’s hat suits the south,
The *Yánglào*’s cheese lacks refinement.
I lean on my whistle, grief welling,
Debate the *Dao*, then drain my cup.

I linger, weary, beating the *gǔ* drum,
A hero’s heart loves gold but scorns its cost.
I pass the elixir’s furnace,
Taste the tea, then test the stone’s worth.

The marsh hides the withered reeds,
The window frames the stripped *wú* tree’s glow.
I mock *Zhāng Hàn*’s return to the south,
Yet lack *Mí Héng*’s talent to be envied.

My spirit fades with distant longing,
My resentment gnaws at my bones.
A chipped whetstone proves the blade’s edge,
A flawed mirror reveals the jade’s luster.

The *Dao*’s source flows thin and clear,
Scholarship thrives on sincerity alone.
I dare not sigh at wasted years—
Better this than chaos’ fleeting rose.

*Xiáng*’s fate was near death’s door,
*Hàn*’s king still held his counsel tight.
Feeding and flight are fated,
Poverty and power are but shifting tides.

The shackled slave may rise to noble rank,
The jesting fool may earn the court’s favor.
Bathing in the sun, who measures its warmth?
Chasing the wind, who counts the miles?

Dust clogs my ears, divides my thoughts,
My liver and gall blend with the autumn’s chill.
I urge *Shǔ* to seize the war’s command,
*Ōu* alone asks for the general’s reins.

A common man may leap in dance,
Ten thousand horsemen march in ranks.
To serve the state is lighter than wife and child,
To guard the border weighs more than plow and sword.

Suddenly, the high cup is passed,
I tire of the *Wǔhóu*’s fish too soon.
Silent, I await the three moves’ decree,
At ease, I calculate the board’s end.

*Sīmǎ*’s laws run deep,
*Èrshī*’s might commands the troops.
The northern snow buries the beacon towers,
The winter cabbage splits the banner’s silk.

Seizing the moment, I draft my decree,
That very day, I sweep the rebels clean.
*Wǔ*’s old might still shakes the customs,
*Wén*’s art now strings the eight chords.

The *Zhēn*’s jade is laid in order,
The *Xià*’s teachings take their first root.
The sprouts smother the demons’ schemes,
The pine and cypress stand firm in virtue.

The *Lángguān* bows in jade-laced halls,
The envoys wear embroidered robes to welcome.
The *Dàozǎng*’s path nears its dawn,
The *Jiāobō*’s waves grow smooth and still.

The scholar blushes to speak of conquest,
The worthy man scorns the *yǐn*’s deceit.
With staff in hand, I sing of the southern fields,
My muscles tense for the northern march.

My talent pales beside *Cáo Dòu*’s timidity,
My scrolls fill like *Huì Chē*’s carts.
*Xiè* pities his brother’s daughter,
*Hào*’s family treasures nephew and niece.

Only the *Huāngzhú*’s hall stands empty,
No gifts for the *Jǐngshān*’s spear.
The worthy’s reputation fades with distance,
My thoughts drift on the lake’s endless tide.

The rudder creaks, the ferry rocks,
The wild geese dip and rise in flight.
The late trees stand sparse in jade-green,
The strange peaks stretch in the clear sky’s light.

The water roars, the *zǐyīng* flowers twist,
The village echoes with the *xiāng*’s incense.
The fisherman’s hat seeks ancient traces,
The guard dog snarls behind the split fence.

My coarse linen wraps my shoulders,
The tax-grain’s green bags hang high.
The land yields its richness in abundance,
Its people thrive in wealth and years.

When friends gather, the wine flows freely,
Alone, the years loom sharp and cold.
The cicadas’ chirp clings to the wall,
The balcony’s crane dances on the beam.

The garrison’s wind howls through the drums,
The neighbor’s moon stirs the *áizhēng*’s strings.
Without skill in letters, how claim clean pay?
The lead melts back to its ore,
I wield the axe—*dīngdīng* sharp.

I fear the carving’s rot,
Yet toil exceeds the jade’s worth.
I focus my spirit on the evening’s bloom,
Strain for the morning’s light.

The moth-eaten scrolls spill from the basket,
The frost-bound orange stands at dawn.
The quiet coral feeds the guest’s hunger,
The idle official scorns the historian’s pen.

Heaven and earth stretch in silent sorrow,
Mountains and rivers shift unseen.
Who can divide the *bì*’s blessings?
Who dares equal *Páng*’s fate?

*Xiàng* was no saint with his double pupils,
*Kuí*’s single foot brought no shame.
*Ruàn Yóu* drank deep of the *yáng*’s wine,
*Zhuāng Yè* laughed at the *shāng*’s sacrifice.

The *páichǐ*’s teeth need no speech,
A broad heart holds no grudge.
But take the furnace’s silk,
Reject the *wèilúo*’s snare.

A single inkstone scrapes the pond’s roots clean,
The boat pushes through the dream’s grain.
The short letter’s bamboo is bound in green,
The low table holds the *fàn*’s red seal.

The frost’s message hastens the willows,
The smoke curls around the *dùjīng*’s stem.
The rafters cradle the swallows’ nest,
The screen frames the drunk *xīngxīng*’s sway.

The knots of the *huáng*’s shadow pile,
The flying spring sprays jade’s treasure.
The tangled vines seek near and far,
The bamboo frame holds the game’s win or loss.

The railing presses the *pībō*’s gourd,
The eaves drip the *yángléi*’s tangerines.
I forget my sorrow with *Zōng Bǐng*’s gaze,
My illness lingers past *Liú Zhēn*’s verse.

The wild harvest boasts of *jùfàn*’s feast,
The *Jiāngshāng* sells the *zhè*’s arrow.
I send the god’s robe with the clay drum,
Leave the guest with the porcelain *yóu*.

I raise the *jiān* to wield the green blade,
Blow the *láng* to guide the distant light.
The crow’s flight darkens the sky’s pall,
The carp’s scales break the water’s calm.

My spear is not for battle’s hand,
My waist’s forge awaits the whetstone’s grind.
Frost makes the reeds stand rigid,
Yet I seek the steel’s true ring.

I sigh at the *chóng*’s sweet emptiness,
Then turn to the *lù*’s bitter lotus.
Grief stretches long, uncut,
The song ends—who will take it up?

The *Yellow Stone*’s teacher is yet untouched,
Yet I alone can speak of *White Technique*’s art.

By nature turbulent, my talent is bound—
*Māng*’s fate must ever be one.

The *jù*’s growth resumes its sprout,
In secluded lands, the lute and cup stand lone.
The stream’s chill echoes with staff and sandals’ tread.

When things align, my heart dissolves in quiet accord,
The halberd falls—our pledge of shared resolve.
Silken strings pull *Língfēi*’s consort’s *sè*,
Golden cases hold *Tàizǐ*’s *shēng*’s clear song.

In hidden dwellings, I cling to bamboo’s embrace,
My thoughts drift through *Péngyíng*’s misty expanse.
I conjure the *Zhū*’s timid phoenix,
Then chase the waves—
The *qīngyīng*’s flight soars.

Deep the mist-shrouded curtains, silent as the grave,
The *yúnqìng*’s chimes ring crisp and bright.

Many the titles I’ve inscribed, yet none compare,
To *Huáyáng*’s kin—my truest brethren.
Incense burns, my mind fixed in a single chamber,
All day I ponder the *céngchéng*’s layers.

Shadows hide in jagged hues,
Voices echo in the *bòxiè*’s hollow wind.
I shall cultivate the mighty *jùshǔ*,
And bind the *chángjīng*’s path to strike.

**Journeying to Máo Mountain**
*Dù Gǒuhè*
Step by step into Máo’s gate,
Where *Dao*’s paths divide like crow-black trails.
Fishermen and woodcutters find no trace,
Wild deer and elk form their own thickets.
From the stone’s face, waters burst forth,
Through the pine’s crown, clouds are split asunder.
Under the moon’s cold, *Dao*’s folk pay homage,
One by one, they bow to Máo’s lord.

**Sending Master Yuán to Return to Máo Mountain**
*Lǐ Jiànxūn*
After years without grain, my countenance blooms like peach,
My cheeks flushed with hues of spring.
Half-drunk, I leave the city’s walls,
A single robe against the snow’s chill.
The stream’s voice greets Máo’s cavern at dawn,
Stone halls cast shadows where clouds once were.
Do not emulate the *Qín*’s wayfarers,
Whose letters fade with time.

**Sending Scholar Xu Chǔshì to Máo Mountain**
*Pān Yòu*
The *Tiāntán*’s clouds drift like snow,
Jade caves hold waters like a lute’s song.
White clouds and flowing streams,
A thousand years to cleanse the heart’s weight.
You depart with your cloth-bound satchel,
The road long, winds calling through the pines.
Once you enter *Huáyáng*’s hall,
Who shall seek you through the ages’ span?

**Lodging at Máo Mountain**
*Xú Xiàn*
Máo’s and *Xǔ*’s *qì*’s cold, sharp breath,
One household, guests beneath the same roof.
The *xiānshān*’s halls stand empty, save the shrine,
Yet none lift wine to honor those within.
Alone I go, true to my calling’s flight,
Floating fame a burden to the pure.
Let each fulfill his year’s longing—strive aright,
For *Yún Dòng*’s spring shall evermore endure.

**The Golden *Xiè* Scroll: Poems of the Song Dynasty on a Journey to the Southern Xu Prefecture and Visiting Máo Mountain**

**Fàn Zhòngyán**
How does the *Dānyáng* prefect’s resolve compare?
First pay homage to the *Máo* sage, then disembark.

With three dismissals, your loyalty to the state now spent,
Yet five decades’ worth of heart you’ve lent to the Dao.
You seek the numinous herb and chance upon the *Zhī*’s grove,
Desiring to knock upon the *Zhēn*’s gate and borrow the jade scroll.
No need to follow others to ask of the pass’s block,
The heavens decree that the officials hide you in the *xiān*’s abode.

**To Zhang the Daoist**
A guest in life loves white clouds,
Yet half his years still cling to the red dust.
The name still lingers on the golden tablets,
And now he meets the jade-rocked sage of the *Máo*’s heights.

**To Daoist Zhang Míngzhēn**
*Liú Dàbēn*
Dull and serene, your bearing simple yet vast,
You dwell in a hut, seeking truth on the *Dà Máo* peak.
Sitting in forgetfulness, worldly cares should fade,
Yet the Dao’s path makes even words seem sluggish.
A thousand miles’ trust arrives by crane’s flight,
A single stove’s smoke and fire, the monkeys tend in lieu.
When shall you return to serve the *Xūhuáng*’s carriage,
Wrapped in seven-hued robes, the nine-colored dragon’s kin?

**Visiting Máo Mountain**
*Téng Zōngliàn*
Within *Jǔqū*’s mountain lies an ancient *Dòngtiān*,
Gold halls and jade chambers linked by earthly fate.
When the lotus seeds reveal the day’s falsehood,
You’ve already passed the *Máo*’s lord’s years of attainment.

**To Zhang Míngzhēn**
*Wáng Suí*
Your *qi* refined, your face like cinnabar’s glow,
You hide in the clouds beside the *Dà Máo* peak.
The *Zhìrén*’s morning ritual passes on the numinous key,
The *Xiān*’s emperor once watched the dragon and bestowed his song.
The sacred scriptures lie asleep beneath the path’s grass,
The divine forms play in the pool’s waves, serpentine and slow.
I shame myself—five steeds bring me from the dust’s embrace,
Yet one breath of the *xiān*’s wind is fortune enough.

**Huáyáng Welcomes Guests**
*Hú Sù*
A humble guest in *Huáyáng*’s retreat,
Years pass unmarked in mountain seclusion.
In wine, the sage’s presence lingers,
Yet at the board, not a trace of the *xiān*.
I’ve mastered the *Guǎnglíng*’s scattered notes,
And transcribed the *Qiūshuǐ*’s scroll.
My cap still bears no cleansing,
Shame fills the old groves and springs.

**Ascending the Máo Peak (Three Poems)**
*Wáng Ānshí*
One peak rises above all others’ heights,
As if the dusty road were thousands of miles apart.
Gazing down, the mists and clouds come not to their end,
Climbing up, the vines and cranes leave no trace before.
They ask who has replaced the *Jiāpíng*’s sovereign,
Who in the earth now knows of *Jǔqū*’s *Dòngtiān*?
The *Chén*’s border’s strife now grows wild with weeds,
While the common crowd still clings to the master’s teachings.
With staff and sandals, I escape the clamor’s din,
No rooster’s crow, no dog’s bark—only silence remains.
I seek the five *Zhī*’s stalks, their leaves now aged,
Yet still climb toward the three *Hè*’s distant flight.
The *Róngxī*’s shadow turns along the winding path,
When the *xiān*’s wind blows, I fall like a woodcutter’s axe.
After my exhilaration fades, the sun slants low,
I return with sluggish steps, grinding moss for the past.

I trace the vines until the path reaches midsky’s end,
Below, the *Máo*’s state lies lost in mist.
The true leisure of the *Wùwài* comes in few moments,
Yet men’s questions of honor I leave to *Língtōng*.

Where white clouds sit, the dragon’s pool vanishes,
When the bright moon returns, the crane’s carriage is empty.
Looking back, which of the three sages is truer?
The *Zǐfáng*’s lineage holds the highest wind.

**Inscription on Xu’s Drill Marks Found on a Stone in Máo Mountain**
A hundred years of wind and rain dim the moss,
Yet *Nán Táng*’s hand still lingers here.
Only fear that the stone’s fate shall end like its carvings,
As autumn’s west wind burns them all away.

**Paying Homage to the Marvelous Daoist Master During His Noonday Sleep**
*Zhāng Fāngpíng*
One pillow of pure wind stirs the quiet hall,
Courtyard pines and cypresses shade in tangled gloom.
Now the inner vision eludes all but the few,
The moon in the *níhuán*, the sun within the heart.

**The Left-Nuanced *Cuì* Before the Jade Morning Hall**
*Yáng Jié*
*Huáyáng*’s mountain enfolds a thousand *guì*,
Yet one stands left-nuanced before the *Yùchén*’s hall.
Its rainbow branches and dragon-like trunk face the morning glow,
Its stature rivals the *sāng*’s, enduring through the ages.

**The Golden *Cuì* at Bózhōu’s *Wō* Water: The Tàiqīng Palace**
Old Master *Lǎozǐ* planted this tree in the ninth year’s spring,
A single *guì* now shares its kindred root.
Its stem is firm, its roots run deep—it should not wither.
I know this blessed land holds sacred wood,
Planted once by the *Shàngzhēn*’s own hand.
Have you not seen the dragon rise from flames,
The tiger born in water’s embrace?
Nature favors the left, not the right.
And again—see how the *Tiānlún* turns left without cease,
The sun, moon, and five stars grind like ants.
The left-nuanced *guì* holds the Dao’s deepest truth,
And those who grasp it shall not die.

**Sending Master Dòngyuán Back to Máo Mountain (Three Poems)**
*Cài Zhào*
Your crimson banner flutters down from *Zǐqīng*,
To further refine your hidden Dao and mend your failing years.
If you meet the *Fāngzhàng* sage, he’ll surely greet you as elder brother,
And from your satchel, the *Chìjiǎ*’s scroll shall emerge.

The *Chóngníng*’s new pavilion rises, cloud-linked,
The *Tiānzhuàn*’s seals float in the sky, their treasure-qi released.
The emperor sends the dragon’s host to guard it night and day,
Yet in the deep of the pool’s wind and rain, you return.

One hut once shared with the savage *Yǐnmán*,
Ancient trees hang with vines through years untold.
Perhaps this is the *Sānshēng*’s law of dwelling,
I’ll follow the staff’s twist and seek you again.

**The Three *Máo*’s Wind and Rain (Illustration)**
The brush asks of the clouds to birth bold strokes,
The paper listens—can the pines’ voices be heard?
I’ve captured the Three *Máo*’s wind and rain,
And in the high hall, June’s chill is like an icy jar.

**Gift to Wáng Quán (With Preface)**
*Gōng Yuán*
Quán, styled *Zǐzhēn*, guest of the *Fùjìng*’s lord.
In the *Yuánfēng* era, he was granted the title *Chōngzhào Chùshì*.
In the *Yuánsù*’s third year, he followed Master *Liú* to receive the *Shàngqīng Lù*.

**Preface:**
Quán, styled *Zǐzhēn*, was a guest of the *Fùjìng*’s lord.
During the *Yuánfēng* period, he was honored with the title *Chōngzhào Chùshì*.
In the third year of *Yuánsù*, he studied under Master *Liú* and was initiated into the *Shàngqīng Lù*.

**On the Sudden Opening of Huàyáng’s Convenient Gate**
The Convenient Gate of Huàyáng’s Cave opened one night—
Since Left *Zǐ* entered the Palace of the Grotto,
It has remained sealed for a thousand years.

**Huàyáng’s New Announcement: The Convenient Gate Opens**
The Convenient Gate of Huàyáng now stands revealed—
Surely the High Ones have come to be recorded.

Ask of the Jade Gate’s sands, near or far,
Yet none surpasses *Yuán Fàng* in Daoist talent.

**To a Daoist Friend on Máo Shān**
**Qiu Jùn**
The phoenix calls me to behold your virtue’s radiance,
Yet the pine and vine resist my heart’s compliance.

A lone peak stands ten thousand *rèn* beneath the moon’s gaze,
An ancient hall—no one returns to its questions.

I would aid *Táng* and *Yú* in opening the Way,
Yet deeply ashamed, I forget the Teachings of Máo and Xù.

Tomorrow again I’ll raise my light sail,
While the purple wood grows fat year after year in vain.

**On Máo Shān**
**Chén Fǔ**
The *Jījīn* Peak’s summit stands as a screen,
A treasure pavilion suspended in layered rainbows.

The crane’s carriage comes and goes to Máo and Xù’s halls,
While the dragon’s feast gathers at Guō Yáng’s estate.

From the Celestial Caverns, men appear like jade,
In the dusty world, all is but hempen triviality.

I was once a fellow of the *Fāngtái*,
So let us seek the path home and plant clouds’ seeds.

**Xiàpò Gōng**
The *Lónghǔ* of Xiányáng ascended here,
And my second brother, bound to Shùshān’s Dao, succeeded.

No trace remains of the *Tánglí* Hall of the *Sìmìng*,
Only the *Dānjǐng*’s clear pool lingers.

**Yùlán**
The prefect’s northern veranda teems with bamboo,
Yet the recluse’s southern cave lacks flowers.

On the western path of *Lánqiáo*, green stretches—
I’ve picked a *jué’ér* child like a tiger’s fang.

**Song of the *Zhīmù* with Preface**
**Zhōu Bāngyàn**
The Daoist *Lú Zhìróu* obtained a *zhī* root growing from wood,
The wood itself rising from stone, its roots entwined beyond severing.
By the *Báihè* Temple’s side, an axe felled it—
Yet it remained as firm as metal and stone.

I, *Bāngyàn*, begged *Lú* for it and carried it to *Shòuchú Wén*:
The heavens of Huàyáng hold countless grotto palaces,
While the *Āxué* Convenient Gate hides in obscure places.
The Three *Máo*’s audience with the Emperor never returned,
Leaving only the *Línglíng* Shrine’s abandoned crane feathers.

The *Yùjīn*’s precious qi long girds the waist,
While the *Língmù*’s divine *zhī* occasionally emerges from the earth.
The sun’s essence secretly illuminates its own clarity,
Yet human effort exhausts itself in vain pursuit of the numinous.

Last year, the *liǎnnuò* was made into a new palace,
Its hollow cliffs echoing with axe and adze.
You came, and the brooding fowl danced in sea-snow,
You left, and the mountain clouds mingled with river rain.

This *zhī* was born from crimson grass to awaken the dusty world,
So the woodcutter was sent into the wilds to seek it.
Its sap is like purple lacquer, its bark as firm as iron,
Beneath it, the *Tiānsu* winds around the rocky basin.

Mortal men fear strange calamities may arise,
Yet the medicine chest worries over divine things being taken.

The governor of *Lúlíng* harbors Daoist winds,
His sturdy bones and pure mien yearn for flight.
His hidden virtue has cured the crippled with joy,
And his sacred herbs have prolonged life—heaven grants it.

I wish to take the elixir and sever worldly desires,
Yet I do not yield to *Nánhú*’s Master of Nourishment.

**Huàyáng Cave**
**Zhāng Shāngyīng**
The white tiger treads the rainbow on violet mist,
How often I’ve seen the sea turn to mulberry fields.

After seeking the *Zhēn* at *Chìchéng*’s jade shoots,
I’ve reached Huàyáng’s eighth heaven once more.

**On the Southern Cave of Máo Shān**
**Zhāng Gāng**
With a purple sash and gold seal at eighty-three,
My decayed frame no longer suits my old official title.
Ask you to write me as a retired rustic,
Sitting in wild garb upon the green rock.

**Sending the Crane Back to Qíyún**
**Zhāng Fǔ**
Who sent the embryo-ascended one to the dusty world?
All day, he sings clear verses with my leisure.

He does not dream of soaring beyond the clouds,
Yet I suspect he carries arrows to aid the *Qīng*—
To chase the *Luán*’s carriage on misty peaks,
Would he linger in the *Jītiān*’s ranks?

Tell Qíyún to take this well,
For in years to come, I’ll seek *Hàoshān*’s heights.

**To Huàyáng’s Master**
**Cài Biàn**
Master arrives at Huàyáng’s Cave,
Its flowers bloom again and again.

The roots must always save the world,
Yet it sends mortals away.

**Parting Bǎoguāng Master for Yùchāng**
**Zhāng Jiān**
The Western Hills call me to join your light ascent,
And the upper hall detains you to nurture your return.
Do not rise to worldly farewells,
For when we meet again, both will be youthful.

**The Crane Temple’s Pine**
The idle picker of *wèilíng* harmed its roots,
And half the tree withered.

Who planted the hundred-*zhàng* ladder of the flying immortal?
The wind shattered it, the rain broke it—
Yet past men were not to blame.

To whom shall I convey this to *Yáng* the Prefect?
Preserve the shoot’s branch for *Lìngwēi*’s return.

**Máo Shān in the Rain**
Sparse mist and rain clear by morning,
Yet the floating clouds refuse to disperse.
Tell the grotto spirits not to halt their journey—
Now, guests of the cave have returned to plow.

**Huàyáng’s Southern Cave**
**Zhōu Wénpǔ**
I bow to the *Língshān*’s numinous peak,
And speak of entering Huàyáng.

The Southern Cave’s wonders are extreme,
Its deep pines and fragrant springs.

A curved desk holds exquisite calligraphy,
And giant stones bear inscribed divine texts.

I tilt my head to the cloud gate,
While the *língfēng*’s breeze dissolves my robes.

The recluse’s hermitage reveres guests,
And warms me with the purple wood’s broth.

He leaves me *éyǎn* coins,
Saying they were hidden in the cave.

Once, seekers of the profound entered,
And saw a golden wall.
Greed may have already arisen,
Nearly meeting a strange ghost’s assault.

If my mortal form should meet such fate,
How dare I lament like a tumbleweed in frost?

I beg for but a square of land,
To build a quiet dwelling.

Morning, I’ll don the *Shénzhī*’s diagram,
Evening, I’ll test the *Fànfāng*’s elixir.

**The *Jīnnióu* Cave**
I descend the perilous ladder with caution,
And sit at the deep well’s pivot.

I turn my body to avoid the clouds and mist,
And lie facing the sun and moon.
The medicine sprouts astonish with their protection,
While the bamboo roots delight the *Xuān* clan.

Who knew beneath the hidden *dì*’s salt,
Such wondrous peaks would rise?

The *Jīnnióu*’s light gleams,
And the immortal records may yet be read.

The hill’s spring has passed its halfway mark,
The *gǒuqǐ* berries like drops of blood.
I fear the toppling wind will stir,
And blow the cliffs apart.

**Three Poems to a Daoist Friend of Huàyáng**
Serving the Three *Máo*’s through a lifetime,
My foolish heart still hopes for the *Yùchē*’s arrival.

Once, I planted *Huánglóng*’s children with my hands,
Now I understand how to carry clouds into the *Tàiqīng*.

The *Jiǔxì* Stele’s pavilion is sun-drenched,
While the recluse sits slumped before the furnace’s blackness.

Who will thank *Huán* the *Sīmǎ* for me?
In *Jùqǔ*’s mountains, only white *lěi* can be bought.

**With a Feather Fan at the Mysterious Orchard**
The *Nǐcháng*’s silks ascend the altar,
While the *Líshāng*’s robes dance on the sacrifice platform.

**Nine-Branched Pine Leaves, Thousand-Petaled Plum Blossoms**
Nine-branched pine leaves rustle bright,
A thousand plum blossoms fade in flight.

At **Yùchén Guan**, the wind howls—
The *Chángshǐ* ascends to Heaven’s court,
While the *Xiānwēng* recluse clutches his sword’s grave.

Before the **Ruìxiàng Hall**, the lost horse’s tracks remain,
And the **Huànlóng Pool** echoes with the cry of a *áo* [tortoise].

**On the Road, Gazing Back at Máo Mountain**
A perilous pavilion bears the name *Yǔshān*,
As the setting sun leans on the *Fúgōu*’s hook.
The white crow waits, poised like a drawn bow.

Last year, I climbed the *Jí*’s heights,
Through the *Yuánsù* pass, where day’s call fades.
The caves exhale spring’s chill,
While the hollow’s door yawns with quiet.

Ah, the venerable master!
His house built where clouds and rain converge.
Yet for the moth’s slaughter, he could not rise—
No dragon’s phoenix to bear him aloft.
His body shed its husk,
His old palace burned to ash.
Now half his *bì* [cinnabar] remains,
A thousand pillars uphold the *Xuán* altar.

Thus, with two paths unborrowed,
He delved deeper into *Zhuānruǎn*’s [recluses’] lore.
Entering the hall, he sought the *Yùfǔ*’s axe,
And plucked the *zhī* [herbs] to cast into the *Jīnhuán* [ring].
The inkwell’s waves seal script,
While the *Dāntái*’s *qi* swirls in a spiral.

He kowtows to the *Dà Sīmìng*,
His unbound hair green against the mountain.
Two lords command cranes,
Both donning *Hàn Xiǎoguān* [Han-style] caps.

When shall I join their flight?
A fleeting vision—Dao’s gaze returns.
Yet worldly bonds still drag me back,
As the alchemy cauldron threatens to boil over.

---
**At Yànkǒu Cave**
*Yànkǒu*’s dragon’s breath clears the air,
Where *Qián Zhēn*’s lingering spirit lingers.
After the immortal brother departed, the master remains,
And when the sister returns, the cave has grown broad.
The cloud-leaves still shimmer like white silk,
While the spring’s voice endlessly chants the *Huángtíng* [classic].

The *bìtáo* blossoms bloom purple at *Jǔpú*,
Left for mortals to paint on screens.

---
**Visiting Yīn Gōng at Yùchén Guan**
*Máo Yǒu* [Friend Mao]:
Once I saw you descend in a flat-bottomed boat,
The wind lifting your jade sleeves—
A mortal turned Daoist.
You’ve traversed the *Ruòshuǐ* [Weak Water] thirty thousand *lǐ*,
Yet met *Cháng’ān*’s five hundred years anew.
Growing old, you’ve learned to find joy wherever you are,
Though this life still owes me sleep unpaid.
Máo Mountain’s wood grows old—
Let virtue spur your talent.
Depend on elixirs and herbs,
Lest you linger in emerald shades.

---
**Following the Rhyme**
*Wèng Yànshēn*:
Hearing of the Three *Máo*’s Five *Dòng*’s gates,
The Daoist comes and goes on wind-borne flight.
No mortal steps may tread the *qí*’s [unicorn’s] path,
Nor ask the tortoise’s age in ancient pines.
By chance, we meet by the river’s mist,
And by the rocks, we dream by the stream’s side.
I, a descendant of *Tiānzhù*’s line, grow old,
While *Jùqǔ*’s clear games merge with green.

---
**A Spontaneous Poem While Traveling Máo Mountain**
*Zhōu Língdà*:
A thousand peaks rise from *Lìyáng*,
Their force like a southwest charge.
They bow to the Three *Máo*’s summit,
Daring not to press the *Zhūnyún*’s [Sovereign’s] glory.
The Three *Máo* hang like a *xuān* [carriage],
Their order strict as brothers.
To the west, the *Yítú* road splits,
Where the grass-immortal’s gate stands.
Even now, the *Xiàbó Gōng*’s [Lower Palace] echoes,
With banners still fluttering in the breeze.

---
**Sending Zhang Dá Dao Back to the Mountain**
*Zhào Rú*:
Borrowing a day from red dust’s toil,
Your wondrous words pierce the *Yōuguān*’s [Misty Pass] depths.
Who knew reclining at the desk was like *Nángé*’s [South Gate’s] retreat?
I, too, am ashamed to draft verses for *Běishān*’s [North Mountain’s] return.
The wind favors my stay,
Yet the moon accompanies you back.
If the Three *Máo* inquire of my fate,
Tell them I wander *Xiāoyáo*’s [Carefree] skies.

---
**Dwelling at Báibái An**
*Lǚ Jiāng*:
A thousand bamboos frame the gate,
Two paths split at the cliff’s edge.
The rushing spring scatters moonlight,
Tall trees block the wandering clouds.
The traveler grows weary, longs to rest,
While the Daoist speaks little of the world.
Only *Qín Xuéshì* [Qin the Scholar] once met *Máo Jūn* here.

**A Year of *Gēngzǐ*’s Eve, Visiting Máo Mountain**
*Yóu Kuò*:
Breaking winter’s chill to set out,
This eve marks the year’s end.
A cold wind drives the *liú* [wagon],
Escorting me to the *Qīngdū*’s [Pure Capital’s] heights.
The Eighth Heaven of *Huàyáng*,
Where the saints of Dao reside.

The cave’s mouth is narrow, yet spacious within,
Like a hall for mortals to dwell.
Before it, the great river flows,
A single *yú* [fish] passage through the dusty world.
To the right, the *Wànshí Lín* [Ten-Thousand Stone Forest]
Stands in a jade-green diagram.
The *Máo’ān*’s depths are lush and refined,
With winding paths of emerald green.
The hidden spring greets visitors with joy,
As if it, too, seeks to escape the mundane.

The mountain’s sun soon burns the traveler,
As swift paths lead to *Yuánsù*.
The *Lín Gōng*’s halls gleam with gold and jade,
While Heaven’s melodies hum through the *shūyù* [tubers].
Glancing at the *Bái Yún* peak,
I face the *Chìshā Hú*’s red sands.
The *Jīntán* [Golden Platform] towers a hundred *zhàng*,
With seven shadowed tunnels beneath.
Gazing down, the world seems a teeming worm’s nest.
Earlier, my coarse nature was unworthy,
Yet I bore the *Chìchéng*’s [Red City’s] talisman.
How could I have known my former green [virtue]?
Now I stand at the gods’ sacred ground.
All my life, I’ve dreamed of this place,
As if I’d walked the *Huáxū*’s [Hua Xu’s] path.
Returning, I bow to the *Lǜ Zhāng* [Green Talisman],
My strength still lingering.
Sixteen halls of treasure—
How could I wander them all?
My exploration ends in regret,
As I sigh and hesitate.

---
**Three Poems to the *Huàyáng Dòng*’s Spirit**
*Yóu Jiǔyán*:
The *Héhàn* [Milky Way] clears,
The azure sky brightens.
The Nine-*Huá* immortal descends to mortal dust,
Blowing a jade flute on the frozen mountain,
As wispy clouds unroll—
The moon stands clear.
The dew glistens on the grass,
Crystalline and bright.
Gazing down, the earth is all *yáomǎ* [jade],
While the lower realm’s thousand gates lie still,
And the empty mountain hums with the sea’s voice.

The immortal departs,
Her cloud-path vanishing.
The wind’s sighs echo with her jade pendants,
As she turns to gaze—
The *Zhōujiū*’s mist swirls,
And the white *Qīānshān*’s moon casts long shadows.

---
**The Great Máo Jūn’s Statue**
*Zēng Jí*:
His face like jade, cold and smooth,
His unbound hair cascades like dry leaves.
Had I not seen him atop *Dà Máo*’s peak,
Mortals would mistake him for *Fúxī* [Fuxi].

---
**To Master Wēn Zūnshī**
*Zhào Shīxiù*:
How many times have I inscribed letters to the mountain?
I know not where to find them read.
The bramble-moss hums on the autumn stones,
While I kneel in the *Tánzhōng*’s [Altar’s] stars.
The crane changes its name—
Yet you have not arrived.
The broken stele’s carvings
Are hard to decipher.
I recall your desire to seek you out,
And plant the *zhī* [herbs]—
Enough to feast upon.

---
**Mountain Travel**
*Tāng Zhìdào*:
Climbing vines through the green ravine,
A wild deer flees the field’s edge.
A crow drops mountain fruit,
Into the deer’s resting place.

**To Elder Brother Wēn Zūnshī**
*Zhào Shīxiù*:
Your *xīngguān* [celestial crown] gleams with adorned majesty,
While your new acceptance of *guānqián* [official stipend] grants you freedom to return.
Yet I, ashamed before the Three Teachings’ [Sanmao] aged kin,
Have spent a lifetime eating wood and clad in grass.

**Mountain Excursion with My Nephews**
*Chén Xù*:
The southern paths wind half toward azure skies,
Yet our bond was never one of common folk.
The jade-like [floating] home of my ancestors startles me—
A dream of hidden cinnabar [alchemical elixir] recalled in the *zhīcǎo* [herbs] of Teachings’ [Sanmao] peak.
The mountain’s summit hosts a Daoist guest who departs like a yellow crane,
While the stone’s surface harbors sacred roots that flee as emerald serpents.

I’ve heard tales of the Western Garden’s wild, unkempt grasses—
Yet the tiny willow you’ve nurtured already surpasses a nest’s embrace.

**Teachings’ [Sanmao] Mountain**
*Yáng Zhìzhí*:
The jade lungs float empty, hence my name of *Shān* [Mountain].
The Five Gates [of immortality] do not lock—*Dòngtiān* [the Cavernly Heaven] is boundless.
Purple blossoms may be eaten as autumn’s *xúnmù* [medicine wood] is sought,
Yet red flames cannot be buried—even at night the cinnabar [elixir] is revealed.

A single ox is painted where the water’s grassy plain begins,
Three cranes alight, each perched on its own peak.
The traces of the Daoist are silent, lost in the lofty winds—
Who will point out the elder’s forehead marks for me?

**Sending Book Recorder Liú to Teachings’ [Sanmao] Mountain to Visit the Southern Peak**
*(Unattributed, likely Liu Zai)*
I remember our shared dwelling in *Huáyáng* [Flower Fragrance],
Where the sky was clear and the purple wood [alchemical cinnabar] fragrant.
Now you seek the empty mountain’s gates,
While I, too, wander the Daoist path.

Grass-dew soaks your double-layered sandals,
A scroll of cinnabar script [alchemical texts] tucked in your linen sack.
You’ll climb *Zhùróng*’s [Zhurong’s] peak with joy,
And offer red oranges to the *bóshāng* [mulberry] groves.

**Sending Master Lín the Daoist to Return to Teachings’ [Sanmao] Mountain**
*Dèng Dàoshū*:
Many years have passed since you served as Teachings’ [Sanmao] Mountain’s host,
In robes of hemp and coarse cloth.
Your eyes discern the noble and the base,
Yet your heart refines—both form and spirit.

You’ve often been dispatched in armor [of ritual office],
While kings and nobles could never claim you as their subject.
Now you return late to *Huáyáng*’s [Flower Fragrance] cavern,
And the *zhīcǎo* [herbs] have sprouted anew.

**Escorting Master Yùhǎi of the Dao to Return to His Mountain**
*Zhào#5 Bóxiù*:
The lake’s muddy Daoist teachings have now ten years passed in quiet study,
And the jade script’s [alchemical] mastery surpasses even the altar’s [Tánzhōng] worth.
The dust stirs—heaven’s moon obstructs the dragon’s [alchemical] outer realm,
While in his later years, he gazes toward *Huáyáng* [Flower Fragrance] and the crane’s return.

Entering the chant of *Wǔyì* [Five Exclamations] nears the cinnabar gates,
Meeting in heart with *Sānyào* [Three Laughs] by the cold painted stream.
Through the world’s green, his Daoist connections have been thoroughly explored—
Now he sits, alone, to guard the *Péizhēn* [Peaceful Perfection] at the Upper Pass.

**Teachings’ [Sanmao] Mountain Gazette, Volume 29 & 30**
*(Annotations: #1 "霞" [mist] as "cloud" in the original; #2 "载" [years] as "autumn" in the original; #3 "已" [already] as "just/right" in the original; #4 "迈" [stride] as "encounter" in the original; #5 "赵" [Zhao] as "Chu" in the original.)*

The **Pure Clarity** successor of the Daoist Master, **Sū Dàbīn**, crafted the *Golden Safflower* compilation of **Yuan** poetry, with a preface to five poems on visiting **Sanmao** Mountain.

**Lú Jiá** heard that the **Jǔqū** Mountain had long been known, and in the spring of the **Yuan Wù** year (1338), while overseeing the **Xian** district, inspecting **Lìyáng** Commandery, and surveying local customs, he found its ruins just a short distance from the mountain’s slopes. All who climbed its lofty peaks and winding streams—places called *Hanging Palaces* or *Blessed Lands*—were greeted by the prefectural officials, as was proper.

At that time, I undertook the **Three Teachings** pilgrimage, arriving at the so-called **Chóngxǐ** Observatory. The **Chóngxǐ** host, a man of the **Zou** clan, styled himself *Heart-Distant* and welcomed me into his refined retreat. His halls and chambers were grand as noble estates, their elegance profound and adorned with splendor. Passing through, one found pavilions extending like wings over streams, trees, bamboo, and rocks, making this mountain the most resplendent and unmatched of all.

The two of us wandered together, unaware of the sun’s descent. My distant teacher, his robes flowing, spoke with such clarity and wit that his discourse was most enchanting. He was also skilled in the arts, able to convey meaning through brushstrokes on plain silk, transforming mere objects into life. His painted cranes were so meticulously crafted that even the finest ancient calligraphers would find no flaw in them—yet his spirit and grace surpassed theirs, for he had learned from those beyond the ordinary. Thus, when we raised our cups, we celebrated his unparalleled talent.

The **Feathered Ones’** dwelling on the upper peak is called the **Yuanfú Wànníng** Palace, also known as the **Zōngtán**. The **Zōngtán** Master, **Xǔ Yì**, invited me to be the **Divine Clarity** guest, and with cup in hand, he summoned the boundless void, lamenting that those who had once hidden here could not be found, and that the **Danqiu** would no longer join us in our wanderings.

Descending to the **Huáyáng** caves, I saw the **jade grease** pool still, the **stone hair** bristling like pincers, trickling streams rushing into deep ravines, carrying floating blossoms along. Passing the **Jìkè** Spring, its waters clear as a polished mirror, it seemed to hold a great stone pestle above it, as if scooped from a well a few *zhang* wide and half *chǐ* deep, encircled by four ropes and sealed with a stone collar, its opening guarded with utmost care. We piled **dòuxiāo** reeds to mark its sacredness, and when guests arrived, the spring’s joy mirrored theirs—its boiling froth like the **Han** River’s birth, as if leaping from a clam’s shell to pierce the **Dragon’s Beard**—so abundant it could not be counted. We called it the *Spring’s Laughter*; otherwise, it would not be. How strange!

Why should I be mocked? I returned to rest at my distant teacher’s abode. The mountain’s visitors had already stayed many nights, and the host’s hospitality showed no sign of waning. I, unable to contain my delight, composed poems and wrote this farewell preface to leave behind.

---

**On the Road: A Light Breeze Scatters the Thin Shade,**
The **jade flute** calls as we pass through **Huá** Forest.
Within the mountain, who is the **prime minister** now?
At dusk, the **blue peaks** resound with **chicken and dog** sounds.

By the ravine’s **jade grasses**, in the cave’s blossoms,
Fine waters flow in spring, bearing **green sands**.
Last night, the **mountain gourd** wine was just fermented—
The **Daoist** had no time to read the *South Hua*.

At the **bamboo tips**, a **flying pavilion** rests on the **stone spring**,
While on the **pine platform**, **fragrant mists** chase the **tea smoke**.
The **crow’s cry** recalls the night’s rain,
The **deer’s dream** startles—another realm has opened.

A **far traveler** comes to visit the **bearded dragon**,
The **virtuous recluse** paints for those who love such things.
The *Laughter Scroll* gathers **cloud and mist** away,
Long may the **ink-stone** teach beneath the **three peaks**.

The **mountain lord**, pleased with my visit, thus sends
The **clear spring’s laughter** without end.

A **ten-thousand-hu** pearl and a **three-foot jade**,
I must take them with me when I cross **Xuan** State.

---

**Inscription for Master Zou’s Pine-Crane Painting**

With **powdered cinnabar** and **aloft brush**, his strokes hold divine spirit—
The **Daoist**, dreamless, reaches the **chicken and dog** sounds.
When will the **venerable guest of the village** arrive, his beard ashen?
Then let him summon **Sanmao**’s ten thousand miles of clouds.

**Gazette of Sanmao Mountain and Its Preface**

In the **Yuan Wù** year (1338), as the old year ended, I returned to **Sanmao** Mountain.
On the **first day of the first month**, in the **Year of the Tiger** (1339), I performed the **ritual of purification** and at dawn climbed the **Heavenly Market** Platform.
